0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	0	Blade Runner, blackout and haemofiltration: dialysis in times of catastrophe Giuseppe Piccoli, Alfonso Pacitti, Giovanni Mangiarotti, Alberto Jeantet, Elisabetta Mezza, Giuseppe Paolo Segoloni and Giorgina Barbara Piccoli.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	1	Chair of Nephrology University of Turin Italy Email: gbpiccoli{at}hotmail.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	2	On 28 September 2003, a long blackout occurred in Italy, lasting from about 3 a.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	3	 until the morning; it was the largest blackout in Italy outside of wartime.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	4	 A few weeks before, a colossal blackout involved the USA and Canada; it was the greatest in history since the diffusion of electricity.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	5	We all know that our small, polluted, violent planet is endangered.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Since 11 September 2001, we feel that globalization is bringing more than the opening up of markets; we now fear terrorist attacks [1].
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The SARS epidemic and mad cow disease confronted us with new, potentially lethal diseases and with the dangers of forcing nature in order to increase food production [2].
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Nevertheless, in daily life we have lost the sense of danger.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	9	In the case of blackouts and other natural catastrophes, one of the crucial problems is the risk of lack of water or of water contamination.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The water purification and distribution systems consume a large amount of electricity and water may not be available during, or safe after, a long electric blackout.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	11	Dialysis, the most widespread chronic life-saving therapy worldwide, requires a large quantity of microbiologically pure, controlled water (500 ml/min of treatment; 120 l for a standard 4 h treatment) [3].
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This is one of the impediments to the diffusion of dialysis in the Third World, but it may also become an acute problem at particular times even in developed countries.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	13	Three years ago, there was a flood in Turin, northern Italy, a city of about 900 000 inhabitants.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The aqueduct water was polluted in some areas and at risk in others.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In such a situation, in which there is the risk of massive microbiological or toxic (metals and biological compounds) contamination, the water depuration systems, targeted to the usually low amount of contaminants present in the aqueduct water, do not guarantee that the water is pure enough for dialysis.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	16	 This is both true in the case of large depuration systems, with reverse osmosis, such as those employed in the large dialysis centres, where a water purity problem could endanger hundreds of patients within a couple of days, and, even more so, in the case of home haemodialysis patients, whose water treatment system consists of a small  portable  osmosis kit and a water softener.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	17	Our dialysis centre was able to overcome the emergency and to support the other dialysis centres in Turin because of its policy of maintaining the haemofiltration (HF) technique (the only one that does not require water) as a  rescue treatment  for patients with poor tolerance of conventional dialysis techniques and for patients with acute renal failure in our hospital, mainly in the intensive care unit (ICU).
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In recent years, this technique was, on average, employed in 3 to 5% of hospital dialysis patients, a pool of 65 to 70 cases, out of a global dialysis population of about 200 patients, 45 to 55 on peritoneal dialysis, 18 to 22 on home haemodialysis and the rest in out-of-hospital settings.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	19	Due to the flood, during the week of 16 to 22 October 2000, the dialysis centre of our hospital shifted the bicarbonate and haemodiafiltration dialysis treatments scheduled for 84 outpatients to HF (208 HF sessions performed).
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Another 45 sessions were performed on hospitalized patients.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Home haemodialysis patients of the area were treated in hospital until the end of the flood and returned home after microbiological and metal control of the water.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	22	Our experience during the flood taught us that HF should be considered not only a  clinical rescue  treatment, able to improve dialysis tolerance in a very small percentage of our most fragile patients, but also a  logistical rescue  treatment.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Therefore, our centre chose not to switch to online HF, so as to maintain in clinical use, without rapidly losing the practical know-how, at least one water-independent extracorporeal dialysis technique.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	24	A further example of the use of this  logistical rescue  occurred during the recent eruption of the Mount Etna volcano.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	25	 A daily home haemodialysis patient, depending on our centre, who was living in the affected area, was ready to switch to HF in case of water purity problems.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	26	During the Saturday night of the recent blackout, the availability of HF allowed us to safely treat a patient needing dialysis before vascular surgery and to perform the slow HF treatments scheduled (12 h) for three patients in ICUs.
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	27	While our habitat steadily approaches the catastrophic panoramas of science-fiction movies, we should also reconsider natural and man-made catastrophes, almost forgotten by the last two generations of Europeans [1,2].
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	28	 No field of medicine is immune to this need; in ours, the wise use of HF (a technique often considered too slow, too costly and too complex), at least at a level maintaining practical knowledge of its management, may be life-saving in times of emergency [4].
0.09740346.15735256.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Only history will tell if this becomes a new indication for HF.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	0	Effects of Different Experimental Conditions on the PrPSc Core Generated by Protease Digestion IMPLICATIONS FOR STRAIN TYPING AND MOLECULAR CLASSIFICATION OF CJD* Silvio Notari, Sabina Capellari, Armin Giese, Ingo Westner, Agostino Baruzzi, Bernardino Ghetti , Pierluigi Gambetti||, Hans A.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Kretzschmar, and Piero Parchi**.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Dipartimento di Scienze Neurologiche, Universita di Bologna, 40123 Bologna, Italy, Institut fuer Neuropathologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitaet, 81377 Muenchen, Germany,  Department of Pathology, Indiana University, Indianapolis, Indiana 46202-5120, and ||Institute of Pathology, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio 44106.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, December 4, 2003 , and in revised form, January 28, 2004.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	4	The cellular prion protein (PrPc), a host-encoded, copper- and membrane-bound glycoprotein of unknown function, has a key role in TSE pathogenesis (4).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	5	 There is no agent replication or transmission of infectivity in the absence of PrPc expression (5).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Moreover, an abnormal, partially protease-resistant isoform (PrPSc) of PrPc specifically accumulates in the nervous system during infection and represents the hallmark of the disease (4, 6).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The conversion of PrPc to PrPSc is a posttranslational event associated with an increase in -sheet secondary structure in the protein (7, 8).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	8	CJD, like scrapie of sheep, comprises a broad spectrum of clinicopathological variants (9).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In scrapie transmitted to mice, the most extensively studied TSE, the strain of the agent and the host genotype variability determined by polymorphisms in the coding region of PRNP are the major determinants of disease phenotype (10).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Different prion strains transmit diseases to syngenic animals that differ in topography, type of lesion, and intracerebral distribution of PrPSc.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In humans, disease susceptibility and phenotypic expression are influenced by PRNP mutations and by the polymorphism at codon 129 that encodes either methionine (M) or valine (V) (11-13).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Distinct agent strains have been demonstrated (14-17) but remain to be characterized in full.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	13	Although uncertainties remain on the molecular basis of TSE strains and the relationship between strains and PrP, several lines of evidence indicate that PrPSc exists in a variety of molecular subtypes showing differences in conformation, glycosylation, protease resistance, and aggregation state (15, 18-23), which may encode, at least in part, strain-specific properties.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Furthermore, evidence from transmission studies indicates that the different PrPSc types showing distinct physicochemical properties represent genuine biochemical signatures of individual strain-host genotype interactions.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Because the analysis of biochemical properties of PrPSc is much less time-consuming than bioassays in mice, unraveling the physicochemical properties of PrPSc associated with each TSE strain or phenotype (i.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	16	 PrPSc "typing") has undoubtedly become of crucial importance for strain typing and molecular classification of TSEs, with wide implications for both disease diagnosis and epidemiologic surveillance.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	17	Unfortunately, there is a significant disparity in the literature regarding the existence of distinct human PrPSc types (23-27), and this to some extent is also true for animal TSEs (28-30).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Based on differences in gel mobility and N-terminal sequence of the core fragments generated by proteinase K (PK), Parchi et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	19	 (23-25) originally identified two human PrPSc types (named type 1 and type 2).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Type 1 has a relative molecular mass of 21 kDa and the primary cleavage site at residue 82, and type 2 has a relative molecular mass of 19 kDa and the primary cleavage at residue 97.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In other studies, however, the PrPSc type 1 from codon 129 MM subjects was further distinguished into 2 subtypes showing a less than a 1-kDa difference in mobility (26, 27).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	22	 (26) the two PrPSc type 1 subtypes, they named types 1 and 2, show indistinguishable fragment sizes only when PK digestion is performed in the presence of 20 mM EDTA, thereby representing two distinct conformations acquired by PrPSc in the presence of metal ions such as copper and zinc.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In contrast, the two putative PrPSc subtypes described by Zanusso et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	24	 (27), also named types 1 and 2 although not comparable with those of Wadsworth et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	25	 (26), would represent two distinct protein conformations because of a different response to pH variations (i.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	26	 one conformation is pH-dependent; the other is not).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The rationale for the study of the effect of metal ions and pH on PrPSc properties lies in the finding that the octapeptide repeat PrPc sequence between residues 51 and 91 is a Cu 2+ binding motif that changes its conformation in the presence of copper and that this copper binding stoichiometry is pH-dependent (31, 32).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	28	In previous studies on PrPSc typing in sCJD, we also reported a certain degree of heterogeneity within both type 1 and type 2 samples, particularly among type 1 samples from codon 129 MM subjects (23, 24).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	29	 However, these were subtle biochemical differences compared with the type 1/type 2 difference in relative molecular mass and failed to show a consistent reproducibility or a correlation with the disease pathological phenotype, suggesting that they might be related to the experimental conditions rather than to intrinsic differences in strains.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	30	 For example, it is noteworthy that the various protocols that have been applied to define PrPSc properties to date included the use of PK well outside its optimal conditions (i.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	31	5; optimum temperature above 37  degrees C) (33, 34) and, above all, were not standardized with respect to variables that might affect its activity.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	32	 On the other hand, the characterization of at least five distinct pathological sCJD subtypes (9) argues for the existence of more than two prion strains and two PrPSc types.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Thus, it is conceivable that the application of more sensitive techniques and more rigorous experimental conditions will lead to the distinction between potential artifacts related to sample preparation and disease-specific biochemical differences suitable for a refined classification of CJD PrPSc types.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	34	 To reach this goal, shed light on the current PrPSc typing controversies, and further contribute to the understanding of the molecular basis of TSE strains and phenotypic variability, we examined the effect of different experimental conditions on the characteristics of PrPSc fragments associated with the sCJD subtypes and vCJD using a high resolution gel electrophoresis system.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Particular emphasis has been given to the study of the interplay between the effects of homogenate pH and PK concentration/activity.

0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	163	  The Effect of Different Proteases To further verify whether the strong influence of pH on the immunoblot profile of PK-generated PrPSc fragments was mainly related to changes in PK activity rather than to pH-induced changes in PrPSc, we tested the effect of other proteases; that is, cathepsin L, whose optimum activity is at pH 5.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	164	5, and chymotrypsin, a serine protease like PK, whose optimum activity is around pH 8.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	165	 We found that chymotrypsin is comparable with PK with respect to both the pattern of PrPSc fragments generated and the sensitivity to different pHs (Fig.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	166	 6), whereas cathepsin L shows a pH-related effect that is just the opposite of those of PK and chymotrypsin (Fig.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Indeed, the concentration of cathepsin L needed to generate a single PrPSc fragment was much higher at pH 6.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	168	 As with PK, however, the progressive reduction of the enzyme concentration was related to the appearance of multiple PrPSc fragments (data not shown).

0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	181	 (26) the PK digestion of PrPSc type 1 (i.

0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Considering our results on the effect of pH and that EDTA, according to the protocol of Wadsworth et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	185	 (26), is prepared in a basic solution at pH 8 and then added to the homogenate, we investigated whether a change in pH rather than the EDTA itself could be responsible for the observed shift in gel mobility of PrPSc.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Indeed, our results indicate that this is the case (Fig.

0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	188	4, significantly increased the pH value of the homogenate (about 0.

0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	190	0 before being added to the homogenate (Fig.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	191	 A potential influence of pH on the copper chelation activity of EDTA is unlikely, since the potential-pH diagram for the copper-EDTA system indicates that EDTA forms stable copper complexes over a wide range of pH values (37).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	192	 In conclusion, our data argue that EDTA at a 20 mM concentration has no direct effect on the pattern PrPSc type 1 cleavage by PK.

0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Indeed, none of the type 2 CJD subtypes showed a pH-dependent shift in PrPSc mobility that could be dissociated from PK activity.

0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	225	View larger version (51K):    FIG.

0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The same result was reproduced at least twice with samples from 3 MM2-cortical subjects.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	233	  PrPSc from Various CJD Subtypes Differs in the Degree of PK Resistance The observation that the number of fragments obtained when PrPSc was digested at acidic pH (at a given PK concentration) varied significantly among samples extracted from distinct sCJD subtypes raised the possibility that distinct PrPSc types differ in the degree of protease resistance.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	234	 To answer this question, we compared the effect of different PK concentrations at a given pH value.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	235	 A qualitative analysis revealed that samples extracted from different CJD subtypes show varying degrees of protease resistance.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In particular, PrPSc extracted from VV2 and vCJD subjects showed the highest degree of protease resistance (Fig.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	237	 In contrast, the type 1 PrPSc extracted from VV subjects was the most sensitive to PK digestion (Fig.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	238	The Effect of Various Detergents To evaluate the influence of detergents on PrPSc and PK activity we compared homogenizing buffers with different compositions.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Sarkosyl (1%) prevented the pH-dependent shift in electrophoretic mobility seen in PrPSc MM1/MV1 (data not shown).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	240	 In addition, an indirect effect on PrPSc digestion by PK was seen with Sarkosyl (1%) or sodium deoxycholate (5%) because in these conditions a higher concentration of PK was needed to obtain a complete PrPSc digestion (data not shown).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	241	We have shown that, due to the lack of sufficient buffer capacities of standard Tris or PBS buffers, there is a significant heterogeneity in pH among CJD brain homogenates even when they are prepared from the same brain.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The homogenate pH in turn influences the size of the PrPSc core generated by protease digestion due to the combination of at least three factors.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	243	 (i) Protease digestion of full-length PrPSc is a step-by-step process yielding fragments with various degrees of resistance, (ii) PK activity is pH-dependent, (iii) in sCJD MM1, MV1, and to a lesser extent in VV1, the size of PrPSc further changes depending on whether protease digestion is performed at a pH below or above 7.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	244	Currently, there is a significant disparity in the literature regarding the existence of distinct human PrPSc types.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	245	 After the original identification by Parchi et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	246	 (24, 25) of two major PrPSc types (named type 1 and type 2) in sporadic human TSEs, two additional classifications of human PrPSc types have been proposed (26, 27).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	247	 (26) PrPSc type 1 from MM subjects can be distinguished into 2 subtypes based on a 0.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	248	5-kDa difference in the relative molecular mass of PrPSc.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	249	 However, when pK digestion is performed in the presence of at least 20 mM EDTA, the two PrPSc subtypes show the same electrophoretic mobility, with an estimated shift of about 1.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	250	650 kDa for the first and second type, respectively.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	251	 (27) also proposed that the Parchi et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	252	 (24) PrPSc type 1 includes two protein subtypes having distinct conformations and strain-specific properties.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	253	 However, at variance with Wadsworth et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	254	 (26), they distinguished the two PrPSc subtypes based on their sensitivity to pH variations rather than on their presumed degree of binding to metal ions.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	255	 According to the study by Zanusso et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	256	 (27), about 60% of type 1 samples show a pH-dependent shift in electrophoretic mobility, whereas the remaining 40% appear unaffected by pH variations.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	257	In our original descriptions of human PrPSc types (23, 24) we also noticed a certain degree of PrPSc heterogeneity among subjects belonging to the same sCJD subtype (i.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	258	), particularly among MM1 subjects.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	259	 However, at variance with the above-mentioned studies, we did not attempt to further sub-classify the human PrPSc types based on the observations that (i) the same degree of variability was also seen in samples taken from the same brain, and ii) this molecular heterogeneity did not correlate with any distinct phenotypic feature.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	260	By demonstrating that the heterogeneity of human PrPSc type 1 within specific groups (MM or MV subjects) strictly depends on pH variations among CJD brain homogenates, the present study provides a reasonable technical explanation for the PrPSc molecular heterogeneity associated with sCJD MM1 or MV1.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Thus, we believe that there is no basis at present for claiming that more than one CJD subtype or CJD strain is associated with the molecular combination codon 129 MM genotype and PrPSc type 1.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Indeed, our results clearly show that, once the experimental conditions (i.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	263	 homogenate pH, PK concentration, type of detergents) are carefully controlled, the electrophoretic mobility of PrPSc type 1 from MM subjects is highly homogenous.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	264	 In this respect, it is also noteworthy that experimental transmission of prions from pure MM1 subjects to non-human primates and mice have given to date homogenous results in terms of incubation time or lesion profile (14, 16, 17).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	265	 These results are in keeping with the original classification of Parchi et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	266	 (9) and strongly suggest that only a single major agent strain is associated with the sCJD MM1 subtype.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	267	We cannot provide a definite explanation for the finding of Zanusso et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	268	 (27), who observed a pH-dependent shift in electrophoretic mobility in only about 60% of MM1 subjects.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	269	 It is of significance, however, that they did not perform any direct measurement of actual pH in the homogenates.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Thus, they may unwittingly have compared PrPSc core fragments generated at different pHs.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	271	 It is also noteworthy that Wadsworth et al.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	272	 (26), in perfect agreement with our results, reported a shift in electrophoretic mobility in all their sCJD MM subjects with either PrPSc type 1 or type 2 (i.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	273	 corresponding to our type 1) when they were treated with 20 mM EDTA at pH 8 before PK digestion.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	274	 However, according to our results the change in PK cleavage depends on homogenate pH variations rather than on EDTA.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	275	Our finding of decreased pH values in brains from patients with sCJD deserves further comment.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	276	 The observation raises the interesting question of whether the acidic pH is somehow related to the disease pathogenesis.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Previous studies document a decline in post-mortem human brain pH values that positively correlate with age at death and agonal state severity (38, 39).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Moreover, we found that in non-human primates experimentally infected with prions who did not suffer from an agonal state, the brain pH was much less acidic (data not shown).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Further studies on brain metabolites in vivo, however, will be required to provide a definitive answer to this issue.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	280	Our data also shed light on the current understanding of the molecular basis of human TSE strains and phenotypic variability.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Several lines of evidence indicate that the pathological heterogeneity of human TSEs is related to the physicochemical properties of protease-resistant prion protein (24, 25).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	282	 However, whether each phenotype is indeed related to a specific PrPSc tertiary or quaternary structure is still unknown.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	283	 In sporadic CJD five phenotypes have been characterized, but only two major PrPSc types have been consistently reproduced based on difference in the relative molecular mass of PrPSc (9).
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	284	 By using gels with improved resolution and different experimental conditions, we have now shown that PrPSc type 1 in codon 129 MM or MV subjects has distinct physicochemical properties from the type 1 in the VV homozygotes.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	285	 In addition, only in MM1/MV1 and VV1 samples did PrPSc show a pH-dependent shift in gel mobility.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Our data also show that distinct physicochemical properties characterize the sCJD subtypes associated to PrPSc type 2.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	287	 For example, PrPSc from MV subjects with kuru plaques is clearly distinguishable from the other type 2s because it uniquely resolves as a doublet, even when a relatively high pK concentration is used.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Furthermore, we have shown that PrPSc from VV2 subjects as well as vCJD display a significantly higher protease resistance than the PrPSc from MM2-cortical cases.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Thus, analysis of protease resistance may allow the distinction between VV2 and MM2-cortical cases without PRNP genotyping and further helps, in combination with the study of PrPSc glycoform ratio (36), to distinguish vCJD from other CJD MM2 subtypes.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Taken together, these data demonstrate that there are specific PrPSc properties associated with each sCJD pathological phenotype as well as vCJD, supporting the notion that at least in human TSEs the pathological phenotype is related to differences in PrPSc molecular structure.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	291	By improving the molecular distinction between sCJD subtypes, our data also have important implications for the future epidemiological studies into the etiology of sCJD.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Indeed, the epidemiology of sCJD to date has been analyzed considering sCJD as a single entity, which might have prevented the discovery of risk factors associated with single or subgroups of sCJD subtypes.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Finally, it is reasonable to believe that our study will also contribute to standardizing and harmonizing PrPSc typing among laboratories, which will represent the basis for the new epidemiologic approach.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	294	 In this regard we wish to underline the protocol, which in our opinion gives the best visualization of the heterogeneity in electrophoretic mobility (typing) among human PrPSc subtypes (Fig.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	295	 This includes (i) a homogenizing solution with strong buffer capacity such as our LB with 100 mM Tris, (ii) protease digestion at pH 6.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	296	9 using a relatively high PK concentration (i.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	297	 2 mg/ml), and (iii) the use of 15% Tris-glycine gels with a 15-cm long running gel.
0.09852033.14754888.html.plaintext.txt	298	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported by European Union Grant QLK3-CT-2001-02345, by the University of Bologna (Fondi ex.

0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	0	Altered pre-lamin A processing is a common mechanism leading to lipodystrophy Cristina Capanni1, Elisabetta Mattioli2, Marta Columbaro2, Enrico Lucarelli3, Veena K.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Parnaik4, Giuseppe Novelli5, Manfred Wehnert6, Vittoria Cenni2, Nadir M.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Maraldi1,2, Stefano Squarzoni1 and Giovanna Lattanzi1,*.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	3	1ITOI, CNR, Unit of Bologna, c/o IOR, Bologna, Italy, 2Laboratory of Cell Biology, Istituti Ortopedici Rizzoli, Bologna, Italy, 3Regeneration and Tissue Engineering Laboratory of the Musculoskeletal Tissue Bank, IOR, Bologna, Italy, 4Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology, Hyderabad 500 007, India, 5Department of Biopathology and Image Diagnostics, University of Rome Tor Vergata, Rome, Italy and 6Institute of Human Genetics, University of Greifswald, Germany.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	4	* To whom correspondence should be addressed at: ITOI, CNR, Unit of Bologna, c/o IOR, Via di Barbiano 1/10, I-40136 Bologna, Italy.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Tel: +39 0516366768; Fax: +39 051583593; Email: lattanzi{at}jolly.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	6	Received January 20, 2005; Accepted April 8, 2005.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	7	In recent years, two major players have emerged as being possibly involved in the pathogenesis of lipodystrophies.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The first is lamin A/C, the nuclear lamina constituent mutated in FPLD and MAD cells (2,3) as well as in progeroid syndromes with lipodystrophy (8 to 11).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Moreover, mutations of ZMPSTE 24, the metalloprotease involved in lamin A processing (12), cause diseases featuring a lipodystrophy phenotype such as MAD in humans (13), a MAD-resembling phenotype in knockout mice (14,15) and a HGPS (Markquardt, personal communication).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	10	The second emerging protein in the pathogenesis of lipodystrophy is the sterol regulatory element binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a transcription factor whose localization and transactivation ability appear to be altered in acquired lipodystrophy (7,16).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In this context, it is noteworthy that mutations of PPAR transcription factor, which is transcribed downstream of SREBP1 activation and mediates adipocyte differentiation (17), are responsible for other forms of partial lipodystrophy (6,18).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Moreover, a single point mutation in the PPAR promoter has been recently associated with FPLD (19).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	13	Lamins A and C are nuclear lamina proteins obtained by alternative splicing of LMNA and are almost ubiquitously expressed in differentiated tissues (20).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Before being assembled in the nuclear lamina, lamin A undergoes complex post-translational modifications including farnesylation of the C-terminus and protease cleavage (12,13,21).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Farnesylation of pre-lamin A is necessary for the following steps of protein cleavage, as metalloproteases fail to bind non-farnesylated lamin A sequence (15).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Mature lamin A forms a heterodimeric complex with lamin C (22), which appears to play structural and functional roles, not completely elucidated (20).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Lamin A/C interacts with lamin B and emerin (23) as well as constituents of the nuclear matrix including lamina-associated polypeptide (LAP) 2 alpha (24), nuclear actin (25,26), transcription factor E2F and protein Rb (27).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	18	 An increasing number of LMNA mutations give rise to several diseases grouped under the definition of laminopathies, but characterized by different tissue-specific defects (28).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Besides the earlier-mentioned disorders affecting adipose tissue and/or causing pre-mature aging, LMNA-linked disorders include autosomal-dominant Emery to Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EDMD) (29), limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 1B (30), dilated cardiomyopathy with conduction system disease (31) affecting skeletal and/or cardiac muscle and other diseases affecting different tissues such as Charcot to Marie to Tooth neuropathy type 2 (32).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The pathogenesis of EDMD and other laminopathies has been extensively investigated in recent years (33 to 37) and there is circumstantial evidence that lamin A/C interaction with either nuclear envelope constituents or chromatin may be affected in the diseases (20,38 to 42).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	21	SREBP/ADD1 was initially cloned from rat adipose tissue (43) and shown to be activated in cultured fibroblasts, adipocytes and liver (44,45).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The human homolog of ADD1, SREBP1, plays a major role in the control of genes involved in adipocyte differentiation, whereas a closely related factor, SREBP2, is mostly related to cholesterol metabolism (46).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	23	 SREBP1 is synthesized as an 125 kDa precursor and it is embedded in the endoplasmic reticulum membrane.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Depletion of cholesterol causes proteolytic cleavage of the transcriptionally active N-terminal portion of SREBP1 from its position to allow translocation into the nucleus (47).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	25	 A number of published data suggest that SREBP1 interacts with the nuclear envelope at an undefined site, while being transferred from the endoplasmic reticulum to the nuclear interior (48).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Interestingly, SREBP1 and lamin A/C do interact in vitro (34), suggesting that alteration of their interplay may underlie the pathogenic mechanism of lipodystrophies.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Recent evidence shows that impairment of SREBP1 accumulation inside the nucleus occurs in pre-adipocytes treated with an agent employed in HAART and causative of acquired lipodystrophy (7,16).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Retention of SREBP1 at the nuclear envelope is observed under these experimental conditions, concomitant with anomalous accumulation of unprocessed lamin A at the nuclear rim (7).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Downstream of SREBP1 retention at the nuclear envelope, activation of the transcription factor PPAR, which regulates adipocyte differentiation, is impaired (16), indicating a possible pathogenetic pathway for acquired lipodystrophy.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	30	In this study, we evaluated lamin A precursor maturation and intermolecular interactions in LMNA-mutated FPLD, MAD and WS fibroblasts and control fibroblasts.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Our results show that pre-lamin A is processed to a reduced rate in FPLD, MAD and WS cells leading to precursor protein accumulation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Pre-lamin A is bound to SREBP1 at the nuclear rim, thus limiting translocation of the transcription factor to the nuclear interior.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	33	 By using 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes as a cellular model, we also show that forced pre-lamin A accumulation reduces the rate of DNA-bound SREBP1 and lowers PPAR expression.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The downstream effects of reduced PPAR expression can be rescued by troglitazone (TZD) treatment.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	35	View larger version (40K):    Figure 1.

0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	171	  Pre-lamin A accumulation reduces PPAR levels in 3T3-L1 nuclei and impairs adipocyte differentiation: rescue by TZD treatment Since the transcription factor PPAR is transcribed following SREBP1 activation in pre-adipocytes induced to differentiate (7,17), we checked PPAR levels in differentiating 3T3-L1 cells accumulating pre-lamin A.

0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	207	  Accumulation of pre-lamin A reduced adipocyte differentiation, as detected by oil red O staining of mevinolin- or FTI-277-treated 3T3-L1 cultures (Fig.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	208	 However, 3T3-L1 cells treated with the PPAR ligand TZD showed positive oil red O staining even after accumulation of pre-lamin A by mevinolin or by FTI-277 treatment (Fig.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	209	 6E), indicating the rescue of adipogenic differentiation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	210	The proposed mechanism involves primarily in the accumulation of pre-lamin A and selective binding of the lamin A precursor to the adipocyte transcription factor SREBP1.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	211	 In MAD, FPLD and WS cells, we observed an accumulation of the lamin A precursor.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Interestingly, the amount of pre-lamin A was not increased in EDMD2 fibroblast cell lines, indicating that impairment of lamin A precursor maturation is specifically associated with lipodystrophy-linked lamin A mutations.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	213	 However, the reason why lamin A processing is selectively affected by R482L, R527H and S143F LMNA mutations is not obvious.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	214	 At present, we can rule out the possibility of altered interplay between pre-lamin A and farnesyltransferases.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	215	 In fact, mevinolin treatment was effective in increasing mutated pre-lamin A amount in MAD, FPLD and WS fibroblasts, suggesting that farnesylation of pre-lamin A is an ongoing mechanism in these cells (MAD being a recessive disease model, only expressing mutated lamin A).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	216	 On the other hand, altered interaction of mutated pre-lamin A with ZPMSTE 24 endoprotease might affect protein processing.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	217	 It is noteworthy that ZPMSTE 24 mutations lead to accumulation of pre-lamin A due to impaired cleavage of the farnesylated protein and cause MAD (13), HGPS (Markquardt, personal communication) and restrictive dermopathy (49) in humans and a MAD-resembling phenotype in mice (14,15).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	218	We localized pre-lamin A-labeled intra-nuclear structures both in wild-type and in laminopathic cells accumulating the lamin A precursor.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Such structures have been previously shown in wild-type cells induced to accumulate pre-lamin A (21,50).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	220	 However, additional dominant negative effects of mutations appear to affect differently both number and shape of pre-lamin A-labeled structures in each laminopathic cell line.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	221	 In the case of MAD and WS fibroblasts, pre-lamin-A-containing structures mostly protrude through the nuclear interior, as was also observed in control nuclei, whereas in R482L FPLD nuclei they are mostly localized at the nuclear lamina level.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	222	 We recently noticed that the number of pre-lamin-A-labeled intra-nuclear structures and the level of lamin A precursor were significantly increased in older MAD patients, though carrying the same R527H LMNA mutation (data not shown).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Noticeably, pre-lamin A-labeled structures may co-localize with emerin in wild-type and EDMD2 nuclei, but not in FPLD, MAD and WS nuclei, suggesting disease-specific changes of intermolecular interactions (42).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	224	Because we had determined a link between pre-lamin A accumulation and LMNA-associated lipodystrophies, we decided to investigate whether pre-lamin A interacted with the transcription factor SREBP1, which mediates adipocyte differentiation (44).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	225	 In vitro binding of SREBP1 to lamin A/C had been demonstrated by Lloyd et al.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	226	 (34) and the site of interaction had been mapped between aminoacids 227 and 487 of SREBP1 N-terminus sequence (34).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	227	 In the present study, we demonstrated for the first time in vivo binding of the lamin A precursor to SREBP1.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	228	 As expected, the low-molecular-weight form of SREBP1 interacts with pre-lamin A, indicating involvement of the nuclear lamina protein in the localization of the active transcription factor.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	229	 (34) performed a GST binding-assay with a lamin A peptide spanning aminoacids 389 to 664, which includes pre-lamin A C-terminal sequence.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Thus, our results confirm that the whole unprocessed lamin A molecule is required for SREBP1 interaction in vivo.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The previously suggested reduction of lamin A to SREBP1 binding affinity caused by R482 LMNA mutation (34) does not appear to affect in vivo interaction between pre-lamin A and SREBP1.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	232	 This might be related to the increased availability of pre-lamin A in FPLD cells, which could overcome the reduced binding affinity caused by the mutation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	233	 In addition, we cannot rule out the possibility that a different aminoacid substitution (R482L instead of R482W) may differently affect protein interplay (42).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	234	By treating pre-adipocytes with farnesylation inhibitors, we obtained a suitable cellular model that reproduced the situation of pre-lamin A accumulation in adipose tissue.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	235	 This allowed us to investigate some biological mechanisms downstream of reduced pre-lamin A maturation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	236	We showed that the retention of active SREBP1 at the nuclear lamina occurs in pre-adipocytes accumulating pre-lamin A, as demonstrated by the significantly increased proportion of mature SREBP1 found in the nuclear insoluble fraction following DNase extraction.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Immunofluorescence labeling allowed us to show co-localization of SREBP1 and pre-lamin A in the nuclei accumulating pre-lamin A.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	238	 In fact, DNA-bound transcription factor disappears from control nuclei after the removal of DNA, whereas lamina-associated SREBP1 is still retained in the nuclei accumulating pre-lamin A and shows a typical nuclear rim staining.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	239	 We suggest that the reduced rate of lamin A precursor processing allows detection of pre-lamin A-bound SREBP1, which is hardly detectable in control cell lines undergoing rapid pre-lamin A maturation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	240	It is noteworthy that SREBP1 nuclear translocation is impaired in Lmna-null mouse cardiomyocytes, but not in the adipose tissue from Lmna null mice (36), indicating that nuclear import of SREBP1 in adipocytes does not require Lmna products.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	241	 These data and our present results support the view that SREBP1 to pre-lamin A interplay has a physiological role in the negative regulation of SREBP1 nuclear translocation in adipose tissue, so that excess accumulation of pre-lamin A selectively sequesters SREBP1 at the adipocyte nuclear envelope.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	242	 On the other hand, pre-lamin A might play a positive regulation role for SREBP1 nuclear import in other cell types such as cardiac myocytes (36).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	243	 In agreement with this hypothesis, pre-lamin A to SREBP1 interplay, which is potentially disrupted by some LMNA mutations causing AD-EDMD (34), might be involved in the nuclear import of the transcription factor in skeletal muscle cells.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	244	Retention of SREBP1 at the nuclear rim was previously reported in 3T3-F442A pre-adipocytes treated with Indinavir, a drug employed in HAART and causing lipodystrophy as a side-effect (7).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Under these experimental conditions, 3T3-F442A fibroblasts show increased pre-lamin A level and reduced PPAR expression (7).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	246	 These and our results strongly suggest that retention of SREBP1 at the nuclear rim of lipodystrophy cells is associated with the presence of increased pre-lamin A level, irrespective of the occurrence of LMNA mutations.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	247	 In fact, the identification of a selective and stable interplay between pre-lamin A and SREBP1 helps to explain the pathophysiology of both acquired and inherited lipodystrophy, the latter due to either lamin A/C or ZMPSTE 24 mutations.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Moreover, it is noteworthy that farnesyltransferase inhibitors (causing pre-lamin A accumulation) have been previously reported to impair adipocyte differentiation (51,52).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Our results help in explaining the biological mechanism underlying this effect.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	250	A key event of adipocyte differentiation is the induction of the transcription factor PPAR which is triggered by SREBP1 (48).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Downregulation of PPAR expression was obtained in pre-adipocytes accumulating the lamin A precursor either by mevinolin treatment or by overexpressing uncleavable pre-lamin A.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Uncleavable mutants of lamin A have been shown to assemble and localize at the nuclear envelope with kinetics comparable with that of wild-type protein (53).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The L648R-lamin A mutant did in fact localize at the nuclear envelope, where it could potentially bind SREBP1, as observed for de-farnesylated pre-lamin A.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Interestingly, a reduced PPAR level was also observed in adipocytes accumulating wild-type FLAG to pre-lamin A.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	255	 In the latter case, the increase of pre-lamin A level was directly attributable to overexpression of the exogenous protein.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	256	 These results support the view that excess accumulation of pre-lamin A is sufficient to sequester an amount of SREBP1, even in the presence of mature lamin A.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Thus, PPAR induction, a key step of adipocyte differentiation, may be altered in laminopathies featuring lipodystrophy, as already proposed for acquired lipodystrophies (7,16).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	258	In fact, adipocyte differentiation was impaired by pre-lamin A accumulation, as determined by oil red O staining of mevinolin- or FTI-277-treated pre-adipocyte cultures.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Given that FTI-277 selectively affects pre-lamin A processing without any interference with ras protein farnesylation or with cholesterol synthesis (54), we conclude that reduced adipocyte differentiation is a direct effect of pre-lamin A accumulation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	260	 It should be noted that highly differentiated cultures were not affected by drug treatment (data not shown), in agreement with the evidence that an early event in the adipocyte differentiation pathway, such as PPAR activation, is affected by pre-lamin A.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	261	PPAR expression has been reported to be regulated dependent on the body district (55).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	262	 This important observation suggests that pre-lamin A accumulation may elicit different effects in different fat depots depending on the extent of PPAR activation required in that particular area.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This could, in part, explain the selective involvement of some but not all adipose tissue districts in partial lipodystrophies.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	264	Treatment of 3T3-L1 cells accumulating pre-lamin A with the PPAR ligand TZD elicited rescue of the adipogenic program.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	265	 The latter finding gives an important insight into possible therapeutic approaches to lipodystrophy, which have been already reported to elicit some promising effects (56).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	266	As MAD is a recessive disease, one would expect pre-lamin A accumulation even in the heterozygous state, i.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	267	 in a percentage of cells from parents of affected individuals bearing one mutated allele (3).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	268	 We did not observe a significant increase of pre-lamin A amount in those cells.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	269	 However, this study deserves further deepening, since we found that overexpression of R527H-mutated lamin A in transfected cells causes accumulation of mutated pre-lamin A (but not endogenous pre-lamin A) (data not shown).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	270	 On the other hand, MAD phenotype is not observed in heterozygous individuals, strongly supporting the view that a threshold pre-lamin A level is required to activate the pathogenic mechanism.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Regarding the pathophysiology of MAD and WS, two main questions need further investigation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The first is the effect elicited by the accumulation of lamin A precursor protein in osteoblasts.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	273	 In fact, bone resorption of the extremities is a specific feature of MAD phenotype (3) and osteoporosis is also observed in WS patients (11) (though it might be related to the aging process featuring this disease).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	274	 We are now addressing this problem by evaluating the effect of high pre-lamin A level in pre-osteocyte differentiation or survival.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The other open question is the pathogenetic mechanism leading to a premature aging phenotype in MAD patients and mostly in WS patients.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	276	 We suggest that this phenotype could be dependent both on an anomalous amount of pre-lamin A and on altered interaction between mutated lamin A/C and its nuclear binding partners.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	277	Transfection of pre-adipocyte cultures A full-length rat lamin A cDNA encoding for pre-lamin A was expressed from the CMV promoter and tagged at the 5' end with a sequence coding for FLAG epitope (FLAG to LA) (58).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The L648R point mutation was introduced into the full-length rat lamin A cDNA using the QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA, USA).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	279	 This mutation impairs cleavage of pre-lamin A by ZMPSTE24 endoprotease and causes accumulation of farnesylated pre-lamin A (12).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	280	 FLAG to LA or L648R to FLAG-lamin A was transfected in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes at day 0 of differentiation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	281	 A FLAG-tagged wild-type emerin construct was used to transfect pre-adipocytes as a control.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Transfection of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes was performed using FuGene 6 reagent according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Cells were fixed at day 4 of differentiation.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	284	Drug treatments Pre-lamin A accumulation in human fibroblasts and 3T3-L1 adipocytes was induced by inhibition of isoprenoid synthesis with 25  microM Mevinolin (Sigma) for 18 h (21).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	285	 This drug subtracts the substrate of farnesyltransferases, thus impairing pre-lamin A farnesylation which is required for further protein processing (59).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Alternatively, pre-lamin A farnesylation was inhibited using the peptidomimetic drug FTI-277 (Calbiochem), which selectively impairs pre-lamin A farnesylation, at the dosage used (20  microM for 24 h) (54).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Treatment with TZD (Sigma) was performed according to the published protocols to trigger PPAR activation (16).
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Briefly, 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were induced to accumulate pre-lamin A by 18 h mevinolin treatment or by 24 h FTI-277 treatment.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Thereafter, cells were transferred in culture medium, containing or not 10  microM TZD, and incubated for 48 h.
0.10063774.15843404.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Incubation was stopped by formalin fixation, as described subsequently.

0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Drosophila model of early onset torsion dystonia suggests impairment in TGF-ss signaling Young-Ho Koh, Kimberly Rehfeld and Barry Ganetzky*.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	1	Laboratory of Genetics, 445 Henry Mall, University of Wisconsin Madison, Madison, WI 53706, USA.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received May 3, 2004; Revised June 23, 2004; Accepted July 1, 2004.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	3	Sequence comparisons demonstrate that HtorA is a member of the HSP100/Clp family of ATP-dependent chaperones that functions in the assembly, disassembly and operation of a variety of protein complexes including those involved in many types of vesicular transport (8).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Immunolocalization of HtorA expressed in transfected cell lines suggests that it is a lumenally oriented protein localized to the intracellular membranes of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	5	 E HtorA has been found in large spheroid intracellular structures that do not colocalize with ER markers (9).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	6	 At the EM level, it was reported that E TorsinA was found in membrane whorls that may derive from ER (10).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In addition, HtorA is localized in Lewy bodies in postmortem Parkinson disease patients (11,12).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Expression of normal HtorA in cultured cells resulted in colocalization with various heat shock proteins and suppressed -synuclein aggregation.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, expression of E HtorA did not suppress -synuclein aggregation (13).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Similarly, expression of normal HtorA suppressed polyglutamine-induced protein aggregation in Caenorhabditis elegans (14).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These observations suggest that HtorA could function as a chaperone involved in the folding or processing of secreted or membrane proteins.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The effects of the E mutation on HtorA functions are unknown although the dominant phenotype together with other observations suggests that the mutant protein has a dominant negative or gain-of-function mode of action.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The basis of the variable penetrance of early onset torsion dystonia caused by E HtorA is still unclear.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	14	 A  second-hit  model in which other genetic mutations or environmental factors increase the susceptibilities of individuals heterozygous for the E HtorA mutation has been proposed (9,15,16).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	15	As Drosophila offers many experimental advantages for genetic and molecular studies, while the basic molecular components and neuronal signaling mechanisms are evolutionarily conserved (17 to 19), it is increasingly being used as a model system to study human neurological disorders.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Here, we have established a Drosophila model of early onset torsion dystonia that may increase our understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms responsible for this disorder.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Several lines of evidences from this study suggest that the behavioral and ultrastructural abnormalities observed in E HtorA-expressing flies involve impaired TGF-ss signaling.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Therefore, we propose that a defect in TGF-ss signaling may also contribute to the etiology of early onset torsion dystonia in humans.

0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	57	Transgenic flies expressing WT or mutant forms of HtorA showed normal life spans when raised at 25 degrees C (Supplementary Material, Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	58	 S4) or 30 degrees C (data not shown), and did not manifest any overt behavioral deficits under those conditions, whether expression was in dopaminergic neurons only, in all neurons or in muscles.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Similar observations were reported by Muraro and Moffat (9th European Drosophila neurobiology meeting abstract, 2002).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	60	 These data suggested that the presence of clusters of E HtorA proteins in neurons or muscles might be not sufficient to induce behavioral abnormalities.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	61	 To explain the 30 to 40% penetrance of the E HtorA mutation in humans, a second-hit model has been proposed according to which environmental factors or other genetic mutations are required to evoke severe behavioral abnormalities (9,15,16).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Therefore, we hypothesized that another factor may be required to induce behavioral defects in flies expressing E HtorA.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	63	In previous studies we have found that a number of mutants in Drosophila with defects in neuronal membrane excitability or synaptic transmission behave normally at room temperature (20 to 25 degrees C), but show severe locomotor defects such as paralysis or seizures when placed at elevated temperatures (25).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Therefore, we tested whether exposing the HtorA-expressing flies to 38 degrees C uncovered any latent behavioral defects (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	65	 We monitored flies at 38 degrees C for a period of 10 min and counted the number of flies remaining active on the sides or top of the vial versus those remaining on the bottom at each time point.

0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	83	E HtorA clusters have distinct subcellular localization To further investigate how the E HtorA protein clusters might contribute to the observed behavioral defects, we examined the subcellular distribution patterns of these clusters in well-characterized type I glutamatergic synapses in larval neuromuscular junction (NMJ).

0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	143	Expression of dSmad2 or hSmad2 suppresses E HtorA phenotypes The presence of free dense bodies in presynaptic terminals associated with expression of E HtorA was also recently observed in several Drosophila mutant affecting receptors or ligands of the TGF-ss signaling pathway (26 to 28).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The phenotypes are not identical however, as mutations in wishful thinking (wit), which affects a type II BMP receptor causes additional synaptic defects including a decrease in levels of Fasciclin II and a distinctive detachment of synaptic membranes, which are not observed in larvae expressing E HtorA (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Those observations suggest that E HtorA expression might disrupt some part of the TGF-ss signaling pathway to interfere with proper synaptic development.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	146	 As E HtorA clusters localized at synapses, SSR, endosomes and the nuclear periphery, it is possible that they disrupt trafficking of some components of TGF-ss signaling from synapses to endosomes or nuclei.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Mad and dSmad2 are known transcriptional effectors of the TGF-ss pathway that regulates target gene expression to control cell proliferation (29), neuronal remodeling during metamorphosis (30) and synaptic plasticity in type I glutamatergic NMJs (26,27).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Studies indicate that dynamic changes in the molecular components of Smad complexes during trafficking from receptors to endosomes or nuclei are essential for eliciting proper responses (31,32).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	149	 We hypothesized that E HtorA interfered with trafficking of mothers against decapentaplegic (Mad) or Drosophila Smad2 (dSmad2) between synapses and nuclei or endosomes.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	150	To explore the possibility that E HtorA interfered with the TGF-ss pathway, we examined the effect of overexpressing Mad or dSmad2 in a E HtorA background.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	151	 At the behavioral level, pan-neural expression of dSmad2 substantially rescued the locomotor defects caused by E HtorA; at 38 degrees C, these flies remained as active as controls (C155-Gal4/+) (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	152	 However, under the same condition, Mad overexpression did not suppress the E HtorA behavioral defects.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Pan-neural expression of dSmad2 alone had no effect on the flies compared with the control background (C155-Gal4/+) (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Although E HtorA behavioral phenotypes were suppressed by dSmad2 overexpression, mutating one copy of dSmad2 to reduce the gene dosage up to 50% did not enhance the phenotypes (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Expression of dSmad2 also rescued the E HtorA morphological and ultrastructural phenotypes (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The volume, surface area and length of synaptic boutons were completely rescued as was synaptic area.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Other presynaptic abnormalities observed in E HtorA animals including synapses with empty synaptic vesicle pools, presence of abnormal extended membrane structures and the presence of free dense bodies were eliminated or significantly reduced by expression of dSmad2 (Table 1).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Furthermore, we found that expression of human Smad2, a human homologues of dSmad2 (33), rescued behavioral abnormalities as does dSmad2 (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Rescue of E HtorA phenotypes by expression of human or Drosophila Smad2 was not due to indirect effect on E HtorA expression as the levels of E HtorA remained unaltered in the appeared backgrounds (data not shown).

0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	174	In fact, we have found several phenotypic abnormalities associated with E HtorA expression that are not temperature-dependent and that could underlie the observed behavioral defects at elevated temperatures.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Similar to what has been observed in transfected human cells in culture (9,10), we found that E HtorA forms protein aggregates when expressed in Drosophila neurons or muscles (Figs 1 and 3).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Localization of E HtorA protein clusters at the confocal microscopy level revealed that some of these clusters were associated with synaptic boutons particularly in the region of the SSR or colocalized with endosomal markers (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	177	 In addition to confirming the presence of E HtorA in SSR and in association with endosomes, immuno-EM studies demonstrated that E HtorA was also found associated with synaptic densities and the nuclear envelope (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The subcellular localization of E HtorA raises the possibility that it could interfere with a signal transduction pathway between synapses and nuclei that is required for proper synaptic development and function.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	179	Detailed confocal and electron microscopic examination of synaptic boutons revealed a number of structural defects in E HtorA-expressing larvae (Figs 5 and 6).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The presence of free dense bodies was particularly intriguing because this phenotype has only previously been reported for mutations that perturb the TGF-ss signaling pathway.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	181	 TGF-ss signaling pathways regulate many developmental and physiological processes both in vertebrates and invertebrates and perturbations in these signaling pathways have been implicated in a wide array of pathological conditions (34).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Recent studies in Drosophila have demonstrated that proper development and plasticity of synaptic boutons in the larval NMJ is dependent on TGF-ss pathway, at least in part, by wit (26,27).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Downregulation of TGF-ss receptors at synaptic terminals via endocytotic internalization appears to be an important mechanism for controlling synaptic plasticity (35).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In addition, experimental evidence suggests that retrograde transport of signaling to endosomes containing the activated TGF-ss receptor/Smads complexes from synaptic terminal or membranes to cell body might also be an essential aspect of the TGF-ss signaling mechanism to control development and function of the synapses (27,36).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	185	The existence of a known signaling pathway from synapse to nucleus via endosomal intermediates that regulates growth and development of synapses was of particular interest in the context of the present work because E HtorA expression perturbs synaptic development and E HtorA protein aggregates are found at precisely those subcellular locations synaptic terminals, endosomes and nuclei where they could most readily interfere with such a signaling pathway.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	186	 This possibility was further strengthened with the finding that the production of free dense bodies in motor terminals is associated with E HtorA expression as it is with mutations of components of the TGF-ss signaling (26,27).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	187	To investigate further whether the phenotypic abnormalities associated with E HtorA expression were, in fact, dependent on perturbing the TGF-ss signaling, we asked whether these phenotypes could be modified by overexpression of Mad or dSmad2, the transcriptional effectors of the TGF-ss pathway (26 to 29).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Remarkably, we found that pan-neural overexpression of dSmad2, but not Mad, substantially suppressed the defects in locomotor behavior as well as in synaptic morphology in E HtorA animals.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	189	As the locomotor defects observed in E HtorA flies at elevated temperatures bear some striking resemblance with the phenotype of torsion dystonia patients the possible involvement of common mechanisms does not seem unreasonable.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Moreover, a variety of data demonstrate that, as in Drosophila, TGF-ss signaling is important for the development of the mammalian nervous system and, in particular, plays an essential role in synaptic development and plasticity (34,37).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	191	 We also showed that expression of hSmad2 rescues abnormal behaviors as that of dSmad2 in flies (Fig.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Consequently, the possibility that the underlying mechanism of early onset torsion dystonia in humans involves a disruption of TGF-ss signaling merits further investigation.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	193	Early onset torsion dystonia is one of many severe complex neurobehavioral disorders caused by the interaction of multiple genes, or by a combination of genetic and environmental risk factors (14,15).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	194	 As there is significant variation in phenotype manifested by human patients, identification of susceptible genes that may be responsible for triggering the severe symptoms is important in seeking an adequate treatment (1 to 5).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	195	 In addition to examining human patients, another strategy is to find susceptible genes by taking advantage of an established animal model.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	196	 As the studies reported here demonstrate, further studies in this Drosophila model for early onset torsion dystonia should provide unique opportunities to obtain additional novel information about the underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms of this disorder.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	197	Generating human TorsinA transgenic flies.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The WT HtorA open reading frame was amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) from a human fetal brain cDNA library (Clontech, CA, USA).

0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Plasmids containing GAG were confirmed by DNA sequencing.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	204	 For generating 18 bp deletion mutant forms (F323 to Y328) of HtorA, three rounds of PCR were performed using three different overlapping primers (5'-CTT TAT CTG AGA AAA CTC TCT CCT CTT TGG GGA AA-3', 5'-GGT GAA CAC CGT TTT GCA GCC TTT ATC GCC TTT ATC TGA GAA AA-3', 5'-TCG TAG TAA TAA TCA ATC TTG GTG AAC ACC GTT TT-3').
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Final PCR products deleted for the desired 18 bp were confirmed by DNA sequencing.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Open reading frames of WT, E302/303 and F323-Y328 of HtorA were cloned into pUAST-germline transformation vectors.
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	207	 DNA sequences were confirmed again and typical germline transformation technique procedure was followed (19).
0.10246989.15269177.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Several independent fly lines were generated for each construct.

0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	0	Methionine 129 Variant of Human Prion Protein Oligomerizes More Rapidly than the Valine 129 Variant IMPLICATIONS FOR DISEASE SUSCEPTIBILITY TO CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE* Abdessamad Tahiri-Alaoui, Andrew C.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Gill ||, Petra Disterer, and William James**.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Sir William Dunn School of Pathology, University of Oxford, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3RE, United Kingdom and the  Institute for Animal Health, Compton, Berkshire, Newbury RG20 7NN, United Kingdom.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, February 17, 2004 , and in revised form, May 4, 2004.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	4	The human PrP gene (PRNP) exists in two major allelic forms that encode either methionine or valine at codon 129, with allele frequencies of 0.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	5	37 in western European and American populations, respectively (8, 9).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This polymorphism is a key determinant of susceptibility to sporadic (10) and acquired (8, 11) prion diseases and may affect age at onset (12 to 14).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Based on the analysis of 300 sporadic CJD subjects, Parchi et al.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	8	 (14) identified six distinct clinicopathological variants of sCJD, which appeared to be specified largely by the genotype at codon 129 and the physiochemical properties of PrPSc.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	9	 More recently, an extensive analysis, which included the metal ion-dependent conformation of PrPSc, of a large number of sCJD cases showed that PrPSc types are associated with the residue encoded at codon 129, the duration of illness, and with neuropathological phenotype (15).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	10	 PrPSc types 1 and 4 have so far been detected only in Met129 homozygotes, type 4 being uniquely associated with vCJD, type 3 in cases containing a Val129 allele, and type 2 in any PRNP codon 129 genotype (16).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The codon 129 polymorphism seemed to modulate the pattern of neuropathology and the extent of lesions in sCJD, as shown in a study that involved 70 patients who died in France between 1994 and 1998 (17).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Codon 129 polymorphism also has epistatic effects on the phenotypic effects of mutations elsewhere in the prion gene.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	13	 For example, the Asp178 Gln mutation combined with a methionine at position 129 results in fatal familial insomnia (18).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In contrast, the same mutation with a valine encoded at position 129 results in familial CJD (19).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Similarly, Val129 homozygotes in association with the Phe198 Ser mutation predispose patients to the Indiana kindred variant of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease (20).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Furthermore, an increased prevalence of genotype Val/Val at the polymorphic site 129 has been described in patients with early onset Alzheimer's disease (21) and a shift in cognitive decline toward early age in carriers of PRNP129 Val/Val has been reported recently (22).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	17	Despite the clear importance of the polymorphism at codon 129 in the PRNP gene and its link to disease susceptibility and pathogenesis, the molecular mechanisms by which these effects are mediated remain unclear.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The in vitro, thermodynamic stability of recombinant PrP is not affected by the Met129 Val mutation or by other substitutions related to inherited human prion diseases (23).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Structural studies, however, have shown evidence for hydrogen bonding between residues 128 and 178, which might provide a structural basis for the highly specific influence of polymorphism in position 129 on disease phenotype that segregates with Asp178 Gln (24).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Molecular dynamic simulations of low pH-induced conformational conversion of PrP has provided further clues as to the role of residue 129 (25).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In these simulations, Met129 seems to interact with Val122 leading to the recruitment of more N-proximal residues into an expanding -sheet.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	22	 As a complementary approach, we have chosen to study the folding properties of the two PrP allelomorphs experimentally by examining the misfolding pathway that leads to the formation of -sheet-rich oligomeric isoforms (26).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	23	 We show that PrP-Met129 has a higher propensity to form -sheet-rich oligomers, whereas PrP-Val129 has a higher tendency to fold into -helical-rich monomers.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	24	 We also provide evidence that the dynamics of maturation of the oligomers differ between the two variants.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The maturation process occurs over time at the expense of the -helical-like monomers at a faster rate for PrP-Met129 than for PrP-Val129.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Once the oligomers from either allelomorph have been formed they show similar proteinase K resistance that does not change throughout the oligomer maturation process.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The observed differences in the misfolding of PrP-Met129 and PrP-Val129 could explain the high susceptibility of individuals that are methionine homozygote to sporadic as well as variant CJD.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	28	Oligomer Formation by HPLC Gel Filtration and Dialysis Methods  Rapid refolding of proteins into oligomeric isoforms was carried out at concentrations of 10 and 30 mg/ml.
