0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	105	 To investigate the behavior of monomeric species in peak III under the same oligomeric-promoting conditions, we compared the rate of oligomerization of the Met129 variant to that of the Val129 variant collected from SEC at time 0.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Time course comparison between the two allelomorphs clearly revealed that monomeric Met129 has a higher propensity to oligomerize than monomeric Val129.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	107	 This difference in oligomerization rates was apparent after 2 days of incubation at room temperature (see supplementary Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	108	From these data we conclude that, under these conditions, the Met129 variant has an intrinsically higher propensity to form oligomer isoforms than the Val129.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The high oligomerization propensity of the methionine variant becomes even more apparent under the highest protein concentration and rapid refolding conditions.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Since this is true for denatured, aggregated, or natively folded monomeric protein, the higher propensity of oligomerization is clearly independent of the starting state of the protein.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	111	The Oligomers of Both Met129 and Val129 Variants Are Conformationally Heterogeneous and Show Different Kinetics of Maturation It has been shown that the oligomeric isoforms of mouse and Syrian hamster PrP are formed of populations of structurally heterogeneous proteins (26).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	112	 RP-HPLC analysis showed that reduced forms of recombinant mouse PrP existed in multiple -sheet-rich isoforms with distinct retention times (30, 31).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Accordingly, we used RP-HPLC to investigate the effect of the residue encoded at codon 129 on the composition of the oligomer population that eluted from SEC in peak II.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Aliquots of this fraction were incubated at room temperature in SEC elution buffer (20 mM sodium acetate, 0.

0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	117	 3A); however, for PrP-Val129 only one major peak was observed (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	118	 A second peak could be seen only after 12 days of incubation.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The two peaks were designated IIa and IIb, with shorter and longer retention times, respectively.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	120	 To rule out the possibility that the two peaks represented unexpected modification to the proteins, we analyzed them by mass spectrometry (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The deconvoluted mass spectra of PrP-Met129 IIa and PrP-Met129 IIb demonstrate that they represent proteins of the same molecular mass (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Similarly, the deconvoluted mass spectra of PrP-Val129 IIa and PrP-Val129 IIb showed that they also represented proteins with similar molecular masses (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	123	 From these analyses we infer that no covalent differences are evident and that the two peaks observed by RP-HPLC represent different conformations, with different amounts of hydrophobic residues exposed at the protein surface.

0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Over time, this conversion seemed to occur much quicker with PrP-Met129 than with PrP-Val129 (Fig.

0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The cleavage occurred at the same rate for both Met129 and Val129 variants and at a region of the N terminus that was PK-sensitive (see below) and, therefore, was unlikely to impact the differences that were observed during oligomerization of the two allelomorphs.

0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	173	  The Oligomers of Met129 and Val129 Show Similar Proteinase K Resistance Limited PK digestion has been used widely to distinguish the disease isoform, PrPSc, from PrPC as well as to probe differences between PrPSc strains (33, 34).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	174	 We therefore used limited PK digestion in combination with on-line capillary HPLC mass spectrometry to probe differences between Met129 and Val129 variants during oligomerization.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	175	 After treatment for up to 60 min with a 1:24 ratio of PK to protein, capillary HPLC mass spectrometry demonstrated that digestion of the oligomers from both allelomorphs yielded a range of short peptides that eluted before 20 min (insets in Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	176	 5, A and B) that were liberated from the N- and C-terminal His tag regions of the protein.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The central and C-terminal domains remained intact and eluted after 20 min as two peaks from the reversed-phase column (insets in Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	178	 These polypeptides separated into two peaks that started either from residues 117 or 135, respectively, as a result of differential cleavage within the hydrophobic region (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Comparison of deconvoluted mass spectra of polypeptides starting at 117 between PrP-Met129 (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	180	 5B) oligomers showed three major PK-resistant cores with matching cleavage sites for each variant.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The differences in masses (32 Da) between these PK-resistant fragments were due only to the presence of methionine or valine at position 129.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Similarly, the comparison of deconvoluted mass spectra of polypeptides that started at 135 between PrP-Met129 (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	183	 5D) oligomers revealed four major PK-resistant polypeptides with identical molecular masses for Met129 and Val129.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Most, if not all, of the C-terminal His tag remained PK-sensitive (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	185	 5F) during oligomerization, indicating that it was unlikely to interfere with the oligomerization process.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	186	 SDS-PAGE separation of the PK digests at various times of oligomerization (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	187	 5E) provided additional evidence that oligomers from PrP-Met129 and PrP-Val129 have similar PK-resistant properties.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	188	Our experimental data show that, under conditions that favor rapid formation of oligomers, SEC can be used to partition protein folded into aggregated, monomeric and oligomeric states so that differences in folding of Met129 and Val129 variants become clear.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	189	 It has been shown that folding of recombinant, murine prion protein into -helix-rich conformation is extremely rapid (41) and is under kinetic control (28).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	190	 We show in this work that the propensity of recombinant human prion protein to fold into monomeric -helical-rich population is increased when residue 129 was occupied by a valine.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	191	 However, when the same position is occupied by methionine a tendency for oligomerization can be observed, with comparatively little monomeric -helical-rich population.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	192	 These differences in folding behavior can be explained by a fundamental event in protein folding, which is driven by a small number of specific residues involved in the formation of a well defined, specific nucleus that then allows the rest of the structure to coalesce efficiently around it (42, 43).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The high -sheet propensity of valine residues as compared with methionine residues (44, 45) makes PrP in which valine is present at residue 129 more favorable to adopt the native local -sheet that would temporarily stabilize the Val129 allelomorph in the monomeric -helical PrP.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	194	Differences between the oligomers formed from Met129 and Val129 could be seen when we explored the hydrophobicity of the oligomers as they evolved over time.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	195	 These differences were consistent with early events that were observed during the rapid misfolding process.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	196	 That is, the proportion of oligomer subunits with hydrophobic properties resembling those of the -monomer was higher in PrP-Val129 than in the PrP-Met129.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Over the course of several weeks of incubation, the oligomerization process in both variants occurred at the expense of the -helical-like population that became a substrate for oligomer recruitment (28, 46).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The presence of the -helical-like species in the oligomer reflected the heterogeneous nature of this nonnative form of PrP.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	199	 This finding was consistent with the previously published supra-molecular electrospray ionization mass spectrometry results (26).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	200	 On the basis of these observations we propose a model (Fig.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	201	 6) that depicts the formation of non-native -oligomers in vitro.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Under appropriate conditions (low pH and high protein concentration) the acquisition of this non-native form can happen from either denatured, aggregated, or native forms and involves two steps: a rapid oligomerization phase followed by a slow maturation phase characterized by a structural rearrangement of the oligomers.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The presence of a methionine at codon 129 affects both the kinetics of oligomerization and those of the maturation phase.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	204	View larger version (31K):    FIG.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Schematic model illustrating in vitro formation and maturation of oligomer isoforms of recHuPrP90 to 231 Met129 and Val129.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Under appropriate conditions (low pH and high protein concentration) the acquisition of non-native form can happen from either denatured, aggregated, or native forms and involves two steps: a rapid oligomerization phase followed by a slow maturation phase characterized by a structural rearrangement of the oligomers.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The presence of a methionine at codon 129 affects both the kinetics of oligomerization and those of the maturation phase.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	208	  A hallmark of the disease isoform, PrPSc, is its partial resistance to proteinase K digestion compared with normal cellular PrP.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	209	 This property has also been used to probe differences between PrPSc conformations.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	210	 We found that once oligomers from both allelomorphs are formed they show similar proteinase K resistance that does not change throughout the oligomer maturation process.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	211	 This indicates that if one relies solely on PK digestion to investigate PrP conformations, one could miss the detection of dynamic conformational changes influenced by the polymorphism at codon 129 in human PrP during disease pathogenesis.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	212	 A similar PK cleavage site (starting at residue 117) in the protease-resistant core of the oligomers from both human PrP variants has been reported for recombinant mouse PrP23 to 231 (47).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	213	 It is important to emphasize that this PK cleavage site is not the same as the termini around codon 90 found for authentic PrPSc (48).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	214	It has been reported that two mutations in -synuclein that are linked to early-onset Parkinson's disease can accelerate the oligomerization but not fibrilization suggesting that formation of nonfibrillar oligomer is likely to be critical in disease pathogenesis (49).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	215	 There is no evidence so far that these -oligomers exist in vivo or can directly cause prion diseases either alone or with the help of other factors.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The high affinity and newly reported ligands that we have isolated in our laboratory (50, 51) would help investigating the presence in vivo of the -oligomers.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The observed differences in the misfolding behavior between Met129 and Val129 variants could provide a kinetic explanation to the observed high susceptibility of individuals that are methionine homozygote to sporadic as well as to variant CJD.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The attempt to model a heterozygote situation by mixing Met129/Val129 (1:1) and allowing the rapid refolding to occur has yielded some promising results in that the amount of oligomers formed was reduced by 30% as compared with the homozoygote-like situation in the Met129 alone, indicating certain degree of inhibition of the oligomerization in the heterozygote.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	219	Phylogenetically, methionine is the ancestral amino acid at codon 129 (52), and Val129 is a mutation found in humans.
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Worldwide PRNP haplotype diversity and coding allele frequencies suggest that strong balancing selection at this locus occurred during the evolution of modern human and made heterozygosity at PRNP a significant selective advantage (53).
0.10508279.15131108.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Our data could provide a mechanism based on prion protein folding properties as an additional selective pressure against, particularly, Met129 homozygosity.

0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	0	Identification of putative atypical scrapie in sheep in Portugal Leonor Orge1,2, Alexandre Galo1, Carla Machado1, Carla Lima1, Cristina Ochoa1, Joao Silva1, Manuel Ramos1 and J.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Laboratorio Nacional de Investigacao Veterinaria, Lisboa, Portugal 2 Instituto Gulbenkian de Ciencia, Rua da Quinta Grande 6, 2780-156 Oeiras, Portugal 3 Laboratorio de Microbiologia, Faculdade de Medicina, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisboa, Portugal.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	2	In Portugal, despite the completion of previous scrapie surveillance plans, both at the clinical and histopathological levels, as yet no scrapie cases have been diagnosed.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	3	 The absence of scrapie in Portugal cannot be attributed to a genetic basis and the possibility has been suggested for subclinical or other forms of scrapie strains to be present (Orge et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	4	 In this study, as a result of the EU active scrapie surveillance plan, we have identified the first cases of sheep with detectable PrPres deposition in the central nervous system (CNS) in Portugal.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	5	Since its implementation in 2002 (according to EU regulation 999/2001 and subsequent alterations) until February 2004, a total of 30 269 sheep over 18 months of age were screened for the presence of PrPres in the brainstem by the Bio-Rad rapid test done according to manufacturer's instructions.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	6	 All the cases that tested positive by the rapid test had been selected for human consumption.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	7	 These cases were analysed further for the presence of vacuolation by histopathology, for the deposition of PrPres by immunohistochemistry and for the analysis of the PrPres electrophoretic profile by Western immunoblotting, and the Prnp (codons 136, 154 and 171) genotypes were also determined.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Brainstems were divided sagittally with one half frozen for rapid test analysis, Western immunoblotting and DNA extraction, and the other half fixed in 10 % saline formalin and processed for routine paraffin histology.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	9	 For immunohistochemistry, three anti-PrP monoclonal antibodies, 2G11 (Institute Pourquier-Farmoquil), SAF84 (SPI-bio) and L42 (RIDA; R-Biopharm), were used in three confirmatory independent assays essentially as previously described (Orge et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	10	 For 2G11, sections were pretreated with formic acid followed by autoclaving.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In the case of SAF84 and L42, sections were, in addition to formic acid treatment, pretreated with proteinase K as described previously (Bencsik et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The specificity of PrPres immunolabelling was controlled using sections from known scrapie-positive [kindly supplied by the Veterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA) archive] and scrapie-negative cases.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	13	 For Western immunoblotting analysis of PrPres, frozen brainstem tissue was processed according to a new protocol from Bio-Rad developed for ovine tissues.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	14	 For Prnp genotyping, genomic DNA extracted from frozen brainstem tissue was subjected to PCR with Prnp specific primers (upper and lower primers: 321 to 340 and 572 to 590 nt, respectively, according to GenBank accession no.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	15	 AF180389) to yield an amplicon that encompassed codons 136, 154 and 171.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	16	 PCR products were then submitted to automated cycle sequencing in both orientations using an ABI Prism 377 DNA sequencer (Perkin Elmer).
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	17	As a result of the rapid test screening, seven sheep slaughtered for human consumption that tested positive for the presence of PrPres (Table 1) were confirmed for the deposition of PrPres in the brainstem at the level of the obex, both by us and the VLA despite the absence of obvious vacuolation.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	18	 All cases showed the same granular PrPres deposition in the neuropil of the spinal tract nucleus of the trigeminal nerve (STN V) (Fig.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Remarkably, no PrPres deposition could be detected in the neuropil of the dorsal vagal nucleus (DVN) (Fig.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	20	 1a, d, g and j), which is the neuronal nucleus that is always associated with PrPres deposition in scrapie.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In three sheep (Table 1; cases 4, 6 and 7), focal granular immunostaining in the neuropil of the nucleus of the solitary tract (NST) was also observed (Fig.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	22	 This distribution is unusual because of the consistent absence of detectable PrPres in the DVN and the deposition in the STN V.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In scrapie, it has been extensively reported that the DVN is the first CNS nucleus to show vacuolation and PrPres deposition (Andreoletti et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	24	, 1997), hence, is the elected nucleus used for routine diagnosis.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Thus, the distribution of PrPres deposition obtained with three different anti-PrP specific antibodies was atypical in all seven cases reported here.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Recently, scrapie cases have been reported that also diverged phenotypically from typical scrapie (Benestad et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In particular, in several atypical scrapie cases that have been reported in Norway, PrPres deposition was observed in the cerebellum, midbrain and cerebral cortex, but no PrPres could be detected in the obex region (Benestad et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In these cases, designated Nor98, although inconsistently, PrPres deposition was also detected in the STN V.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	29	 These findings are consistent with those described here in that no PrPres could be detected in the DVN.

0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	55	  Notably, four of seven cases reported here had genotypes rarely associated with scrapie, including one animal homozygous for ARR (Table 1).
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Susceptibility to clinically apparent scrapie is determined by polymorphisms in Prnp, particularly at codons 136 (A, V or T), 154 (R or H) and 171 (Q, R, H or K).
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Genotypes with VRQ and ARQ alleles are linked to a higher susceptibility to scrapie, whereas, genotypes with AHQ and ARR alleles are linked to a lower susceptibility and increased resistance to scrapie (Billinis et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Under experimental conditions, polymorphisms in Prnp have also been shown to influence the transmission of BSE to sheep, with the allele ARQ being associated with a shorter incubation period and ARR with increased resistance (Foster et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	59	 However, successful transmission of BSE by the intracerebral route to homozygous ARR sheep has been reported recently (Houston et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	60	, 2003) and other recently reported scrapie cases in Europe (Buschmann et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	61	, 2004), the cases reported here can also be considered as atypical.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Thus far, all cases of sheep with PrPres deposition in the CNS identified in Portugal are from sheep with no apparent clinical disease and came from flocks dispersed throughout the country.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Notably, of the 30 269 sheep tested none showed a pattern of PrPres deposition coherent with typical scrapie.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	64	 This finding is consistent with the fact that to date no clinical scrapie has been diagnosed in Portugal.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Thus, it is not clear if the cases described in this study represent an endemic form of a prion disease in sheep not previously identified and not linked to any specific Prnp genotypes or represent a recently acquired new form of scrapie.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	66	In order to gain further insight into the epidemiological and public health relevance of this apparent atypical scrapie, it is extremely important to show if it is transmissible and assess if it constitutes a new scrapie strain like Nor98.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The occurrence of such a putative atypical scrapie strain, independently of the Prnp genotype, may be of significance for current EU sheep breeding programmes for selection of non-susceptible haplotypes.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Furthermore, given the recent BSE epidemic in Portugal (Donnelly et al.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	69	, 1999), and thus the geographical risk of transmission of BSE into sheep, a possible link to BSE cannot be excluded.
0.11211797.15483267.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Although, we cannot rule out the possibility of adaptation of BSE in sheep following natural transmission, the fact that the PrPres electrophoretic profile described for this putative atypical scrapie strain is distinct from that observed in BSE experimentally infected sheep, makes this link less probable.

0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	0	Farm animal genomics and informatics: an update Ahmed Fadiel*, Ifeanyi Anidi and Kenneth D.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	1	Yale University School of Medicine, Yale Center for Research On Reproductive Biology New Haven, CT 06511, USA 1Mount Sinai School of Medicine New York, NY 10029, USA.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	2	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Tel: +1 203 737 1218; Fax: +1 203 785 5294; Email: afadiel{at}yale.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	4	Proteomics, or the science of protein structure and function, is now a hot spot in biomedicine.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	5	 A key component to the next revolution in the  post-genomic  era will be the increasingly widespread use of protein structure in rational experimental design.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	6	 New computational methodologies now yield structure models that are, in many cases, quantitatively comparable to crystal structures, at a fraction of the cost (4).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The technical challenge is the complete coverage of physicochemical properties for thousands of proteins (5).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Thus, by analytically investigating genes and proteins, researchers have developed the umbrella study of bioinformatics, the science of analyzing biological data using cutting-edge computing techniques.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	9	Bioinformatics deals with methods for storing, retrieving and analyzing biological data, such as nucleic acid (DNA/RNA) and protein sequences, structures, functions, pathways and genetic interactions: the computational management of all kinds of biological information (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	10	gov/About/primer/bioinformatics.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Rather than merely a mixture of computer science, data management and genome sciences, Bioinformatics now encompasses both conceptual and practical tools for the propagation, generation, processing and understanding of scientific ideas and biological information (6).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	12	DNA and protein sequences data banks The availability of many complete genome sequences from different species can bring insight into the function of conserved non-coding regions of DNA sequence (7).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Organization of the data into coding (genes) and non-coding sequences, in addition to organizing these data into databases for  DNA databases  and proteins (Table 1), is central for bioinformatics (6,8,9).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Parsing the sequence of DNA or protein is a first step, followed by curation then analysis and sometimes re-curation based on the analysis.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The presence of these databases and derivative search engines gave rise to programs, such as FASTA (10) and PSI-BLAST (11), which are DNA and protein sequence analysis tools, respectively (12).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	16	 These tools facilitate searches for sequences that resemble one another and homologous relationship inferences.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Utilization of similarity search programs, which operate on sequences, has helped in augmenting annotated databases, which house information about sequence domains.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Information recording, retrieval and cataloging continue to advance further database capabilities (13).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Collaborating research centers, particularly in the US, Japan and the UK, have been actively collecting sequence data and making it accessible to public (14) (Table 1).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	20	View this table:    Table 1 General genomics and proteomics databases: comprised of resources for human, goat, mouse, deer, rat, and horse genomes.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	21	  Farm animals: an unexploited gold mine for biotech Farm animals are quite valuable as resources, often notable as models for pathology and physiology studies.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Magnussen (15) discusses how a variety of these farm animal models are used.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The reproductive physiology of farm animals is more similar to humans than that of rodents because farm animals have longer gestation and pre-pubertal periods than mice (16).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Specific farm animal physiology, such as the digestive system of the pig is similar to that of humans (17).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	25	 These attributes of farm animals reveal that they are an unparalleled resource for research replicating human physiological function (15).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	26	For decades, breeders have altered the genomes of farm animals by first searching for desired phenotypic traits and then selecting for superior animals to continue their lineage into the next generation (18).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	27	 This genomic work has already facilitated a reduction in genetic disorders in farm animals, as many disease carriers are removed from breeding populations by purifying selection (19).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	28	 By studying diverse phenotypes over time, researchers can now monitor mutations that occur as wild species become domesticated (20).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Farm animal food safety will remain a concern for some time; however, advancements such as the discovery of Escherichia coli resistant genes in the pig (21) can mediate most of the problems.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Moreover, resources devoted to investigating the genomes of farm animals can bring eventual economic benefits.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	31	 For example, isolation of DNA from animal tissue can be used as an inexpensive method for tracking the origin of a meat sample, providing the recipient with the quality assurance of that food (22).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	32	2005: the year of the chicken There has been significant interest in the first complete analysis of the draft genome sequence of the chicken.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	33	 This sequence has given rise to chicken genome array chips and a number of web based mapping tools.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The great importance of the chicken as a scientific resource can be seen from the research on avian leucosis virus, which has led to developments in the areas of proviral insertion-mediated oncogenesis and vertebrate viral-host interactions (23,24).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Still, many chicken lines are being lost due to facility downsizing and closings (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	36	The release of the first draft of the chicken genome in March 2004 spawned the current boom in chicken genomic research (25) (Table 2).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	37	 From an evolutionary standpoint, investigation of the chicken genome will provide significant information needed to understand the vertebrate genome evolution, since the chicken is between the mammal and fish on the evolutionary tree (26).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Furthermore, the chicken remains significant as a food animal which comprises 41% of the meat produced in the world and serves as a reliable model for the study of diseases and developmental biology (26).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	39	 With this sequenced genome, chicken breeders will have a framework for investigating polymorphisms of informative quantitative traits to continue their directed evolution of these species.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The chicken genome is also effective as a comparative genomic tool that sheds additional light on various aspects of our own genome (27).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	41	 In addition, complementary DNA microarrays for the chicken have already been produced for the study of metabolic and other systemic processes (27,28).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	42	View this table:    Table 2 Chicken-based internet genomic resources.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	43	  The swine sequence The sequencing of the pig genome generated an invaluable resource for advancements in enzymology, reproduction, endocrinology, nutrition and biochemistry research (29,30).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Since pigs are evolutionarily distinct to both humans and rodents, but have co-evolved with these species, the diversity of selected phenotypes make the pig a useful model for the study of genetic and environmental interactions with polygenic traits (31).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The sequencing of the pig genome is also instrumental in the improvement of human health.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Clinical studies in areas such as infectious disease, organ transplantation, physiology, metabolic disease, pharmacology, obesity and cardiovascular disease have used pig models (32) (Table 3).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	47	 In the near future, the sequencing of the porcine genome will allow gene markers for specific diseases to be identified, assisting breeders in generating pig stocks resistant to infectious diseases (33).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Furthermore, as researchers investigate the swine genome and isolate genes that may impact the economics of breeding, members of the commercial pig industry are able to use this information to garner benefits (30).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	49	View this table:    Table 3 Genomic and proteomic internet sites devoted to the study of the swine genome.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	50	  The Bos taurus genome The mammalian order Cetartiodactyla (possessing B.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	51	taurus or cattle) is of great interest since it represents a group of eutherian mammals phylogenetically distant from primates (34,35).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Working with the cow species, B.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	53	taurus, is significant because the cow is such an economically important animal.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	54	 This form of livestock makes up the beef and milk production industry, which is one of the largest industries in the United States.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The identification of numerous single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) makes it possible for geneticists to find associations between certain genes and cow traits that will eventually lead to the production of superior-quality beef (36).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	56	 After the completion of the September 2004 B.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	57	taurus draft assembly (Table 4), this genome has functioned as a vehicle for studies on non-primate and non-rodent genomes as well as in comparative genomics (37).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Similar to the pig, the cow also serves as a good animal model for obesity, infectious diseases and female health (34,38).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	59	View this table:    Table 4 Cow genomics and proteomics resources on the Internet.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	60	  Sheep (Ovis aries) genome project Bioinformatics researchers from New Zealand, US, UK and Australia have come together to work on the sheep genome map.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The focal point of interest in sheep is based on the quest to maximize sheep meat and cotton wool production.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	62	 This sector of the corporate farming industry is so intent on this biotechnology project that AWI, Meat and Livestock Australia and nine other partners are investing $50 million into the Sheep Genome Project to ensure its completion (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	63	 As a resource in biological science, researchers have mapped a subset of genes that have also been mapped in humans and mice (39).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	64	 These studies have revealed the existence of mutations that yield phenotypes unique to the sheep, demonstrating that genetic analysis of the sheep can enhance our knowledge of biological pathways in other mammalian species (39,40).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Table 5 provides information on current genome informatics resources available on the Internet related to sheep.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	66	View this table:    Table 5 Internet informatics resources pertaining to the sheep genome.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	67	  The fish genome project Fish are one of the most studied organisms.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Researchers have investigated the genome of zebrafish, medaka, pufferfish (Fugu rubripes and Tetraodon nigroviridis) and sticklebacks.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The zebrafish genome has attracted the attention of various pharmaceutical and biotech companies owing to the ease with which scientists can use this fish to study the gene function (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	70	uk/en/genome/genesandbody/hg05f006.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The number of databases and informatics resources related to fish genomic study on the Internet is consistently growing (Table 6).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Japanese researchers are interested in medakas from an evolutionary standpoint (40).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Other fish genome sequences, such as the pufferfish genome are similar to the Fugu genome in size and are 7.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	74	5 times smaller than the human genome.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	75	 This has led many to believe that the genes conserved between these two species would reveal the minimal number of genes required for a vertebrate organism (41).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Further investigation of the Fugu genome supported this hypothesis and showed the ability of the Fugu genome to aid in the study of vertebrate functional non-coding sequences (41).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Other studies of fish have focused on the stickleback, for its variable body shapes, ecology or its behavior (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	78	gov/Pages/Research/Sequencing/SeqProposals/SticklebackSEQ.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	79	 In general, fish genomic work is of interest to the commercial fish farming community.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Based on transgenic studies, antifreeze protein and fish growth hormone have been introduced into fish genomes, creating fish with greater cold tolerance and faster growth rates (42).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	81	View this table:    Table 6 Fish genomic resources on the internet.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	82	  The forgotten rabbit Little genomics attention is paid to rabbits in comparison with other animal models, such as the mouse, rat and fruit fly in the pre- and post-genomic era.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	83	 However, experimental models, such as the Alba or the  mighty lighting rabbit , were developed as glowing mutants that shine under special light for commercial reasons.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	84	 French scientists created Alba using a process called zygote microinjection.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	85	 In this process, the scientists plucked a fluorescent protein from the fluorescent jellyfish Aequorea victoria.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Then, they modified the gene to make its glowing properties twice as powerful.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	87	 This gene, called EGFG (enhanced green fluorescent gene, was then inserted into a fertilized rabbit egg cell that eventually grew into Alba (Amanda onion).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Debates about the project itself and about the practice of manipulating genes in animals for research have quickly arisen in the research community.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The French National Institute of Agronomic Research hesitated to release these rabbits owing to protests over its development.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	90	Chinese scientists have placed rabbit genes in cotton plants, producing cotton fibers as bright and soft as rabbit hair but stronger and warmer.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	91	 This indicates not only the rise of the rabbit in experimental models for genetics engineering, but also for future medical experimentation models.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Despite the controversy that the  shining rabbit  and the  cotton rabbit  raised, it is clear that this type of genetic engineering is at an early stage.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Currently available sources of information about the rabbit on the web can be seen in Table 7.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	94	View this table:    Table 7 Rabbit informatics databases.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	95	  Farm animal genomics: current statistics As researchers delve into the composition of farm animal genome sequences, new functional and biological data emerge.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Table 8 is compiled from the Ensembl database (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	97	org/) and illustrates a summary of current analysis on coding regions within genomes for selected farm animals.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	98	 For example, in the cow genome, 239 000 exon regions and just over 29 000 transcripts have been tallied from among the 565 million bp found in the genome.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	99	View this table:    Table 8 Ensemble (gene build July 2005) and NCBI statistics of available farm animal genomesa.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	100	  One of the major sources of information on farm animal genomics is the ArkDB (43), which is available through the Roslin Institute (UK) and Texas A and M University (USA).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The ArkDB provides detailed genomic mapping data on sheep, chicken, cow and pig genomes (44), including data on PCR primers, genetic linkage map assignments of specific loci and markers, and cytogenetic map assignments.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Information about farm animals in this database is displayed in Table 9 and provides a snapshot of current resources available for each genome.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Quantitative functional information, such as the number of clones, microsatellites and associated mapping assignments, can lend insight into the complexity of the models available.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	104	 For example, the number of primers tabulated in the swine genome currently far exceeds that known for the cow, indicating more varieties of genes are available for study in the swine.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Much of this information remains at an early stage and with increasing experimentation, compilation and analysis, will be refined.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	106	View this table:    Table 9 Current status summary provided by the ArkDB.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	107	  Expression sequence tags Expression sequence tags (ESTs) are small pieces of cDNA sequence (usually 200 to 500 nt long), which are useful as markers for a desired portion of RNA and DNA that can be used for gene identification and positional mapping within a genome (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The NCBI provides the most comprehensive EST database for many farm animals.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Tabulation of chicken EST information, including quantities of ESTs and their tissue sources can be found in the BBSRC ChickEST Database (http://chick.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	110	 ChickEST provides access to 339 000 Gallus ESTs, generated from 21 different embryonic and adult tissues.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Cow EST information is available on ArkDB, Ensembl (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	112	cgi?taxid=9031) and the NCBI Cow genome EST.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	113	 A collection of pig ESTs is also available through the pig EST database (http://pigest.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The first version contains 14 000 EST sequences obtained from porcine whole embryo, term placenta, anterior pituitary, hypothalamus and ovary.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The second, newer version of the database accommodates 99 000 pig ESTs.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Pig sequence homology comparisons can be readily studied on the Iowa State University's website.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, database updates were carried out only until January 2002.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Among farm animals, there is sparse information about rabbit ESTs.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	119	 NCBI does not provide comprehensive EST information, with virtually no physical maps on the rabbit.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	120	 However, NCBI is still the central source for information about rabbit ESTs, mining 2275 GenBank rabbit ESTs (dbEST release 082605).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	121	Physical mapping Genome maps in livestock species have been under development for the last decade.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Mapping, which involves understanding the relative distances between genes on a chromosome, has been performed for the many farm animals.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The NCBI provide comprehensive mapping information for many farm animal species.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Mapping information is available at http://www.

0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	126	 For example, the chicken mapping site can be found at NCBI MapView website (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The US Livestock Species Genome Projects (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	128	org/) suggest using ArkDB (mentioned above), for mapping information on farm animals.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The Laboratory of Biochemistry and Cytogenetics (Jouy-in-Josas, France) at the National Institute for Agricultural Research (INRA) provides the rabbit  Lepine  genome mapping database (http://dga.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The database provides access to information about rabbit genomic information which includes so far 410 loci with 1327 homologue loci on 129 species, 21 polymorphisms, 314 genes and their physical location on chromosomes.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Other information about primers, probes and enzymes are also included.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Genes in the RabbitMap database are hyperlinked to a separate page that provides locus information.

0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The Ensemble database also provides a comprehensive map viewer for zebrafish and the chicken (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	135	 High-resolution maps for sheep chromosomes are available at http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	136	Quantitative trait loci and genetic linkage One of the primary challenges in modern biology is the understanding of the genetic basis of phenomic diversity within and among species (20).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The foundation for this diversity lies in genetic governance of both how traits are expressed and the associated linkage maps.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Genes mapped in some farm animals serve as  anchors  across the comparative maps of other species (39).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Quantitative trait loci (QTLs) play a major role in farm animals and the related biotechnology industry, as they can further the identification of traits related to meat and milk production.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	140	 A number of studies have been conducted to detect QTLs that can be used for determining gene variances (48,49).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The third generation of sheep linkage map (50) contains 1062 loci (941 anonymous loci and 121 genes) and is a compilation of genotype data generated by 15 laboratories using the IMF population (http://rubens.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The ArkDB provides current summaries of linkage and cytogenetic map assignments, polymorphic marker details, PCR primers and two point linkage data (see Table 9).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The ArkDB also is a major source for mapped sheep loci, with SheepBase containing almost 1500 loci.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The Roslin Institute has developed the  resSpecies  (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	145	org/) database to study genetic linkage maps, QTLs, alleles and other markers (44,51).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Bovine QTL databases are available from several sources (52,53).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Various traits, such as milk yield and composition, are available along with QTL dot maps, which provide varied positional and statistical information.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	148	org/QTLdb/) includes two release versions from NCBI in May 2004 and from NAGRP in December 2004.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	149	 The pig QTL database, or pig QTLdb, contains all published pig QTL data from the past decade.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The user can locate genes responsible for quantitative traits central to pig production.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	151	 To date, 791 QTLs from 73 publications, representing 219 different traits are incorporated into the database in the first release and 1129 QTLs, from 86 publications representing 235 different traits in the second release.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The project also provides maps at http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	153	org/cgi-bin/QTLdb/viewmap and links to the NCBI pig EST Map database (http://pigest.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	154	Genome policies for transgenic animals The federal government's role as a legal authority for protecting the environment from scientifically introduced transgenic organisms has not been clearly outlined (55).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	155	 This underscores the need for greater governmental attention to address legal problems that will arise as animal biotechnology continues to grow.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Many argue that it is not only a moral imperative to respect the intrinsic sentience of animals but also a legal one (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	157	org/library/consultations/BBSRCgenomics.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The European Union's Treaty of Amsterdam states that animals must be treated humanely, as sentient beings, which some argue implies respect for their intrinsic nature and protection against such infringements of that respect in studies such as transgenic animal experiments (http://www.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Furthermore, US food regulatory agencies, such as the United States Department of Agriculture and the Food Safety and Inspection Service, charged with the duty of making sure that transgenic animals anticipated for human consumption are correctly labeled and wholesome, have already moved forward to institute policies regulating the slaughtering of non-transgenic animals created from transgenic animal experiments (56).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	160	Ethical reservations of farm animal genomic study As farm animal species continue to be sequenced (one of the latest being the cow, B.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	161	taurus), farming companies are using this information to perform genetic profiles of traditionally bred animals and to genetically engineer or clone other animals (57).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Although many farmers may enjoy access to greater genetic resources, animal rights organizations oppose the use of animals such as transgenic goats that produce silk proteins used to make Biosteel fibers because of the allegedly inhumane treatment of animals during these studies (58).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Proponents of such experiments point to the ability of transgenic mouse mammary glands to assemble and secrete recombinant human fibrinogen (59).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	164	 These studies raise many concerns about research ethics and species integrity (60,61).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	165	The potential of farm animal genomics Farm animal genomic studies continue to attract audiences excited by the multitude of applications (62).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The meat industry can now use cow and chicken genomic data to confirm the quality of meat products.
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	167	 For example, meat producers can now confirm the parentage of an Angus cattle breed by performing a genetic blood test or attempt to identify the SNPs associated with high-quality beef (57).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Other companies are using genomic information to determine disease-resistant genes in shrimp and then are selectively mating the shrimp that carry them in order to create disease resistant strains (57).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In the healthcare arena, farm animal genomic work will aid in enterprises such as xenotransplantation (the transfer of animal tissues or organs into humans).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Though animal organs may be used someday to satiate organ donor shortage, genomic work in this area is still in its early stage (63).
0.11293201.16275782.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Many of the immediate practical applications of farm animal genomics show potential for growth in this field.

0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	0	The Mad and Myc Basic Domains Are Functionally Equivalent* Mikhail A.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Nikiforov, Nikita Popov , Iulia Kotenko, Marie Henriksson , and Michael D.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the  Department of Molecular Biology, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544 and the   Microbiology and Tumorbiology Center, Karolinska Institutet, SE-171 77 Stockholm, Sweden.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, December 3, 2002, and in revised form, January 17, 2003.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	4	The c-myc gene encodes a transcription factor, c-Myc, that dimerizes with Max to serve as a master regulator of cell growth, cell division, and cell differentiation in all metazoans (reviewed in Ref.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Mutations that disrupt the regulated expression of c-myc (or the related N-myc and L-myc genes) are common, causative lesions in many human and animal cancers (2).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In addition to its prominent link to cancer, myc is also required for timely progression through the cell cycle and is an essential downstream effector of mitogenic signals (3-5).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The Myc family proteins function as transactivators when assayed on reporter constructs containing consensus binding sites or when the Myc N terminus is tethered to DNA through a heterologous DNA binding domain (6, 7).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Recognition of specific chromosomal targets primarily involves the basic region, which forms an extended -helix with helix 1 in the Max homodimer crystal structure (8, 9).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Myc/Max heterodimers recognize a preferred consensus site ACCACGTGGT, although other related sites are also bound with varying affinity (10-12).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The helix-loop-helix and leucine zipper domains dictate the highly specific dimerization of Myc with Max, which prevents dimerization with numerous other transcription factors that have related HLH1 and/or leucine zipper motifs (13).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	11	 An increasing number of cellular targets for Myc/Max heterodimers have been defined (14) with compelling evidence that Myc protein can be cross-linked to target sites in vivo using chromatin immunoprecipitation (15-18).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	12	More recently, the Max superfamily was extended to include the Mad and Mxi proteins that form alternate heterodimers with Max (reviewed in Ref.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Unlike Myc, Mad/Mxi proteins function as repressors of transcription and inhibitors of both cell proliferation and oncogenic transformation (20-22).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Mad/Max heterodimers recognize consensus binding sites in vitro that are indistinguishable from those recognized by Myc/Max, suggesting that these alternate Max complexes may activate and repress common target genes.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Although this is an appealing model, there remains only limited evidence to support it.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Whereas Myc protein is expressed in all proliferating cells, Mad protein expression is more restricted and primarily found in terminally differentiated cells (23-26).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Thus, in mitogen-deprived cells where Myc levels are low, there is no evidence that Mad supplants Myc to repress target genes.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Some specific gene promoters, tert and cyclinD2, have been shown to bind to Mad1 protein in vivo, using HL60 cells, which differentiate and express high enough levels of Mad protein to cross-link (16, 18).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In undifferentiated cells that express Myc rather than Mad, Myc was bound to the same promoters, suggesting that Myc and Mad can bind sequentially to common promoters.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	20	 However, these are isolated examples so far, and no other promoters were examined.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Further support for antagonistic functions of Myc and Mad/Mxi comes from mouse gene knockout experiments in which Mad and Mxi knockouts exhibit minor hyperproliferative disorders or occasional tumors, suggesting that these genes can function as tumor suppressors (27-29).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	22	 However, no homozygous mutations in mad or mxi genes have been found in human or animal cancers to establish any direct role for these proteins as tumor suppressors.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	23	Previous studies compared Myc and Mxi/Mad binding with cellular promoters through either the introduction of Mad/Mxi1-specific amino acid substitutions into the Myc basic region or the complete substitution of the Mad1 basic/HLH/LZ region into Myc (30, 31).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Since the basic region is responsible (when dimerized with Max) for the recognition of DNA sequence elements at chromosomal sites, it was suggested that these mutants would offer insight into Myc versus Mad/Mxi target gene recognition and biological function.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	25	 One study noted a substantial decrease in the transforming activity of the Myc(Mxi1-BR) exchange mutants and a shift in the spectrum of genes regulated in human fibroblasts (30).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	26	 From this, it was suggested that the biological activities of Myc and Mxi1 involve the regulation of both common and distinct sets of target genes governing diverse biological processes.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	27	 A second study with a complete B/HLH/LZ exchange came to the different conclusion that DNA binding activity and target gene regulation in terms of cell proliferation were similar for the Myc and Mad1 proteins but that the induction of apoptosis was substantially different (31).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	28	Vectors-- Expression plasmids were created by standard methods in retroviral expression vector pLXSH and verified by sequence analysis.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Details of individual constructs are available upon request.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	30	Cell Culture, and Retroviral Infection-- The human promyelocytic leukemia cell line HL60 was grown in RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% fetal calf serum and 2 mM L-glutamine.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	31	 To induce cell differentiation, cells at a density of 0.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	32	4  x  106 cells/ml were treated with 1.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Normal human fibroblasts (IMR90), rat c-myc-null fibroblasts (HO15.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	34	19 cells), and retroviral producer PhoeNX cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	35	19 and IMR90 cells was performed according to published protocols (32), using PhoeNX cells.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	36	 PhoeNX cells were transfected via the calcium phosphate method.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	37	 To obtain a transduced cell population, cells transduced with LXSH-based retroviruses were selected for resistance to hygromycin (150  microg/ml) for 7 days.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	38	Fluorescence-activated Cell Sorter-- To induce apoptosis, ~106 cells were incubated in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 0.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Floating and adherent cells were harvested after 48 h of starvation.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The cells were pelleted, and the pellet was resuspended in 500  microl of phosphate-buffered saline + 0.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	41	5% fetal calf serum and fixed in 70% ethanol at 20  degrees C overnight.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The fixed cells were pelleted and resuspended in 500  microl of phosphate-buffered saline +0.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	43	5% fetal calf serum and an equal volume of the DNA extraction buffer (192 ml, 0.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	44	8) was added to each sample followed by incubation for 5 min at room temperature.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The cells were pelleted and resuspended in 800  microl of phosphate-buffered saline +0.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	46	5% fetal calf serum supplemented with 8  microl of propidium iodide (1 mg/ml in 20 mM sodium citrate) and 4  microl of RNase A (DNase free, 10 mg/ml) in a 1-ml total volume.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The cells were incubated for 30 min at 37  degrees C and analyzed on a BD Biosciences FACScan fluorescence activated cells sorter.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	48	Chromatin Immunoprecipitation-- Chromatin immunoprecipitation assay on logarithmically growing and differentiating HL60 cells was performed according to Xu et al.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Conditions for the chromatin immunoprecipitation assay on HO15.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	50	19 cells were described previously (33).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The following sets of primers were used: rat nm23-specific primers NM23a (5'-GGTCGTTCTCGTCTCTGCTC-3') and NM23b (5'-TTCTGCTCGAATCGCTTGAT-3'); rat mSHMT-specific primers RmSHMT1 (5'-CTGGATGACCAGTGGAAAGG-3') and RmSHMT2 (5'-GACCCTTGCGTGATGAAAGT-3'); rat nucleolin-specific primers NUCLa (5'-CTGGGAGGGCGATGTAGAGT-3') and NUCLb (5'-GGAAGGGGGTTATCTCGAAG-3'); rat glucokinase-specific primers GLUa (5'-TGCCCGATTTTCATCTTCTT-3') and GLUb (5'-CCAAGGACTTCCGCACTAAC-3'); hsp60-specific primers HSPa (5'-GGCTGGGGATAAGTCTGTCA-3') and HSPb (5'-GACGGTGCAAAACCCTCTAA-3'); human mSHMT-specific primers SC-25 (5'-CGAGTTGCGATGCTGTACTTCTCT-3') and SC-26 (5'-GCTCGGTTGCATCATCTGCA-3'); human cad-specific primers hCAD-CPs (5'-CCAGTTCCCATTGGTGTTGTTGCC-3') and hCAD-CPa (5'-GAGAGGCGCATCACAGAGTGGGATAA-3'); human hsp60-specific primers hHSP60-CPs (5'-CTCCGCCTCAGACTCGTACT-3') and hHSP60-CPa (5'-AGAGGAGGAAGGCCCACTC-3'); human cdk4-specific primers hCDK4-CPa (5'-CTCTGGGTGGCCTAGGTTG-3') and hCDK4-CPb (5'-TAGAGAGGCCCCCTCACC-3').
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	52	To normalize samples by the amount of nonspecific DNA, we amplified a region in the promoter of the rat pcna gene, PCNa (5'-CGAAGCACCCAGGTAAGTGT-3') and PCNb (5'-ATCGTATCCGTGGTTTGAGC-3'), or in the third intron of the human -globin gene, SC-46 (5'-ATCTTCC-TCCCACAGCTCCT-3') and SC-47 (5'-TTTGCAGCCTCACCTTCTTT-3').
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	53	 One of the primers in each pair was end-labeled with [-32P]ATP.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Amplification was performed in a T3 Thermocycler (Biometra ) for 31 cycles at 94  degrees C for 45 s, 60  degrees C for 45 s, and 72  degrees C for 60 s followed by a final extension step at 72  degrees C for 5 min.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The optimal number of cycles for exponential amplification was determined by kinetic analysis.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	56	 PCR products were resolved on a 4 or 6% polyacrylamide gel.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	57	 PCR products were quantitated and normalized using the Amersham Biosciences phosphorimaging system.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	58	Mad Binds to Myc Target Genes in Vivo-- To explore the binding of Mad1 protein in vivo, we took advantage of HL60 cells, which produce Mad1 protein after being induced to differentiate with Me2SO.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	59	 We analyzed the binding of Mad1 protein to a number of chromosomal Myc targets in vivo by chromatin immunoprecipitation (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	60	 We found that Mad1 protein could be efficiently cross-linked to the cad, cdk4, hsp60, mSHMT, and Id2 promoters in differentiated HL60 cells where Mad1 expression is induced, but not in the same cells before inducing differentiation where Mad1 is not expressed.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	61	 All of these genes have been shown previously to bind to Myc in several different cell types.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Nonspecific PCR amplification of DNA from the -globin gene, which does not bind to Myc, served as a negative control for normalization.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	63	 These data add to the previous demonstration that Myc and Mad1 bind to the promoters of tert and cyclinD2 in logarithmically growing and differentiated cells, respectively (16, 18).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	64	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	65	   Mad1 binds to the promoter of Myc-responsive genes.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Logarithmically growing (not expressing Mad1) or Me2SO (DMSO)-treated, differentiated HL60 cells (expressing Mad1) were cross-linked and lysed, and chromatin was immunoprecipitated with Mad1-specific antibodies followed by the reversal of the cross-linking and DNA isolation.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Isolated DNA was used in PCR with radiolabeled oligonucleotides flanking Myc binding sites in the promoter of the genes indicated on the right side.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	68	 For a negative control, PCR was carried out with oligonucleotides complementary to the third intron of the human -globin gene.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Quantitation of the PCR products was performed using the Amersham Biosciences phosphorimaging system.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Numbers below a panel indicate the fold difference in the signal intensity determined by dividing the PCR signal in the DMSO column by a corresponding signal in the Log column and by the ratio of these signals for -globin.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	71	Exchange of Myc and Mad Basic Regions-- Different antibodies are used for Myc and Mad1 chromatin immunoprecipitation; therefore, we cannot determine whether binding to cellular targets is quantitatively equal between the two proteins.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	72	 To dissect the contribution of the basic DNA recognition domain alone, we decided to test the DNA binding activity of the Myc and Mad basic regions through functional assays.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	73	 A comparison of the basic regions of the Myc and Mad/Mxi families is shown in Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Both protein families have a bipartite basic region that extends ~20-25 amino acids N-terminal to helix 1.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The only crystal structure from this gene family is of Max/Max homodimers in which the proximal basic residues are in a helical structure and have defined base contacts (8, 9).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	76	 However, phosphorylation of serine 11 in Max inhibits DNA binding activity (35), indicating that amino acids distal to the basic region can dramatically influence its function.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Both Myc and Mad/Mxi have 6 basic residues proximal to helix 1; however, the Mad/Mxi basic region extends over 19 amino acids, whereas the Myc basic region extends over only 13 amino acids.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The Myc and Mad/Mxi basic regions are both bounded by proline or glycine, which are likely positions for a domain boundary.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Given these structural considerations, we decided to test the Mad basic region function by exchanging 24 amino acids of mouse c-Myc with 21 amino acids of mouse Mad1, using an N-terminal proline as one boundary and an invariant leucine in helix 1 as the C-terminal boundary.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Within the domain exchanged, 9 out of the 25 amino acids are identical or conservative substitutions.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	81	View larger version (36K):    Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	82	   Schematic representation of wild-type Myc, Mad1, and Myc with the Mad1 basic region.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The shaded region on the Myc(Mad-BR) line represents the extended basic region of Mad that was exchanged into the c-Myc protein.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Basic residues are indicated in bold.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	85	Ectopic transient expression of WT c-Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) gave equivalent levels of protein and equivalent binding to E-box elements in electrophoretic mobility shift assay (data not shown).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	86	 To assess the ability of the two proteins to promote cell proliferation, we reconstituted Myc-null rat fibroblasts with each Myc protein and established that they were expressed at similar levels (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	87	 We then examined the cell morphology (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Both WT c-Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) fully rescued the growth defect in Myc-null fibroblasts, giving doubling times of 18 and 19 h, respectively, which is equivalent to the doubling time (18 h) of the parental cells with WT c-myc genes.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In contrast, the Myc-null fibroblasts have a doubling time of ~45 h.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	90	 We also tested the relative fraction of cells in each phase of the cell cycle by propidium iodide staining (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	91	 When compared with the pronounced accumulation of cells in G1 in the Myc-null cells (69%), both c-Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) had an equivalent reduction in G1 fraction (52 and 50%), respectively.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Cells reconstituted with c-Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) had similar increases in S phase cells (20 and 21% respectively) when compared with myc-null cells (11%).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Thus, the Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) proteins rescue the cell cycle defect in Myc-null cells to an equivalent extent.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (61K):    Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	95	   Phenotypes of wild-type Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) in cell growth and primary cell transformation.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	96	 A, expression of Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) proteins in stably reconstituted HO15.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Equal amounts of nuclear extract were immunoprecipitated (IP) with anti-FLAG antibody and probed with anti-Myc (N262; Santa Cruz Biotechnology).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	98	 B, colony size and morphology of HO15.

0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	104	View larger version (32K):    Fig.

0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Both floating and adherent cells were harvested and analyzed by flow cytometry to determine the percentage of apoptotic cells.
