0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	110	 B, quantitation of the fraction within each gate in panel A.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	111	To compare the oncogenic activity of Myc(Mad-BR) with WT c-Myc, we tested each construct for focus formation in primary rat embryo cells in cooperation with an H-ras(G12V) oncogene.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Both WT c-Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) induced equivalent numbers of foci, ~15/dish for each (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Similar results were obtained for three independent assays.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The morphology of the foci was indistinguishable between WT and the exchange mutant (data not shown).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	115	 We conclude that the Mad basic region has an equivalent biological function to that of c-Myc.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Since the proliferative and oncogenic activities of c-Myc are presumably a manifestation of the complex sets of target genes that it regulates, we infer that all of the critical functional targets recognized by the c-Myc basic domain are also recognized by the Mad basic domain.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	117	Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) Induce Equivalent Apoptosis-- As a final test of biological activity, we examined the induction of apoptosis by the Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) proteins.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The Myc-null cells were reconstituted with each protein using a long terminal repeat-driven reconstitution vector, which is sustained in expression when serum survival factors are withdrawn.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	119	 This constitutive Myc expression induces apoptosis, unlike in the parental Rat1 (thioguanine-resistant (TGR) subclone) cells where Myc is down-regulated upon serum withdrawal.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	120	 As reported previously, the Myc-null cells have no detectable apoptosis when starved in 0.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	121	1% serum for 24-48 h, whereas cells reconstituted with a constitutively expressed WT c-Myc protein exhibit a substantial amount of apoptosis (23%) as measured by the appearance of floating cells with a sub-G1 DNA content (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Notably, there was no difference in the fraction of cells that activated the apoptotic death program with WT c-Myc when compared with Myc(Mad-BR) (20%) (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Therefore, the basic region of Mad is capable of activating the same apoptotic pathway as that of the WT c-Myc protein.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	124	Myc and Mad Basic Regions Recognize Equivalent Chromosomal Targets-- The data above support a model in which the Myc and Mad basic region recognize an equivalent set of chromosomal target genes.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	125	 To address this question more directly, we analyzed the expression of several target genes in reconstituted Myc-null fibroblasts (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The expression of five different c-Myc target genes (hsp60, nm23, nucleolin, mSHMT, and cad) was analyzed by reverse transcription-PCR, and all genes exhibited equivalent induction in response to both WT c-Myc and Myc(Mad-BR).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In each case, target gene expression is stimulated by ectopic Myc expression above the level in the Myc-null cells (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	128	 gapdh levels were unchanged by ectopic Myc expression and were used as a negative control.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	129	 A much more sensitive assay for the activation of chromosomal targets by c-Myc is the activation of the tert gene in primary human fibroblasts (36).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The tert gene is tightly suppressed in primary cells and activated by ectopic Myc expression through the recruitment of TRRAP-containing chromatin modifying complexes (33).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	131	 We found that both WT c-Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) activated the endogenous tert gene to the same extent (Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	132	View larger version (60K):    Fig.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	133	   Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) bind to and activate the same cellular targets.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	134	 A, wild-type Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) regulate the same set of genes.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Quantitative PCR was performed with cDNA synthesized on total RNA isolated from cells expressing the empty vector, Myc, or Myc(Mad-BR) proteins using radiolabeled oligonucleotides specific for the rat genes shown on the right.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Quantitation of the PCR products was performed using an Amersham Biosciences phosphorimaging system.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Numbers below a panel indicate the fold induction determined by dividing an hsp60, nm23, nucleolin, mSHMT, cad, or gapdh-specific signal by a corresponding gapdh-specific signal and by the ratio of these signals in the vector lane.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	138	 B, wild-type Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) bind equivalently to the same chromosomal sites in rat fibroblasts.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	139	19 cells expressing empty vector (vector), WT c-Myc (indicated by Myc), and Myc(Mad-BR) were cross-linked and lysed, and chromatin was immunoprecipitated with c-Myc-specific (M) or Gal4-specific (G) antibodies followed by the reversal of the cross-linking and DNA isolation.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Isolated DNA was used in PCR with radiolabeled oligonucleotides flanking Myc binding sites in the promoter of the genes indicated on the right side.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	141	 For negative controls, two types of PCR were performed.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The first used oligonucleotides flanking CACGTG sites that do not interact with c-Myc in the promoter of rat glucokinase gene (GLU).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Another PCR was performed with oligonucleotides flanking a DNA region containing no CACGTG sites in the rat pcna gene.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Quantitation of the PCR products was performed by using the Amersham Biosciences phosphorimaging system.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Numbers below a panel indicate the fold difference in the signal intensity determined by dividing a given PCR signal by a corresponding pcna-specific signal and by the ratio of these signals in the Gal4 lane.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	146	In this study, we have conducted a thorough analysis of the DNA recognition properties of the Myc and Mad1 basic regions.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	147	 We conclude that there is no measurable difference in DNA site recognition in vivo between the Myc and Mad1 basic regions, and therefore, that these two domains can recognize equivalent sets of target genes.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The precise fusion proteins that we analyzed and their resulting biological activities differ significantly from two previous reports (30, 31) that addressed similar questions.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	149	 It is informative to compare and contrast each study to understand the precise contribution of the basic region to target gene selection by the Myc/Max/Mad family of proteins.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	150	Our conclusions differ most significantly from a previous study by O'Hagan et al.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (30) that attempted to create a Mxi-like basic region within Myc through the mutation of 2-4 amino acids in the Myc basic region to those found at the corresponding positions in Mxi (and Mad) proteins.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The most disruptive mutation in this study was R357S (numbered from the human c-Myc initiation methionine), which changes one of the basic amino acids in Myc into a non-basic residue.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	153	 It seems quite possible that target gene recognition by Myc is dependent on an extended set of basic amino acids within this region, and thus, this mutation debilitates Myc function.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The basic region exchange used in our study included two additional basic amino acids farther toward the N terminus.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	155	 We speculate that these amino acids provide important nonspecific DNA interactions with the phosphate backbone to increase target gene recognition in vivo.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	156	 It is also possible that other conformational aspects of the Mad1 basic region are preserved in the more extended Mad/Myc exchange.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	157	 This interpretation is supported by the partial restoration of transforming activity in the Myc(R357S/V361E) double mutant, which exchanges two positions of the Myc basic region with the corresponding residues from Mxi1 and Mad1 (30).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The indistinguishable transforming and proliferative activity of the Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) exchange mutant in our study argues that the basic regions of Myc and Mad1 can recognize the same critical target genes in vivo.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	159	Our findings also contrast a more recent report that the Myc and Mad1 B/HLH/LZ domains differ in apoptotic potential but not in proliferative activity (31).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	160	 We find that the c-Myc and Myc(Mad-BR) proteins induce indistinguishable levels of apoptosis, implying that these two proteins activate or repress the same target genes that promote apoptosis in the absence of survival factors.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The simplest explanation for the differences between the two studies is the potential contribution of the HLH/LZ domain to biological activity since our study exchanged only the extended basic region and not the entire DNA binding/Max dimerization domain.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Structural studies imply that the helix 1 and loop domains can affect DNA binding activity (37, 38), although no differences in DNA binding between WT c-Myc and the Mad bHZ exchange were found using in vitro assays (31).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Of more interest are reported differences in protein interactions with the HLH/LZ domains, where Myc can bind to Miz1 and Mad1 cannot (39).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	164	 We also note a significant difference in the ability of the previously described bHZ exchange protein to rescue the growth defect in Myc-null cells.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	165	 We find indistinguishable cell doubling times for Myc and Myc(Mad-BR), whereas the growth rate for the Myc(MadbHZ) exchange was less than for WT c-Myc (31).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Even greater differences were found in the rescue of the cell cycle defect.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	167	 In the Myc(MadbHZ) study, 48% of cells were in G1 for the Myc(MadbHZ) exchange when compared with 58% for Myc-null cells and 28-29% for both Myc reconstituted and parental Rat1 cells (31).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Similarly, the S phase fraction was 25% for Myc-null, 43% for WT c-Myc, and 37% for Myc(MadbHZ).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In contrast, we find indistinguishable profiles for G1-S-G2/M between Myc and Myc(Mad-BR), similar to the results for cell doubling time.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Thus, the Myc(MadbHZ) exchange protein only rescues part of the growth defect in Myc-null cells.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	171	 These differences between our study and the bHZ exchange study may be attributable to specific protein-protein interactions with the HLH and/or LZ domains rather than to any differences in target gene recognition.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	172	 It is also possible that the defect in apoptosis noted in the Myc(MadbHZ) mutant is coupled to the defect in cell cycle rescue.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	173	The most important question that remains unresolved is whether or not Myc and Mad/Mxi regulate the same target genes under normal developmental conditions.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Our study provides the most extensive evidence to date for the direct binding of Myc and Mad1 to the same target genes in vivo.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Since the endogenous Myc and Mad/Mxi proteins differ in antibody reactivity, it is impossible to provide an accurate quantitative assessment of the relative binding efficiency of each protein at individual targets, and it is also difficult to assess the activity of each protein once binding has occurred.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	176	 However, in the differentiating HL60 cells that we studied, Mad1 binds to all of the Myc target genes we tested under the differentiated/growth arrest conditions where Mad1 is induced.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	177	Our data support a model in which Myc/Max and Mad/Max heterodimers recognize equivalent target genes in vivo.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The primary biological difference between these complexes is their precise regulation and their recruitment of nuclear cofactors, i.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	179	 activators versus repressors (reviewed in Ref.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Mad/Mxi family proteins are mainly expressed at distinct stages of development and differentiation, almost all of which are associated with growth arrest.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	181	 An exception to this is the nearly ubiquitous expression of Mxi1 and the S phase-specific expression of Mad3.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	182	 In addition, Mxi1-deficient primary cells have a higher colony-forming ability when plated at low density, suggesting an enhanced proliferative capacity (27).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In contrast, Myc proteins are expressed in all dividing cells and repressed under virtually all growth arrest conditions.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Thus, in many cells, target genes will be down-regulated in non-dividing cells by the absence of Myc activation but not through active repression by Mad/Mxi.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Furthermore, we note that most Myc target genes are still expressed basally even in the complete absence of Myc, such as in Myc-null fibroblasts (33, 40).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	186	 This Myc-independent target gene expression is likely due to promoter elements that bind other nuclear factors, and the Myc-dependent induction of its targets is usually quite modest (3-fold) in log phase cells (33, 40).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	187	 One factor with a potential role in this system is Mnt, which is simultaneously expressed in dividing cells with Myc.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Mnt can bind the Sin3A corepressor and block Myc function (41), and Mnt/Max complexes are significantly more abundant than Myc/Max complexes in nuclear extracts (26, 42).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	189	 It is not known whether Mnt/Max heterodimers constitutively repress Myc target genes and act to down-regulate their expression when Myc is repressed.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Moreover, induction of Mad/Mxi under conditions where Myc is already down-regulated may recruit additional repressive cofactors to shut down target gene promoters below their level of basal transcription.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Yet another complication in this system is the upstream stimulatory factor (USF) transcription factor, which has been shown to bind to many Myc/Max binding sites under conditions when Myc is not expressed (43).
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Our data are consistent with a model in which all Myc target genes can be suppressed by Mad/Mxi when the latter proteins are induced in development and/or differentiation.
0.11612061.12538578.html.plaintext.txt	193	* This work was supported by grants from the NCI, National Institutes of Health (to M.

0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	0	Identification of Distinct N-terminal Truncated Forms of Prion Protein in Different Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease Subtypes* Gianluigi Zanusso, Alessia Farinazzo, Frances Prelli, Michele Fiorini, Matteo Gelati, Sergio Ferrari, Pier Giorgio Righetti , Nicol&ograve; Rizzuto, Blas Frangione, and Salvatore Monaco||.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Departments of Neurological and Visual Sciences, Section of Neurology and  Agricultural and Industrial Biotechnologies, University of Verona, 37134 Verona, Italy and the Department of Pathology, New York University Medical Center, New York, New York.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, May 17, 2004 , and in revised form, July 7, 2004.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	3	Neuropathological hallmarks of transmissible spongiform encephalopathies include spongiosis, neuronal loss, and gliosis accompanied by PrPSc deposition at synaptic locations and at the rims of vacuoles or as large extracellular amyloid plaques and plaque-like aggregates (10).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Different patterns of PrP deposition and intracerebral regional distribution of lesions are explained by the existence of prion strains with identifiable biological properties and distinctive physicochemical features of PrPSc (1).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	5	sCJD has an annual incidence of 1-1.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	6	5 per million worldwide and a still unknown etiology; prevailing hypotheses suggest that the disorder is triggered by pathogenic somatic mutations in the prion protein gene (PRNP) or by random spontaneous changes in PrPC conformation (11).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, there is concern that some sCJD cases could be secondary to environmental exposure, case-to-case transmission, or unnoticed food chain contamination, as suggested by the occurrence of atypical phenotypes, spatiotemporal disease clusters (12), and the increased incidence of the disorder recently observed in Switzerland (13).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Because of the variability in clinical presentation, signs at evolution, and neuropathological changes, the disorder with the double eponym Creutzfeldt-Jakob should be properly called syndrome rather than disease.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Different sCJD phenotypes largely correlate with the PRNP codon 129 genotype, a site of methionine or valine polymorphism, and distinct PrPSc types (14) currently classified according to the molecular mass of their PrP27-30 core fragment in turn reflect the tertiary structure of PrPSc.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	10	 However, controversial results have been obtained by different authors who have proposed the classification of sCJD PrP27-30 into two (14) and four types (15).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Two main limitations of these studies are (i) the use of a relatively crude technique of protein separation, such as SDS-PAGE, and (ii) the detection of PrP species with an antibody recognizing the N-terminal 109-112 epitope, which precludes the recognition of PrP molecules lacking this region.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	12	Here we studied 32 subjects, with definite sCJD of all genotypes at PRNP codon 129 and with different PrPSc types, to characterize C-terminal PrPSc fragments in distinct disease phenotypes and host genotypes.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Brain homogenates resolved by SDS-PAGE and two-dimensional electrophoresis were immunoblotted with anti-PrP antibodies recognizing epitopes located in the N-terminal and C-terminal regions.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Here we report the detection of novel truncated PrPSc species in association with distinct PrP27-30 types.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In addition, we provide evidence that sCJD phenotypes with PrP amyloid plaques or plaque-like deposits are associated with pathological PrP species matching the so-called C1 PrPC fragment.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	16	View this table:    TABLE I Demographic, molecular, and phenotypic features in SCJD cases.

0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	56	Effect of pH on PrP27-30 and on Truncated PrP Fragments In a previous study, we observed that one type of PrPSc, detected in the classical form of sCJD, changes its conformation after exposure to acidic and basic pH values (18).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	57	 This property, likely dependent on the presence of octapeptide repeats in the PrPSc molecule, enabled us to distinguish two PrPSc types that share an identical electrophoretic mobility after solubilization in lysis buffer at pH 7.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Following immunoblot with 3F4, the PK-resistant fragment of 21 kDa, detected in 9 MM subjects and in 1 VV case, migrated slower at pH 5 as compared with the migration observed when samples were solubilized at pH 8 (Table I).

0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	60	 To further clarify the influence of the octapeptide region in determining sensitivity to pH, brain homogenates from each single case of the group sensitive to pH were exposed to consecutive PK digestions, first to acidic and subsequently to basic pH.

0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	64	5 and 20 kDa bands differ at the N terminus and not at the C terminus.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Conversely, the electrophoretic migration of the C-terminal fragment of 16-17 kDa was unaffected by serial acidic and basic digestion procedures (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	66	 1D, lanes 1 and 2), confirming the role of the octapeptide region in conferring PrPSc susceptibility to conformational changes.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	67	Two-dimensional mapping of PrP isoforms in control and sCJD brains Recently, we provided a detailed two-dimensional mapping of PrPC glycoforms by using the 3F4 antibody, recognizing a linear epitope expressed in the full-length PrPC and in the C2 fragment (17).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	68	 When analyzing PrPC in two dimensions, the customary di-, mono-, and unglycosylated bands of the protein, obtained after SDS-PAGE, are separated in several spots according to two independent features: the isoelectric point (which reflects the net charge) and the mobility (determined by the molecular mass).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In addition, after two-dimensional separation, each spot can be assigned to glycosylated or unglycosylated species based on its shape, configuration, tail, and smear.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Although the 6H4 antibody was unable to detect PrPC molecules after two-dimensional separation of control brain homogenates, the SP-214 monoclonal antibody revealed several glycosylated and unglycosylated PrP forms with faster migrating species being detected at 18 kDa, corresponding to unglycosylated C1 isoforms (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Negative results obtained with 6H4 suggest that this antibody recognizes a conformational rather than a linear PrP epitope and that this epitope is lost after solubilization of PrP in high molar urea.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	72	 After PNGase treatment, truncated PrPC glycoforms were all reduced into several spots migrating at 20- and 18-kDa zones (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	73	 2B), corresponding to PrP fragments referred to as C2 and C1, respectively.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Differing from controls, each single homogenate of cortical areas, subcortical nuclei, and cerebellum from sCJD brains showed increased amounts of C2 (migrating at 21 kDa in cases with type 1 PrPSc and 19 kDa in those with type 2 PrPSc) and the presence of additional acidic PrP glycoforms and low molecular mass unglycosylated species.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The composition, electrophoretic migration, and relative abundance of these PrP species were different among distinct sCJD subtypes.

0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Interestingly, truncated PrP species observed in different sCJD subtypes were partially recovered in the detergent-insoluble fraction from different brain areas (Fig.

0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	94	  Two-dimensional Mapping of PK-resistant PrP Fragments in Different sCJD Subtypes A sextet of molecular sCJD subtypes has been previously recognized based on the combination of two PrP27-30 types and three possible PRNP codon 129 genotypes (14).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	95	 More recent phenotypic classifications propose six variants, which consider MM1 and MV1 cases a single subtype, whereas MM2 subjects are classified in two forms, cortical (MM2C) and thalamic (MM2T), named sporadic fatal insomnia (20).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	96	 With the exception of sporadic fatal insomnia cases (not available for the present study), all other molecular and phenotypic sCJD subtypes were investigated.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	97	 PK-treated brain homogenates from subjects with type 1 PrP27-30 of all genotypes showed, in addition to 30-, 25-, and 21-kDa glycoforms containing the 3F4 epitope (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	98	 4, A, C, and E), more acidic SP-214-positive glycoforms of 21-25 kDa and showed several spots migrating at 16-17- and 12-14-kDa zones, pI 4-5 (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Some variability was observed among individual cases in the relative intensity and representation of these spots, but their migration and configuration were highly comparable in all cases.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Additionally, slight quantitative but not qualitative differences were seen in different brain regions from each case.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	101	 After deglycosylation and PK-treatment, major glycoforms of 21-30 kDa were reduced to 21 kDa, pI 6.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	102	2, whereas lower molecular mass species were detected at 16-17- and 12-14-kDa zones, pI 4.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	103	View larger version (53K):    FIG.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Two-dimensional mapping of sCJD brain homogenates after PK treatment and deglycosylation.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	105	 PK-resistant PrP products of brain homogenates from representative sCJD subjects were resolved by two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and immunoblotted with the 3F4 antibody (A, C, E, G, I) and with SP-214 monoclonal antibody before (B, D, F, H, L) and after PNGase treatment (B', D', F', H', L').
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	106	 As shown previously (17), immunoblot with 3F4 of PK-digested frontal cortex homogenates from sCJD subjects show the presence of differently glycosylated PrP charge isomers, with unglycosylated PrP27-30 species migrating at 21 (A, C, E) or 19 kDa (G, I) in different disease phenotypes.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Immunoblot with SP-214 of PK-resistant PrP molecules shows additional unglycosylated PrP spots migrating at 16-17 and 12-14 kDa, in all sCJD subjects with type 1 PrP27-30 (B, D, F); barely detectable spots with an identical migration pattern as those associated with type 1 PrP27-30 are also seen in MM2 subjects (H).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Conversely, only small amounts of the 12-14-kDa fragments, but not the 16-17-kDa spots, are identified in MV2 and VV2 sCJD cases (L).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	109	 In all sCJD brains with type 1 PrP27-30, PNGase treatment of PK-digested frontal cortex homogenates showed a similar two-dimensional pattern with PrP species being resolved at 21-, 16-17- and 12-14-kDa zones (B', D', F').
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Again, a similar qualitative pattern of truncated PrP species, with the presence of very small amounts of the 16-17- and 12-14-kDa spots, was seen in MM2 cases (H').
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	111	 On the contrary, two-dimensional maps of PNGase-treated, PK-digested frontal cortex homogenates from MV2 and VV2 subjects disclose several spots at 18 kDa (L').
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	112	  In the MM2C group, the 3F4 antibody showed differently glycosylated forms of PrP27-30 (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	113	 4G), and barely detectable, faster migrating PrP forms were stained by SP-214 antibody in all sampled brain areas (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	114	 After deglycosylation, the 19-kDa PrPSc core fragment was associated with low amounts of PrP forms showing a migration pattern similar to that found in subjects with type 1 PrP27-30 (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	115	Finally, in the MV2 and VV2 groups, major 3F4-positive glycoforms of 29, 25, and 19 kDa (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	116	 4I) were associated with small amounts of 12-14-kDa species recognized by the SP-214 antibody (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, after glycan removal, a set of spots migrating at 17.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	118	5-18 kDa was detected in cortical and subcortical brain regions (Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Based on their pI values and apparent molecular masses, these spots matched the corresponding C1 PrPC peptides observed after deglycosylation of normal brain homogenates (see Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	120	These results indicate that in MV2 and VV2 cases, glycosylated C1 isoforms acquire PK-resistance, although the possibility that C1-sized fragments are generated upon protease treatment cannot be ruled out.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	121	 On the contrary, unglycosylated isoforms of C1 detected in both normal and pathological brain homogenates (see Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	122	 2, A and C) lack detergent insolubility (see Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	123	 3C) and PK-resistance (see Fig.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	124	 5) depicts different patterns of truncated PrP fragments found in association with distinct molecular sCJD subtypes.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	125	View larger version (11K):    FIG.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Schematic diagram of PK-resistant C-terminal PrP core fragments in sCJD subtypes.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The 16-17-kDa forms, seen in sCJD with type 1 PrP27-30 (A) and in MM2 cases (B) are represented in red, whereas 12-14-kDa species are depicted in blue.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In MV2 and VV2 groups, C1 PrPSc spots are shown in orange (C).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	129	Using sensitive protein separation techniques and Western blot with antibodies recognizing the C-terminal globular domain of prion protein, we have identified new protease-resistant PrP species in brain homogenates from sCJD subjects.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	130	 These new fragments, detected in the mass interval between 16 and 18 kDa, showed two distinct and highly reproducible electrophoretic patterns, each segregating preferentially with type 1 or type 2 PrP27-30.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The electrophoretic migration of these newly identified PK-resistant PrP products is, therefore, intermediate between the unglycosylated PrP27-30 fragment (which is currently used to classify molecular PrPSc types) and the 12-14 kDa PrP molecules observed in all sCJD subtypes and named CTF 12/13 (9).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The immunoblot detection of low molecular mass PrP fragments in untreated whole brain homogenates from sCJD subjects indicates that such fragments are generated by an endogenous proteolytic mechanism.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	133	 It should also be emphasized that the detergent insolubility of these molecules and the lack of shift in their apparent molecular weight after PK digestion support the view that these PrP species adopt a fully protease-resistant conformation in vivo.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	134	Taken together, the present findings point out that multiple abnormal PrP conformers are expressed during the spreading of sCJD strains.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	135	 This could result from diverse subcellular sites of formation or, alternatively, from the generation of PrP conformers from full-length and N-terminally truncated PrPC precursors.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Furthermore, the identification of the 16-17- and 12-14-kDa forms in subjects of all genotypes with type 1 or MM with type 2 PrPSc suggests that the mechanism involved in the formation of these forms is not influenced by codon 129 and by the type of PrP27-30.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Although the three classes of PrP fragments characterized in the present study show biochemical properties of pathological PrP, it remains to be determined if they maintain all of the biological properties of PrPSc.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	138	A further implication of the identification of 16-17-kDa forms is related to the molecular classification of PrPSc types encountered in sCJD.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The influence of several experimental conditions, including pH and EDTA concentration, on the conformation of type 1 PrPSc and, therefore, on its electrophoretic migration is well known (18, 19).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	140	 On this basis, we propose the use of conventional Western blot with 6H4 antibody, which is able to detect an accompanying fragment of 16-17 kDa in all cases with type 1 PrPSc.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Such a standardized molecular classification of sCJD would have major implications for epidemiological studies, whereas more sophisticated investigations, such as two-dimensional mapping and PrP sequencing, should be reserved for atypical cases.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	142	To date, the existence of distinct strains of the agent responsible for human prion diseases has been difficult to explain with just the biochemical findings of two main PrP27-30 conformations and with microsequencing analyses showing two truncation patterns in sporadic, inherited, and acquired diseases (21).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	143	 It is well known that glycans may play a role in the phenotypic determination of some prion conditions, and their role has been recently proposed to explain differences between sporadic fatal insomnia and MM2 sCJD, two conditions sharing PrP27-30 type and PRNP codon 129 (22).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	144	 However, different glycosylation states of PrPSc cannot fully account for prion diversity.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Recent transmission studies of sCJD to transgenic mice show three distinct incubation periods of different sCJD subtypes (23).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In particular, inocula from subjects MM1 and MV1 have the same incubation times, and, therefore, these molecular types appear as a homogeneous group.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	147	 MV2 and VV2 cases, when transmitted to mice with Val at position 129, induce the disease at the same post-inoculum intervals and thus suggesting similar biological properties of these sCJD strains.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	148	 On the other hand, MM2 inocula show heterogeneous transmission properties and incubation times different from the above groups.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	149	Based on the biochemical patterns obtained by combining the PrP27-30 core fragment and lower truncated PrP species, here we show three distinct groups of disease-associated PrP species in sCJD with type 1 PrPSc, MM2 subjects, and MV2/VV2 cases.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Strikingly, similar molecular groups of PrP species are obtained by Satoh et al.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (8) when combining truncated fragments of 11-12 kDa with type 1 and type 2 PrP27-30.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Whether the present biochemical findings represent a molecular basis for different biological properties of the above sCJD strains remains to be determined.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	153	Despite the recognition of conformational variants of disease-associated PrP species in experimental and naturally occurring prion diseases, little is known about the influence of different molecules on disease phenotype (24).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Although it is commonly believed that PrP27-30 has a major role in modulating sCJD phenotype, it would be of interest to learn whether different truncated PrPs are related to specific clinical and pathological traits.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Previous studies have disclosed that an internal PrP fragment of 7-8 kDa detected in patients with P102L Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease (7, 25) and a C-terminal fragment associated with familial Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease due to E200K mutation (26) are toxic to neurons in combination with or in the absence of PrP expression (27, 28).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Here we have found that a fully glycosylated PrP fragment, closely matching the C1 PrPC fragment, was associated with amyloid plaques in MV2 cases and plaque-like PrP deposits in VV2 subjects.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	157	 On the contrary, C1 PrPSc was not observed in sCJD subtypes lacking extracellular PrP deposition.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	158	 It is noteworthy to emphasize that we also determined2 the presence of C1 PrPSc in subjects with variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (a condition characterized by florid PrP amyloid plaques) as well as in the newly identified bovine amyloidotic spongiform encephalopathy (BASE) (3) but not in amyloid-free typical bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Earlier studies have shown that C1 is a cell surface glycophosphoinositol-anchored protein starting at amino acid 110/111 in human neuroblastoma cells (6) and present under multiple truncation forms in brain tissue (17).
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	160	 According to our findings, it is conceivable that extracellular release of C1 PrPSc could be responsible for PrP deposition and aggregation, as observed in MV2 and VV2 sCJD subtypes.
0.11677446.15247220.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Altogether, these results show that PrP-truncated fragments may influence the disease phenotype of sCJD and that their characterization is important for the molecular definition of sCJD subtypes.

0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	0	The law of mass action applied to neurodegenerative disease: a hypothesis concerning the etiology and pathogenesis of complex diseases Andrew Singleton, Amanda Myers and John Hardy*.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	1	Laboratory of Neurogenetics, National Institute on Aging, National Institutes of Health, Building 10, Room 6C103, MSC1589, Bethesda, MD 20892, USA.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received January 2, 2004; Revised February 3, 2004; Accepted February 9, 2004.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	3	These findings are well established and have driven therapeutics research, especially because they have allowed the development of animal models of these diseases as well as defined therapeutic targets (7).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	4	 In each of these examples, the precise  pathologic species  of protein is obscure, if there is one, and it is debated whether the deposits themselves, or some intermediate species such as an oligomer, are responsible.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	5	 This has been extensively investigated, with the balance of recent data favoring smaller intermediate species as the toxic entities (8); however, the generality of the fact that the mutated protein in each example can be deposited suggests that the process of pathogenicity is related to, although perhaps separable from, the process of deposition.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	6	By studying the autosomal dominant forms of these and other diseases, researchers hope to gain insight into the more common, sporadic forms, and from a mechanistic perspective, this has certainly been the case.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, perhaps more surprisingly, over this last 4 years, it has become clear that, in the case of many of these diseases at least, the haplotype of the Mendelian pathogenic locus influences the disease risk for sporadic disease.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	8	In this review, we briefly summarise these data, and then make predictions concerning the etiology and pathogenesis of these and other neurodegenerative diseases.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	9	 First, though, it is worth noting what a  haplotypic association  means from a mechanistic perspective: in the absence of coding changes, a haplotypic association implies there is genetic variability either in the amount of expression of the protein, or in the alternate splicing of the protein, and that this contributes to disease risk.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	10	Alzheimer's disease Extensive sequencing of the APP gene in late-onset Alzheimer's disease has failed to identify mutations (13).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	11	 However, analysis of data from sibpairs affected with late-onset Alzheimer's disease has consistently suggested that APP is a locus for this form of disease (14,15).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This suggests that genetic variability at the APP locus contributes to disease risk, although the precise variability has not been identified.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Such a finding is consistent with the longstanding observation that individuals with trisomy 21 inevitably develop Alzheimer pathology by their fifth decade (16); however, those few cases of Down syndrome caused by triplication of chromosome 21 distal to the APP gene do not develop Alzheimer's disease (17).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Thus, having three copies of the APP gene leads to Alzheimer pathology in the fifth decade and as yet unidentified genetic variability at the APP locus appears to contribute to disease risk.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	15	Frontal temporal dementia: tangle diseases Mutations in the tau gene cause many cases of autosomal dominant frontal temporal dementia in which there is tau pathology.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	16	 There are many sporadic diseases in which tau pathology occurs, usually as tangles, but also as Pick bodies or Argyrophilic grains (18).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	17	 There are two genetic haplotype clades in Caucasian populations, designated H1 and H2, which differ in intron sizes, promoter sequence and wobble bases (19).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The H1 haplotype has a frequency of 75% in Caucasians, and thus the H1 homozygotes constitute 60% of such populations.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	19	 However, individuals with one of the three sporadic tau diseases, progressive supranuclear palsy (19), corticobasal degeneration (20) and argyrophilic grain disease (21), although not Pick's disease (22) or Guam disease (23), show a robust association with H1 homozygosity, with a frequency of H1 homozygotes being 95%.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	20	 These data show clearly that variability in either tau expression or tau splicing variability (or both) contribute to disease risk.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In this case, it is difficult to determine whether it is control of splicing or control of expression which is the key variable because it is indeed clear that many mutations which lead to Mendelian disease do so through altering alternate splicing (2,24).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	22	Parkinson's disease/Lewy body dementia Mutations in the -synuclein gene cause autosomal dominant Parkinson's disease, and -synuclein is the primary component of Lewy bodies, the pathognomic feature of Parkinson's disease (25).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Genetic variability in the -synuclein promoter contributes to the risk of sporadic Parkinson's disease (26,27) with the  associated  promoter allele being a stronger promoter (28).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Perhaps most convincingly, triplication of the whole -synuclein locus causes autosomal dominant Parkinson's disease/Lewy body dementia with an onset age in the fourth decade (29) and duplication of the locus leads to disease in the fifth decade (30).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Thus, with Parkinson's disease, there is a clear dose relationship between synuclein expression and disease occurrence, with normal genetic variability in the promoter contributing to the risk of typical idiopathic disease and with multiplications of the locus causing Mendelian disease with an onset age determined by the precise  dose .
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Protein studies in cell lines from affected individuals in these kindreds reveal that the amount of -synuclein produced correlates with disease (A.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	27	While these findings were unexpected, perhaps they should not have been.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	28	 All chemists know the power of the law of mass action, and perhaps it should not have surprised us that it may have profound implications in determining our risks of neurodegenerative disease (36).
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Of course, one therapeutic approach in all cases, therefore, would be to aim to reduce the concentrations of the toxic proteins in the relevant tissue compartment either through decreased production, increased breakdown, or both.
0.11926218.14976159.html.plaintext.txt	30	   FOOTNOTES   * To whom correspondence should be addressed.

0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 JEM, Volume 199, Number 12, 1679-1688 This Article Abstract PDF (Full Text) Alert me when this article is cited Citation Map Services Alert me to new content in the JEM Download to citation manager Cited by other online articles Google Scholar Articles by Karlsson, M.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Articles citing this Article PubMed PubMed Citation Articles by Karlsson, M.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Allergen-responsive CD4+CD25+ Regulatory T Cells in Children who Have Outgrown Cow's Milk Allergy Malin R.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Karlsson1, Jarle Rugtveit1,2, and Per Brandtzaeg1.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	5	1 Laboratory for Immunohistochemistry and Immunopathology (LIIPAT), Institute of Pathology, Rikshospitalet University Hospital, N-0027 Oslo, Norway 2 Department of Paediatrics, Ulleva;l University Hospital, NO-0407 Oslo, Norway.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	6	Address correspondence to Malin Karlsson, Laboratory for Immunohistochemistry and Immunopathology, Institute of Pathology, Rikshospitalet, N-0027 Oslo, Norway.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Phone: 47-23071489; Fax: 47-23071511; email: malin.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	8	Key Words: human   oral tolerance   regulatory T cells   food allergy   cytokines.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	9	Abbreviations used in this paper: ss-lactoglobulin; ss-LG; PHA, phytohemagglutinin; Treg cell, regulatory T cell.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	10	Decreased robustness of mucosally induced tolerance in "westernized" populations is suggested by the recent striking rise of atopic diseases (4), and some 5 to 8% of children up to 3 yr of age now develop food allergy.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	11	 This disorder is associated with serious health consequences and may unfortunately also be the starting point for an "allergic march," i.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	12	, the development of subsequent atopic diseases in the airways.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Therefore, it is of great importance to understand the immunological mechanisms involved in break of oral tolerance against dietary antigens.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	14	Indirect evidence exists to suggest that the development of food allergy may be controlled by CD4+CD25+ Treg cells.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Patients with immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked syndrome, or X-linked autoimmunity-allergic dysregulation syndrome lack this T cell subset, and they often develop food allergic reactions and increased specific IgE antibody levels accompanied by severe eczema (5, 6).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Further support for a role of CD4+CD25+ Treg cells in mediating oral tolerance has been obtained from feeding experiments in mice (7 to 11).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Other T cell subsets possibly involved in oral tolerance, at least in animals, are Th3 cells which produce TGF-ss, Tr1 cells which produce IL-10, and TGF-ss and NK T cells (12 to 14).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	18	 However, it is not firmly established whether all these subsets represent separate cell lineages or different maturational phenotypes.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	19	A few years after the discovery of naturally occurring CD4+CD25+ Treg cells in mice, a similar T cell subset has been identified in human peripheral blood, thymus, LNs, and cord blood (15).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In mice, the CD4+CD25+ Treg cells reportedly play a role in the control of immune responses to infectious agents, transplants, and cancer as well as in graft-versus-host reactions (16 to 21), whereas in humans CD4+CD25+ Treg cells have been shown to be involved in regulating cancer immunity (22 to 24).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These human cells are typically anergic upon TCR stimulation (25), although recent studies in mice suggest that Treg cells can be expanded both in vitro and in vivo when interacting with the appropriate APC type (26).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	22	 This might explain why a constant number of CD4+CD25+ Treg cells is maintained in the circulation.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	23	Common phenotypic markers of CD4+CD25+ Treg cells are CD45RO, L-selectin (CD62L), CTLA-4 (CD152), CD25, and glucocorticoid-induced tumor necrosis factor receptor (27 to 30), although the same phenotypic profile can also be displayed by other T cell subsets.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Therefore, only functional assays can firmly identify CD4+CD25+ Treg cells.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Nevertheless, recent studies in mice and humans have demonstrated that a novel transcription-repressor protein, FOXP3, is exclusively expressed by naturally occurring and induced CD4+CD25+ Treg cells (31 to 38).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	26	Current evidence suggests that human CD4+CD25+ Treg cells employ several mechanisms to suppress immune responses, for instance, via direct cell contact or indirectly by reducing the antigen-presenting capacity of APCs (39).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In addition, at least in mice, suppressive cytokines appear to be involved in the effector function of Treg cells (40, 41).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	28	 It remains an open question whether one or more of these down-regulatory properties may be acquired by any naive CD4+ T cell in a normal peripheral immunostimulatory process.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	29	Cow's milk allergy in children is often a disease of relatively short duration, which makes it an interesting clinical model for the development of oral tolerance.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Using depletion of CD25+ cells as a read-out test for the suppressive effect that the Treg subset exerts on effector T cells, we were able to show that children who had outgrown their allergy (i.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	31	, are now tolerant against cow's milk allergens), developed a population of CD4+CD25+ T cells with regulatory function in their peripheral blood 1 wk after an in vivo milk challenge.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	32	 This subset was numerically and functionally reduced in children who remained allergic to cow's milk.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	33	 These results suggested mucosal induction of Treg cells in response to cow's milk proteins or, alternatively, that centrally generated Treg cells had become activated and expanded in children with outgrown food allergy.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	34	The original allergy diagnosis had been made at a median age of 5 mo (range 2 to 18 mo) based on the following criteria: persistent gastroenterological symptoms without, or in combination with, extraintestinal symptoms (see next paragraph) reported by the parents, followed by total disappearance of these symptoms on cow's milk-free diet for a period of at least 1 mo, and then followed by reappearance of similar symptoms by at least two open milk challenges observed by the parents (see next paragraph).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Children with a history of anaphylactic symptoms or evidence of cow's milk-specific IgE antibodies were excluded to make the test group as homogeneous as possible.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	36	The patients had demonstrated one or more of the following symptoms (number of cases in parenthesis): bloody and usually loose stools (n = 4), diarrhea (n = 8), failure to thrive (n = 5), eczema (n = 2), vomiting or regurgitation (n = 5), excessive crying (n = 5), and anemia (n = 1).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The symptoms had been observed by the parents from a median age of 3 mo (range 2 wk to 12 mo).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Where suspected, lactose intolerance was excluded by routine lactose challenge test (H2 breath test).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	39	Cow's Milk Challenge Procedure The reintroduction of cow's milk into the diet was done gradually, increasing the amount of milk or cow's milk-based formula to at least 100 ml/day during the first two days, continuing until the parents experienced unacceptable symptoms or until a routine evaluation was performed at the out-patient clinic after 1 wk.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	40	 All these clinical evaluations were performed by the same pediatrician, and 8 children (median age 24 mo, range 16 to 45 mo) were deemed to display persistently active cow's milk allergy, whereas 13 children (median age 24 mo, range 9 to 49 mo) had outgrown their allergy since they were now found to be tolerant to the milk challenge.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	41	 A blood sample was taken just before and 1 wk after the start of cow's milk reintroduction.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	42	Ethics The study was approved by the local Regional medical ethics committee (East Norway, Blindern, pb1139, Norway), and informed consent was obtained from the parents.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	43	Cell Isolation PBMCs were obtained from heparinized blood by Lymphoprep centrifugation (Nycomed Pharma).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Cells were washed and finally diluted in RPMI-1640 medium supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated pooled human serum, 1% L-glutamine, and 1% gentamycin (GIBCO BRL).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	45	Proliferation Assay PBMCs (105) were cultured in 96-well round-bottom tissue culture plates (200  microl/well) and stimulated with phytohemagglutinin (PHA; 10  microl, 100  microg/ml) or ss-lactoglobulin (ss-LG; 10  microl, 20 mg/ml) from cow's milk (L0130; Sigma-Aldrich).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Radioactive thymidine (3H-Tdr, 1 mCi/well, TRK 120; Amersham Biosciences) was added to the wells 6 d after the initiation of stimulation.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The cells were harvested 12 to 16 h later.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Incorporation of 3H-Tdr was determined in a ss-counter.

0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Briefly, 20  microl of CD25-specific beads were suspended together with 5 x 106 to 107 PBMCs and incubated for 15 min on ice, followed by two washes.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	51	 LD columns were prepared as recommended by the manufacturer and used for magnetic depletion.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The effluent PBMC samples contained  < 0.

0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	142	  To examine whether the suppressive effect of CD25+ cells was mediated via a cell contact-dependent mechanism or by soluble factors, we examined FACS -sorted T cell subsets in a transwell system.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Due to severe ethical restraints on blood sampling in children under 2 yr of age, we were unable to purify autologous APCs for antigen-specific stimulation in these experiments.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Instead, we employed anti-CD3/CD28 activation of the purified T cell subsets.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	145	 When CD25+ and CD25 to  T cells isolated from PBMCs collected 1 wk after in vivo milk challenge were cocultured, a significantly reduced proliferative activity (P  <  0.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	146	03) was observed compared with the result obtained when the two subsets were separated by the transwell membrane (Fig.

0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	159	  In addition to the cell contact-mediated effect of Treg cells, we examined production of the immunosuppressive cytokines TGF-ss (Fig.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	160	 6 B) in ss-LG to  or PHA-stimulated PBMC cultures.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	161	 We could not detect any striking differences in cytokine concentrations for samples obtained either before or after the in vivo milk challenge.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	162	 However, it was notable that PBMCs from the tolerant group tended to show increased TGF-ss production after ss-LG stimulation when we compared the levels after and before the in vivo milk challenge (P = 0.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	163	27), and a similarly increased trend associated with tolerance was observed for IL-10 before the challenge when the two groups were compared (P = 0.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Interestingly, the TGF-ss response was significantly decreased after challenge in the allergic group (P  <  0.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	165	03), although it tended to be higher than in the tolerant group before challenge (P = 0.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Such trends for cytokine changes were not apparent when PHA was used to stimulate PBMCs (Fig.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	167	View larger version (24K):    Figure 6.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Generation of the immunosuppressive cytokines TGF-ss1-LAP and IL-10 by PBMCs purified from blood of allergic or tolerant children before and 1 wk after in vivo challenge with cow's milk.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	169	 (A) Production of TGF-ss1-LAP determined in supernatants from PBMCs stimulated for 96 h with ss-LG (1 mg/ml) or PHA (50  microg/ml) by subtracting the TGF-ss1-LAP concentration in unstimulated wells.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	170	 (B) Production of IL-10 under the same culture conditions as in A.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Student's t test was used for statistical analysis.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	172	Our study compared phenotypic and functional characteristics of PBMCs from children with clinically active or outgrown cow's milk allergy collected before and 1wk after an in vivo challenge with cow's milk.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	173	 PBMCs from the tolerant group showed reduced proliferation induced in vitro by the major milk allergen ss-LG.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Furthermore, the same children had a CD25+ T cell subset within their PBMCs that was able to suppress such proliferation.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	175	 In this group, 30% of CD4+CD25+ T cells expressed the maturation marker CD45RO both before and after challenge with cow's milk, whereas the corresponding figure was only some 5% in the group with active allergy.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	176	 All children included in our study had negative skin prick test against cow's milk proteins and no elevated specific IgE antibody levels in serum.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	177	 This suggested that the observed symptoms were most probably produced via cell-mediated immunity.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Approximately 50% of children suffering from food allergy appear by standard diagnostic tests to have a non-IgE to mediated allergic reaction (43, 44), presumably delayed-type hypersensitivity, although the pathological process in the gut may be indistinguishable from an atopic disorder (45).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	179	 We selected our patients to be homogeneously nonatopic, but it would certainly be of interest in the future to also study children with elevated IgE antibody levels against food allergens in a similar experimental set-up.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	180	Such studies in young children (with repeated sampling) have profound ethical restrictions.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Therefore, we had to design our in vitro experiments on the basis of the limited blood volumes available.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	182	 We also had to take into account that with the large age range of the patients (6 to 56 mo), they had a highly variable immunological history in terms of exposure to antigens from vaccines and the environment.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	183	 This related not only to their systemic but also to their mucosal immune system.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Importantly, we investigated tolerance induction via the gut, and recent animal experiments have demonstrated that the systemic and local immunization routes provide different results when it comes to dampening of mucosal allergy (46).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	185	 In view of this complex scenario, we decided that PHA stimulation, rather than an arbitrarily selected T cell to dependent antigen, would best ensure a consistent base-line response as a reference for the mucosal induction of Treg cells by cow's milk proteins.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	186	The in vitro proliferative activity of PBMCs against ss-LG was presumably a T cell recall response.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Notably, however, there was no significant difference when we compared PBMCs collected from the two groups of children before the in vivo cow's milk challenge with regard to proliferation elicited by ss-LG, frequency of CD4+CD25+ T cells, and a suppressive effect of CD25+ cells revealed by their depletion.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	188	 This result probably reflected that the patients with active allergy at this time point did not have a substantially larger number of circulating memory T cells specific for ss-LG than tolerant children.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The avoidance of cow's milk proteins for at least 2 mo before the challenge might have reduced this number, and specific T cells activated in GALT and mesenteric LNs would presumably start homing back to the intestinal lamina propria during milk challenge.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Thus, there was a reduced relative frequency of circulating CD4+CD25+ T cells in most allergic children after the challenge (Fig.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	191	It is of note that the ss-LG preparations contained LPS comparable to an endotoxin activity of 5000 EU/ml at 5 mg/ml (Limulus Amebocyte Lysate test); but the polyclonal immunostimulation exerted by this contamination did not mask the antigen-specific T cell response elicited by ss-LG in vitro (unpublished data).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Interestingly, the proliferative response of PBMCs against ss-LG was significantly decreased in milk-tolerant compared with allergic children after the in vivo milk challenge.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Our findings therefore suggested that in the tolerant children this challenge had resulted in GALT activation and expansion not only of specific effector T cells but also of CD4+CD25+ Treg cells, which suppressed the in vitro proliferative response elicited by ss-LG.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The observed relative increase of this circulating subset in half of the tolerant children 1 wk after challenge (Fig.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	195	 1 B) was probably an underestimate due to homing of allergen-activated T cells to the milk protein to exposed gut lamina propria as alluded to above.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	196	Although it was originally believed that CD4+CD25+ Treg cells are anergic, at least two independent reports recently showed that mouse CD4+CD25+ T cells initially multiply in vivo after appropriate antigen stimulation (26, 47).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	197	 We cannot exclude that the increased frequency of circulating CD4+CD25+ T cells after challenge in tolerant children partly reflected expansion of ordinary memory to effector T cells, but the striking increase (fivefold) of proliferative activity against ss-LG exhibited by PBMCs from these children after depletion of CD25+ cells strongly suggested that their CD4+CD25+ subset contained a substantial fraction of Treg cells.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	198	 This homeostatic mechanism most likely explained that they had outgrown their cow's milk allergy.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	199	 For ethical reasons we could not obtain blood at a later time point after the milk challenge, so we have no information with regard to the persistence of the elevated level of CD4+CD25+ T cells in the circulation of the tolerant children.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	200	Expression of integrin 4ss7 and CCR9 on T cells determines their homing into the small intestinal lamina propria (48).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	201	 We analyzed the frequency of T cells with these markers, but there were no apparent differences between the two groups of children.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	202	 It has been reported that the 4ss7 subset is increased in peripheral blood from children with cow's milk allergy, but that finding was obtained with T cells kept in culture for 1 wk (49).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Also, it might be unrealistic to expect that we should be able to identify a phenotypic change induced by milk proteins in the total circulating pool of T cells with gut-homing properties.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	204	Most functional studies of Treg cells have been performed in animal models for autoimmunity, inflammatory bowel disease, and transplantation.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The first human studies of CD4+CD25+ Treg cells were in fact published quite recently (39, 50 to 52).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Evidence suggests that Treg cells may be antigen nonspecific, at least in the effector phase, and bystander suppression is a well-known phenomenon in oral tolerance (53, 54).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	207	 A nonspecific effect of Treg cells could explain why we obtained a moderate enhancement of proliferation against PHA in PBMCs from tolerant children after depletion of CD25+ cells (Fig.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Altogether, our results implied that mucosally induced Treg cells responding to milk antigens were involved in the observed tolerance induction or, alternatively, that centrally generated Treg cells had become activated and expanded in the children with outgrown cow's milk allergy.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	209	Expression of CTLA-4 has been associated with human CD4+CD25+ Treg cells (55).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	210	 This molecule is constitutively expressed in the cytoplasm (27, 39), but once the cell is activated via the TcR complex it appears on the surface.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	211	 However, the mechanistic role of surface CTLA-4 in cell contact to dependent suppression in humans is debated.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Several studies show that blocking CTLA-4 with antibodies does not abolish the suppressive activity of Treg cells (39, 51, 52).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	213	 We did not find any difference in the expression level of this surface marker, either between the two groups of children or the two time points for sampling of PBMCs.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Nevertheless, transwell experiments demonstrated that CD4+CD25+ Treg cells from milk-tolerant children exert their antiproliferative effect via a contact-dependent mechanism.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Regrettably, we had no possibility to study the involvement of other inhibitory molecules such as PD-1 (39, 56).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	216	The role in oral tolerance of the immunosuppressive cytokine TGF-ss derived from so-called regulatory Th3 cells induced in experimental animals is extensively documented (57).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The reduced production of TGF-ss by ss-LG to stimulated PBMCs after the in vivo milk challenge in the allergic group (Fig.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	218	 6 A) is in line with a recent study by Perez-Machado et al.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	219	 (58) which shows that T cells obtained from duodenal mucosa of food-allergic children had a decreased potential for TGF-ss production compared with healthy controls.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Conversely, we found that PBMCs stimulated by ss-LG 1 wk after the in vivo challenge tended to show increased production of TGF-ss in children with outgrown allergy, which could have contributed to the observed suppressive effect on proliferation.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The major source for IL-10 production in ss-LG to stimulated PBMC cultures in our experiments remains unknown, and the results obtained were inconclusive.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	222	It has been shown in mouse models that the thymic epithelium is important in the generation of naturally occurring CD4+CD25+ Treg cells involved in the maintenance of tolerance (59).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Because our study strongly suggests that CD4+CD25+ Treg cells reactive to dietary antigens can be induced via the gut, it will be of considerable interest to investigate whether exosomes released from the intestinal epithelium play a role in the development of such cells.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	224	 We have previously obtained results indicative of a tolerance-inductive function of epithelial exosomes produced in the gut of experimental animals and therefore called these structures "tolerosomes" (60).
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	225	In conclusion, the observations presented here provide new insight into the possible relationship between mucosal induction of CD4+CD25+ Treg cells and protection against food allergy in humans.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	226	 These results may aid the development of better diagnostic tools for such disorders and perhaps contribute to promote a future goal of generating Treg cells in vitro for immunotherapy of allergic diseases.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	227	   Acknowledgments   We thank Helena Kahu for her outstanding technical assistance and for creating a stimulating working atmosphere.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Lazarovits are acknowledged for providing anti-CCR9 and anti-4ss7 mAb, respectively.
0.12080864.15197226.html.plaintext.txt	229	This work was supported by grants from the Norwegian Foundation for Health and Rehabilitation, the Norwegian Asthma and Allergy Association, the University of Oslo, the Research Council of Norway, and the Norwegian Cancer Society.

0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	0	Characterization of two distinct prion strains derived from bovine spongiform encephalopathy transmissions to inbred mice Sarah E.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Linehan, Melanie Desbruslais, Susan Joiner, Jennifer Buckell, Sebastian Brandner, Jonathan D.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	2	MRC Prion Unit and Department of Neurodegenerative Disease, Institute of Neurology, University College, London WC1N 3BG, UK.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	3	Multiple prion strains have been described that are distinguished by their incubation periods and patterns of neuropathology when passaged in inbred lines of mice, and these distinctive phenotypes are preserved on multiple passage in the same host (for review, see Bruce et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The existence of prion strains challenges the protein-only hypothesis of prion propagation.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	5	 However, it is clear that prion strains are associated with biochemical differences in PrPSc itself including differences in conformation (Hill et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	6	, 1997, 2003; Bessen  and  Marsh, 1992, 1994; Collinge et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	7	, 1999), glycosylation (Hill et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	8	, 1996) and overall protease resistance (Kuczius  and  Groschup, 1999).
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	9	 That these strain-associated biochemical differences in PrPSc fragment sizes and glycoform ratios following proteolysis can be transmitted to PrP in an experimental host argues that they may be responsible for encoding strain diversity.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	10	 While the precise nature of the molecular basis of prion strain diversity is unclear, that prion strains may be distinguished by the differing molecular mass of fragments following partial proteinase K digestion and by differing ratios of di-, mono- and unglycosylated PrPSc is clear.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Using this approach, we described four common PrPSc types in humans (Collinge et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	12	 PrPSc types 1 to 3 are seen in sporadic and iatrogenic CJD, while type 4 PrPSc is exclusively associated with variant CJD (vCJD) and is associated with a di-glycosylated-dominant PrPSc pattern on a Western blot (Collinge et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	13	 This characteristic glycoform ratio is also seen in BSE-infected cattle brain and these observations, together with bioassay data from wild-type and transgenic mice and non-human primates, have proved critical in establishing a link between BSE and vCJD (Hill et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	14	 This characteristic molecular signature of BSE-derived prion isolates is seen in all UK cattle BSE cases examined and, together with biological strain typing studies in inbred and transgenic mice, suggests that BSE is caused by a single strain of agent (Hill et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	15	, 1996; Kuczius  and  Groschup, 1999; and our unpublished data).
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	16	 This molecular pattern, in additional to biological characteristics, is also maintained on transmission to other hosts such as domestic cat, sheep, macaque and other exotic animals, either by natural exposure or by experimental transmission (Bruce et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Recent data from French and Italian screening programmes suggest that more than one strain of BSE may exist in cattle (Biacabe et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	18	 We have also shown that on BSE transmission to a line of transgenic mice expressing only human PrP Met-129, Tg(HuPrP129M+/+Prnp0/0)-35, two distinct molecular phenotypes can be produced: one that mirrors the vCJD phenotype with type 4 PrPSc and an additional molecular phenotype that is indistinguishable from that of sporadic CJD with PrPSc type 2 (Asante et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	19	 These transgenic mice were generated on a mixed genetic background, and one possibility was that the different patterns were determined by background effects in individual mice (Asante et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	20	 This interpretation was supported by the demonstration that vCJD and BSE prions on primary passage to a series of inbred lines of mice were also able to produce two distinct molecular phenotypes on Western blotting, dependent only on the genetic background of the mice (Asante et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These data argued that two distinct strains had been propagated from cattle BSE.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	22	 However, since the parameters that distinguish prion strains (incubation time, neuropathology and PrPSc type) are also known to be modulated by host genetic background, these cannot be adequately compared after primary passage in different lines of inbred mice (Bruce, 1993; Moore et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	23	 We therefore subpassaged these mouse-adapted BSE prions in the same inbred mouse line to determine whether distinctive biological characteristics resulted, indicative of different strains, and whether these correlated with the different PrPSc types propagated in the animals.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	24	For second passage to SJL mice, a single brain from a terminally sick mouse from the primary passage to SJL group (I783) was used to produce inoculum I1590 [cattle BSE (I783)SJL mice (I1590)SJL mice].
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	25	 For second passage to C57BL/6 mice, a single brain from a subclinically infected mouse from the primary passage to C57BL/6 group (I038) was used to produce inoculum I656 [cattle BSE (I038)C57BL/6 mice (I656)C57BL/6 mice].
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	26	For third passage, the SJL-passaged inoculum was generated from a single mouse brain from the SJL second passage group (I1891) and was used to inoculate a group of SJL mice [cattle BSE (I783)SJL (I1590)SJL (I1891)SJL mice].

0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	64	  To determine whether the two different PrPSc types corresponded to distinguishable prion strains, we completed additional passages so that they could be compared on the same host genetic background.
