0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	68	Third passage of BSE to SJL and C57BL/6 mice All third passages were carried out in SJL mice and were therefore appropriate for comparison of all criteria of prion strains: incubation time, PrPSc type and neuropathology.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The incubation time on third passage was reduced for both the SJL- and C57BL/6-derived BSE, suggesting further adaptation to mouse (Table 1).
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The incubation times of 110 plus or minus 3 days for SJL-derived BSE and 155 plus or minus 1 days for C57BL/6-derived BSE were highly significantly different (P < 0 0001, Mann to Whitney test).
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	71	 As inoculation was intracerebral with brain homogenate from terminally affected animals, there should be no titre effects, also evidenced by the remarkably consistent incubation periods, and there are no genetic background effects since all transmissions were to inbred SJL mice.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	72	 These data are therefore consistent with propagation of two distinct prion strains in these SJL mice.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	73	Brains from each of these groups were examined by Western blotting.

0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	103	SJL mice were able to support both the MRC1 and MRC2 strain patterns.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	104	 However, it will be important to establish whether these strains are stable on further passage in SJL and other strains of mice.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Both C57BL/6 and SJL mice share the same PrP amino acid sequence and therefore the strain selection must be a feature of other genetic loci.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Within the limits of resolution available from Western blotting, the fragment sizes following proteinase K digestion were the same for the PrPSc associated with both strains, raising the possibility that the differences related to glycosylation and not to gross conformational differences, at least as differentiated by proteinase K digestion.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Additional studies will be required to characterize precisely the conformation and physico-chemical properties of PrPSc associated with these prion strains.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	108	Although recent reports suggest that alternative strains of BSE can be found in cattle, previous studies have suggested that BSE is caused by a single strain of agent (Bruce et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	109	 301V and 301C represent previously reported independent BSE strains; however, these were propagated in different strains of mice, which not only had very different genetic backgrounds (VM/Dk and C57) but also had two amino acid coding differences in PrP and therefore their  strain  characteristics cannot be directly compared.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	110	 It is possible that MRC2 represents the same strain as 301C; however, formal comparisons will be required to investigate this.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	111	The strain characteristics associated with MRC1 resemble those seen with passage of Chandler/RML scrapie in these strains of mice with respect to incubation time (122 plus or minus 1 days), histology and PrPSc type on Western blotting (unpublished data).
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	112	 We are confident that our findings are not the result of contamination with mouse scrapie as these transmissions were performed in accordance with rigorous biosafety protocols for preparation of inocula, inoculations and care of mice.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Disposable equipment was used for each inoculum and each mouse was identified with a unique transponder.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In addition, the MRC1 strain was also seen on primary passage to RIIIS mice and also on primary passage of vCJD to SJL mice (Asante et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	115	 vCJD is caused by a BSE-like prion strain (Hill et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	116	, 1996); therefore, it is not surprising that the same phenomenon is seen with both vCJD and BSE prions in the same strains of mice.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Further transmission studies are under way to characterize these vCJD-derived mouse strains.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	118	 A similar bifurcation of the BSE strain characteristics was also observed with independent BSE inocula in transgenic mice expressing human PrP with methionine at codon 129, Tg(HuPrP129M+/+Prnp0/0)-35 (Asante et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	119	MRC2 and MRC1 were derived from different sources of BSE prions, I038 and I783, respectively.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	120	 I038 originated from a pool of five infected cow brainstems.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	121	 However, our extensive transmission studies with these isolates excluded the pooling of material from five cows as the source of the strain variation that we observe in these transmissions.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	122	 I038 gave the  classical  BSE signature and the novel phenotype was derived from I783, which originated from a single cow brain.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	123	 I783 has been used for transmissions in several inbred lines of mice in our laboratory and consistently produces the MRC2 strain (as determined by Western blotting) in C57BL/6JOlaHsd, FVB/NHsd, NZW/OlaHsd, SM/J and SWR/OlaHsd mice.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	124	 However, it also consistently produces the MRC1 strain (as determined by Western blotting) in SJL/OlaHsd and RIIIS/J mice (Fig.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	125	 DNA sequence analysis of the bovine Prnp gene in I783 confirmed that the animal was homozygous for PrP amino acids, thereby excluding PrP heterozygosity as the source of the strain bifurcation.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	126	 I038 and other independent BSE inocula have also been shown to produce two  strains' in Tg(HuPrP129M+/+Prnp0/0)-35 transgenic mice, which are on a mixed genetic background.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	127	 We therefore believe that the prion strain selection or  mutation  is a feature of the genetic background of the mice and studies are under way to identify the genes involved.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Although recent data suggest that more than one strain of BSE may exist in cattle (Biacabe et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	129	, 2004), in this study, both I038 and I783 appeared to be the same single strain.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	130	 However, Western blotting was unable to determine whether a mixed population of strains already existed in either of these brains or whether the alternative strains were generated de novo in the mice.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The inbred lines studied to date represent only a small proportion of the allelic variation that exists in the mouse genome; therefore, the study of other strains of mice, particularly those derived from unrelated strains such as trapped wild mice, may reveal additional BSE-derived strains.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	132	The human population exposed to BSE has a much more diverse genetic background than can be observed using laboratory strains of inbred mice.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Therefore, it is possible that BSE infection may be revealed not only as the type 4 PrPSc and associated vCJD clinicopathological phenotype seen to date (Collinge et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	134	, 2003), but in future, may also present with alternative PrPSc types, incubation times and neuropathology that may not be distinguishable from sporadic CJD (Hill et al.
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	135	, 2002) or represent additional novel phenotypes (Collinge, 1999).
0.12289999.15269389.html.plaintext.txt	136	 BSE may also have infected sheep flocks in the UK and, given the genetic diversity of sheep breeds, it is also possible that in some breeds BSE propagates as a strain type that is indistinguishable from natural sheep scrapie.

0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	1	Can you recollect your teenage years? Disraeli said that "The blunders of youth are preferable to the triumphs of manhood or the success of old age", and perhaps he was right; that unconquerable sense of optimism, that seeming immortality, that sometime faltering sense of self.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Annals of Oncology is 15 years old this year.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	3	 This may seem a minor achievement when compared with the 340 years of Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, but I know it is a cause of some satisfaction, if not some surprise, to those present at its birth.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	4	 We need not speak overmuch of the conception, which legend has it occurred in a bar; I wasn't there.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Credit is due to Franco Cavalli and those who worked with him to make that barroom banter into a reality and in the space of 10 years made Annals what it is one of the world's leading clinical oncology journals.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	6	It may be worthwhile to remind ourselves how recent 1990 is and how far Annals has come in those 15 years.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	7	 1990 began with George Bush Sr in the White House, Margaret Thatcher in 10 Downing Street and Nelson Mandela in prison.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In Berlin, the Wall began to be taken down and thousands stormed the Stasi's HQ.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In Britain, thousands rioted against the poll tax, and a government minister fed his daughter a beefburger on television to counter rumours of mad cow disease.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In August Iraq invaded Kuwait, precipitating the Gulf War.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In November a computer scientist working at the CERN laboratory in Geneva published a paper describing something he called the World Wide Web.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	12	The contribution of Annals of Oncology to these world events was exactly nil.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	13	 To suggest otherwise would be hubristic nonsense.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	14	 But within clinical oncology Annals has made, and is making, a difference.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Let me give you some numbers: in 1990 Annals of Oncology received 252 manuscripts; last year that figure was nearly 1000.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In 1990 Annals published barely 450 pages; last year that figure was over 1800.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In the last 5 years alone the impact factor of the journal has gone up some 26%, with last year's increase, to 3.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	18	605, the biggest single-year increase on record.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Subscriptions to the journal have grown dramatically, paralleling the growth of ESMO, and with the advent of the online journal (http://annonc.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	20	org) institutional access to the journal has increased from a few hundred paper subscribers to several thousand online.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Last year the Annals web site served over 700 000 full text articles to readers all over the world, including those in not-for-profit institutions in over 120 developing or middle-income countries, who are now able to apply for free or receive greatly discounted online access to the journal through initiatives operated by Oxford University Press (OUP), the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the International Network for the Availability of Scientific Publications.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	22	This year Annals, with the full support of both ESMO and OUP, will move to a copyright licence system that will allow authors to retain copyright of their published articles.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	23	 All concerned agree that this is fair and right, and it will, I believe make a further contribution to expanding access to Annals.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In parallel with this development we will be making changes to the journal's website.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Operation of the website will remain in the inestimable hands of Stanford University's HighWire Press, but we again hope to tweak things to improve the experience and expand access.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Significant among these tweaks will be the move to advance access publication, or publication ahead of print (charmingly shorthanded to PAP by the cognoscenti).
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	27	 This will involve an accepted article being published on the journal's website as soon as a finalised, corrected proof becomes available, irrespective of the paper issue to which it has been assigned.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In this way we hope to be able to bring important articles to Annals readers some 4 to 8 weeks ahead of print publication (see http://annonc.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	29	I hope it is clear from all this that I place the support of authors, editors and referees at the heart of the Journal.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Last year we again awarded the Annals of Oncology prizes [1] and, as predicted [2], it proved to be a worthwhile experience, thanks to the support of authors who chose Annals as the place they wanted to publish their research.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The breadth and diversity of the science submitted to Annals never ceases to astonish me, from significant phase III randomised trials [3, 4] to early clinical [5] and preclinical [6] studies, from analyses of websites for complementary medicine [7] to important epidemiologic analyses [8].
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Similarly, I am able to look at the many invited editorials (e.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	33	 [11, 12]) that have recently been published in Annals with considerable satisfaction.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	34	So there you have it: Annals of Oncology big hearted, clever and still trying hard to fulfill its potential at 15 years old.
0.1233631.15598926.html.plaintext.txt	35	 And hopefully, still with enough honesty and humility to recognize it is in no small part the work of others that has made it what it is.

0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	0	Primary Cultured Neurons Devoid of Cellular Prion Display Lower Responsiveness to Staurosporine through the Control of p53 at Both Transcriptional and Post-transcriptional Levels* Erwan Paitel, Claire Sunyach, Cristine Alves da Costa, Jean-Christophe Bourdon , Bruno Vincent, and Frederic Checler||.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Institut de Pharmacologie Moleculaire et Cellulaire du CNRS, UMR6097, 06560 Valbonne, France and  Ninewells Hospital and Medical School, Dundee DD1 9SY, Scotland, United Kingdom.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, September 22, 2003.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	3	Some clues to further understand PrP-related pathologies might come from a better knowledge of PrPc physiology and putative dysfunctions responsible for the disease.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	4	 In this respect, an interesting discussion revolving around cell death is ongoing, opening a new field of investigation.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	5	 It is clear that apoptosis accompanies the late stages of the disease.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Following that idea, several groups have set out to investigate the putative role of PrPc in the control of cell death.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	7	 From a theoretical point of view, PrP could be antiapoptotic, and the disease could result in the abolition of this function.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Alternatively, PrPc-related pathologies could be due to the exacerbation of a proapoptotic physiological phenotype associated with PrPc.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Studies carried out on distinct cell types, with various methodologies and approaches, have led to somewhat opposite conclusions (8-12).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Our previous studies have shown that overexpression of PrPc in human embryonic kidney cells (HEK293) and TSM1 neurons as well as in an inducible cell line (Rov9) leads to increased susceptibility to apoptotic stimuli, reflected mainly by enhanced caspase-3 activity (13, 14).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	11	 We further demonstrated that in TSM1 neurons, PrPc-induced caspase-3 activation is associated with an up-regulation of p53 expression and transcriptional activity (14).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This appears to be due to Mdm2-related post-transcriptional modification of p53 (14).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	13	In the present study, we first establish that in HEK293, PrPc-related increased cell death is fully dependent on p53 activity.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Moreover, we demonstrate that p53 deletion in fibroblasts fully abolishes both PrPc-induced caspase-3 and p53 transcriptional activities.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	15	 We also show that in addition to our previously described post-transcriptional control of p53 (14), PrPc also enhances the transactivation of the p53 promoter.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	16	Because our TSM1 neurons stably overexpressed PrPc, it was also important to confirm the p53-dependent function of endogenous PrPc.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	17	 We therefore examined the physiological contribution of cellular PrPc to the control of neuronal cell death by comparing primary cultured neurons derived from mice harboring (Prnp+/+) or devoid (Prnp-/-, Zrch-1 mice (15)) of endogenous PrPc.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	18	 We show that neurons derived from Zrch-1 mice embryos are less sensitive to staurosporine and display lower DNA fragmentation, caspase-3 and p53 activities and expression, and higher Mdm2-like immunoreactivity.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	19	 We demonstrate that endogenous PrPc controls neuronal cell death via Mdm2-regulated p53-dependent caspase-3 activation in non-immortalized neurons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	20	Western Blot Analyses Cells were scraped and homogenized in lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	21	5, 150 mM NaCl, 5 mM EDTA containing 0.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Equal amounts of protein (50  microg) determined by the Bradford method (19) were separated on 12% SDS-PAGE and analyzed for their p53, active caspase-3, Mdm2, phospho-P38, and PrPc immunoreactivities by Western blot and hybridization with anti-p53 (mouse monoclonal Pab24, Santa Cruz Biotechnologies), anti-active caspase-3 (rabbit polyclonal, R and D Systems), mouse monoclonal anti-Mdm2 (20), anti-phospho-P38 (Promega), and anti-PrPc (SAF32 (21)), respectively.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	23	Flow Cytometry and TUNEL Analysis Cells were grown in 6-well plates and incubated for 15 h at 37  degrees C in the presence or absence of staurosporine (0.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	24	5  microM, Sigma) and then rinsed with PBS and suspended with 750  microl of buffer (Tris 20 mM, tri-natrium citrate 0.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	25	05%) containing 50  microg/ml propidium iodide.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Cells were left overnight at 4  degrees C, and then the propidium iodide fluorescence of individual nuclei was measured as described previously (14).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	27	 For DNA nick-end labeling, cells were fixed for 20 min in 1% paraformaldehyde in phosphate-buffered saline, rinsed in phosphate-buffered saline, left overnight in 70% ethanol, and then processed for the dUTP nick-end labeling TUNEL technique according to manufacturer's recommendations (kit from Roche Applied Science).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Staining was assessed with a peroxidase-conjugated antibody and revealed with a diaminobenzidine substrate.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	29	Caspase-3-like Activity Assay Cells were cultured in 6-well plates for 15 h at 37  degrees C in the absence or presence of staurosporine (0.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	30	5  microM) (in some cases, cells were preincubated for 24 h with Ac-DEVD-al (100  microM)).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Cells were then rinsed, gently scraped, pelleted by centrifugation, resuspended in 40  microl of lysis buffer, and analyzed as detailed previously (22).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	32	p53 Transcriptional Activity and Its Promoter Transactivation One  microg of PG13-luciferase, a p53 gene reporter construct described previously (23), was co-transfected with 1  microg of a -galactosidase coding vector (to normalize transfections efficiencies) in 3F4-PrPc HEK293 cells, PrP+/+, or PrP-/- primary cultured neurons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Forty-eight hours after transfection, luciferase and -galactosidase activities were measured according to previously described procedures (23).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Mouse p53 promoter was cloned as described (24) except that the same p53 promoter region was cloned upstream of luciferase instead of chloramphenicol acetyltransferase.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The same construct lacking the p53 sequence was used as control.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	36	Statistical Analysis Statistical analysis was performed with Prism software (Graphpad Software, San Diego, CA) using the Newman-Keuls multiple comparison test for one-way analysis of variance and the unpaired Student's t test for pairwise comparisons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	37	View larger version (17K):    FIG.

0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	39	 A, mock- and 3F4-PrPc-transfected HEK293 cells were treated for 16 h with 2  microM staurosporine in the absence (CT, control) or presence of 1  microM pifithrin- (PFT) or its inactive precursor analog (PC), and then caspase-3 activity was measured as described under "Materials and Methods.

0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	42	 B, under identical treatment conditions, pifithrin- fully abolishes p53 transcriptional activity measured as described under "Materials and Methods.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	43	  We previously documented the fact that PrPc increases p38-like immunoreactivity and controls Mdm2-dependent p53 metabolic stability in TSM1 cells (14).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Here we show that besides this post-transcriptional effect, PrPc also exerts transcriptional control of p53.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Thus, 3F4-HEK293 cells display a significantly higher p53 promoter transactivation than mock-transfected cells as indicated by the luciferase reporter activity (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	46	View larger version (14K):    FIG.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	47	 PrPc expression increases p53 promoter transactivation.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Transactivation of the p53 promoter was measured as described under "Materials and Methods" in mock-transfected or 3F4-PrPc-expressing HEK293 cells.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Bars are the means  plus or minus  S.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	50	 of luciferase activities (to which control luciferase activity was subtracted) measured in 12 independent determinations.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	51	  We have previously established a link between p53 and the PrPc-induced phenotype using fibroblasts in which the p53 gene harbors a loss-of-function mutation.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	52	 To confirm this finding and preclude the possibility of a refolding/restoration of p53 activity after the chaperoning of mutated p53 (25), we have now switched to a fibroblastic cell line in which p53 has been invalidated and examined the phenotype triggered by overexpression of PrPc.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	53	 In the absence of p53, there is an important staurosporine-induced caspase-3 activation (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Interestingly, this p53-independent caspase activity was not enhanced by PrPc (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	55	 3B), whereas the combination of PrPc expression and p53 complementation led to an additional increase of caspase-3 activity (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Finally, the co-transfection of PrPc with p53 cDNA drastically potentiated the p53 transcriptional activity exhibited by p53 cDNA transfection alone (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Altogether, these data, combined with those observed after pifithrin- inhibition, clearly indicate that the PrPc proapoptotic phenotype is completely dependent on p53 and that the latter is controlled by PrPc at both the transcriptional (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	58	 2) and post-transcriptional (14) levels in human and neuronal cells.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	59	View larger version (18K):    FIG.

0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	64	  PrP-/- Primary Cultured Neurons Display Lower Susceptibility to Staurosporine Our previous statements above were based on several cell lines overexpressing PrPc.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	65	 It was therefore important to assess the contribution of endogenous PrPc.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	66	 We thus measured the staurosporine susceptibility of primary cultured neurons from Zrch-1 mice embryos in which the Prnp gene had been disrupted (15).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	67	 As expected, these neurons do not display any PrPc-like immunoreactivity (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	68	 That PrP-/- neurons exhibit lower staurosporine-induced responses is evidenced by both TUNEL (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	69	 4, B and C) and DNA fragmentation (Table I) analyses.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Clearly, the staurosporine-induced increase in the number of apoptotic nuclei observed in PrP+/+ neurons is drastically lowered in neurons devoid of PrPc (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	71	 This lower staurosporine susceptibility exhibited by PrP-/- primary cultured neurons is accompanied by lowered caspase-3-like immunoreactivity (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	72	 It is noteworthy that the effect of staurosporine is dose-dependent in both PrP+/+ and PrP-/- cells, as was another apoptotic effector, ceramide C2 (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	73	 However, the effect triggered by both pharmacological agents always remains lower in PrP-/- neurons than in PrP+/+ neurons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	74	View larger version (62K):    FIG.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	75	 TUNEL-positive neurons are lower in PrP-/- than in wild-type primary cultured neurons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	76	 A, endogenous PrPc-like immunoreactivity was visualized in PrP+/+ and PrP-/- neurons as described under "Materials and Methods.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	77	" In B, TUNEL labeling was measured in the absence (-) or presence (+) of staurosporine in the indicated neurons.

0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	90	  PrPc Complementation Partially Restores Staurosporine-induced Caspase-3 Activation in PrP-/- Primary Cultured Neurons Transient transfection of PrP+/+ neurons with 3F4MoPrPc cDNA led to enhanced PrPc-like immunoreactivity (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The treatment of mock-transfected PrP+/+ neurons with staurosporine increases caspase-3-like immunoreactivity, a phenotype that was drastically enhanced in 3F4MoPrPc-transfected primary cultured neurons (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Accordingly, this was accompanied by a consistent elevation of staurosporine-induced caspase activation upon 3F4MoPrP transfection of PrP+/+ neurons (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	93	 These data indicate that primary cultured neurons were transfectable and that 3F4MoPrPc overexpression in these cells mimics and potentiates the staurosporine-stimulated caspase activation phenotype observed in untransfected primary cultured neurons (see Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (34K):    FIG.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	95	 PrPc cDNA transfection increases staurosporine-induced caspase activity and immunoreactivity in PrP+/+ neurons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	96	 After transient transfection of wild-type primary cultured neurons (PrP+/+) with 3F4MoPrPc cDNA or empty vector (pcDNA3), PrPc- and caspase-3-like (casp.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	97	3) immunoreactivities (A) and caspase activity (B) were measured under control (-) and staurosporine-stimulated (+) conditions (see "Materials and Methods" for details).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Experiments in B correspond to three independent transfections with 3F4MoPrPc cDNA.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	99	  We took advantage of this feature to examine whether the lowering of caspase activation observed in PrP-/- primary cultured neurons could be rescued even partially by 3F4MoPrPc overexpression.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	100	 7A shows that a PrPc-like immunoreactivity was detectable in 3F4MoPrPc-transfected PrP-/- neurons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	101	 This was accompanied by a partial but reproducible recovery of the staurosporine-induced caspase activation responsiveness displayed by PrP+/+ neurons (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Thus, although mock-transfected PrP-/- display only 54% of the responsiveness of PrP+/+ neurons to staurosporine, three distinct 3F4MoPrP transfections of PrP-/- neurons consistently restored the staurosporine-induced caspase-3 activation to about 81% of the control.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	103	 This incomplete rescue is in apparent agreement with the relatively low efficiency of 3F4MoPrP cDNA transfection illustrated by the expression of exogenous PrPc in PrP-/- primary cultured neurons and agrees well with all of the data described above.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	104	View larger version (29K):    FIG.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	105	 PrPc cDNA transfection partially restores staurosporine-induced caspase activation in PrP-/- neurons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Transient transfection of PrPc cDNA in PrP-/- neurons increases PrPc immunoreactivity (A) and partially restores staurosporine-induced caspase activation (B).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Bars correspond to the staurosporine-induced increase of caspase-3 activity expressed as the percent of control corresponding to staurosporine stimulation of wild type PrP+/+ neurons transiently transfected with empty pcDNA3 vector (means of three independent transfections with 3F4MoPrPc cDNA).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	108	  PrP-/- Neurons Display Lower p53 Expression and Activity We examined the putative modulation of the tumor suppressor oncogene p53 by endogenous PrPc.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Primary cultured neurons devoid of their endogenous PrPc content display decreased p53 immunoreactivity (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	110	 8A) and transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	111	 8B), thereby demonstrating that endogenous PrPc controls p53 expression and activity.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Of greatest interest was the observation that p53 expression in the 1-month-old mouse brain was drastically lower in PrP-/- than in wild-type mice (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	113	 8C), indicating that PrPc also controls p53 expression in vivo.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (28K):    FIG.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Endogenous PrPc modulates p53-like immunoreactivity and transcriptional activity.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	116	 p53-like immunoreactivity (A and C) and transcriptional activity (B) were monitored as described under "Materials and Methods" in PrP+/+ and PrP-/- primary cultured neurons (A and B) and in adult mouse brain homogenate (C).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Bars represent the means  plus or minus  S.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	118	 of 4-6 independent experiments (triplicate determinations).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Mdm2-like immunoreactivity (D) and phosphorylated p38 MAPK (E) were measured in PrP-/- and PrP+/+ primary cultured neurons as detailed under "Materials and Methods.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	120	  PrPc Controls Post-transcriptional Modulators of p53 Activity We searched for post-transcriptional modulators of p53 activity that would be under the control of endogenous PrP in primary cultured neurons.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Mdm2 was recently shown to decrease p53 metabolic stability thereby lowering its activity (20).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	122	 We demonstrate here that Mdm2 immunoreactivity is higher in PrP-/- than in wild-type neurons (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	123	 8D), a phenotype completely opposite from that observed for p53 immunoreactivity (see Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	124	 As p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (p38 MAPK) was reported to up-regulate p53 activity via upstream of Mdm2 expression (26), we also examined the endogenous levels of the active, phosphorylated counterpart of p38 MAPK.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Active p38 immunoreactivity was higher in wild-type than in PrP-/- neurons (Fig.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	126	 8E), suggesting that PrPc also controls p38 phosphorylation at endogenous levels.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	127	Few things really are known concerning the physiological function of PrPc, but several lines of evidence indicate that PrPc could modulate cell death.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	128	 PrP mutations could trigger caspase activation (31), and murine scrapie appears to be associated with cell death (32).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Furthermore, prion infection impairs the cellular response to oxidative stress inducers (33) and triggers apoptosis in a hypothalamic neuronal cell line (34).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Altogether, these data suggest the ability of PrPc to modulate cell death, but whether this is due to an exacerbation of a proapoptotic function or, alternatively, to the alteration of an antiapoptotic phenotype could both be envisioned.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The literature in this field does not really solve the debate, and there are opposing data supporting both possibilities.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	132	 (8) have shown that serum deprivation-induced cell death is exacerbated in hippocampal neurons prepared from Prnp-/- mice.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	133	 On the other hand, PrPc also appears to protect human neurons from cell death triggered by overexpression of the proapoptotic oncogene Bax (9).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Finally, a recent paper indicates that PrPc could be a cellular mediator protecting retinal tissue from anisomycin-induced apoptosis (10).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	135	 From the above data one should expect a drastic deleterious effect of PrPc deletion due to the abrogation of this antiapoptotic phenotype.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	136	 This seems not to be the case, as PrPc-deficient mice are safe, healthy, and apparently develop and behave normally (15).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Furthermore, a recent article indicates that post-natal deletion of the PrPc alters the excitability of CA1 hippocampal neurons but does not induce neurodegeneration in adulthood (12).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	138	We had previously established that overexpression of PrPc enhances staurosporine-induced cell toxicity and DNA fragmentation and activates caspase-3 in stably transfected HEK293, TSM1 neurons, or inducible Rov9 cell lines (13, 14).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Furthermore, we showed that PrPc-induced caspase-3 activation is mediated by an Mdm2-regulated p53-dependent pathway in TSM1 neurons (14).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	140	 These data are fully in agreement with a previous work demonstrating that transgenic mice overexpressing wild-type PrPc could exhibit severe neurodegeneration (11).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	141	 However, it could be argued that the PrPc-related phenotype could be, in both cases, due to overexpression of the protein.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In line with such an hypothesis, a recent study nicely established that in N2A murine neuroblastoma cells, neurotoxicity and neurodegeneration could be associated with cytosolic accumulation of PrPc (35).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	143	 These data fully agreed with our demonstration that the manipulation of cytosolic PrPc concentration could indeed affect cell death.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Thus, proteasomal inhibition leads to increased PrPc-like immunoreactivity accompanied by drastic potentiation of caspase activation in HEK293 cells (13).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Conversely, depletion of cellular PrPc by immunosequestration at the membrane precludes the PrPc-induced proapoptotic phenotype (13).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	146	The present study first confirms that overexpression of PrPc enhances staurosporine-stimulated caspase-3 activity and demonstrates for the first time that in HEK293 cells, all PrPc-related phenotypes are p53-dependent.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	147	 These data have been fully reinforced by our observation that PrPc is inactive in p53-deficient fibroblasts.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Interestingly, we have established that, besides post-transcriptional modulation of p53, PrPc also enhances p53 promoter transactivation.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	149	It was most important to establish that the p53-dependent PrPc-related phenotype was not solely due to an artifactual perturbation of the cell physiology caused by the overexpression of the protein.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In this context, we examined the contribution of endogenous PrPc to apoptotic response by monitoring cell death in primary cultured neurons derived from mice embryos in which the Prnp gene had been abrogated (Zrch-1).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Our data show that deletion of PrPc led to a phenotype fully opposite of PrP overexpression.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Prnp-/- neurons are indeed less sensitive to staurosporine as monitored by TUNEL-positive cells, DNA fragmentation, and caspase activity and immunoreactivity.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Furthermore, this phenotype appears linked to a drastic reduction of p53 activity and immunoreactivity.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Finally, the p53 activator (p38 MAPK) and inhibitor (Mdm2) immunoreactivities are reduced.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	155	 This indicates that PrPc likely controls p53, at least in part, at a post-transcriptional level, as we demonstrated in TSM1 neurons by an overexpression approach (13).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Therefore, our current study further demonstrates that PrPc controls caspase activity through a p53-dependent and Mdm2-regulated process and that this proapoptotic phenotype is not caused artifactually by overexpression of the protein.
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	157	We recently established that in Alzheimer's disease, presenilin-2, a protein that when mutated mainly contributes to Alzheimer's disease-related pathologies, also controls cell death response to staurosporine by an identical p53-dependent mechanism (36).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	158	 This observation, together with our demonstration that similar proteolytic dysfunctions occur in both Alzheimer's and prion diseases, suggests that several common features could link apparently distinct neurodegenerative diseases (37).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	159	 This is also true when one considers Parkinson's disease pathology in which an -synuclein anti-apoptotic physiological phenotype (22) is associated to p53 down-regulation, which is abolished by 60H-dopamine, a toxin associated with this pathology (38).
0.12702371.14570892.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Altogether, these observations suggest envisioning p53 as a molecular target for therapeutic strategies in various neurodegenerative pathologies.

0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	0	  Rockefeller University Press, 0022-1007/2003/7/1 $5.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 The Journal of Experimental Medicine, Volume 198, Number 1, 1-4 Commentary.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	2	Dangerous Liaisons between a Microbe and the Prion Protein Adriano Aguzzi1 and Wolf-Dietrich Hardt2.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	3	1 Institute of Neuropathology, Department of Pathology, University Hospital of Zurich, CH-8091 Zurich, Switzerland 2 Institute of Microbiology, Department of Biology, ETH Zurich, CH-8092 Zurich, Switzerland.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	4	Address correspondence to Adriano Aguzzi, Institute of Neuropathology, Department of Pathology, University Hospital of Zurich, Schmelzbergstr.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	5	 12, CH-8091 Zurich, Switzerland.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Phone: 41-1-255-2869; Fax: 41-1-255-4402; E-mail: adriano{at}pathol.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	7	Aren't bugs a source of continuous amazement? Consider, for example, how cunningly bacteria conspire to shanghai the molecular machines of their mammalian hosts for their own goals.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Besides serving the bugs, this evil intelligence is exploitable for studying cellular physiology, and the bewildering affinity of bacterial toxins for crucial host cell proteins has taught us many a thing on how cells work.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	9	Perhaps Brucella may help teach us the function of the normal prion protein (1).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Brucella species are Gram-negative facultative intracellular pathogens.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	11	 They invade, resist intracellular killing, and replicate in phagocytic and nonphagocytic cells (2).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	12	 But how does Brucella initiate replication in macrophages? The contact with the bug instructs the macrophage to internalize it; the mode of internalization (Fc and complement receptors vs.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	13	 uptake of nonopsonized bugs) determines the fate of the bug (2).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	14	Brucella actively modulates its own engulfment.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	15	 It induces peculiar membrane ruffles at its site of contact with the macrophage and slow "swimming internalization" into a macropinosome.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Then, Brucella takes full control of the macropinosome.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	17	 It inhibits its maturation into a degradative lysosome (3) and reprograms it to acquire endoplasmic reticulum markers and mature into a "replicative phagosome" where bacteria start multiplying (Fig.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	18	View larger version (27K):    Figure 1.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	19	 abortus: A role for the Hsp60 to PrPC interaction.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	20	 abortus transports Hsp60 via the VirB type IV system onto its surface.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Upon encounter with a macrophage, Hsp60 binds to PrPC, which is embedded in lipid rafts on the macrophage surface.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	22	 This is thought to modulate phagocytosis (swimming internalization), mediate macropinosome formation, inhibit lysosome fusion, and steer the macropinosome to the formation of the replicative phagosome.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Other, hitherto unknown effector proteins traveling via the VirB system are also involved (see text; based on the findings by Watarai et al.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	24	  For playing these tricks, Brucella relies on a set of virulence factors, including a bacterial injection organelle termed VirB or type IV secretion system (4 to 8).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	25	 When exposed to macrophages in vitro, virB-deficient bugs cannot modulate phagocytosis and are degraded in the lysosome.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	26	 But what does the VirB system exactly do in this context? According to Watarai et al.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	27	 (1), it may be needed for transporting the bacterial heat shock protein Hsp60 onto the surface of the bug.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Unexpectedly, the chaperonin Hsp60, which normally hangs out in the cytoplasm and deals with unfolded proteins (9), turns out to reside on the surface of wild-type Brucella abortus but not virB mutants.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	29	On the macrophage surface, Brucella attaches to cholesterol-rich microdomains called lipid "rafts" (10 to 12).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	30	 There, Hsp60 appears to snatch at an unlikely friend, the cellular prion protein (PrPC), which is encoded by the Prnp gene and resides preferentially in rafts.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	31	 PrPC is apparently recruited to the macrophage's membrane protrusions, which engulf the bacteria, and subsequently to the early macropinosome.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	32	 abortus does not modulate phagocytosis nor phagosome maturation.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	33	 This is strikingly similar to the behavior of Brucella virB mutants and suggests that the Hsp60 to PrPC interaction is instrumental for these actions.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	34	The latter presumption is backed up by animal studies.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Wild-type Brucella replicates in wild-type mice, whereas virB mutants do not (13).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	36	 In Watarai's (1) experiments, both wild-type and VirB-deficient bugs are avirulent in PrPC-deficient mice.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Hence, the Hsp60 to PrPC connection is important in real infections (Fig.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	38	So, what can Brucella teach us about PrPC? The prion is the infectious agent causing transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (14).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Its only known constituent is PrPSc, a conformational isoform of PrPC, which is expressed at various levels in most mammalian cells.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The only established function of PrPC in vivo is to enable transmissible spongiform encephalopathies.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Ablation of Prnp abrogates prion replication (15) and pathogenesis (16).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	42	 However, the physiological function of PrPC has remained mysterious.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Prnpo/o mice show no obvious developmental defect and live long, happy lives (17).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Subtle changes in circadian rhythms (18) and alterations of hippocampal function (19 to 22) have been described in Prnpo/o mice.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	45	 However, some of these phenotypes were not reproduced by others (23) and none were clarified in molecular terms.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	46	Biochemically, PrPC was reported to do almost everything, including the opposite of everything.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	47	 For example, PrPC binds copper (24) and was suggested to be a cuproenzyme, but others hold this finding for a red herring (25).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	48	 PrPC may have antiapoptotic properties (26 to 29), but others find that it sensitizes neurons to apoptosis (30).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	49	 PrPC peptides might be neurotoxic (31), or maybe not (32).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Prion toxicity might be due to retrotranslocation of PrPC from the endoplasmic reticulum to the cytoplasm (33), but maybe retrotranslocation does not occur after all (34).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Hence, no unified view of PrPC function in health and disease has emerged from these observations, apart from the fact that PrPC is dispensable for life and normal development.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	52	And yet reverse genetics shows that PrPC must have some biological function and bind to one or more partners in a functionally meaningful way.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Transgenic expression of amino proximally truncated PrPC mutants causes cerebellar degeneration and early death (35).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	54	 This phenotype is only observed in Prnpo/o mice and is fully reverted by substoichiometric coexpression of full-length PrPC.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	55	 It follows that truncated PrP interferes with a physiological function of PrPC and that its effector domain lies in its amino proximal half.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	56	 A similar phenotype is elicited by overexpression of the Dpl protein (36), which resembles truncated PrPC and may therefore represent an endogenous PrPC antagonist (37).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	57	Population genetics provides further evidence that PrPC is doing more than bestowing prion diseases on us.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Protective variations in the human prion gene, which arose recently in evolution, have disseminated much more efficiently among human populations than nonprotective polymorphisms (38).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	59	 This provides a compelling case for a role in evolutionary fitness, similarly to globin gene mutations that are protective against malaria.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Selective pressure to maintain heterozygosity might have come from Kuru, a cannibalism-transmitted prion disease that was a prime cause of death in New Guinea tribes.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	61	 One disturbing conclusion is that cannibalism was commonplace among our ancestors (38).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Consequently prion diseases, now exceedingly rare, have probably ravaged human populations in the distant past.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	63	 What is most mystifying, Prnp null alleles were not selected for, despite the presumptive evolutionary advantage of resistance to cannibalism-induced prion disease.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	64	At face value, the resistance of PrPC knockout animals to B.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	65	 abortus infection provides further hints to the usefulness of PrPC.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Animals have probably dealt with Brucella infections for a long time and Brucella-resistant individuals with disrupted Hsp60 binding domains from PrPC should have had an edge.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	67	 However, this has not happened.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	68	So, what are the elusive functions and partners of PrPC? Several PrPC binding factors have been described, including the laminin receptor precursor protein (39), heparan sulfate (40), N-CAM (41), and bcl-2 (42), yet none of these interactions were linked to biological functions.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Could PrPC serve as a general Hsp60 sensor? Hsp60 homologues are found in bacteria and all eukaryotic cells, and can induce inflammation and immune responses (43, 44).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	70	 It will be exciting to test whether PrPC is involved in an Hsp60-dependent common "danger sensing" mechanism for detection of destructed body cells and pathogenic microbes (43, 44).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	71	Watarai's provocative report hints at novel, surprising aspects of bacterial and prion biology.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Many of the following exciting ramifications deserve to be studied: (a) Hsp60 is the first B.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	73	 abortus protein whose presence on the outer surface relies on the type IV secretion system, yet it does not seem to participate to the type IV secretion apparatus itself.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	74	 How is Hsp60 recognized and transported by the VirB type IV system? And how is it retained on the bacterial surface? (b) What is the function of the Hsp60 to PrPC complex? Is it simply slowing down the initial steps of phagocytosis to allow sufficient time for injection via the VirB type IV system and the manipulation of the early macropinosome by other so far unidentified effector proteins? Or does it serve as an anchor for assembling a whole set of host cellular proteins on the macropinosome membrane? (c) The Hsp60 to PrPC interaction is clearly insufficient for proper macropinosome formation and maturation.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Hence, the function of the type IV secretion system must go beyond surface exposure of Hsp60.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Which effector proteins travel via this pathway and what is their function? (d) Bacteria often accomplish their deeds by disrupting specialized cellular functions.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Does Brucella interfere with the function of PrPC? If so, what does it get out of it? Answers to these questions may come from analyzing interactions between Hsp60 and amino terminally truncated versions of PrPC.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	78	Many microbial pathogens invade and replicate within host cells.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	79	 All these bugs face death in the lysosome and have devised strategies to escape this fate.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Shigella and Listeria lyse the vacuole membrane and dwell in the host cell cytoplasm.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Others (including Salmonella typhimurium, Legionella pneumophila, mycobacteria, Chlamydia trachomatis, and certain Escherichia coli strains) manipulate the endosome/lysosome pathway and reside in some type of restructured vesicle.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Interestingly, some of these bugs (mycobacteria [45], C.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	83	 trachomatis [46], and certain E.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	84	 coli strains [47]) need, like Brucella, intact lipid rafts on the host cell surface to reach this niche (48).
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	85	 It will be exciting to test whether the Hsp60 to PrPC connection is involved.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Future work may test whether host cell manipulation via PrPC will be an exception, or the rule.
0.12703612.12847133.html.plaintext.txt	87	Submitted: May 5, 2003 Accepted: May 7, 2003.

0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Since Zmpste24 is involved in post-translational processing of prelamin A, the abnormal phenotypic features of Zmpste24-/- mice were attributed to defective processing of prelamin A (8,9).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The generation of mature lamin A from prelamin A involves farnesylation of cysteine in the conserved CAAX motif at the carboxy-terminal (10) by the enzyme farnesyl transferase (Fig.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The AAX tripeptide is then proteolytically removed by ZMPSTE24, followed by methylation of the prenylated cysteine by isoprenylcysteine carboxyl methyl transferase.

0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In the first step, farnesyl diphosphate is used to farnesylate the cysteine in the conserved CAAX motif (CSIM in prelamin A) at the carboxy-terminal using the enzyme farnesyl transferase (FT).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	16	 During the second step, the peptide bond between the cysteine and serine residues (indicated by an unfilled triangle) is proteolytically cleaved by ZMPSTE24, resulting in removal of SIM tripeptide.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	17	 This reaction is followed by methylation of the farnesylated cysteine residue by isoprenylcysteine carboxyl methyl transferase (ICMT) using S-adenosyl methionine as the methyl donor.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Finally, a second proteolytic cleavage occurs between the tyrosine and leucine residues (indicated by a filled triangle), which is either catalyzed by ZMPSTE24 or by another, as yet unidentified, endoprotease, and this cleavage removes 15 amino acids from the carboxy-terminal, resulting in formation of mature lamin A.

0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This motif is located in exon 8 and is critical for proteolytic activity.

0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	30	  The human ZMPSTE24 gene located on chromosome 1p34 spans 43 kb with 10 exons that encode a 475 amino acid protein (Fig.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Exon 8 retains the conserved zinc metalloprotease motif, HEXXH, shown to be critical for proteolytic processing of proteins (12,14).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The mutated residue, tryptophan 340, is adjacent to this motif and is conserved among species (Fig.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	33	The human ZMPSTE24 protein was modeled for transmembrane spanning regions using the method developed by Jones et al.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The protein has seven transmembrane domains similar to the predicted domains of yeast ste24 (12).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The residue tryptophan 340, which is mutated to arginine, lies adjacent to the catalytic motif close to the membrane on the cytoplasmic side, but is not embedded in the membrane (Fig.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	36	 However, the frameshift mutation affects the phenylalanine 361 residue, which lies within the sixth membrane spanning domain and leads to a truncated protein (Fig.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Thus, the carboxyl terminal of the mutant protein lies on the luminal side of the membrane and is not available for the catalytic action of the protease.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	38	View larger version (39K):    Figure 3.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The predicted model of human ZMPSTE24 protein and the mutations.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	40	 (A) The schematic of the protein shows seven transmembrane domains and the conserved zinc metalloprotease motif, HEXXH, which is critical for proteolytic processing of proteins.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The catalytic motif and the carboxy terminus are on the cytoplasmic side.

0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Thus the carboxyl terminal of the mutant protein is on the luminal side of the membrane and cannot participate in the catalytic action of the protease.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	46	  Ste24, a yeast homolog of ZMPSTE24, has a parallel role in the processing of prenylated mating pheromone a-factor (14,16).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Ste24 not only functions as a carboxy-terminal CAAX protease, but is also necessary for proteolytic cleavage of seven amino-terminal residues from the a-factor precursor.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Ras converting enzyme 1 (Rce1), a prenylprotein-specific CAAX protease, is also capable of carboxy-terminal processing of a-factor.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Finally, another amino-terminal proteolytic cleavage mediated by Ax11 or Ste23 proteases yields a mature form of a-factor.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Human ZMPSTE24 expressed in yeast can also process a-factor and complement the mating defect of the haploid MATa yeast lacking the STE24 and RCE1 (ste24rce1) genes (12,16).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	51	 We therefore assessed the functional significance of the two ZMPSTE24 mutations in the yeast complementation assay.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	52	 In this assay, the secreted mature a-factor diffuses into the medium and arrests the growth of the MAT strain leaving a  halo  surrounding the MATa strain.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The size of the halo is proportional to the production of the mature a-factor.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	54	Figure 4 shows the results of the yeast halo assay assessing the complementation of the a-factor processing defect by transforming the ste24rce1 yeast with expression vectors for the wild type ZMPSTE24 or the mutations found in our subject.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	55	 As expected, the ste24rce1 yeast with an empty vector did not produce a zone of growth inhibition (halo) on the lawn of MAT cells since they cannot produce mature a-factor.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The expression vector containing human ZMPSTE24 (wild-type) restored mature a-factor production and resulted in growth arrest of MAT cells as judged by the halo surrounding the yeast colony.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The ZMPSTE24 mutant, Phe361fsX379, was inactive in complementing the yeast a-factor and produced no halo around the yeast colony consistent with the severe structural alteration of the protein (Fig.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The mutant Trp340Arg, however, was partially active and produced a smaller halo compared to the wild type ZMPSTE24.

0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	67	  Our patient had a small chin, nose and mouth with poor postnatal growth in infancy (17).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	68	 At age 2, skin atrophy and contractures on the limbs, delayed closure of anterior fontanelle, acro-osteolysis and clavicular hypoplasia were observed.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	69	 She had a progeroid appearance with a pinched nose and multiple intracutaneous  bony knots  on her fingers and toes that contained sclerotic tissue with calcification.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	70	 At age 16, she had severe skin contractures around all of the interphalangeal joints, sparse and brittle hair, and mottled pigmentation on the trunk.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Skin on the face, head, arms and legs was very thin with underlying venous prominence suggesting generalized loss of subcutaneous fat (17).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The progeroid appearance and skeletal changes were progressive and she also developed progressive glomerulopathy, which resulted in chronic renal failure necessitating dialysis.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	73	 She died at age 24 due to pulmonary edema and malignant hypertension secondary to renal failure.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	74	Our patient also showed retarded growth and development and died prematurely, phenotypic features similar to those noted in the two lines of Zmpste24-/- mice (8,9).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	75	 She also had scarce and brittle hair similar to the loss of fur in the Zmpste24-/- mice.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	76	 However, instead of showing  growth plate dysplasia  or bone fractures, our patient showed progressive mandibular and clavicular hypoplasia and acro-osteolysis of the distal phalanges.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Although our patient had generalized lipodystrophy, there was no evidence of cardiomyopathy, abnormal gait or muscular dystrophy.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Furthermore, our patient had severe progressive glomerulopathy which most likely was the reason for death.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Although renal histopathology was not reported, in the end stage Zmpste24-/- mice serum creatinine levels were normal (8).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	80	  Bony knots  on the phalanges and severe skin contractures were also peculiar features present in our patient.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	81	  Bony knots  have only been rarely reported in patients with mandibuloacral dysplasia (18,19).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Progeroid features have been previously described in patients with MAD and some of them were initially diagnosed as having Werner or progeroid syndrome (18,20 to 24).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Recently, mutations in LMNA have been reported in patients with Hutchinson to Gilford progeria syndrome (HGPS), a rare genetic disorder characterized by features of premature ageing such as growth retardation, alopecia, atherosclerosis, sclerodermatous skin, and premature death during teenage years (25 to 27).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Our data suggest that besides mutant forms of lamins A and C, defective processing of prelamin A due to ZMPSTE24 mutations could also lead to progeroid features and early death.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	85	Prelamin A is as yet the only recognized substrate of ZMPSTE24 in mammals; therefore, the clinical manifestations of the affected patient with ZMPSTE24 mutations may be solely attributed to defective processing of prelamin A.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	86	 However, abnormal or inadequate processing of other farnesylated proteins by ZMPSTE24, which might have additional roles including signal transduction, could be responsible for the unique phenotypic features of our patient.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Although our patient had no documented evidence of dilated cardiomyopathy, muscular dystrophy and other skeletal disorders, which have been noted in Zmpste24-/- mice, ZMPSTE24 mutations could result in phenotypic heterogeneity and may be implicated in these disorders (8,9).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Finally, since three patients with MAD did not show any mutations in either the LMNA or the ZMPSTE24 gene, other genetic loci may also be responsible for MAD, particularly those which interact with lamins A/C or are involved in the processing of lamin A.

0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	93	5 degrees C decrease with each cycle).
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	94	 This was followed for another 15 cycles as above except at an annealing temperature of 55 degrees C.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The PCR product was purified to remove primers and dNTPs and sequenced using ABI Prism 3100.
0.12956092.12913070.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Sequences were compared using Vector NTi Suite 6 software and by visual inspection.

0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	0	Dpp-responsive Silencers Are Bound by a Trimeric Mad-Medea Complex* Sheng Gao, Janet Steffen, and Allen Laughon1.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Laboratory of Genetics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin 53706.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, June 24, 2005 , and in revised form, August 12, 2005.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	3	In contrast, Smad complexes bind to several Drosophila silencer elements without the assistance of a cofactor (11, 12).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	4	 These silencers repress the brinker (brk), bag of marbles (bam), and gooseberry (gsb) genes in response to signaling by decapentaplegic (dpp).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Repression of brk plays a central role in the dpp pathway (13, 14); in addition to direct activation by Smads, Dpp targets are regulated indirectly through repression by the Brk protein (15 to 18).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Repression of brk occurs through a silencer that binds a complex of the Smad proteins Mothers Against Dpp (Mad) and Medea (Med) (11).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Mad is homologous to the BMP2-specific Smad1, Smad5, and Smad8 receptor-activated Smads (rSmads).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Med is the homolog of Smad4, the coSmad that forms complexes with rSmads.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Genetic and biochemical analyses confirmed that Mad and Medea are both required for repression of brk (11, 19, 20).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Repression of brk also requires the large zinc finger protein Schnurri (Shn) (11, 19, 20).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Although Shn contains three zinc finger clusters, alone it does not bind to the silencer, and repression requires only a carboxyl-terminal region containing three zinc fingers that confer interaction with the silencer-bound Mad-Med complex (11, 12).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In the gonad Dpp signaling and Shn are also required for repression of bam (21, 22), a differentiation factor that must be kept off in germ line stem cells (23).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	13	 A Dpp-responsive silencer is located in the bam 5'-untranslated region just 27 bp from the transcriptional start (24).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Both silencers consist of paired Mad and Med binding sites (12, 25), and binding of the Mad-Med complex in turn allows binding of Shn.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	15	The ability of Mad-Med complexes to recognize the brk and bam silencers without help from cofactors suggests that Smad complexes are capable of greater DNA binding affinity and specificity than had been observed previously.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	16	 One means of achieving this would be for a greater number of MH1 domains to interact with DNA in a sequence-specific manner.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The number of MH1 domains contained within a Smad complex is determined by the way in which Smad MH2 domains oligomerize (26 to 29).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The tendency of MH2 domains to crystallize as trimers and heterotrimers (30 to 34) suggests that heterotrimers are the principal heteromeric Smad complex in vivo (34).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	19	 However, work from several groups has provided evidence that Smads also form other types of complexes, including heterodimers (35 to 37).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	20	Here we report that Mad and Med bind to the brk and bam silencers through all three MH1 domains of a Mad-Med heterotrimer.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The results reveal a mechanism by which Smad complexes bind certain regulatory elements with high affinity and specificity.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The arrangement of these sites is critical for silencing, and minor alterations can result in Dpp-responsive transcriptional activation instead of repression.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	23	View larger version (54K):    FIGURE 1.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Dpp-responsive silencers are bound by a Mad-Med complex.
