0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	75	To investigate the stoichiometry of silencer-bound Mad-Med complexes, we fused one or two copies of eGFP to the amino-terminal ends of FLAG-tagged Mad and of FLAG-tagged Med.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	76	 eGFP was deemed suitable for this approach (43) because it is effectively monomeric (44, 45).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The resulting 1x and 2x GFP fusions to Mad and Med bound to BamSE and BrkS probes in gel shift assays with about the same affinity as their normal counterparts but with slower mobility that was easily distinguishable from the wild-type Mad-Med-silencer complex (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	78	 This allowed us to test whether each Smad existed in one or two copies within the DNA-bound complex.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For example, if only one Mad exists in the complex, coexpression of Mad and 2xGFPMad (together with Med and TkvQD) should give two bands, the normal Mad-Med complex and the slower mobility 2xGFPMad-Med complex.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	80	 If the complex contains two Mad subunits, there should be three bands, Mad-Mad-Med, Mad-2xGFPMad-Med, and 2xGFPMad-2xGFPMad-Med.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Using a BamSE probe, the combination of Mad, 2xGFPMad, and Med resulted in three bands (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	82	 2A), of which the intermediate band was the strongest in intensity, as expected because Mad-2xGFPMad-Med complexes should be twice as abundant as complexes containing only one Mad isoform.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Furthermore, the intermediate band had the same mobility observed for a 1xGFP-Mad + Med complex, consistent with a mobility shift caused by the presence of two copies of eGFP.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The same result was obtained using a BrkS probe (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	85	 2B), and thus we conclude the Mad-Med-silencer complex contains two Mad subunits.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In contrast, we found that lysates containing Mad, Med and 2xGFPMed formed only two bands (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	87	 2, A and B), indicating that the Mad-Med-silencer complex contains only a single Med subunit.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	88	Mad Contacts GRCGNC by Means of the -Hairpin The DNA-binding interface of Smad3 is a -hairpin structure (42) that is completely conserved in all rSmads, with only two amino acid differences in coSmads.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	89	 This conservation of the DNA-binding interface suggests that all Smads might bind DNA with the same sequence specificity.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	90	 However, the GC-rich binding sites first described for Mad and later for Smad1 appear to be distinct from the canonical Smad3 GTCT site, and it has been proposed that such sites are bound through sequence-nonspecific contact with the lysine-rich helix 2, which lies adjacent to the -hairpin (46, 47).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	91	Single base pair substitutions in the GRCGNC sites of BrkS and BamSE diminish binding of the Mad-Med complex and repression (12) (data not shown), evidence that binding of the Mad-Med complex to GRCGNC sites is sequence-specific.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	92	 To investigate the basis for this sequence specificity, we introduced alanine substitutions at three positions within the Mad -hairpin, Arg-88, Gln-90, and Lys-95, each of which corresponds to a Smad3 residue whose side chain makes direct base-specific contact in the Smad3-DNA structure (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Western blots showed that these mutations and all others described below had little or no effect on the level of Mad or Med in whole cell lysates (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Nonetheless, all three mutations strongly reduced complex formation with BrkS (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	95	 As expected, alanine substitutions at the corresponding positions in Med had a similar effect (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	96	 We also tested an alanine substitution for Mad His-93, which corresponds to His-79 in Smad3, a residue that makes indirect base contact through water molecules (47), and found that it caused a less drastic but reproducible reduction in binding affinity for BrkS (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	97	 These results demonstrate that the -hairpin of Mad is necessary for contact of GRCGNC sites, just as it is for GTCT contact by Med.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	98	View larger version (24K):    FIGURE 4.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Both Mad subunits require the -hairpin.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Shown is a gel shift assay demonstrating that formation of the Mad-Med-BrkS complex is disrupted if one of the Mad subunits is mutant for a -hairpin base contact residue.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	101	 293T cell lysates added to the binding reactions had been transfected with effector plasmids for TkvQD, Med, 2xGFPMad, and wild-type or mutant version of unfused Mad, as indicated.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The composition of shifted Mad-Med complexes is indicated alongside the gel as described in the legend for Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The image also shows that complex formation is disrupted if one of the Mad subunits harbors the R58A mutation.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	104	 An asterisk marks the background band.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	105	  Helix 2 Contributes to DNA Binding Although our results indicated that binding of Mad to the GRCGNC occurs via the -hairpin, we went on to test whether residues within or adjacent to helix 2 might nevertheless contribute to binding.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The lysine-rich stretch of helix 2 has been shown to function as a nuclear localization signal (48, 49) but a series of helix 2 lysine to alanine mutations resulted in little or no change in Mad or Med levels in whole cell lysates of transfected 293T cells, as determined from Western blots (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Comparing these lysates in gel shift experiments, we found that Mad-Med-BrkS complex formation was strongly disrupted by Mad R58A, a residue that is just carboxyl-terminal to helix 2, with moderate effects caused with Mad K46A and by Med R66A, K74A and D80A (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The results show that helix 2 and carboxyl-terminally adjacent residues contribute to the DNA binding activity of Med as well as that of Mad, suggesting that helix 2-backbone contact may be a general feature of Smad-DNA interaction and not exclusive to interaction with the GRCGNC site.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Together, these results suggest that Mad and Med both contact DNA via the -hairpin in a configuration that is similar to that of the Smad3 MH1 domain bound to GTCT, possibly with helix 2 tilted somewhat closer to the DNA backbone.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Notably, alanine substitutions in helix 2 of Mad and Med had no obvious effect on recruitment of ShnCT (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Because binding of ShnCT requires precise 5-bp spacing between GRCGNC and GTCT (discussed below), the MH1 domains are likely sites for Shn interaction.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	112	 These results indicate that any MH1 contact with ShnCT does not depend critically on solvent-exposed helix 2 side chains.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	113	The stretch of basic amino acids that starts in helix 2 extends further in Mad than in Smad3, and we found that one of these additional residues, Arg-58, is required to form the silencer complex.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	114	 However, from comparison with the Smad3MH1-DNA crystal structure, it is doubtful that Arg-58 would be able to contact the DNA backbone from its position at the end of helix 2.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Indeed, the R58A substitution had little effect on binding of purified maltose-binding protein-MadNL (which binds as a monomer) to probes containing GTCT or GGCGAC, whereas R88A dramatically reduced binding to both probes (data not shown), evidence that Arg-58 is not directly involved in DNA contact.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Rather than directly contacting DNA, Arg-58 may engage in protein-protein interactions that stabilize the DNA-bound Mad-Med heterotrimer.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, we cannot rule out the possibility that, when bound as a heterotrimer, the Mad MH1 domain adopts a structure in which Arg-58 contacts the DNA backbone.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	118	The -Hairpin Is Required in Both Mad Subunits The results described above prove only that the -hairpin is required in at least one of the two Mad subunits contained within the heterotrimer.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	119	 To test whether the -hairpin is required in both Mad subunits, we coexpressed Mad R88A, Q90A and K95A mutant proteins with wild-type 2xGFP-Mad and performed a gel shift with a BrkS probe.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	120	 If -hairpin contact was required in only one of the two Mad MH1 domains, we expected to observe an intermediate band containing 2xGFPMad and MadR88A (or Q90A/K95A).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Faint intermediate bands were observed (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	122	 4), but even the strongest of these, Q90A, was much weaker than for wild-type.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	123	 We interpret these results as a demonstration that an intact -hairpin is required in both Mad subunits, although presence in just one subunit does allow for some residual binding.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Interestingly, Arg-58 was also required in both Mad subunits.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	125	View larger version (33K):    FIGURE 5.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Shn binding and repression require correct spacing and orientation of binding sites within the Dpp-responsive silencers.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	127	 A, selected mutations in BrkS that demonstrate the importance of binding site sequence and topology for repression.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Changed bases in Mut1 and Mut2 are in bold lowercase type.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	129	 B, gel shift assays showing the effects of topological changes in the BrkS silencer.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Compared with wild-type, reversal of the GTCT (Mut1) disrupted binding of the Mad-Med complex.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	131	 In contrast, changing GTCT to GGCG (Mut2) reduced the Mad-Med complex only slightly but binding of ShnCT was undetectable.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Reducing the distance between the Mad and Med binding sites by 1 bp (Mut3) had little effect on binding of the Mad-Med complex but binding of ShnCT was undetectable.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	133	 DNA binding reactions contained BrkS probe and lysate from 293T cells transfected with effector plasmids for expression of Flag-Mad, HA-Med, or ShnCT, as indicated (all transfected with TkvQD).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	134	 C, reporter assays in Drosophila S2 cells showing that Smad binding site sequence, orientation and spacing are critical for repression.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Repression in response to TkvQD was disrupted by reversal of the Med binding site (Mut1), whereas Mut2 and Mut3 show that changing GTCT to GGCG or reducing the spacing between Mad and Med sites resulted in TkvQD-induced activation.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	136	 As diagrammed above the graph, the reporter plasmids contained BrkS positioned upstream of a 3xSu(H) binding site array, which allowed for activation in response to cotransfected effector plasmids for Suppressor of Hairless (Su(H)) and an activated version of Notch (Nact) (11, 12, 40).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Amounts of effector plasmids used per transfected well (in nanograms) are indicated below the chart.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	138	 D, gel shift assay using GFP fusion constructs as in Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	139	 2 demonstrates that activating Mad-Med complexes (arrowheads) still contain a heterotrimer with a 2:1 Mad:Med ratio.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Probes and composition of 293T cell lysates were as indicated above the lanes.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The mobility of complexes is more tightly spaced for the Mut3 probe.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	142	View larger version (16K):    FIGURE 6.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Model of the Mad-Med heterotrimer bound to a Dpp-responsive silencer.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The positions of the two Mad MH1 domains in contact with the GRCGNC site are depicted as symmetrical but a tandem arrangement has not been ruled out.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Shn is depicted as contacting the MH1 domains because of its sensitivity to spacing between the Mad and Med binding sites.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	146	 However, Shn also interacts with the Mad and Med MH2 domains (71, 72).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	147	  A Mad-Med Heterotrimer Can Activate Transcription The significance of the GRCGNC(N)5GTCT topology was investigated with a series of rearrangements (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Reversal of the GTCT in BrkS (mut1 in Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	149	 5A) reduced binding of the Mad-Med-silencer complex formation (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	150	 5B) and essentially eliminated repression (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In contrast, changing GTCT to GGCG (mut2 in Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	152	 5A) had only a modest effect on Mad-Med binding but prevented recruitment of Shn (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	153	 5B), transforming the silencer into a Dpp-responsive activating element (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Similarly, a 1-bp increase (data not shown) or decrease (mut3 in Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	155	 5A) in spacing converted the silencer into an activating element (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	156	 5C), again disrupting Shn binding without severely affecting the binding of Mad and Med (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	157	 In the latter two cases, Mad and Med still bound to the DNA as a heterotrimer with a 2:1 ratio (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Similar results were obtained with the same alterations of BamSE.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	159	 These results demonstrate that repression is dependent on a precise (GRCGNC)-(N)5-GTCT arrangement and that trimeric Smad complexes that cannot recruit Shn behave as transcriptional activators.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	160	Our findings contradict a previous report that Mad and Med bind to BrkS as a dimer (12).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Although no documentation was provided for how this was determined experimentally, our own attempts to determine stoichiometry by means of antibody supershift experiments suggest a possible explanation for the discrepancy.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	162	 We found that epitope tags at the Mad amino terminus are only readily accessible to the antibody on one of the two Mad subunits (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	163	 1D), possibly because of crowding by the adjacent DNA-bound MH1 domain of Med.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	164	 This problem led us to turn instead to the use of protein fusions as a strategy (43) for assessing stoichiometry.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	165	Mad and Med appear to be the only factors that directly contact the bam and brk silencers (11, 12).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	166	 This conclusion is based on mutational analysis of the BrkS element, which showed that mutations that disrupt silencing also disrupt binding of the Mad-Med complex.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The only exceptions were mutation of GTCT to GTCG (12) or to GGCG (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	168	 5) and a 1-bp deletion between the Mad and Med sites (12) (Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	169	 5), each of which allowed binding of the Mad-Med complex but disrupted recruitment of Shn.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Overexpression of activated Mad-Med complexes is sufficient to generate these gel shift complexes, and therefore it is unlikely that an unknown cofactor is required because it would presumably need to be expressed at high levels endogenously in both Drosophila and human cells.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The demonstration that binding of the Mad-Med heterotrimer requires all three MH1 domains also weighs against cofactor involvement because it becomes difficult to explain how GRCGNC could be contacted by a cofactor in addition to two Mad MH1 domains (the Med MH1 contacting GTCT).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Nonetheless, it is possible that a cofactor present in Drosophila and human extracts has gone undetected, although the evidence suggests it could not play a direct role in sequence-specific DNA contact.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	173	The apparent ability of a Mad-Med complex to bind silencers without cofactors contrasts with the general reliance of Smads on DNA-binding cofactors for target specificity.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	174	 brk could be considered a special case because it is negatively regulated by Dpp globally (15 to 18), whereas other Dpp targets require tissue-specific regulation (41, 52 to 57).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	175	 However, bam expression is specific to germ line cells, and thus it is unexpected that DNA contact by Mad and Med would be sufficient for the regulatory specificity of the bam silencer.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The existence of a similar Dpp-responsive silencer regulating gooseberry (12) provides further evidence that these novel arrangements of Smad binding sites provide sufficient specificity for regulation in response to signaling.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Nonetheless, tissue specificity might be augmented by cooperative interaction of DNA-bound corepressors with Smads bound to BrkS/BamSE-like sites.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	178	The high affinity of Mad and Med for these silencers is explained by the trimeric stoichiometry and involvement of all MH1 domains in directly contacting DNA.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The ability of a single Smad complex to engage all three MH1 domains in DNA contact has several implications.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The most obvious is that Smad complexes may in some cases make a greater contribution to target recognition than was previously apparent.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	181	 As in the case of brk, this provides a mechanism by which Dpp, BMP, or even transforming growth factor- signaling might trigger a general response without the need for a tissue-specific cofactor.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Such a response need not be limited to silencing because slight alterations in the silencers transform them into Dpp-responsive activating elements, possibly by allowing CBP to interact with the Mad-Med complex (58) in the absence of Shn.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Conserved sites exhibiting the BrkS/BamSE motif have been identified within BMP-response elements for the Id genes (59 to 61), which as a class are responsive to BMP signaling (62, 63).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Conversely, tissue specificity might be conferred upon such tripartite Smad response elements by adjacent binding sites for other transcription factors.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	185	A second implication is that Smad complexes may have greater flexibility in their ability to recognize binding sites than was previously apparent, particularly for moderate affinity sites to which only two MH1 domains make sequence-specific contact.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The observed flexibility in spacing between the Mad and Med sites in BrkS and BamSE suggests that DNA binding by Med plus just one Mad MH1 domain might be able to occur in a variety of permutations.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	187	 However, loss of binding when the Med site was reversed (mut1 in Fig.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	188	 5B) shows that the topology of Smad sites has strict limits.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	189	 A moderate affinity site might also consist of just the GRCGNC Mad binding site without an adjacent Med binding site, as appears to be the case for many Dpp-responsive enhancer elements (41, 52 to 54, 57, 64, 65).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	190	3 Such moderate affinity sites would activate transcription in response to Dpp signaling, but only when the necessary tissue-specific cofactor is present.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Some Mad sites serve also as binding sites for the Brk protein, which opposes Dpp signaling by direct competition for Mad binding and by functioning as an active repressor (40, 66 to 69).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	192	The third implication is for complexity in the response to BMP signaling.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	193	 In vertebrates that possess three BMP-responsive rSmads, Smad1, Smad5, and Smad8, BMP signaling might trigger the formation of a variety of trimeric rSmad complexes with Smad4 (e.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	194	 There is the potential for six such combinations (114, 554, 884, 154, 184, and 584).
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	195	 If such mixed complexes do form, as has been shown for Smad2, Smad3, and Smad4 in activation of p15Ink4B (70), it will be important to determine whether differences exist among them in the range of binding sites that can be bound by means of two or three MH1 domains.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	196	 The likelihood of differential cofactor interactions by Smad1, Smad5, and Smad8 adds an additional layer of complexity.
0.13232653.16109720.html.plaintext.txt	197	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported by a grant from the National Science Foundation.

0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	0	Commentary: Shaw s critique of health care is still valid K Srinath Reddy.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	1	All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Ansari Nagar, New Delhi, 110 029, India.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	2	The preface provided by George Bernard Shaw to The Doctor s Dilemma1 is a profoundly insightful and deliberately provocative essay on the short-comings of health care, as provided by doctors who are deficient in scientific thought and are driven by petty profit motives.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	3	 It is also an eloquent espousal of an ideal public health system, devoid of those flaws.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Though Shaw was unduly harsh on Pasteur, improperly critical of the efforts to eliminate smallpox and his prototype of an underpaid doctor driven to malpractice no longer exists in many parts of the world, most of the ideas developed in the preface are of great contemporary relevance.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	5	Shaw s consistent demand for credible evidence is the hallmark of a truly scientific mind.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	6	 He expresses despair, and even disgust, at the usual medical practitioner not applying the methods of scientific enquiry and the principles of statistical analysis to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the treatment methods which they espouse with ill-informed enthusiasm and willingly inflict on an unsuspecting public.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The situation has not improved greatly since Shaw s time.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Even as  evidence  constantly accumulates in the pages of prolific research publications, the average practitioner is often distanced from its message.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Even when a part of that message does reach him or her, often through the pharmaceutical industry s sales promoters or through the lay media, the aptitude and the ability to subject that message to serious scientific scrutiny are severely deficient.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	10	Shaw protests against the incorrect use of statistics and the lack of matched comparison groups.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	11	 He argues convincingly that apparent benefits of interventions are easily demonstrable in the absence of a matched comparison group and cautions that such spurious interpretations ought not to guide medical practice.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	12	 He makes out a good case for employing the scientific design of a controlled trial for evaluating medical interventions.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	13	 He is particularly caustic about the ecological fallacies that arise from analyses that depend on time trends and do not take into account the confounding effects of concomitant changes in other determinants.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The example he provides, of the relationship between disappearance of typhus and amputation of the little finger, is particularly telling.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The clarity with which he identifies and describes confounding as a factor which bedevils  causal  associations would do an epidemiologist proud.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	16	He especially emphasizes the role of socioeconomic status as an important determinant of differences in the levels of health and as a powerful confounder which influences the effect of interventions which aim to alter health.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	17	 His socialist ideology and scientific temper blend into a brilliantly incisive analytical tool as he dissects out the contributions of poverty and deprivation to ill health and pours out his convictions in a passionate piece of advocacy urging greater attention to such broader determinants of health.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The adverse health implications of a low socioeconomic status have now been widely documented in virtually all areas of health, from under-nutrition and infectious diseases to many of the non-communicable diseases.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	19	 While a Virchow, a McKeown, or a Marmot may call attention to this from among the public health fraternity, it requires the writing power of a Dickens or a Shaw to stir the conscience of the world to take heed and initiate action.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	20	The issues related to  confidence intervals  and  absolute risk  also come up in Shaw s preface, although the specific terms are not used.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	21	 He questions the validity of drawing conclusions from estimates based on a zero numerator and a denominator which is very small (he uses a sample size of one in the smallpox vaccination example).
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The need to estimate confidence intervals and use them for judging the possible range of the effect size associated with an intervention has been emphasized often enough in statistics.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Yet a substantial section of published research, and clinical practice even more so, have not yet benefited from the statistical lesson that Shaw provides us.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Too often the  zero numerator  exercises a seductive appeal that clouds judgement, as the upper confidence limit is blissfully ignored by those who interpret the numbers.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	25	2 Similarly, published studies too often focus on relative risk to put a  spin  on the results of trials, without informing the practising doctor as to the difference that is likely to occur in the absolute risk of an event.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Thus a measure of risk which is relevant to the study of aetiological associations is substituted, in a pseudoscientific sleight of hand, for a measure of risk which is relevant to decision making on individual management in clinical practice.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The  cruder tricks  which disturbed Shaw continue to dismay us when results of scientific investigations are inaccurately interpreted, either out of ignorance or with deliberate intent to mislead.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	28	Shaw is particularly lucid when he talks of the benefits of  attention  to health, which need to be accounted for, before ascribing the virtue of independent benefit to an intervention.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The beneficial effects of placebos and of the attention bestowed on the participants in a clinical trial have been well described in many recent publications on clinical research methodology.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	30	 That Shaw demanded rigorous proof of a truly independent contribution made by an intervention is remarkable, when we consider that even now policy and practice are all too frequently swayed by the results of uncontrolled or inadequately controlled studies (such as some demonstration projects) wherein the effects of co-intervention and confounding are poorly assessed.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	31	Shaw discusses the influence of demand and supply on the nature of medical practice from two seemingly contradictory but essentially complementary viewpoints.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	32	 On the one hand, he laments (and rightly so) that giving the doctor a pecuniary interest in prescribing costly tests, medication, or surgery motivates him to manipulate the  demand  to suit his interests.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	33	 That such a  supplier driven demand  makes medical care a prime example of market failure is all too evident in the present era of technology-intensive high cost investigations and interventions.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	34	 At the same time, he also argues that the laity can reset the nature of the supply, by demanding certain types of care or expressing a preference for hygienic modes of disease prevention.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	35	 This too is true, as the growing market for  complementary  or  alternative  systems of medicine demonstrates.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	36	 It is not surprising that practitioners of  modern  medicine are also now warming up to some of these treatment methods, after many years of scepticism.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The fact that there is now a great scientific and public health interest in the health promoting effects of fresh fruit and vegetables as well as in the merits of a Mediterranean diet supports the contention that doctors recognize the need to respect conventional wisdom and respond to it with research which can confirm or repudiate.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	38	However, the dominance of the profit motive in those who provide or control health care would still lead them to manipulate the demand to the maximal extent they can.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	39	 They would employ reductionist research to seek out the protective phytochemicals, antioxidants or fibre from fruits and vegetables, so that they can be marketed as pills and potions.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The imbalance between a supplier-driven demand and a consumer-generated demand would always be resolved in favour of the provider, till consumers (acting as communities and as individuals) become better informed and more assertive in resetting the demand for the health care they deserve and desire.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	41	Shaw finally suggests a model, wherein pubic health which is protected and promoted by a Public Health Service comprising Medical Officers of Health who are committed to act as benefactors of the community, to replace the petty private tradesmen profiteering from illness.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	42	 This is a model that has only been partly developed and insufficiently applied, even in countries with socialized systems of health care, and hence cannot be considered as one adequately tried and tested.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	43	 It is tragic, therefore, that the model is being discarded as a failure and that national health services are being dismantled in a hurry to provide a free rein to privatized and commercialized medical care.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Shaw s vision is even more relevant today than at the time of his writing.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	45	 This is because the commodification of health care has proceeded to far more sinister levels of organization than in the days of the  precarious, shabby-genteel, irresponsible  private practitioner whom he perceived as the principal danger.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The Jekyll to Hyde pathway of transformation has proceeded through stages, from the benign family physician to the greedy private doctor to the medical cartels in larger hospitals to the present state where large corporations control the production and distribution of drugs, devices and other technologies for which the individual doctor is only a robotic sales agent.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	47	 As the juggernaut of commercial medicine rolls on, the individual doctor s role too becomes inconsequential and the citizen s health is further forfeit to corporate profits.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	48	It is tempting to speculate on how Shaw would have reacted to the social forces which are shaping global health today as well as to the new threats to public health that have emerged since his time.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The epidemics of non-communicable diseases now sweeping across the world are being driven by some of the undesirable elements of industrialization, urbanization and globalization.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	50	 From tobacco to processed food and from drugs to vaccines, the language of trade threatens to dominate the discourse on public health.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The agents of ill health are marketed aggressively by transnational mega-corporations as they battle to win over the minds and the money of consumers spread over many countries.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Even communicable diseases come in new forms as globalized trade not only speeds up human travel but also promotes livestock farming at an industrial level.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	53	 One wonders what caustic comments would have come from Shaw s critical pen about the factors that led to  mad cow disease  or even sudden acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), which may be a byproduct of an expanding animal to human interface in a setting of unhygienic livestock breeding for commercial purposes.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	54	The solutions needed today, therefore, go beyond the creation of a responsive and responsible Medical Officer of Health.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	55	 We require a broader and stronger edifice of global public health in which the multiple determinants of health are addressed and influenced from a perspective where peoples  health takes precedence over corporate wealth.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The mould which makes the individual doctor too needs to be recast.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Epidemiology, economics, and ethics which are sadly deficient in modern medical training need to be strengthened, so that the doctor who emerges from the portals of the medical college is endowed with a scientific temper, a spirit of social responsibility, and the ability to utilize available resources more efficiently for promoting better health outcomes.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The role of non-physician health care providers has increased since Shaw s time and needs to be further strengthened.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Well informed involvement of communities in health promotion and of patients in self care are receiving greater emphasis in the participatory models of health care that seek to replace the prescriptive models.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	60	 All of these components must contribute to a more scientific, efficient, and equitable pattern of health care.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Towards the end of this preface, Shaw expresses optimism that public health will get the champions it needs to provide a social solution to the medical problem.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	62	 I too will end this commentary with the hope that global consciousness will rise to ensure the triumph of public health over the many threats it faces.
0.13508143.14681245.html.plaintext.txt	63	 If nothing goes wrong is everything is all right? JAMA 1983;249:1743 to 45.

0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	0	Human prion diseases and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) Human prion diseases and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) John Collinge.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	1	Prion Disease Group, Neurogenetics Unit, Imperial College School of Medicine at St.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	2	Prion diseases are transmissible neurodegenerative disorders which affect a range of mammalian species.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	3	 In humans they can be inherited and sporadic as well as acquired by exposure to human prions.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Prions appear to be composed principally of a conformational isomer of host-encoded prion protein and propagate by recruitment of cellular prion protein.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Recent evidence argues that prion protein can also encode disease phenotypes by differences in its conformation and glycosylation.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Such molecular analysis of prion strains suggests that new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is caused by BSE exposure.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The novel biology of prion propagation may not be unique to these rare degenerative brain diseases.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	8	The human prion diseases or transmissible spongiform encephalopathies have been traditionally classified into Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease (GSS) and kuru.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	9	 They are rare neurodegenerative disorders affecting ~1 person per million world-wide per annum.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Despite their rarity, remarkable attention has been recently focused on these diseases.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	11	 This is because of both their unique biology and concerns that the epidemic of a newly recognised bovine prion disease, bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), could pose a threat to public health through dietary exposure to infected tissues.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	12	Transmissibility of the human diseases to experimental animals was demonstrated with the transmission, by intracerebral inoculation with brain homogenates into chimpanzees, of first kuru and then CJD in 1966 and 1968 respectively (1 ,2 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Transmission of GSS followed in 1981 (3 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The prototypic prion disease, scrapie, is a naturally occurring disease of sheep and goats, and has been recognised for >200 years (4 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Scrapie was demonstrated to be transmissible by inoculation in 1936 (5 ) and it was the recognition that histopathologically kuru, and then CJD, resembled scrapie that led to suggestions that these diseases may also be transmitted by inoculation (6 ,7 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Kuru is a neurodegenerative condition characterised principally by a progressive cerebellar ataxia which reached epidemic proportions amongst the Fore linguistic group in the Eastern Highlands of Papua New Guinea and which was transmitted by cannibalism.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Since the cessation of cannibalism in the 1950s the disease has declined but a few cases still occur as a result of the long incubation periods in this condition (8 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Transmission of CJD from case to case has occurred by a number of routes involving accidental inoculation with human prions as a result of medical procedures.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Such iatrogenic routes include the use of inadequately sterilised neurosurgical instruments, dura mater and corneal grafting, and use of human cadaveric pituitary derived growth hormone or gonadotrophin.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	20	The epidemiology of the human prion diseases encompasses the three aetiological types of prion disease: inherited, sporadic and acquired (Table 1 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Inherited cases constitute ~15% of cases, acquired cases (kuru and iatrogenic CJD) are rare.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Most human cases are sporadic, and their precise aetiology is still unclear.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Both human and animal prion diseases share common histopathological features.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The classical triad of spongiform vacuolation (affecting any part of the cerebral grey matter), astrocytic proliferation and neuronal loss, may be accompanied by the deposition of amyloid plaques (9 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	25	 These plaques are composed principally of an abnormal, partially protease resistant isoform of a host encoded sialoglycoprotein, prion protein (PrP).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	26	 PrP is expressed widely but at much higher levels in neuronal cells as a glycosylphosphatidyl inositol-anchored cell surface protein (10 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	27	MOLECULAR GENETICS OF THE HUMAN PRION DISEASES AND A MODEL FOR PRION PROPAGATION.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	28	The transmissible agent, or prion, seems to consist principally of an abnormal isoform of the prion protein (PrP), designated PrPSc (11 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	29	 PrPSc is known to be derived from the cellular isoform, PrPC, by a post-translational mechanism (12 ,13 ) and evidence is mounting that this change is conformational rather than covalent (14 ,15 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	30	While PrPC is fully sensitive to proteolysis, PrPSc, which accumulates in the brain during disease, is partially protease resistant.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The human PrP gene (PRNP) is a single copy gene located on the short arm of chromosome 20 (16 ); it spans 16 kb and contains two exons (17 ,18 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The complete open reading frame of 759 nucleotides is contained within the larger second exon which comprises the majority of the 2.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	33	 A key advance in the understanding of prion biology was the identification of mutations in PRNP in the familial forms of the human diseases.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The first mutation to be identified in PRNP was in a family with CJD and constituted a 144 bp insertion into the coding sequence (19 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	35	 A second mutation was reported in two families with GSS and genetic linkage was confirmed between this missense variant at codon 102 and GSS, confirming that GSS was an autosomal dominant Mendelian disorder (20 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	36	 This genetic variant was not present in the normal population but was rapidly identified in numerous other unrelated GSS kindreds.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	37	 These diseases are therefore both inherited in the germline and transmissible by inoculation, and are biologically unique in this regard.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	38	The identification of one of the pathogenic PrP gene mutations in a case with neurodegenerative disease allows not only molecular diagnosis of an inherited prion disease (21 ) [and pre-symptomatic testing of at risk individuals (22 )] but also its sub-classification according to mutation.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Pathogenic mutations reported to date in the human PrP gene consist of two groups: (i) point mutations within coding sequence resulting in amino acid substitutions in PrP or in one case production of a stop codon resulting in expression of a truncated PrP; (ii) insertions encoding additional integral copies of an octapeptide repeat present in a tandem array of five copies in the normal protein (Fig.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The availability of direct gene markers for these diseases has enabled identification of highly atypical cases and has widened the known phenotypic range of these disorders (23 ,24 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Remarkable phenotypic variability may be present in the same family, with phenotypes ranging from classical CJD to atypical dementias with extremely long duration and lacking the typical histological features of spongiform encephalopathy (25 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Clinical and pathological syndromes of the human inherited and other prion diseases are reviewed in detail elsewhere (26 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	43	Genetic susceptibility is also relevant to both the sporadic and acquired prion diseases.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	44	 There is a common polymorphism of the human prion protein, with either methionine or valine present at residue 129.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	45	 In Caucasians, ~38% are homozygous for the more frequent methionine allele, 51% are heterozygotes and 11% are homozygous for valine (27 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The large majority of sporadic CJD occurs in individuals homozygous for this polymorphism (28 ) and most pituitary hormone related iatrogenic CJD cases are homozygotes, with a particular excess of valine homozygotes (29 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	47	 This protective effect of PRNP heterozygosity is also seen in some inherited prion diseases where the age at onset of disease is 1-2 decades later in heterozygotes at PRNP codon 129 as compared with homozygotes (30 ,31 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	48	Although prion diseases can be transmitted between mammalian species by inoculation, in practice it is difficult to do so, and typically transmission occurs in only a small proportion of inoculated animals and then only after prolonged incubation periods on primary passage.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	49	 On second and subsequent passage of infectivity into animals of the same species, incubation periods are typically much shortened, relatively synchronous as compared with primary passage, and all inoculated animals succumb to disease.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	50	 A key component of this so-called `species barrier' is the degree of homology between the PrP in the donor and recipient species.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Mice transgenic for hamster PrP lose their species barrier to hamster prions (32 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	52	 When such transgenic mice were challenged with mouse derived prions, the infectivity they produced was fully pathogenic for mice but not hamsters, while on challenge with hamster derived prions they produced prions fully pathogenic to hamsters but not mice.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The interpretation of this finding is that a direct interaction between PrP molecules occurs at some stage in the process of prion propagation and that such interaction occurs most easily if the interacting PrP molecules are identical.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Such work led to the idea that replication of prions may occur by PrPSc interacting directly with PrPC and catalysing the conversion of PrPC to PrPSc (32 ,33 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Such an effect could then lead to a chain reaction of conversion leading to the progressive conversion of increasing amounts of PrPC to PrPSc.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The pathogenic mutations in the prion protein may result in the production of a protein that converts spontaneously to PrPSc in individuals with inherited prion diseases.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Such a model provides an explanation of how a disease can be simultaneously inherited and transmissible.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The finding that nearly all sporadic CJD occurs in homozygotes with respect to a common and apparently innocent protein polymorphism lends strong support to such a mechanism (28 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Again prion protein interaction would occur most favourably in individuals with two identical copies of the prion protein.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Heterozygotes, producing two different proteins, would be somewhat protected, as if by an internal `species barrier'.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	61	 It is possible that the occasional individuals heterozygous at codon 129 who do develop sporadic CJD have a more prolonged illness although more detailed studies are required to investigate this further (34 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	62	 PrP valine 129 and PrP methionine 129 would be expected to differ slightly in their propensity to conversion to PrPSc.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The excess of PrP valine 129 homozygotes amongst human pituitary hormone related cases suggests that PrP valine 129 may be the more susceptible (29 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Pathogenic mutations reported to date in the human prion protein.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	65	The aetiology of sporadic CJD remains unclear.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	66	 It has been speculated that these cases might arise from somatic mutation of PRNP or spontaneous conversion of PrPC to PrPSc as a rare stochastic event.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The alternative hypothesis, that such cases arise as a result of exposure to an environmental source of either human or animal prions, is not supported by epidemiological evidence (35 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Since transgenic mice expressing extremely high levels of wild-type hamster or murine PrP develop a spontaneous neuromuscular disease (36 ), that appears to be transmissible, it has also been suggested that some cases of sporadic CJD may arise as a result of PrP overexpression.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	69	Table 1 Human prion diseases Type Clinical syndromes Aetiology Acquired Kuru Cannibalism   Iatrogenic CJD Accidental innoculation with human prions Sporadic CJD ?Somatic PRNP mutation   Atypical CJD or spontaneous conversion PrPC to PrPSc Inherited Familial CJD Germline PRNP mutation   GSS     FFI     Various atypical dementias   CJD, Creuzfeldt-Jakob disease; GSS, Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease; FFI, fatal familial insomnia; PRNP, human prion protein gene.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	70	A high resolution structure of full length PrP has not yet been reported, but an NMR structure determination of a mouse PrP fragment spanning residues 121-231 represents an important step forward (37 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	71	 However, this structure lacks a highly conserved hydrophobic region (106-126), which contains several of the known pathogenic human mutations, as well as the N-terminal octapeptide repeat region, expansion of which by integral numbers of repeat elements results in a group of inherited prion diseases.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The conformation of this repeat region has been studied by circular dichroism and appears to form an extended, flexible domain with properties similar to the poly-L-proline type II helix (38 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	73	 It has been hypothesised that this may form a low specificity binding domain.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	74	Despite the wealth of evidence indicating the central role of PrP in these diseases, its normal cellular function remains unclear.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Mice homozygous for PrP null alleles appear to develop and behave normally (39 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Such mice are completely resistant to developing prion disease following inoculation and do not propagate infectivity (40 ,41 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	77	 However, electrophysiological studies have demonstrated impaired GABAA mediated synaptic inhibition in hippocampal brain slices maintained in vitro and also reduced long-term potentiation (42 ), an abnormality independently confirmed in a different PrP knockout line (43 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	78	 However, others have failed to replicate this finding, albeit using different techniques and experimental conditions (44 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	79	 That this phenotype is rescued by expression of human PrP in such mice confirmed its specificity for PrP (45 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	80	 These abnormalities of synaptic inhibition are reminiscent of the neurophysiological abnormalities seen in patients with CJD and in scrapie infected mice (46 ), raising the possibility that prion neurodegeneration may be, at least in part, due to loss of PrP function rather than to a deleterious effect of PrPSc (42 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The relative normality of PrP null mice, which do not develop progressive neurodegeneration, could result from effective adaptive changes during neurodevelopment.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	82	 It is possible that the sequestration of PrPC into PrPSc during prion disease in a developed nervous system lacking such plasticity has more severe consequences.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Certainly, PrPSc does not appear to be toxic to cells lacking PrPC (47 ) and PrPSc is difficult to detect in some cases of the inherited human prion disease fatal familial insomnia (FFI) (48 ), and in transgenic mice infected experimentally with FFI (49 ), suggesting that, at least in these cases, neurodegeneration may not be the result of PrPSc toxicity.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	84	 According to such a model, the gain of function implied by the autosomal dominant mode of inheritance could reflect the formation of PrPSc which then functionally depletes PrPC by a dominant negative effect.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	85	Two additional phenotypes have now been described in PrP null mice, abnormalities of circadian rhythms (50 ) and cerebellar Purkinje cell degeneration (51 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Further neurophysiological abnormalities in the hippocampus of PrP null mice, including disrupted Ca2+-activated K+ currents and abnormal intrinsic properties of CA1 pyramidal cells have recently been reported (52 ,53 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and the `new variant' putatively linked to BSE.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	88	Extensive epidemiological studies of CJD have been performed in a number of countries and all obtained broadly similar results (35 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The overall annual incidence in most studies was ~1 case per million.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	90	 No significant case clustering is present other than with respect to familial clusters.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Cases are distributed apparently at random with a frequency related only to local population density.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In particular, there is no evidence for case-to-case spread or association with local scrapie prevalence.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	93	 For instance, CJD is as common in Australia and New Zealand, which have been scrapie free for many years, as in the UK where scrapie is endemic.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Numerous case control studies have not shown consistent associations with particular occupational groups or dietary components.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	95	The core clinical syndrome of CJD is of a rapidly progressive dementia usually with myoclonus.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The onset is usually in the 45-75 year age group with peak onset between 60-65.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Sporadic CJD is exceedingly rare in individuals under age 30.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The clinical progression is typically over weeks progressing to akinetic mutism and death often in 2-3 months.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Around 70% of cases die in under 6 months.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	100	However, in late 1995 two cases of sporadic CJD were reported in the UK in teenagers (54 ,55 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Only four cases of sporadic CJD had previously been recorded in the literature in teenagers, and none of these cases occurred in the UK.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In addition, both cases were unusual in having kuru-type plaques, a finding seen in only ~5% of CJD cases.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Soon afterwards a third very young sporadic CJD case occurred (56 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	104	 These cases caused considerable concern and the possibility was raised that they might suggest a link with BSE.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	105	 By March 1996, further extremely young onset cases were apparent and review of the histology of these cases showed a remarkably consistent and unique pattern (57 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	106	 These cases were named `new variant' CJD although it was clear that they were also rather atypical in their clinical presentation; in fact most cases did not meet the accepted clinical diagnostic criteria for probable CJD (57 ) and, in some respects at least, clinically more closely resembled kuru (58 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Extensive studies of archival cases of CJD or other prion diseases failed to show this picture and it seemed that this did represent the arrival of a new form of prion disease in the UK.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The statistical probability of such cases occurring by chance was vanishingly small and ascertainment bias seemed most unlikely as an explanation.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	109	 It was clear that a new risk factor for CJD had emerged and appeared to be specific to the UK.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The UK Government advisory committee on spongiform encephalopathy (SEAC) concluded that, while there was no direct evidence for a link with BSE, exposure to specified bovine offal (SBO) prior to the ban on its inclusion in human foodstuffs in 1989, was the most likely explanation.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	111	 A case of the new variant was reported in France soon after (59 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	112	 PRNP analysis showed that all cases available for study were homozygous, for methionine at codon 129, and that no known or novel pathogenic mutations were found in PRNP coding sequence (60 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Recently, transmission of BSE to three macaques has been reported, with production of histopathological appearances that are closely similar to the very unusual pattern of pathology seen in new variant CJD (61 ), providing further evidence that these cases may result from BSE transmission.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	114	 However, detailed comparisons with transmissions of typical CJD cases to macaques will be needed to fully evaluate the significance of this finding.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	115	If these cases do represent transmission of BSE to humans it is unclear why none had a pattern of unusual occupational or dietary exposure to BSE; it is possible that they represent a genetically susceptible sub-population.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	116	 In addition, it is unknown why this age group should be particularly affected.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, little is known about which foodstuffs contained high-titre bovine offal.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	118	 It is possible that certain foods containing particularly high titres were eaten predominately by younger people.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	119	 It is also possible that children have an inherently higher intrinsic susceptibility or shorter incubation period following dietary exposure to the BSE agent.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Possibilities might include, for example, differences in gut permeability or lymphoreticular system or higher PrP expression levels.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	121	Direct experimental evidence that new variant CJD may be caused by BSE was provided by molecular analysis of human prion strains (PrPSc typing) (see below).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The identification of a biochemical marker that distinguished new variant CJD from previously recognised forms of sporadic and iatrogenic CJD confirmed that this was a novel variant and implied that it was caused by exposure to a single novel prion strain type (62 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The lack of any history of iatrogenic exposure to humans in these patients suggested that this was a novel animal prion.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The molecular strain characteristics of new variant CJD closely resembled those seen in BSE itself and BSE transmitted to mice, domestic cat and macaque, consistent with BSE being the origin of new variant CJD (62 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Such PrPSc markers are detectable in tonsil (63 ), which may allow pre-mortem diagnosis of new variant CJD without brain biopsy, and may potentially allow earlier diagnosis.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	126	Experimental transmission studies of the human prion diseases have, until recently, largely involved transmission to laboratory primates, in particular chimpanzees and squirrel monkeys.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The extensive experience of the NIH group, reporting >300 successful transmissions has recently been summarised (64 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	128	 However, transmission studies in primates are severely limited by the expense of such studies and by ethical concerns as to the use of primates in such work.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Attempts by most laboratories to transmit human prions to rodents have been fairly unsuccessful, with only occasional transmissions occurring and then at very prolonged incubation periods close to the natural lifespan of the mice.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Some groups have, however, reported more frequent transmissions (65 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Recently transgenic mice have become available which have increased susceptibility to human prions.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Mice expressing a chimaeric human/mouse PrP were susceptible to three CJD isolates with short incubation periods (66 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	133	 It has now become clear that transgenic mice expressing wild-type human PrP, but not mouse PrP, are highly susceptible to CJD, with all inoculated mice succumbing at short incubation periods usually in the range of 180-220 days (67 ,68 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Such mice appear to lack a species barrier to human prions and can now be used for extensive studies of the transmission characteristics of human prion diseases and to bioassay human prions (68 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Molecular basis of prion strains.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	136	A major problem for the `protein-only' hypothesis of prion propagation has been how to explain the existence of multiple isolates or strains of prions.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Such strains are distinguished by their biological properties: they produce distinct incubation periods and patterns of neuropathological targeting in inbred mouse lines.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	138	 As they can be serially propagated in inbred mice with the same Prn-p genotype they cannot be encoded by differences in PrP primary structure.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Furthermore, strains can be re-isolated in mice after passage in intermediate species with different PrP primary structures (69 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Understanding how a protein-only infectious agent could encode such phenotypic information has been of considerable biological interest.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	141	Support for the contention that strain specificity is encoded by PrP alone is provided by study of two distinct strains of transmissible mink encephalopathy prions which can be serially propagated in hamsters, designated hyper (HY) and drowsy (DY) (70 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	142	 These strains can be distinguished by differing physiochemical properties of the accumulated PrPSc in the brains of affected hamsters (71 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Following limited proteolysis, strain specific migration patterns of PrPSc on polyacrylamide gels can be seen.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	144	 DY PrPSc appears to be more protease sensitive than HY PrPSc producing a different banding pattern of PrPSc on Western blots following proteinase K treatment.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	145	 This relates to different N-terminal ends of HY and DY PrPSc following protease treatment and implies differing conformations of HY and DY PrPSc (72 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Furthermore, the demonstration that these strain specific physiochemical properties can be maintained during in vitro production of protease resistant PrP, when PrPC is mixed with HY or DY hamster PrPSc, further supports the concept that prion strains involve different PrP conformers (73 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	147	Recently, several human PrPSc types have been identified which are associated with different phenotypes of CJD (62 ,74 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The different fragment sizes seen on Western blots following treatment with proteinase K suggests that there are several different human PrPSc conformations.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	149	 However, to fulfil the criteria of strains, these patterns must be transmissible to animals both in same and in different species.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Remarkably, this is the case, with both PrPSc fragment sizes and the ratios of the three PrP glycoforms (diglycosylated, monoglycosylated and unglycosylated PrP) maintained on passage in transgenic mice expressing human PrP (62 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Transmission of human prions and bovine prions to wild-type mice results in murine PrPSc with fragment sizes and glycoform ratios which correspond to the original inoculum (62 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	152	 New variant CJD is associated with PrPSc glycoform ratios which are distinct from those seen in classical CJD.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Similar ratios are seen in BSE and BSE when transmitted to several other species (62 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	154	 These data strongly support the `protein only' hypothesis of infectivity and suggest that strain variation is encoded by a combination of PrP conformation and glycosylation.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Transmission of PrPSc fragment sizes from two different sub-types of inherited prion disease to transgenic mice expressing a chimaeric human mouse PrP has also been reported (75 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	156	 As PrP glycosylation is thought to be a co-translational process, the different glycoform ratios may represent selection of particular PrPC glycoforms by PrPSc of different conformations.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	157	 According to such a hypothesis, PrP conformation would be the primary determinant of strain type with glycosylation being involved as a secondary process.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	158	 However, since it is known that different cell types may glycosylate proteins differently, PrPSc glycosylation patterns may provide a substrate for the neuropathological targeting that distinguishes different prion strains.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Particular PrPSc glycoforms may replicate most favourably in neuronal populations with a similar PrP glycoform expressed on the cell surface.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Such targeting could also explain the different incubation periods which also discriminate strains, targeting of more critical brain regions, or regions with higher levels of PrP expression, producing shorter incubation periods.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	161	Such studies may allow a new molecular classification of human prion diseases; it is likely that additional PrPSc types or strains will be identified.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	162	 This may well open new avenues of epidemiological investigation and offer insights into causes of `sporadic' CJD.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	163	 In addition, PrPSc typing can be applied to other species; it is already apparent that PrP glycoform analysis alone can distinguish a number of mouse passaged scrapie strains (76 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The combination of fragment size and glycoform analysis should allow better resolution and might be applied, for instance, to study if BSE has transmitted to other species involved in the human diet such as sheep.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	165	 It will be necessary to study the full range of sheep strains to determine whether these can all be distinguished at a molecular level from BSE, it is possible that more refined molecular techniques may be necessary (77 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Classical strain typing, involving mouse transmissions, takes 1-2 years and can only be applied to limited numbers of cases.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Molecular strain typing takes days and allows large scale screening.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	168	The ability of a protein to encode a disease phenotype has important implications in biology, as it represents a non-Mendelian form of transmission.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	169	 It would be surprising, and also itself intriguing, if evolution had not used this mechanism for other proteins in a range of species.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The recent identification of prion-like mechanisms in yeast is particularly interesting in this regard (78 ,79 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Bovine to human species barrier.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	172	As BSE appears to have transmitted to humans, a key issue is the extent of the bovine to human species barrier.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Clearly, this cannot be measured directly since this would require inoculation of humans with BSE.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	174	 However, transgenic models may offer a way to address this issue, at least in part.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The principal determinants of the `species barrier' are the degree of homology between PrP molecules in the host and inoculum (32 ) and strain of agent; however, BSE appears to be caused by a single prion strain (69 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Transgenic mice expressing human PrP, which are competent to produce human PrPSc and `human' prions on CJD challenge, offer an opportunity to address the issue as to whether it is possible for bovine prions to induce production of human PrPSc.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	177	 To date results are reassuring.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Incubation periods to BSE were unaltered in mice expressing human PrP in addition to mouse PrP, and only mouse PrPSc appeared to be produced (68 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	179	 A potentially more revealing experiment is to challenge mice expressing only human PrP with BSE (68 ).
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	180	 No transmission occurred at incubation periods well beyond those of CJD in these mice (68 ); it remains to be seen if transmission will occur at longer incubation periods.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	181	 These mice express valine at polymorphic codon 129 of PRNP and these studies are being repeated with mice transgenic for human PrP methionine 129.
0.1370075.9300662.html.plaintext.txt	182	 This is of particular importance given that all new variant CJD cases seen to date are methionine 129 homozygotes.
