0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	0	The Residue 129 Polymorphism in Human Prion Protein Does Not Confer Susceptibility to Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease by Altering the Structure or Global Stability of PrPC* Laszlo L.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Trevitt, Samantha Jones, Mark Batchelor, Daljit Bhelt, Kanella Prodromidou, Anthony R.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Medical Research Council Prion Unit, Department of Neurodegenerative Disease, Institute of Neurology, University College London, Queen Square, London, WC1N 3BG, United Kingdom and Krebs Institute for Biomolecular Research, Department of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, University of Sheffield, Sheffield S10 2TN, United Kingdom.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, December 16, 2003 , and in revised form, March 24, 2004.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	4	According to the "protein-only" hypothesis (6), prions are composed principally or entirely of abnormal isoforms of host-encoded prion protein (PrP) (7).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The disease-related isoform, PrPSc, is derived from its normal cellular precursor, PrPC, by a post-translational process that involves conformational change.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	6	 PrPSc can be distinguished biochemically from PrPC by its partial protease resistance and detergent insolubility.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	7	Although the precise molecular events involved in this conversion remain ill defined, molecular genetic and in vitro studies support the hypothesis that some sort of direct interaction between PrPSc and either PrPC or some less organized state occurs.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	8	 This interaction results in the PrPSc conformation being imposed upon the substrate protein, and the process of conversion is favored by sequence complementarity (8 to 13).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	9	 A key piece of evidence supporting this and the protein-only hypothesis in general is the finding that the large majority of cases of sporadic CJD are homozygous with respect to a common polymorphism at position 129 in the human prion protein, in which either methionine or valine can be encoded (only 49% of the UK population are homozygous with respect to this polymorphism) (9).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	10	Elderly survivors of the kuru epidemic (an acquired prion disease largely restricted to the Fore linguistic group of the Papua New Guinea Highlands, which was transmitted during endocannibalistic feasts) who had multiple exposures at mortuary feasts, are, in marked contrast to younger unexposed Fore, predominantly PRNP 129 heterozygotes.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Kuru imposed strong balancing selection on the Fore, essentially eliminating PRNP 129 homozygotes.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	12	 World-wide PRNP haplotype diversity and coding allele frequencies have suggested that strong balancing selection at this locus occurred during the evolution of modern humans (14).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	13	This polymorphism is crucial to the etiology and neuropathology of prion disease; to date, only individuals homozygous for methionine (Met/Met) have succumbed to variant CJD (3, 15, 16), and iatrogenic CJD occurs predominately in homozygotes with an excess of valine homozygotes in cases related to exposure to contaminated human pituitary hormones (17).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The importance of sequence homology is further emphasized by the observation that in some families with inherited prion diseases, the age of onset is significantly later in individuals heterozygous to this polymorphism (18 to 21).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Thus, heterozygosity with respect to this polymorphism appears to confer substantial resistance to prion disease.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	16	Perhaps more fundamentally, this polymorphism is also associated with the propagation of distinct human prion "isolates" or strains seen in different CJD phenotypes.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Prion strains can be distinguished by their biological properties: distinct incubation periods, clinical features, and pattern of neuropathological targeting in experimental animals.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	18	 It is now apparent that human prion strains are associated with the different biochemical features of PrPSc, with differences in PrPSc conformation and glycosylation that can be serially propagated in transgenic mice expressing human PrP (3, 5).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The residue 129 HuPrP polymorphism appears to be able to affect the generation of these strain-specific PrPSc conformers and by inference the phenotype of human prion disease (22, 23).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Such phenotypic effects of this polymorphism are also seen in inherited prion disease associated with the D178N mutation in PRNP, where this mutation may result in the phenotype of CJD or fatal familial insomnia, depending on the 129 genotype of the mutant allele (24).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	21	Further, there are multiple distinct molecular forms of human PrPSc identified by molecular strain-typing studies (5, 22, 25, 26).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	22	 These are thought to represent distinct conformational states of PrPSc that differ in either the fold of the individual polypeptide chains or in the manner in which the chains are packed in a multimolecular complex or both.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These states are manifested at the molecular level by (a) their response to cleavage by proteinase K and subsequent sizing of the resistant segment of polypeptide chain by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and (b) the ratio of diglycosylated, monoglycosylated, and unglycosylated forms found in the protease-resistant PrPSc material.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	24	 These PrPSc types are associated with distinct clinico-pathological phenotypes in affected patients.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Types 1 to 3 are associated with classical CJD, whereas variant CJD is only associated with the type 4 strain (5).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The propagation of these strain types is highly dependent upon the codon 129 genotype and hence the primary structure of the prion protein.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	27	 For instance, the type 1 strain is only seen in methionine homozygotes, whereas the type 3 strain has not been seen on this genetic background.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Most strikingly, variant CJD has only been seen to date in homozygous MM individuals.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	29	This polymorphism is thus fundamental to prion disease in humans, and therefore an understanding of its influence on PrP folding may provide strong clues as to the molecular mechanisms that underlie prion propagation.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Current theories concentrate on the differing abilities for methionine or valine to be accommodated within -sheet structure or the thermodynamic stabilities of both forms of PrPC, both of which are thought to affect the propensity of PrPC to convert to PrPSc (17, 27, 28).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	31	As a first step in characterizing this polymorphism, its effect on the three-dimensional structure of the valine form of PrPC has been determined.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Here we describe the influence of the polymorphism on the fold stability, solution dynamics, and unfolding characteristics of the normal cellular form of prion protein (PrPC).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	33	The ligated pTrcHisB/PRNP construct was used to transform the Escherichia coli host strain BL21(DE3) (Novagen), genotype F' ompT hsdSB (rB- mB-) gal dcm (DE3), which was then plated onto Luria-Bertoni (LB) agar plates containing 100  microg/ml carbenicillin.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Following sequence verification that clones contained the correct construct, cultures were grown for purification using a modification of protocols previously described (29).

0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The loop comprising residues 167 to 171 is characterized by extensive line broadening of NMR signals.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	98	 This has been reported for a number of prion proteins from different species and is due to conformational exchange between two or more backbone conformations, on the millisecond time scale, which results in broadening of NMR signals.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The lack of definition observed within the NMR ensemble for this region of the protein is thus due to lack of constraints, as well as conformational averaging.

0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	110	 These regions comprise loop 167 to 171, and the C termini of helices II and III, regions for which the greatest conformational variability is also observed, as discussed above.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Therefore, the degree of structural definition for these regions of the protein is rather limited.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	112	View larger version (29K):    FIG.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Comparison of the secondary structure and side chain packing of residue 129 in HuPrP(129V) (yellow), HuPrP(129M) (red) (NMR structure) (51), HuPrP(129M) (crystal structure) (green) (52), and sheep prion protein (crystal structure) (blue) (49).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Coordinates for the huPrP(129M) NMR and crystal structures were obtained from the Protein Data Bank (accession codes 1QM0 [PDB] .
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	115	pdb respectively), whereas the coordinates for sheep prion protein were very kindly provided by G.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Dodson in advance of publication.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	117	 A, superposition of secondary structure elements.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The position of residue 129 is marked with a sphere.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Residues 187 to 195 have been removed from the backbone trace of the HuPrP(129M) crystal structure, since this region is perturbed in the three-dimensional domain-swapped dimer).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	120	 B, comparison of side chain packing and hydrogen bonding surrounding the residue 129 polymorphism.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Backbone traces of residues 127 to 131, 160 to 165, and 176 to 180 are shown together with the side chains of Tyr128, Met/Val129, Arg164, and Asp178.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	122	  The site surrounding the polymorphism is better defined, allowing a detailed examination of the effect of the methionine to valine substitution at position 129 (Fig.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	123	 For this, we have compared the HuPrP(129V) NMR structure with the high resolution crystal structures of human (52) and sheep prion protein (49), as well as the HuPrP(129M) NMR structure, all of which contain methionine at position 129.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Overall, the region surrounding the polymorphism is remarkably similar between the two forms (Fig.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The methionine and valine side chains are well defined in the NMR structure ensemble, and both occupy similar spatial regions, with no significant deformation of the residues surrounding the polymorphism site with either residue.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	126	 This is of particular interest, since a D178N mutation is associated with a clinico-pathological phenotype of FFI when residue 129 is methionine and of CJD when it is valine.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	127	 It has been proposed that the side chains of residues 129 and 178 interact via hydrogen bonds between the side chains of Tyr128, Arg164, and Asp178 (24, 53) (although in the averaged NMR structure of HuPrP(129M), the side chain of Arg164 is not in a position to accomplish this (51)).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The side chains of these residues are well defined in the HuPrP(129V) NMR structure, and NOEs between the backbone and side chain resonances of residues 128, 129, 164, and 178 are observed.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	129	 From the distribution of conformations within the NMR ensemble, it is not possible to determine unambiguously whether the side chains of Tyr128, Arg164, and Asp178 are hydrogen-bonded to each other, but these residues are sufficiently close in individual members of the ensemble for this hydrogen-bonding to be present.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Hence, the close association of the side chains of residues 128, 164, and 178 is maintained in both polymorphs, and there does not appear to be a significant disruption of the hydrogen-bonding network surrounding residue 129 (Fig.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	131	 This conclusion is further supported by amide exchange and chemical shift data described below.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Thus, the effect of residue 129 in the D178N mutation does not appear to be resolvable through examination of the structure surrounding the polymorphism.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	133	Fold Stability and Partially Unfolded Species Populated by HuPrP Polymorphs Although the three-dimensional structures of the HuPrP polymorphs appear very similar, it is entirely possible that either may access, to varying degrees, alternatively folded states involved in the disease process.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	134	 To assess this, the folding behavior of both species was determined in detail.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	135	First, the equilibrium unfolding behavior of both polymorphs was examined; the equilibrium denaturation profiles of both species are shown in Fig.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The amide and aromatic CD curves show that both molecules denature in a single co-operative transition, without the formation of any populated intermediate species during equilibrium unfolding.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The equilibrium constant between the native and unfolded states derived from these unfolding curves for both proteins are, within error, the same, at 5000.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	138	 This finding is similar to that obtained when the methionine of the mouse prion protein is substituted with valine (54).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	139	View larger version (18K):    FIG.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	140	 A, equilibrium denaturation curves of HuPrP(129V) and HuPrP(129M), as measured by amide CD absorption at 222 nm.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The lines superimposed upon the data are fits to Equation 1.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	142	 B, amide protection factors (kex/kint) in HuPrP(129M) and HuPrP(129V) for those residues with measurable protection.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	143	 (Those additional residues that appear protected in HuPrP(129V) are due to peak overlap in HuPrP(129M), which precluded measurement of those peaks.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	144	) The protection factor corresponding with the equilibrium constant between the native (N) and unfolded (U) states of the protein is plotted as a dashed line (log10K(N/U)).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Regions of highest protection surround the disulfide bond that links helices II and III and that forms a core of residual structure in what is believed to be the unfolded state of the protein.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	146	 C, chemical shift differences of C nuclei between HuPrP(129V) and HuPrP(129M) at pH 5.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Regions of secondary structure in HuPrP are denoted by arrows (-strands) and cylinders (-helices).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The chemical shift differences of residue 129 have been corrected for the intrinsic chemical shift differences of methionine and valine in an extended -strand (60).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	149	  Although this indicates that both proteins have the same overall stability for the folded state and that the residue 129 polymorphism does not appear to be acting on prion disease by altering the fold stability of PrPC, this does not exclude the possibility of other folding intermediates that are transiently populated in the folding process being present to differing degrees in both forms of the protein.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	150	To investigate this, the rates of hydrogen/deuterium exchange for backbone amide resonances were determined, which has been used to identify regions of the protein that remain hydrogen-bonded until the protein becomes unfolded (Fig.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The observed amide exchange protection data shows that the stabilities of secondary structure elements are very similar in both polymorphs.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The regions of highest stability within both forms of the protein are located in the three helical regions of the protein that associate to form the core of the molecule.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	153	 For both forms of PrPC, the protection factors show the stability of these secondary structure elements to be equivalent to the equilibrium constant between native and unfolded states of the protein.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The only regions of the protein where this is not the case are the region centered around the disulfide bond that links helices 2 and 3 and the first strand of the -sheet, where the polymorphism resides.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The former displays anomalously high protection factors, due to residual local structure in the unfolded state of the protein (55).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The latter region, however, displays protection factors that are below the detectable limit (50 under the conditions of the present experiment).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	157	 However, protection factors for residues 161 and 163, which are on the other strand of the -sheet, exhibit similar protection factors in both forms of PrPC.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Thus, although we can say that substitution of valine for methionine has not significantly increased the stability of hydrogen bonds surrounding residue 129 to a level where protection is observable (50), it does not appear to have significantly affected the stability of hydrogen bonds associated with the opposite side of the -sheet.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	159	 We can therefore conclude that for both forms of HuPrP, there are no significantly populated species, either folding intermediates or alternatively folded states in which the three helical and second -strand core of the protein is disrupted, and that the effect of the polymorphism on PrPC (if any) is likely to be outside of this core region.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	160	Some secondary structure elements of the protein show very little protection from exchange.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	161	 For example, the C-terminal regions of helix II (residues 186 to 194) and helix III (residues 219 to 226) and the first strand of the -sheet exhibit protection factors below the detectable limit, consistent with a significant level of conformational flexibility in these regions of the protein.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In the case of the -sheet, this conclusion is supported by weak, broadened 1H15N HSQC signals observed from this region (residues 129 to 131 and 161 to 164), whereas for the helical regions, although downfield-shifted C chemical shifts characteristic of -helical structure are observed, the downfield shift is reduced, consistent with these regions being in equilibrium with more unfolded structures (data not shown).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	163	The higher conformational variability in the C termini of these helices in comparison with the core of the protein is further supported by small chemical shift differences between the M and V polymorphs.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	164	 These chemical shift differences are small but lie outside the uncertainty in measurement.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The changes in C chemical shifts indicate that there is a slight stabilization of the C terminus of helix III, and destabilization of the C terminus of Helix II in HuPrP(129V) compared with HuPrP(129M).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	166	 In previous studies, chemical shift differences in these regions of the protein between different PrP constructs have been variously ascribed to small pH differences between samples or to transient interactions between the folded domain and the unstructured N terminus of the protein (51, 56).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The chemical shift differences observed here lie outside those caused by uncertainty in the precise pH of the solutions and indicate a difference in the distribution of stability throughout the molecule, implying a possible role for the polymorphism.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Chemical shift changes immediately adjacent to the polymorphism are, however, harder to interpret, since there are inevitably changes that are associated with the change in chemical composition.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Indeed, the sequence surrounding a residue can cause a change in C chemical shift on the order of  plus or minus 0.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	170	3 ppm in unfolded proteins, which is larger than the chemical shift changes observed adjacent to the polymorphism (57).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Any changes in conformation reported by these chemical shift perturbations are small, since they do not affect the observed structure or stability of the protein and reflect small changes in the population distribution of the structural ensemble, which fall within the resolution of the solution structure.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	172	Spin Relaxation Measurements In order to further characterize the conformational dynamics of both polymorphs and in particular the regions of low amide protection and conformational variability, both constructs were probed using 15N spin relaxation measurements (Fig.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	173	 4), which provide information on flexibility within the protein.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The steady-state 15N{1H} NOEs and the longitudinal and transverse relaxation times (T1 (15N) and T2 (15N)) for the folded, well defined, regions of HuPrP(129V) are characteristic of a globular protein of this size.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	175	 In particular, residues within the -sheet region, where the polymorphism resides, do not exhibit dynamic properties significantly different from the rest of the protein, despite the low amide protection factors and broadened 15N1H HSQC signals.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Residues 190 to 199, however, which link helices II and III, display smaller but still positive 15N{1H} NOE values (and slightly increased T2 values), indicating that these residues are indeed relatively more flexible than the structured parts of the protein, resulting in the decreased definition in the NMR structure ensemble for this region.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The degree of flexibility for this region is still significantly less than the N and C termini of the protein (residues 91 to 124 and 227 to 231), which display large negative 15N{1H} NOE values indicative of molecular motions on the subnanosecond time scale, consistent with previous observations that they are unstructured.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The increased flexibility within the C terminus of helix III appears to extend to residue 220 and is consistent with the lack of amide exchange and the reduced downfield C chemical shifts.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	179	View larger version (24K):    FIG.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Dynamics data used to assess the mobility of the globular region of HuPrP(129V) and HuPrP(129M).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Regions of secondary structure are denoted by arrows (-strands) and cylinders (-helices) in the top panel.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Top, longitudinal 15N spin relaxation times (T1).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Middle, transverse 15N spin relaxation times (T2).
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Bottom, steady-state 15N{1H} NOE data.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	185	  Overall, the spin relaxation properties of both polymorphs are very similar.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In particular, the region surrounding the residue 129 polymorphism shows remarkably little difference in spin relaxation values for both constructs, with slight changes in the 15N{1H} NOE for HuPrP(129V) suggestive of only a slight increase in conformational mobility surrounding the polymorphism.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	187	The above arguments establish the general point that the residue 129 polymorphism confers different molecular properties on the prion protein and that these properties strongly influence both susceptibility to disease and the conformation of PrPSc.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	188	 It follows that an understanding of the mechanism underlying this methionine/valine effect would provide valuable insights into the process by which the cellular conformation of the protein is converted to the disease-related PrPSc state.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	189	 To this end, we addressed the question of whether the influence of the M and V residues at this position results from changes in the conformation and stability of PrPC.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Our results establish a close similarity of the valine and methionine forms of the protein in the PrPC conformation.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	191	 No obvious effect on the side chain packing or dynamics in the region surrounding the mutation are discernible in the structural ensemble calculated from NOE-derived constraints, and chemical shift data for this region also show remarkably little difference between the two sequences.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	192	 In addition, the polymorphism does not affect the global stability of the molecule, as evidenced by the lack of effect on the denaturant-induced unfolding transition and on the hydrogen exchange behavior.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The latter measurements also probe the propensity for local regions of the protein to unfold or for the protein to adopt less stable, alternative conformations.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	194	 In these respects, also, the methionine and valine forms behave identically.
0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	195	From these observations, it seems likely that the influence of residue 129 on prion disease results from its effect on the conformational properties of PrPSc, such that the type 1 and type 4 conformations are formed only by the methionine variant, whereas type 3 is favored by valine and the type 2 conformation is formed equally well by either.

0.13729805.15123682.html.plaintext.txt	203	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We are grateful to Ray Young for assistance in the preparation of figures for this manuscript and to Guy Dodson for access to a presubmission manuscript.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	0	MINIREVIEW Molecular Genetics of Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathies* Charles Weissmann.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Institut fur Molekularbiologie der Universitat Zurich, Abteilung I, Winterthurerstrasse 190, 8057 Zurich, Switzerland.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	2	Transmissible spongiform encephalopathies are degenerative disorders of the central nervous system that occur naturally in man and in a variety of other animals.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	3	 They include scrapie of sheep and goats, bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE)1 in cattle, and several human diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker syndrome (GSS), and fatal familial insomnia (FFI).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Since its first recognition in 1986, BSE reached epidemic proportions in the UK (1), and there is substantial evidence that a new variant of CJD may be because of consumption of BSE-contaminated products (2).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	5	The unusual properties of the transmissible agent, or prion, early on suggested that it might be devoid of nucleic acid (3).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Currently, the most widely accepted proposal is the "protein only" hypothesis, first outlined in general terms by Griffith (4) and enunciated in its updated and detailed form by Prusiner (5, 6).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	7	 It proposes that the prion is identical with a conformational isoform of PrPC (5), a normal host protein (7-9) found predominantly on the outer surface of neurons.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Introduction of the abnormal conformer into the organism would result in the conversion of PrPC into a likeness of itself (Fig.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	9	View larger version (47K):    Fig.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	10	 A, in the normal cell PrPC is synthesized, transported to the cell surface and recycled.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	11	 B, the protein only model assumes that the prion is identical with PrPSc (or PrP*).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Exogenous prions cause the conversion of the normal cellular protein PrPC into PrPSc, either at the cell surface or after internalization.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	13	 C, PrPSc accumulates intracellularly in late endosomes or lysosomes, and the cell surface is depleted of PrPC.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	14	 PrPSc is also released into the extracellular space.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	15	During the course of prion disease, a largely protease-resistant, aggregated form of PrP, designated PrPSc, accumulates mainly in brain (7, 10).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Prusiner and co-workers (11) proposed that PrPSc is the main or only constituent of the prion.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Because no chemical differences were found between PrPC and PrPSc, the two species are believed to differ in their conformation.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The three-dimensional structure of PrPC has been elucidated (12) but not that of PrPSc; however, the -sheet content of PrPSc was found to be high whereas that of PrPC is low (13).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Because the ratio of infectious units to PrPSc molecules is only about 1:100,000 (14), the structure of the PrP molecule actually associated with infectivity cannot be definitively inferred.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	20	 For this reason the PrP species responsible for infectivity is presently better designated as PrP* (15).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The conclusion that some form of PrP is the essential (perhaps only) constituent of the infectious agent is based on compelling biochemical and genetical evidence (5, 16).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	22	     Familial Spongiform Encephalopathies Are Associated with Mutations in the PrP Gene.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	23	Although most cases of human prion disease are sporadic, about 10% are familial and linked to one of a number of mutations in the PrP gene (Fig.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	24	 It is believed that these mutations allow spontaneous conversion of PrPC into PrPSc with a frequency sufficient to cause disease within the lifetime of the individual (5, 19).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Sporadic CJD could be attributed to rare instances of spontaneous conversion of PrPC into PrPSc or rare somatic mutations in the Prnp gene.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	26	 In both cases the initial conversion would be followed by autocatalytic propagation.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Mice overexpressing a murine PrP transgene with a mutation corresponding to the human GSS mutation Pro-102  Leu spontaneously contract a lethal scrapie-like disease, and it has been reported that this disease can be transmitted to mice expressing the same mutant transgene at lower levels, which do not lead to spontaneous disease (20, 21).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	28	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	29	   Mutations of the PrP gene are associated with prion diseases.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The top rectangle represents the coding region of the human PrP gene; the hatched green areas indicate the amino- and carboxyl-terminal signal sequences, and the five dark green boxes (R) are the "octa repeats," sequences of 8 amino acids.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The red arrows indicate amino acid replacements in individual mutant PrP genes.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The diseases associated with these mutations are given in blue (CJD, GSS, FFI).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The Met-129  Val replacement represents a polymorphism, which in itself is not associated with disease; however, it modifies the effects of the Asp-178  Asn mutation, such that when the latter is combined with Met-129 it is associated with FFI and when combined with Val-129 it is associated with CJD.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Amplification of the number of octa repeats has been found in cases of familial CJD and GSS.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	35	     Mice Devoid of PrPC Are Resistant to Scrapie.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	36	The "protein only" hypothesis predicts that in the absence of PrPC mice should be resistant to scrapie and fail to multiply the infectious agent.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Mice devoid of PrP (Prnpo/o) were generated by homologous recombination and found to be essentially normal (22).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	38	 When challenged with mouse prions, mice devoid of PrP were completely protected against scrapie disease, and prions failed to accumulate in spleen and brain, in contrast to wild-type mice (23, 24).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Introduction of murine Prnp transgenes into Prnpo/o mice resulted in several lines with varying expression levels of PrPC, which were susceptible to mouse prions; the higher the PrPC content of the brain, the shorter the incubation times (25).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	40	The demonstration that disruption of the PrP gene confers resistance to scrapie and that reintroduction of a PrP-encoding transgene restores susceptibility paved the way to reverse genetics of PrP, that is the introduction of deletions or mutations into the Prnp gene and determination of the capacity of the modified gene to confer susceptibility to scrapie to a PrP knockout mouse.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Transgenes encoding PrP with deletions extending to codon 93, but not to 106, restored susceptibility to scrapie (25).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	42	2     Transport of Prions from the Periphery to the CNS.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	43	Acquired forms of prion diseases are mostly transmitted through oral uptake of prions or peripheral administration, raising the question as to how the agent finds its way to the CNS.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	44	Prnp+/+ neuroectodermal tissue introduced into the brain of newly born Prnpo/o mice develops into differentiated Prnp+/+ nervous tissue.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Intracerebral inoculation of such engrafted mice leads to typical scrapie pathology in the graft but not in the surrounding Prnpo/o tissue (26).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	46	 However, because intraperitoneal inoculation of these mice does not lead to pathology in the Prnp+/+ graft, transport of prions from the periphery to the CNS is seen to require interposed PrP-bearing tissue (27).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	47	 It has also been shown that Prnp+/+ immunodeficient mice lacking mature B cells fail to transport prions from the periphery to the CNS, suggesting a role of the lymphoreticular system in transport (28).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	48	 It is believed that the follicular dendritic cells, which depend on B cells for their maintenance in a mature state, are the site of prion replication in the spleen (29, 30) and that transport to the CNS is, in addition, dependent on the peripheral nervous system (31).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	49	     The Species Barrier Is Abolished by Introducing the PrP Transgene of the Prion Donor into the Recipient.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	50	Prions are transmitted from one species to another much less efficiently, if at all, than within the same species and only after prolonged incubation times.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	51	 In the case of prion transmission from hamsters to mice, this so-called species barrier was overcome by introducing hamster Prnp transgenes into recipient wild-type mice (32, 33).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Importantly, the properties of the prions produced in these transgenic mice corresponded to the prion species used for inoculation (32), that is infection with hamster prions led to production of hamster prions, but infection with mouse prions gave rise to mouse prions.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Within the framework of the "protein only" hypothesis this means that hamster PrPC but not murine PrPC (which differs from the former by 10 amino acids) is a suitable substrate for conversion to hamster PrPSc by hamster prions and vice versa.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Interestingly, susceptibility of the mouse to prions from other species, such as hamster, mouse, or man, is increased when the PrP transgenes are introduced into a PrP knockout mouse, suggesting that the resident murine gene inhibits the propagation of the alien prions (23).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	55	     The Puzzle of Prion Strains.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	56	Dickinson and colleagues (34, 35) showed that many distinct strains of scrapie prions can be derived from sheep isolates.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	57	 These strains differ by their incubation times in various inbred mouse lines and by the lesion patterns they occasion in the affected brains.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Interestingly, different strains can be propagated in one inbred mouse strain (homozygous with regard to its PrP gene) (35).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Within the framework of the protein only hypothesis this is at first blush puzzling, because it means that one and the same polypeptide chain is able to mediate different strain phenotypes.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The conformational hypothesis proposes that each strain is associated with a different conformation of PrPSc (or PrP*) and that each of these can convert the PrPC of its host into a likeness of itself (19).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Marsh and colleagues (36) showed that the PrPSc species associated with two hamster-adapted scrapie strains, HY and DY, are cleaved to products of different length by proteinase K; the different susceptibility to protease is readily explained by different conformations.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Similar findings were made with other prion strains propagated in the mouse (37, 38).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Moreover, PrPSc of certain strains differ in the ratio of the diglycosylated to the monoglycosylated form (39).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	64	Is it possible that a dozen different strains of prions can differ in regard to the conformation of the PrPSc they are associated with and that all these conformations can "breed true"? It has recently been claimed that PrPSc molecules of as many as eight different strains could be differentiated by virtue of their relative affinity for a monoclonal antibody directed against an epitope that is fully available in PrPC but partially occluded in PrPSc.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	65	 In addition, some strains differed in their susceptibility to denaturation by guanidinium chloride, adding further credibility to the conformational hypothesis of strain specificity (40).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	66	Conversion of PrPC to PrPSc in scrapie-infected cells is a late post-translational process, occurring after PrPC has reached its normal extracellular location or thereafter (41).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Why is spontaneous formation of PrPSc an extremely rare event and how does scrapie infection promote conversion? The "refolding model" (Fig.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	68	 3A) proposes that conversion requires that PrPC be unfolded to some extent and refolded under the influence of a PrPSc molecule (19), a process that would have to overcome a high activation energy barrier and might require a chaperone and an energy source.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	69	 3B) proposes that PrPC is in equilibrium with PrPSc (or a precursor thereof) and that PrPSc is only stabilized when it adds onto a crystal-like seed or aggregate of PrPSc.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	70	 If a stable aggregate needs to consist minimally of a substantial number of PrPSc molecules, then its spontaneous formation would be a very rare event.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	71	 However, once a seed is present, monomer addition could ensue at a rapid rate (42-44).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Trapping of PrP by essentially irreversible aggregation would drive the bulk conversion process.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The proposed process is akin to the assembly of (protease-sensitive) flagellin to (protease-resistant) flagellar filaments (45).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Interestingly, the same flagellin molecule can assemble into two types of flagella, depending on the provenance of the seed (46), thereby providing an analogy for conformationally determined prion strain specificity.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	75	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	76	   Models for the conformational conversion of PrPC to PrPSc.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The conformational change is kinetically controlled, a high activation energy barrier preventing spontaneous conversion at detectable rates.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Interaction with exogenously introduced PrPSc causes PrPC to undergo an induced conformational change to yield PrPSc.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	79	 This reaction may involve extensive unfolding and refolding of the protein to explain the postulated high energy barrier and could be dependent on an enzyme or chaperone.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In the case of certain mutations in PrPC (see Fig.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	81	 2), spontaneous conversion to PrPSc may occur as a rare event, explaining why familial CJD or GSS arises spontaneously, albeit late in life.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Sporadic CJD may come about when an extremely rare event (occurring in one among a million individuals per year) leads to spontaneous conversion of PrPC to PrPSc and gives rise to a conversion cascade (5, 32).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	83	 PrPC and PrPSc (or a PrPSc-like molecule) are in equilibrium strongly favoring PrPC.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	84	 PrPSc is only stabilized when it adds onto a crystal-like seed or aggregate of PrPSc.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Seed formation is a rare event; once a seed is present, monomer addition can ensue at a rapid rate (43, 44).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	86	 To explain exponential conversion rates, it must be assumed that the aggregates are continuously fragmented to present increasing surface for accretion.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	87	Caughey and colleagues (47) have shown that incubation of 35S-labeled PrPC with PrPSc yields a radioactive product that resembled PrPSc with regard to its protease resistance.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The conversion reaction exhibited the "species specificity" observed in vivo; thus PrPC from mouse was readily converted to protease resistance by murine PrPSc but poorly by bovine PrPSc and vice versa (48).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Moreover, even strain specificity has been demonstrated in this type of reaction, in that labeled PrPC incubated with PrPSc from the DY or the HY hamster transmissible mink encephalopathy strains described above yielded labeled PrPSc with the properties typical for the input PrPSc (49).
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Despite efforts by several groups, it has not been possible to demonstrate net synthesis of infectivity over the background given by the PrPSc preparation.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	91	Although each individual piece of evidence described above could be explained in several ways, the conjunction of data strongly supports the proposal that the prion is composed partly or entirely of a PrP-derived molecule (PrP* or PrPSc) and that protein-encoding nucleic acid is not an essential component.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Probably the closest one could come to irrefutable proof for the protein only hypothesis would be the demonstration that biosynthetic, pure PrPC can be converted not only into a protease-resistant form but to infectious scrapie agent under defined conditions in vitro.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	93	Many questions still need to be elucidated, in particular the mechanism and the requirements for the conversion reaction, the transport of the prion from periphery to CNS, and the mechanism of pathogenesis, to name but a few.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	94	 From a practical side, early diagnosis of prion disease and treatments aimed at arresting or reversing the disease in humans are important goals.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	95	Finally one may raise the question whether prion-like agents cause other diseases or appear in non-vertebrate organisms.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Although several human diseases accompanied by amyloid formation are known, none of them have been reproducibly transmitted.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Interestingly, two yeast phenotypes have been ascribed to "heritable protein conversion," namely the [URE3] and the [PSI] systems (50), and have opened new perspectives for the elucidation of this phenomenon.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	98	* This minireview will be reprinted in the 1999 Minireview Compendium, which will be available in December, 1999.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	99	 This is the first article of three in the "Prions of Mammals and Fungi Minireview Series.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	100	To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	101	: 41-1-6353110; Fax: 41-1-6356864; E-mail: weissma{at}molbio.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	102	The abbreviations used are: BSE, bovine spongiform encephalopathy; CJD, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; GSS, Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker syndrome; FFI, fatal familial insomnia; CNS, central nervous system.
0.13843356.9867802.html.plaintext.txt	103	Copyright   1999 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	0	Deciphering synergistic and redundant roles of Hedgehog, Decapentaplegic and Delta that drive the wave of differentiation in Drosophila eye development Weimin Fu* and Nicholas E.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Molecular Genetics, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, NY 10461, USA.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	2	Author for correspondence (e-mail: nbaker{at}aecom.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	3	Key words: Drosophila eye, Morphogenetic furrow, Hedgehog, Decapentaplegic, Notch, Delta.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	4	Progression of the morphogenetic furrow depends primarily on Hedgehog, which is secreted by differentiating photoreceptor neurons.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Hedgehog is necessary for furrow progression (Ma et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Ectopic Hh expression is sufficient to initiate ectopic furrows in the anterior undifferentiated region (Heberlein et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Despite the primary role of Hh, cells unable to receive Hh signals are still able to differentiate because Hh triggers the secretion of secondary signals, and cells unable to respond to Hh still respond to these other signals (Strutt and Mlodzik, 1997).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Dpp is one important secondary signal, and acts redundantly with Hh.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Cells must be able to respond to either Hh or Dpp to begin differentiating (Heberlein et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	10	, 1993; Greenwood and Struhl, 1999; Curtiss and Mlodzik, 2000).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	11	 It has been proposed that Notch signaling also contributes (Baker and Yu, 1997; Li and Baker, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Ectopic Notch and Dpp together can initiate differentiation as effectively as ectopic Hh does (Baonza and Freeman, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	13	In this paper we sought to define the individual roles and interactions of each signal through the study of loss-of-function mutations affecting response to Hh, Dpp or N signals, both alone and in combination.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	14	 We also sought to determine the basis of the redundancy between Hh and Dpp, and how the two signals replace each other, and we investigated whether there is redundancy between Hh and N, and for what events, if any, each signal is individually sufficient in the absence of the others.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	15	Although redundant functions can be studied through ectopic expression experiments, a loss-of-function approach that removes components from the redundant pathways has the advantage of addressing gene function at the normal time and place, and at normal expression levels.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	16	 As each of Hh, Dpp and N signals are important many times during Drosophila development from embryogenesis onwards, it was necessary to use a conditional genetic approach.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	17	 We employed mosaic analysis using the FLP/FRT system to obtain clones of retinal cells lacking function of Hh, Dpp and N pathway components.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Each of these genes also plays roles in the initiation of the morphogenetic furrow at the posterior margin of the eye field, so that furrow initiation fails when eye margin cells are mutated, leaving the region to the anterior undifferentiated (Lee and Treisman, 2002).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The present study is therefore restricted to the progressive onset of differentiation by cells within the retinal field.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	20	Initially, we found that removing Smo did not prevent accumulation of the Ci activator Ci155.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	21	 However, we found that differentiation of Smo-mutant cells depended not on Ci, but on Dpp and N signaling.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Perhaps because Dpp and Hh would otherwise act over different ranges, the pace of furrow progression is constrained by inhibitors, such as Hairy, which are themselves regulated by Dpp, Hh and N.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	23	smo Clones were obtained in: eyF; smo3 FRT40/[armlacZ] FRT40, hsF; smo3 FRT40/[armlacZ] FRT40, hsF; smoD16 FRT40/[armlacZ] FRT40, and y hsF; smo1 FRT42 en /smo3 FRT42 [smo+ hs:Gfp] [ci+]; ci94 /Dp(1;4)y+ spa larvae with equivalent results.

0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	94	  To test whether the smo mutations completely abolished Hh signaling, Ci155 accumulation was examined.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	95	 As well as stimulating Ci155 transcriptional activator activity, Hh causes Ci155 accumulation by preventing SCFSlimb from processing Ci155 to the repressor form Ci75 (Ingham and McMahon, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Ci155 is specifically detected by monoclonal antibody 2A1, which does not recognize Ci75 (Motzny and Holmgren, 1995; Aza-Blanc et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In the smo-mutant cells, Ci155 stabilization was not abolished but only delayed (Dominguez, 1999) (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	98	 As the smo mutations have since been shown to be null (Chen and Struhl, 1998), a slower-acting, smo-independent mechanism of Ci155 stabilization was implied.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Ci155 was later lost from the most posterior margins of smo-mutant clones (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	100	Since smo-mutant cells differentiate in response to Dpp (Greenwood and Struhl, 1999; Curtiss and Mlodzik, 2000), we tested whether Ci155 was being stabilized by Dpp signaling.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Ci155 levels were examined in clones of cells mutant for both smo and tkv, or for both smo and Mad.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	102	 tkv encodes the Type I Dpp receptor, Mad encodes the essential transcription factor target.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Ci155 did not accumulate when both Hh and Dpp signal reception was inactivated, indicating that Dpp signal reception was required to accumulate Ci155 proteins in the absence of Hh signal reception (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	104	 A modest but reproducible reduction in Ci155 levels was seen in cells mutant for tkv alone, indicating that Dpp signaling through Tkv contributes to the level of Ci155, even in the presence of the Hh pathway (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	105	Ci is dispensable Dpp signaling might promote furrow progression and differentiation by regulating Ci155 processing to Ci75, as Hh does.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	106	 If so, ci-mutant cells should resemble cells that are unable to respond to either Hh or Dpp, and thus would be unable to differentiate.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	107	 An alternative model was that Dpp acted independently of its effects on Ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	108	 If so, ci-mutant clones should exhibit delayed differentiation as do clones mutant for smo.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Cells homozygous for a deletion of the ci gene were examined to distinguish between these two models.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	110	Unexpectedly, clones of ci-mutant cells differentiated normally in all respects (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The temporal and spatial pattern of ato expression was completely normal in ci-mutant cells, unlike in cells unable to respond to Hh or in cells unable to respond to Hh or Dpp (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Normal neural differentiation occurred in ci-mutant cells without any delay (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Cells lacking ci were morphologically normal in adults, both externally and on sectioning to reveal differentiated cellular morphology (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	114	 There were no defects in ommatidial chirality or planar polarity.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The genotype of the ci-mutant cells was unequivocally confirmed using antibodies against Ci to detect ci-mutant cells directly (Fig.

0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	135	  Ci75 plays an important role One possibility suggested by these results is a novel pathway of Hh signal transduction that is dependent on smo but not on ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	136	 A second possibility is that Hh signaling is essential only to prevent formation of the repressor protein Ci75.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	137	 If Ci155 was unimportant, deletion of the entire ci gene could mimic Hh signaling, by eliminating Ci75.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	138	If smo signals independently of ci in the eye, smo ci clones should show delayed differentiation like smo clones (e.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	139	 If smo is only essential to eliminate Ci75, smo ci clones should develop normally without any delay, like ci clones.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	140	 3E shows that smo ci clones developed normally like ci, and were not delayed like smo clones of the same size (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Therefore, smo appeared to be essential only to prevent processing of Ci to the Ci75 repressor protein.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	142	We targeted ectopic expression of different forms of Ci protein to the developing eye.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The Gal4 line hairyH10 was used to target UAS:ciCell expression anterior to the morphogenetic furrow (Ellis et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	144	 ciCell encodes a Ci protein truncated at amino acid 975 and mimics Ci75 (Methot and Basler, 1999).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Atonal expression was reduced, although eye patterning occurred normally (data not shown).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Mlodzik) was used to misexpress UAS:ciCell ventrally (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	147	 When expressed under the control of Fng:Gal4, ciCell prevented furrow progression and differentiation in ventral cells, but permitted furrow progression across the dorsal region of the eye disc (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Fng:G4 and hH10 were also used to drive expression of UAS:ciU, which encodes a Ci protein with a deletion of amino acids 611-760, which is defective in processing to Ci75 and which behaves as a Hh-dependent activator protein (Methot and Basler, 1999), and UAS:ZnAD and UAS:ZnRD transgenes, in which the DNA binding domain of Ci was coupled to transcriptional activator and repressor domains, respectively (Hepker et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	149	 These were without detectable effect (data not shown).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Taken together, these findings suggested that differentiation might depend on blocking production of Ci75 in response to Hh or Dpp.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	151	Ci-independent furrow progression in response to Dpp and N There also had to be a ci-independent signal required to induce differentiation even in the absence of Ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	152	 If differentiation depended entirely on eliminating Ci75, deletion of the ci gene would remove the barrier to differentiation anywhere in the eye field, but instead ci-mutant cells initiated differentiation in the same temporal progression as wild-type cells (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	153	 ci-independent differentiation could not depend on Hh, because smo ci cells also initiated differentiation with precisely normal timing (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	154	The second signal might be Dpp, acting independently of Ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	155	 If this was correct, we would expect that Mad ci mutant cells would fail to differentiate.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Mad ci mutant cells were examined and were found to differentiate, but such differentiation was delayed (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	157	 This result confirmed that Dpp signaling through Mad contributed to differentiation in the absence of ci, but that some signal from posterior cells was still able to progress slowly through Mad ci mutant cells.
