0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	183	  One possibility is that mutation of Mad did not completely abolish Dpp signaling.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The Mad1-2 allele, although similar to null alleles of tkv in effects on patterning, permits more normal growth than do tkv-null alleles and so retains a minimal response to Dpp.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Perhaps this limited activity becomes significant in the absence of ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Another possibility is that N signaling might contribute to differentiation in Mad ci cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	187	 To distinguish whether N or residual Dpp signaling was responsible for the differentiation of Mad ci-mutant cells, we examined tkv ci-mutant cells, as well as cells triply mutant for Su(H), Mad and ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	188	Differentiation was not observed in tkv ci-mutant clones.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Clones of cells mutant for both tkv and ci grew poorly, and only small clones were recovered (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Such clones were rarely recovered in the posterior region of the eye disc, where they seemed to sort out.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Large clones of tkv ci-mutant cells were obtained using the Minute Technique.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	192	 These large clones always had round shapes, indicating that there was reduced mixing with wild-type cells throughout the eye disc (data not shown).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	193	 No retinal differentiation was detected.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	194	 These findings indicate that some Dpp signaling occurred in Mad ci-mutant cells, which contributed to the slow differentiation of Mad ci cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Clones of Mad Su(H) ci-mutant cells also failed to differentiate, indicating a role for N signaling in the delayed differentiation of Mad ci-mutant cells (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	196	N augments Dpp signaling Two interpretations of the role of N could be considered.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	197	 One was that N signaling and Dpp signaling were each required for differentiation in the absence of ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The alternative was that N activity enhanced sensitivity to Dpp so that the limited Dpp signaling that occurs in Mad-mutant cells became sufficient for delayed differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	199	If N signaling was required for differentiation in the absence of ci, we would predict that Su(H) ci-mutant cells would be unable to differentiate.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	200	 However, Su(H) ci-mutant cells did initiate differentiation, but such differentiation was delayed (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Thus N signaling was not absolutely required for differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Delayed differentiation in the absence of Su(H) and ci must depend on Dpp signaling, as it did not occur in Mad Su(H) ci-mutant cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Su(H) mutations must reduce the effectiveness of Dpp, as the timing of differentiation was normal in ci-mutant cells but delayed in Su(H) ci-mutant cells (differentiation in ci-mutant clones must be due to Dpp signaling, because tkv ci-mutant cells did not differentiate).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	204	 These results indicate that N signaling made Dpp signaling more effective, at least in the absence of Ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	205	Ci155 augments Dpp signaling The differentiation of Su(H) ci-mutant cells differed from that of Su(H)-mutant cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Su(H)-mutant cells show a profound neurogenic phenotype in which the majority of mutant cells take an R8 fate (Ligoxygakis et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Morphogenetic furrow progression can accelerate so that differentiation begins earlier at the anterior of large Su(H)-null clones than it does in nearby wild-type regions (Li and Baker, 2001) (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	208	 By contrast, differentiation of Su(H) ci-mutant cells was delayed, and R8 differentiation was increased only moderately compared with wild type (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	209	 These data show that differentiation without Su(H) was more effective in the presence of ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	210	 This was the first data to indicate a role of Ci155 that could not be replaced by deleting the ci gene to eliminate Ci75.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	211	 More evidence is reported below.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	212	Hh-dependent differentiation requiring Ci155 One model for the importance of Ci75 was that Ci75 antagonized Dpp and N function.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	213	 In this view the only normal role of Hh would be to help downregulate Ci75 at the furrow so that Dpp and N could act more promptly.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Delayed differentiation in smo clones would be due to ci75 antagonizing the Dpp/N function that we have found is sufficient for normal furrow progression in the absence of ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	215	 This model does not predict delayed differentiation in Su(H) ci-mutant clones (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	216	To isolate the role of Hh we examined cells mutant for Mad and Su(H).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	217	 If the only role of Hh was to derepress Dpp and N signaling, then Mad Su(H)-mutant cells would not differentiate because of missing Dpp and N signals.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	218	 By contrast, Mad Su(H) cells differentiated at the normal rate (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	219	 A neurogenic phenotype reflected dependence of lateral inhibition on Su(H) (Ligoxygakis et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Initiation of Atonal expression has also been reported in Dl Medea-mutant cells, which should resemble Mad Su(H) cells in lacking N and Dpp signaling (Baonza and Freeman, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	221	 These results show that Dpp and N were dispensable for differentiation if Hh signaling was intact.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	222	 As Mad Su(H) ci cells did not differentiate, differentiation of Mad Su(H) depended on a positive role of Ci that was not mimicked by deleting the ci gene to remove Ci75.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Thus Hh, through Ci155, could drive differentiation in the absence of Dpp and N signaling.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	224	N and Hh each turn off Hairy Notch signaling contributes to differentiation by downregulating Hairy and Extramacrochaetae expression at the morphogenetic furrow (Baonza and Freeman, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Hairy is a transcriptional repressor protein that antagonizes Atonal (Ohsako et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	226	 We monitored Hairy expression to evaluate the contributions of Hh, Dpp and N signaling to turning off Hairy, and to correlate this with differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The results are summarized in Table 1.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Hh, Dpp and N signals do not appear essential to turn Hairy on, although Dpp does contribute because Hairy levels appear lower in clones mutant for tkv, Mad and their combinations with other mutations (Greenwood and Struhl, 1999) (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	229	One, or more, of Dpp, Hh or N signaling is required to turn Hairy off at the morphogenetic furrow, because Hairy expression was maintained cell autonomously in Mad Su(H) ci clones (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Hairy was turned off in Mad ci clones and tkv ci clones, although downregulation was delayed in the center of the clone (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	231	 This implies that N signaling is sufficient to downregulate Hairy in response to a signal from more posterior cells outside the clone.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	232	N signaling was required, and was sufficient, for Hairy downregulation, because Hairy was not shut off in Su(H) ci clones (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	233	 If N signaling was essential to shut off Hairy under all circumstances then we would expect Hairy expression to be maintained autonomously in Su(H) clones.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	234	 By contrast, there was only a brief delay to shutting off Hairy in Su(H) clones (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Hairy was also shut off in Mad Su(H) clones, although after a delay (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	236	 These results show that either N or Hh signals from posterior cells is sufficient to shut off Hairy expression, but that Hairy expression is maintained indefinitely in Mad Su(H) ci and Su(H) ci cells unable to respond to either pathway.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Downregulation of Hairy in response to Hh as well as N explains why N is not required for differentiation in response to Hh, even though it is required for differentiation in response to Dpp.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	238	Hairy retards differentiation Downregulating Hairy was neither necessary nor sufficient for differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Whereas Mad Su(H) ci-mutant cells both failed to differentiate and maintained Hairy expression (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	240	 4E), tkv ci cells did not differentiate even though Hairy expression was shut off (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	241	 By contrast, Hairy expression was maintained in Su(H) ci-mutant clones, even though Su(H) ci cells could differentiate.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	242	 However, Hairy downregulation may contribute to prompt differentiation because differentiation is delayed in Su(H) ci compared with ci, and is less neurogenic in Su(H) ci than in Su(H) (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	243	As Hairy was shut off by either Hh or N signaling, Hairy maintenance away from the boundaries of Mad ci, tkv ci and Mad Su(H) clones shows that these genotypes were defective for Hh and Dl secretion.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Hh is normally secreted by differentiating photoreceptor cells (Ma et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Atonal and then Egf receptor activity promotes expression of Dl, the activating ligand for Notch (Baker and Yu, 1998; Tsuda et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Both Hh and Dl expression should be absent or delayed in Mad ci, tkv ci and Mad Su(H) clones.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	247	The pathways implied by our results shown in Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	248	 5A shows how Hh, Dpp and N signaling pathways act within each cell.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	249	 5B illustrates the spatial and temporal relationships of the extracellular signals during morphogenetic furrow progression.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	250	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Positional signals and regulatory gene expression.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	252	 (A) Cell autonomous responses of Atonal and Hairy expression to Dpp, Hh and N signal reception as inferred from our results, illustrating the roles of Ci155 and Ci75.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Positive and negative interactions do not imply that direct molecular interactions between proteins or between proteins and genes have been demonstrated, only that interactions occur within the same cell without further intercellular signals.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Ci75 must repress Ato since mutation of smo imposes a delay on differentiation that is released by deleting ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Ci155 must activate Ato since Mad Su(H) cells differentiate but Mad Su(H) ci cells do not.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Tkv must activate Ato independently of Ci because ci cells differentiate normally but tkv ci and Mad ci cells do not.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Tkv is shown inhibiting Ci75, because Tkv promotes Ci155 accumulation in smo-mutant cells; this Ci155 is presumed to be inactive.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Tkv also promotes Ci155 accumulation in cells not mutant for smo.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Hairy has been shown previously to repress Ato function (Brown et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Ci155 must repress Hairy as Hairy is maintained cell autonomously by Mad Su(H) ci-mutant cells but can be downregulated by Mad Su(H) cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	261	 N must repress Hairy as Hairy is maintained cell autonomously by Mad Su(H) ci-mutant cells but can be downregulated by Mad ci cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	262	 N may activate Atonal independently of Hairy as well, because the furrow progresses faster through Su(H)-mutant clones where Hairy is still expressed (Li and Baker, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Hairy expression must be initiated in part by another signal, although Dpp has an input, as revealed by the quantitative reduction of Hairy levels in cells mutant for tkv (Greenwood and Struhl, 1999) and Mad, and all their combinations with Su(H) and ci.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The network accounts for all the mutant phenotypes.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	265	 In the absence of Ci, normal differentiation occurs in response to Dpp and N.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	266	 In the absence of smo, differentiation is delayed because activation pathways through Ci155 are lost but repression by Ci75 retained.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	267	 In the absence of both Dpp and N, differentiation occurs in response to Hh.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Absence of either tkv or N alone has little effect, reflecting either the dominant role of Hh, or perhaps that both positive and negative inputs are lost in each case.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	269	 (B) Extracellular signaling to Atonal and Hairy.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Hh, Dl and Dpp are shown at the locations of their expression.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The signal acting most anteriorly to the morphogenetic furrow is Dpp.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Dpp is expressed at the anterior of the morphogenetic furrow in response to Hh.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	273	 More posteriorly, Dpp synergizes with the relatively indiffusible Dl signal to induce Atonal.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Dl is expressed in response to Atonal, and later in response to activation of Egfr by ligands produced by Atonal-dependent R8 cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Hh also induces Atonal through the Ci155/Ci75 ratio.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Hh is secreted by photoreceptor cells specified by Egfr activation by ligands produced by Atonal-dependent R8 cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Both N and Hh downregulate Hairy.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Despite intrinsically different ranges of Dpp and Hh signals, their activation of Ato coincides because Dpp also elevates Hairy, which must be downregulated by Hh or Dl.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	279	  The development of Mad Su(H) ci-mutant cells is a helpful starting point, as they may reflect a `ground state' of eye development that requires extracellular signals to differentiate.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Mad Su(H) ci cells fail to express the atonal or senseless genes that initiate R8 differentiation, and, consequently, fail to support retinal differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	281	 This shows that the absence of Ci75 is not sufficient for differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	282	 in Su(H) ci clones), but N and Dpp signaling together are required to activate Atonal with normal kinetics, as occurs in ci-mutant cells.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	283	 N signaling alone (in tkv ci clones) is insufficient.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	284	 In the presence of Ci, prompt differentiation required Hh to downregulate Ci75, and differentiation was delayed in Smo clones that lacked this input.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The normal role of Hh is not just to remove Ci75 thus permitting Dpp and N to work, because Atonal is turned on normally in Mad Su(H) clones that do not respond to Dpp or N signals.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Such differentiation depends exclusively on Hh yet progresses normally, except that a neurogenic phenotype reflects dependence of lateral inhibition on Su(H).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Hh depends positively on ci to drive differentiation in Mad Su(H) cells and, therefore, requires Ci155.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The positive role of ci can also be inferred from the delayed differentiation of Su(H) ci clones in comparison with Su(H) clones.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	289	We find that Hairy is downregulated redundantly by Hh and N signaling.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Prolonged Hairy expression is not sufficient to block differentiation completely but it does antagonize it (e.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Downregulation of Hairy in response to Hh as well as N explains why both ci and Su(H) mutant clones can differentiate promptly, and why N enhances differentiation in response to Dpp but is not required for differentiation in response to Hh.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	292	Hh or Dpp is sufficient for differentiation Comparison between Mad Su(H) ci cells that do not differentiate and Mad Su(H) cells that do shows that Hh signaling is sufficient to initiate eye differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	293	 This is consistent with previous studies of ectopic Hh activation (Heberlein and Moses, 1995; Li et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	294	, 1995; Ma and Moses, 1995; Pan and Rubin, 1995; Strutt et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Our experiments confirm this conclusion at the normal time and place of Hh signaling at the anterior of the morphogenetic furrow, and confirm directly that Dpp and N signaling are not necessary for Hh signaling to be sufficient.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	296	Comparison between Mad Su(H) ci cells and Su(H) ci cells shows that Dpp signaling is sufficient to initiate eye differentiation in its normal location in the absence of Hh or N signals, but such differentiation is delayed.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	297	 The normal timing of differentiation is restored by combined Dpp and N signals (in ci clones).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	298	 This is the basis for the ectopic differentiation on co-expression of Dpp and Dl ahead of the furrow (Baonza and Freeman, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	299	Superficially, our results differ from previous ectopic expression studies that concluded that Dpp signaling alone was not sufficient to induce ectopic differentiation in all locations (Pignoni and Zipursky, 1997; Greenwood and Struhl, 1999; Baonza and Freeman, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	300	 This discrepancy is probably explained by the baseline repressor activity of Su(H) protein (Hsieh and Hayward, 1995; Morel and Schweisguth, 2000).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Our previous work shows that without N signaling, repressor activity of Su(H) protein retards differentiation (Li and Baker, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Dpp signaling is sufficient for differentiation in our experiments where the Su(H) gene has been deleted.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	303	 In the presence of the Su(H) gene, Dpp may be most effective at locations where there is little Su(H) repressor activity, such as close to the morphogenetic furrow where N signaling is active.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	304	Comparison between Mad Su(H) ci cells, which do not differentiate, and Mad ci or tkv ci cells, which differentiate slowly or not at all, shows that Notch signaling alone is insufficient for differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Premature differentiation reported when N is activated ectopically ahead of the furrow must reflect endogenous Dpp signaling at such locations (Baonza and Freeman, 2001; Li and Baker, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	306	Mechanisms of redundancy Our experiments reveal an outline of the mechanisms of Hh, Dpp and N redundancy (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	307	 First, our results show that Mad and Ci independently reinforce differentiation, presumably through the transcription of target genes because Mad is sufficient for differentiation in the absence of Ci, and vice versa.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Our results show unequivocally that the transcriptional activator Ci155 activates differentiation in addition to Ci75 antagonizing differentiation.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	309	It was surprising to find that Dpp stabilizes Ci155 in the absence of Smo, which suggested Dpp input into Hh signal transduction.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Although the requirement for smo-dependent input through fused makes it unlikely that Ci155 is functional in smo clones (Ohlmeyer and Kalderon, 1997; Methot and Basler, 1999), Ci155 accumulation might be associated with reduced Ci75 levels.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Ci75 is shown to repress differentiation in smo clones because smo ci clones differentiation normally.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	312	 Ci155 stabilization cannot be due to an indirect effect of Dpp signaling on Hh, Ptc or Smo expression levels because the effect is detected in the absence of smo, and, therefore, reflects an effect on Hh signal transduction components downstream of Smo.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	313	 One idea is that Dpp signaling (or Dpp-induced differentiation) may replace SCFSlimb processing of Ci (which cleaves Ci155 to Ci75) with Cullin3-mediated Ci degradation, just as normally occurs posterior to the morphogenetic furrow (Ou et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	314	 In a smo clone, Ci155 would accumulate because Smo is required for Cullin3 to degrade Ci (Ou et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	315	 However, the SCFSlimb-to-Cullin3 switch may not be the only effect of Dpp on Ci processing, because Tkv slightly enhanced Ci155 accumulation even when smo is present (Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	316	Finally, downregulation of Hairy by N requires the Su(H) gene.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	317	 N also overcomes baseline repressor activity of Su(H) protein to promote progression of differentiation (Li and Baker, 2001).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	318	 This role of N must be independent of Hairy.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	319	Signal combinations control the rate of differentiation Dl, Hh and Dpp are generally thought to signal over very different distances.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	320	 How can signals of such different range substitute for one another to permit normal eye development? Fig.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	321	 5B shows signal sources and targets in the eye disc.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Dpp is transcribed in response to Hh signaling and is produced where Ci155 levels are highest (Heberlein et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	323	, 1993; Strutt and Mlodzik, 1996).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Dl is regulated by Hh indirectly through Ato and Ato-dependent Egfr activity in differentiating cells (Baker and Yu, 1998; Tsuda et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Hh is expressed most posteriorly of the three, in differentiating photoreceptors (Ma et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	326	Eye differentiation uses Hh to progress through cells unable to respond to Dpp (tkv, Mad) or N (Su(H)).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The range of Hh diffusion depends in part on the shape of the morphogenetic furrow cells (Benlali et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	328	 The Dpp that drives differentiation through ci-mutant cells unable to respond to Hh must diffuse from outside the ci clones because Dpp synthesis is Hh dependent (Heberlein et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	329	, 1993; Methot and Basler, 1999).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Large ci clones develop normally so Dpp diffusion cannot be limiting (dpp-mutant clones offer no information about the range of Dpp because they express and differentiate in response to Hh).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Instead the rate of progression in response to Dpp is controlled by Dl.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Dl signals over, at most, one or two cell diameters at the morphogenetic furrow (Baker and Yu, 1997).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	333	The previous view of eye patterning was influenced by the morphogen function of Hh and Dpp in other discs (Nellen et al.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	334	, 1996; Strigini and Cohen, 1997).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	335	 It was thought that domains of Ato and Hairy expression reflected increasing concentrations of Hh and Dpp (Greenwood and Struhl, 1999; Lee and Treisman, 2002).
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	336	 Our data shows that, in the eye, the combination of signals is important.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	337	 Differentiation is triggered where Dl and/or Hh synergize with Dpp, regardless of where the source of Dpp is.
0.14052135.12954721.html.plaintext.txt	338	 The additional requirements limit Dpp to initiating differentiation at the same locations that Hh does.

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	0	Deletion of N-terminal Residues 23 to 88 from Prion Protein (PrP) Abrogates the Potential to Rescue PrP-deficient Mice from PrP-like Protein/Doppel-induced Neurodegeneration* Ryuichiro Atarashi  , Noriyuki Nishida , Kazuto Shigematsu  , Shinji Goto ||, Takahito Kondo ||, Suehiro Sakaguchi  and Shigeru Katamine  **.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Departments of Molecular Microbiology and Immunology,  Pathology, and ||Biochemistry and Molecular Biology in Disease, Institute of Atomic Bomb Disease, Nagasaki University Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences, 1-12-4 Sakamoto, Nagasaki 852-8523, Japan.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, April 8, 2003.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	3	We previously established a line of PrP-deficient mice, designated Ngsk Prnp0/0, that exhibited late-onset ataxia because of cerebellar Purkinje cell degeneration (4), which was rescued by the mouse wild-type PrP gene (Prnp) (5).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Subsequently, these results were reproduced in two independent lines, Rcm0 and Zrch II Prnp0/0 mice (6, 7).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In contrast, two other independent lines, Zrch I and Edbg Prnp0/0, have never revealed such a phenotype (8, 9).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Recent studies have provided evidence that the ectopic expression of a PrP-like protein/Doppel (PrPLP/Dpl) in the neuron of ataxic Prnp0/0 mouse lines but not non-ataxic lines could explain the discrepancy between phenotypes (6, 10).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Disruption of a part of the Prnp intron 2, including its splicing acceptor, in all the ataxic lines leads to unusual intergenic splicing between Prnp and the downstream gene, designated Prnd, encoding PrPLP/Dpl.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	8	 As a consequence, the PrPLP/Dpl gene comes under the control of the Prnp promoter, leading to the ectopic expression of PrPLP/Dpl in the neuron.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In the physiological situation, PrPLP/Dpl mRNA is expressed at a high level in the testis and heart but is not detectable in the brain except for transient expression by brain endothelial cells around 1 week after birth (11).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	10	 A study using PrPLP/Dpl-deficient mice has suggested a physiological role for PrPLP/Dpl in spermatogenesis (12).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Recent reports demonstrated that introduction of a transgene encoding PrPLP/Dpl rendered Zrch I Prnp0/0 mice capable of reproducing the Purkinje cell degeneration observed in the Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice (13).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This is direct evidence confirming that both ectopic expression of PrPLP/Dpl and functional loss of PrP are required for the neurodegeneration in Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	13	PrPLP/Dpl, a glycoprotein expressed on the cell surface with a glycosylphosphatidylinositol moiety (14), consists of 179 amino acids with 23% identity to PrP in the primary structure but lacking the unique octapeptide-repeat region and hydrophobic region present in the N-terminal half of PrP (10).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	14	 An NMR study revealed similarities in the tertiary structure between PrPLP/Dpl and the C-terminal half of PrP, both of which are composed of two short -strands and three -helices (15).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Interestingly, expression of a transgene encoding truncated PrP lacking N-terminal residues 32 to 121 or 32 to 134 in nonataxic Zrch I Prnp0/0 mice also resulted in severe cerebellar degeneration, which was abrogated by reintroduction of the wild-type mouse PrP gene (16).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	16	 These results have suggested that PrPLP/Dpl and N-terminal-truncated (del32 to 121 or 32 to 134) PrP are toxic to neurons through similar mechanisms and that wild-type PrP may have a neuroprotective function.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	17	In the present study, to further elucidate mechanisms of the Purkinje cell death, we generated five different transgenic mouse lines expressing, respectively, heterologous, chimeric, and mutant PrPs on the Ngsk Prnp0/0 background.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	18	 A transgene encoding PrP-lacking N-terminal residues 23 to 88 failed to rescue the Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice from Purkinje cell degeneration, indicating a crucial role for the residues.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The roles of PrPLP/Dpl aggregation and impaired metabolism of reactive oxygen species in the brain tissues of Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice were also evaluated.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	20	Antibodies The anti-PrP polyclonal mouse antiserum used was described previously (5).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	21	 We produced anti-PrPLP/Dpl polyclonal rabbit antiserum using full-length (27 to 155) recombinant mouse PrPLP/Dpl.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	22	 3F4 anti-PrP antibody was purchased from Dako.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	23	 SAF-mix antibody was a kind gift from Dr.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-mouse IgG and anti-rabbit IgG antibodies were purchased from Amersham Biosciences.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	25	Western Blotting Brain homogenates (10%, w/v) were prepared in a lysis buffer containing 150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	26	5% sodium deoxycholate, 1 mM EDTA, and protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Applied Science).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Postnuclear supernatants were collected after low speed centrifugation, and protein concentrations were determined using the BCA protein assay (Pierce).

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Anti-PrP polyclonal mouse antiserum or anti-PrPLP/Dpl polyclonal rabbit antiserum was used as a probe, and immunoreactive bands were visualized using the ECL system (Amersham Biosciences).

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	38	Immunohistochemistry Deparaffinized sections were digested with 1 mg/ml trypsin for 15 min at 37  degrees C and then placed in 3% H2O2 in methanol for 30 min at room temperature to abolish endogenous peroxidase activity.

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	40	 To detect spot 35 immunoreactivities, we used the EnVision+, in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations (Dako).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The antibody-bound peroxidase was revealed with 0.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	42	Superoxide Dismutase (SOD) and Glutathione Peroxidase (Gpx) Activities Brain homogenates were prepared in phosphate-buffered saline containing 1 mM EDTA and protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Applied Science).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Homogenates were centrifuged at 10,000 x g for 10 min, and supernatants were subjected to analysis.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The protein concentration of the supernatants was determined using the BCA protein assay (Pierce).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The total SOD activity was measured by inhibition of the reduction rate of nitro blue tetrazolium, monitored at 560 nm using xanthine and the xanthine oxidase system.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	46	 One unit of SOD activity was defined as the amount of the enzyme required to inhibit the reduction rate of nitro blue tetrazolium by 50%.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The activity was expressed as units/mg of protein.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	48	 To measure Mn-SOD activity, the reaction mixture was treated with 2 mM potassium cyanide.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	49	 To obtain Cu/Zn-SOD activity, the amount of Mn-SOD activity was subtracted from the total SOD activity.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The Gpx activity was measured by determining the rate of NADPH oxidation to NADP, monitored at 340 nm using glutathione reductase and the NADPH system.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The activity was expressed as nmol/min/mg of protein.

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	92	Expression Levels and Detergent Insolubility of PrPLP/Dpl in the Brain Tissues of Tg/Ngsk Prnp0/0 Mouse Lines PrPLP/Dpl expression levels in the brains were examined by Western blotting with polyclonal anti-PrPLP/Dpl rabbit antiserum.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Although the brain tissues of Prnp+/+ mice expressed no detectable PrPLP/Dpl, the Tg/Ngsk Prnp0/0 mouse lines all exhibited PrPLP/Dpl expression at levels equivalent to those of Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice (Fig.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The expression levels remained stable during aging, even after the onset of ataxia (data not shown).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	95	View larger version (38K):    FIG.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	96	 PrPLP/Dpl expression levels are similar among the brain tissues from wild-type, Ngsk Prnp0/0 and Tg/Ngsk Prnp0/0 mouse lines.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	97	 PrPLP/Dpl in brain tissues from each mouse line was visualized by Western blot analysis using anti-PrPLP/Dpl polyclonal rabbit antiserum.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Each lane contains 60  microg of total protein.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	99	Accumulating evidence has indicated that certain neurodegenerative conditions are caused by aggregation of detergent-insoluble proteins, such as PrPSc, in the central nervous system (24).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	100	 To evaluate the possibility of PrPLP/Dpl aggregation in the brain tissues, we examined the detergent-insolubility of PrPLP/Dpl in the brains of ataxic Ngsk Prnp0/0 and Tg-SHa/Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice at 98 weeks of age.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	101	 6A, PrPLP/Dpl was partially insoluble in the buffer containing 0.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	102	5% sodium deoxycholate but completely solubilized by 1% sarcosyl.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The levels of Triton X-100-insoluble fraction of PrPLP/Dpl were similar between Ngsk Prnp0/0 and Tg-SHa/Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice even at 98 weeks of age and did not increase during aging (Fig.

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	107	 PrPLP/Dpl in the resulting pellets (Plt) and supernatants (Sup) was visualized by Western blotting.

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	109	SOD and Gpx Activities in the Brain Tissues of Ngsk Prnp0/0 Mice Are Not Reduced Finally, the possible involvement of the down-regulation of anti-oxidative enzyme activities in the neurodegeneration in Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice was evaluated.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The activities of SOD and Gpx in the brain tissues of Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice at 6 months of age were measured and compared with those of two age-matched control mouse lines, Prnp+/+and Tg-Mo.

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	115	 There was no statistically significant difference.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Gpx activities were also similar among the mouse lines: 67.

0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	118	View larger version (21K):    FIG.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Activities of Cu, Zn-SOD, Mn-SOD, and Gpx are not reduced in the brains of Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The activities of Cu, Zn-SOD, and Mn-SOD (A) and Gpx (B) are compared among brain tissues from wild-type, Ngsk Prnp0/0, and Tg-Mo.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Three mice from each line were used.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	122	 All measurements were repeated two to three times for each brain.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Vertical bars indicate standard errors.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	124	Although various hypothetical models have been proposed, precise mechanisms for the neurodegeneration seen in Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice remain to be elucidated.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	125	 In addition to the structural similarities between PrP and PrPLP/Dpl, the previous finding that a recombinant C-terminal PrP (121 to 231) fragment could convert into a -sheet-rich structure at acidic pH in vitro (26) prompted us to examine the involvement of abnormal PrPLP/Dpl aggregation in the neurodegeneration.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	126	 However, we failed to detect detergent-insoluble PrPLP/Dpl accumulation in the central nervous system of Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice even after the onset of ataxia.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	127	 PrPLP/Dpl contains two intramolecular disulfide bonds at the C-terminal portion (14), in contrast to PrP with a single disulfide bond, which has been shown to be necessary for conversion to the pathogenic isoform, PrPSc.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The structures determined by intramolecular disulfide bonds may account for the difference between the two proteins in the potential for structural conversion.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	129	del23 to 88 transgene, which encoded a product lacking almost the entire unique octapeptide-repeat region, failed to rescue Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice from neurodegeneration.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Little difference was observed in the pathology and onset of ataxia between Ngsk Prnp0/0 and Tg-MHM2.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The PrP expression level of Tg-MHM2.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	132	del23 to 88/Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice was higher than that of Tg-SHa and Tg-MH2M/Ngsk Prnp0/0 but similar to that of Tg-MHM2/Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	133	 This strongly indicates that the N-terminal part of PrP is essential to the rescue from Purkinje cell death.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	134	del23 to 88 PrP was shown to retain the potential to convert into the pathogenic isoform in prion-infected cell cultures (27) and brain tissues of Tg-MHM2.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The N-terminal region could thus be a key factor for determining whether physiological function is maintained but is likely to be less important in pathogenic structural conversion.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	136	Because the unique octapeptide-repeat region has the potential to bind copper (28), PrP may function in the transport or metabolism of copper in the neuron (29 to 31).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Copper is involved in various aspects of reactive oxygen species metabolism (32).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	138	 It could thus be possible that impaired copper transport may result in reactive oxygen species accumulation, leading to cell death.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Indeed, the reduced activity of Cu/Zn-SOD in the brains of Zrch I Prnp0/0 mice has been reported (33).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	140	 However, along with other contradictory reports (34), the present study failed to show reduced activities of Cu/Zn-SOD, Mn-SOD, and Gpx in the brains of Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The fact that Cu/Zn-SOD-deficient mice have never developed any neurological signs such as ataxia (35) also argues against a causal relationship between reduced activity of Cu/Zn-SOD and Purkinje cell death.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	142	Interestingly, Tg mice expressing PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	143	del32 to 121 or 32 to 134 on the Zrch I Prnp0/0 background also developed cerebellar cell death, but those with wild-type Prnp background did not (16).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The two mutant PrPs lack a part of or most of the hydrophobic region (111 to 134), in addition to the octapeptide-repeat region, which are also absent in PrPLP/Dpl.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The structural similarities between PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	146	del32 to 121/32 to 134 and PrPLP/Dpl strongly suggested that a common mechanism is involved in the neurodegeneration in the Tg mice and Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Behrens and Aguzzi (36) have hypothesized an as yet unidentified ligand, which harbors affinities to both PrP and PrPLP/Dpl or the N terminus-truncated PrPs.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In the absence of PrP, binding of the putative ligand to PrPLP/Dpl or PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	149	del32 to 121/32 to 134 may trigger an apoptotic signal or prevent a survival signal.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	150	 On the other hand, in the presence of PrP, the binding would be impeded because of much lower affinity.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	151	 If this is the case, the failure of MHM2.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	152	del23 to 88 PrP in the phenotype rescue suggests that residues 23 to 88 include a site critical for ligand binding or functional transduction of ligand signals.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Recent studies have demonstrated that copper binds not only to the octapeptide-repeat region but also to the C-terminal PrP-(91 to 231/121 to 231) fragments (37, 38) and PrPLP/Dpl (39).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Hence, copper could be one candidate for this hypothetical ligand, acting to raise a neurotoxic signal or prevent a survival signal through binding to PrPLP/Dpl or PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	155	del23 to 88 PrP, as well as full-length PrP, underwent proteolytic cleavage leading to the production of C1.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	156	 This indicated that loss of the N-terminal residues 23 to 88 did not affect the cleavage, and C1 was not necessary for the phenotype rescue.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	157	 It has also been shown that a N-terminal cleavage product, PrP-(23 to 110/111), designated N1, was released into the supernatant of cultured cells (40).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	158	 An intriguing hypothesis is that N1 may play a neuroprotective role outside of the cells.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	159	 For instance, it may bind to copper or other molecules to produce a neuroprotective signal.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	160	del23 to 88 PrP lacking the octapeptide-repeat region is unlikely to preserve this function.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	161	 It would be of value to examine the potential of N1 to rescue Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice from the Purkinje cell death.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	162	Another model for the neurodegeneration to be evaluated is that the absence of PrP might make cerebellar cells vulnerable to a constitutive weak apoptotic signal transduced by PrPLP/Dpl (36).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	163	 PrP could raise an anti-apoptotic signal independently and protect from the PrPLP/Dpl-induced apoptosis.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Accumulating evidence has supported an anti-apoptotic role of PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	165	 For instance, overexpression of PrP protected human primary neurons from Bax-mediated apoptosis (41).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The protective effect was abolished by deletion of the octapeptide-repeat region, residues 56 to 88, of human PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Serum withdrawal-induced apoptosis of immortalized hippocampal cells derived from Prnp0/0 mice was also prevented by overexpressed PrP or Bcl-2 (42).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	168	 (43) recently demonstrated evidence that a peptide capable of binding to residues 113 to 128 of PrP protected developing retina neurons from apoptosis via activation of cAMP-dependent protein kinase.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The same group has identified stress-inducible protein 1, a heat-shock protein, which binds residues 113 to 128 of PrP and promotes a neuroprotective signal (44).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Interestingly, expression of PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	171	del32 to 121/32 to 134 in Zrch I Prnp0/0 mice induced cerebellar neurodegeneration, but MHM2.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	172	del23 to 88 PrP preserving residues 113 to 128 did not.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The absence of the potential to bind to stress-inducible protein 1 may be crucial for the neurotoxic effects of PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	174	del32 to 121/32 to 134 and PrPLP/Dpl.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	175	In prion diseases, the constitutive conversion of PrP into the pathogenic isoform, PrPSc, is likely to result in the functional loss of normal PrP (45).
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	176	 If PrPSc mimics the neurotoxic role of PrPLP/Dpl or PrP.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	177	del32 to 121/32 to 134, Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice lacking PrP but ectopically expressing PrPLP/Dpl in neurons could be a valuable model for the neurodegeneration.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Alternatively, it is also possible that the mechanisms of neurodegeneration in mice are distinct from those of prion diseases, based on the present finding that no detergent-insoluble PrPLP/Dpl was detectable in mouse brain tissues.
0.15615378.12759361.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Elucidation of the molecular mechanisms responsible for the neurodegeneration in Ngsk Prnp0/0 mice would provide new insights into the understanding of the pathogenesis of prion diseases and other neurodegenerative conditions, as well as the physiological function of PrP.

0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	0	dSmurf Selectively Degrades Decapentaplegic-activated MAD, and Its Overexpression Disrupts Imaginal Disc Development* Yao-Yun Liang  , Xia Lin  , Min Liang  , F.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Charles Brunicardi , Peter ten Dijke  , Zhihong Chen , Kwang-Wook Choi  || ** and Xin-Hua Feng   .
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	2	 DeBakey Department of Surgery, Department of Molecular  and  Cellular Biology, ||Ophthalmology, **Program of Developmental Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas 77030 and the  Division of Cellular Biochemistry, The Netherlands Cancer Institute, 1066 Cx Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, January 21, 2003 , and in revised form, May 12, 2003.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	4	Ubiquitin conjugation is catalyzed by an enzymatic cascade including ubiquitin-activating E1, ubiquitin-conjugating E2, and specific ubiquitin E3 ligase.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The specificity of ubiquitination derives from the highly specific protein-protein interaction between E3 ligase and substrate (6, 7).
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In TGF- signaling, HECT-class E3 ligases Smurf1 and Smurf2 specifically promote degradation of Smad1, Smad2 (8 to 10) and possibly I-Smads and TGF- type I receptor (11, 12).
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In Xenopus embryos, Smurf1 showed inhibition of BMP signaling and affected pattern formation (8).
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Recently, a Drosophila ligase E3 dSmurf has been identified by genetic screen (1); the null mutation of dSmurf resulted in a lethal defect in hindgut organogenesis.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, the mechanisms underlying dSmurf actions in DPP signaling and embryogenesis remain unclear.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	10	In this study, we present biochemical and genetic evidence for the biological functions of dSmurf.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The results revealed that dSmurf specifically inhibited DPP signaling by targeting DPP-activated MAD, not dSmad2, Medea, or Dad, for ubiquitination/proteasome-dependent proteolysis.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Targeted overexpression of dSmurf in imaginal discs strongly reduces the level of phosphorylated MAD and consequently causes disruption of DPP-dependent patterning of imaginal discs, demonstrating that dSmurf is a negative regulator of DPP signaling in vivo.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	13	Yeast Two-hybrid Assay A LexA-based yeast two-hybrid assay was performed as described previously (9).
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	14	 MAD, dSmad2, and Dad were obtained by PCR from respective cDNA (gifts of Kohei Miyazono and Richard Padgett) and cloned into a yeast bait vector pEG202.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	15	 dSmurf wild type and the dSmurf deletion mutants, obtained by PCR, were cloned into prey vector pJG4 to 5 at sites of EcoRI and SalI.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Smurf1 (gift of Jeff Wrana) was also subcloned into pJG4 to 5.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	17	 -Galactosidase activity is measured by liquid assay according to the method of Matchmaker two-hybrid system 2 (Clontech).

0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	92	dSmurf Mediates Ubiquitination of MAD To dissect the function of dSmurf as a ubiquitin E3 ligase, we tested whether dSmurf stimulated the ubiquitination of MAD.

0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Markedly, the C1029A mutant of dSmurf could not conjugate HA-ubiquitin to MAD (lane 4).
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	95	 This suggests that the catalytic activity of dSmurf is required for the ubiquitination of MAD.

0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	115	Overexpression of dSmurf Leads to Loss of Phospho-MAD and Disruption of Imaginal Disc Development DPP signaling is essential for patterning of imaginal discs.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	116	 DPP is expressed along the anterior-posterior border of the wing disc and activated phospho-MAD is expressed in wider area around the AP border.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Using UAS-Gal4 targeted expression system (20), we tested whether overexpression of dSmurf along the AP border can reduce or abolish phospho-MAD.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	118	 As expected, when dSmurf expression was targeted to the AP border using ptc-Gal4, there was a strong reduction of phospho-MAD level in the ptc expression domain (Fig.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	119	 ptc-Gal4;UAS-dSmurf (ptc > dSmurf) flies failed to eclose due to severe developmental defects.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Pharate adult flies removed from the pupal case showed rudimentary wings (Fig.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	121	 5L) and truncated legs (not shown), indicating strong reduction of DPP signaling.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	122	 In contrast, overexpression of catalytically inactive dSmurf in ptc > dSmurf(C1029A) showed no significant defects in appendages.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Wing discs from ptc > dSmurf(C1029A) showed slight increases in the level of phospho-MAD (Fig.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	124	 5, E to G), suggesting that dSmurfCA may titrate the function of normal dSmurf.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	125	View larger version (59K):    FIG.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	126	 dSmurf degrades MAD in vivo and disrupts wing disc development.

0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	136	 L, adults with ptc > dSmurf show only rudimentary wings.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	137	dSmurf also interacts with dSmad2 dependent of receptor activation.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The binding specificity of dSmurf is similar to that of its structurally related Smurf2 which binds both BMP- and activin-activated R-Smads in vertebrates (9, 10).
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	139	 One remaining question is whether dSmurf also targets dSmad2 for degradation.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Since activin signaling through dSmad2 appears to have no effects on patterning of wing development (23), the hypothetical dSmurf-mediated dSmad2 degradation in the wing imaginal disc should have no contributions to the severe phenotype observed in the dSmurf transgenic flies.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	141	 It is the disappearance of phophos-MAD that completely shuts down DPP signaling during wing development.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	142	Unlike its vertebrate homologs, dSmurf fails to interact with DAD, the inhibitory Smad in fly.
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	143	 In vertebrates, Smurf1 and Smurf2 can form a strong association with Smad6 and Smad7 (12), which may promote the degradation of TGF- receptors (11, 12).
0.16014898.12754252.html.plaintext.txt	144	 While the physiological role of mammalian Smurf in controlling receptor homeostasis remains to be clarified, dSmurf has no apparent functions in the proteolytic degradation of DPP receptors.

0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	5	A supplementary figure showing ME7 and 301V incubation times in mice expressing codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms is available in JGV Online.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	6	Present address: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA), Veterinary Research Division, TSE Research Unit, Dean Stanley Street, London, UK.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	7	Present address: Department of Genetics and Genomics, Roslin Institute, Edinburgh, UK.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	8	The host PrP gene (Prnp) has a major influence over the outcome of TSE disease.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	9	 PrP polymorphisms have been shown to alter incubation time and TSE susceptibility in mice (Moore et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Classical genetic analysis of the control of TSE incubation time in mice identified the presence of a single gene (Sinc) encoding two alleles (s7 and p7), which programmed short and long incubation times, respectively, for the ME7 strain of scrapie (Dickinson et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Similar differences in incubation time have been found between NZW/LacJ and Iln/J mouse strains when infected with the Chandler isolate, identifying a single locus, Prni, that controlled incubation time, which was linked closely to Prnp (Carlson et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Following isolation and characterization of the gene encoding PrP in mice (Prnp) (Basler et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1986), mouse strains carrying Sinc s7 were shown to have a Prnp gene encoding 108L_189T (Prnpa) and those carrying Sinc p7 had a Prnp gene encoding 108F_189V (Prnpb) (Westaway et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	14	 However, due to the different genetic backgrounds of these lines of inbred mice, it was difficult to confirm that the Prnp, Sinc and Prni genes were congruent and that the polymorphisms in Prnp were responsible for the control of scrapie incubation time in mice.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	15	The introduction of 108F and 189T into the murine Prnpa gene by gene targeting produced a line of transgenic mice (FV/FV) that differed from the 129/Ola parental line by only the targeted polymorphisms.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Inoculation of these mice with TSE infectivity produced incubation times similar to those in Prnpb mice, demonstrating that Sinc, Prni and Prnp were indeed the same gene and that the codon 108 and/or 189 polymorphisms were the major factors controlling TSE incubation time in mice (Moore et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	17	, 2003; Barron  and  Manson, 2004).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	18	In order to determine the individual involvement of the codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms in disease and the mechanism by which they control TSE incubation time in mice, 108F and 189V have been introduced separately into the murine Prnpa gene by gene targeting.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	19	 These new alleles are designated Prnpa[108L_189V] (PrnpLV) and Prnpa[108F_189T] (PrnpFT).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Inoculation of mice that were homozygous for Prnpa, Prnpb, PrnpLV or PrnpFT and their heterozygous crosses with mouse scrapie have demonstrated the involvement of both polymorphisms in the control of incubation time.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	21	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Wild-type PrP clones were derived from a 129/Ola HM-1 ES cell genomic library and amino acids were modified by site-directed mutagenesis.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Targeting vectors were constructed by the introduction of a PGK/HPRT cassette (flanked by LoxP sites) and an HSV/TK cassette for selection purposes.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	24	 After homologous recombination in ES cells, the PGK/HPRT cassette was removed with Cre recombinase.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Primer pair W262 and W6991 was used to determine successful homologous recombination in targeted ES cells.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Primer pair W7878 and W6991 was used to screen for the Cre-mediated deletion of the PGK-HPRT cassette (see Methods).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In the presence of the cassette, the PCR fragment is too large to amplify.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	28	 A successfully removed cassette produces a PCR product larger than the wild-type allele, due to the retention of a single LoxP site and part of the pBluescript multiple-cloning site after Cre recombination.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Presence of 108F or 189V polymorphism was confirmed by PCR of the ORF using primers A996 and B188 and digestion of the product with MnlI (108F) or BstEII (189V).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	30	 B, BamHI; E, EcoRI; P, PstI; RV, EcoRV; S, SalI.

0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Targeted clones amplified a 1 75 kb targeting-specific band and were further screened for PrP codon 108 or 189 alterations by a combination of PCR and restriction digestion.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The PrP ORF was amplified with primers A996 (5'-GTGGCTGGGGACAACCCCAT-3') and B188 (5'-GCCTAGACCACGAGAATGCG-3') to generate a 624 bp PCR product [94  degrees C (30 s), 65  degrees C (30 s), 72  degrees C (60 s); 35 cycles].
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The codon 108 alteration was detected by the loss of an MnlI site following the single nucleotide change (CTC to TTC).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The codon 189 alteration was detected by digestion with BstEII as described previously (Moore  and  Melton, 1995).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	40	Cre deletion of the HPRT minigene.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The LoxP-flanked PGK/HPRT module was excised from targeted alleles by transient transfection of ES cells with the Cre recombinase expression construct pMCCreN (Gu et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Clones were transfected with 150  microg pMCCreN (10x106 cells, 900 V, 3  microF) and selected by 6-thioguanine.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Drug-resistant clones were screened for deletion of the LoxP-flanked HPRT minigene by PCR with primers W7878 (5'-AGTCAGGGAGGAGTAACACAGAAGG-3') and W6991 [94  degrees C (60 s), 66  degrees C (60 s), 72  degrees C (95 s); 35 cycles].
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	44	 This generated a 1 61 kb product from the wild-type allele and a slightly larger band of 1 66 kb from the HPRT-deletant allele.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	45	 This size difference arises from the retention of a single 38 bp LoxP site and a portion of the pBluescript multiple-cloning site.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	46	 ES cell clones were examined by Southern analysis for the expected gene structure and the absence of additional recombination events, as described previously (Moore et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Germ-line chimeras were generated as described previously (Thompson et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Briefly, HM-1 ES cells with the desired alterations were introduced into BALB/c 3 5-day-old blastocysts and transferred to pseudopregnant MF1 recipients.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Chimeras were crossed directly to 129/Ola stock-generating mice with PrP codon 108 and 189 alterations, which were co-isogenic with the parental strain 129/Ola Hsd (Harlan).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Germ-line pups were screened by a combination of PCR and MnlI or BstEII restriction digestion, as described above.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	51	 129/Ola littermates heterozygous for the targeted PrP allele that were also wild-type at the deleted HPRT locus in HM-1 cells were crossed to establish the line.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Total RNA was isolated from terminal brains by using RNAzol B, based on the guanidinium thiocyanate/phenol/chloroform extraction method (Chomczynski  and  Sacchi, 1987).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Total RNA (50  microg) was separated on a 1 0 % agarose/formaldehyde denaturing gel and transferred to Hybond-N (Amersham Biosciences) by capillary transfer overnight.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	54	 RNA was fixed to the membrane by baking at 80  degrees C for 2 h before probing.

0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Homogenates of frozen brain tissue [10 % (w/v)] were prepared in NP40 buffer [0 5 % (v/v) NP40, 0 5 % (w/v) sodium deoxycholate, 150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris/HCl (pH 7 5)].
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Clarified homogenates (10 000 g for 10 min at 10  degrees C) were incubated with or without PK (20  microg ml to 1) for 1 h at 37  degrees C and the reaction was terminated by the addition of PMSF to 1 mM.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Samples were prepared at 10 mg ml to 1 in SDS-PAGE sample buffer (Novex; Invitrogen), incubated at 90  degrees C for 20 min and separated on 12 or 4 to 12 % Novex Tris/glycine acrylamide gels (Invitrogen).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Proteins were transferred onto a PVDF membrane by electroblotting and incubated overnight at room temperature with mouse anti-PrP monoclonal antibody 7A12 (Li et al.

0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Proteins were visualized with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-mouse or anti-rat secondary antibody diluted to 200 ng ml to 1 (Jackson ImmunoResearch) and a chemiluminescence detection kit (Roche Diagnostics).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Membranes were exposed to X-ray film for periods ranging from 10 s to 10 min.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Inocula were prepared from the brains of C57BL mice with terminal ME7 scrapie and the brains of VM mice with terminal 301V disease.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	66	 A 1 % homogenate of each sample was prepared in sterile saline prior to use as an inoculum.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	67	 All mice were inoculated intracerebrally with 20  microl inoculum under anaesthesia.

0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	70	Scoring of clinical TSE disease.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The presence of clinical TSE disease was assessed as described previously (Dickinson et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Animals were scored for clinical disease without reference to the genotype of the mouse.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Genotypes were confirmed for each animal by PCR analysis of tail DNA at the end of the experiment.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Incubation times were calculated as the interval between inoculation and cull due to terminal TSE disease.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Mice were killed by cervical dislocation at the terminal stage of disease, at termination of the experiment (between 600 and 700 days) or for welfare reasons due to intercurrent illness.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Half-brains were fixed in 10 % formal saline for 48 h, followed by decontamination in 98 % formic acid for 1 h.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The remaining half-brain was frozen at  to 70  degrees C for biochemical analysis.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Fixed brain tissue was dehydrated in alcohol and impregnated in wax during a 7 h automated processing cycle.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Sections were cut coronally at four levels and mounted on Superfrost slides.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Sections were haematoxylin/eosin-stained and scored for vacuolar degeneration on a scale of 0 to 5 in nine standard grey-matter areas and three standard white-matter areas, as described previously (Fraser  and  Dickinson, 1967).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	81	 A 2 to 3 cm portion of tail was removed post-mortem from each mouse.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	82	 DNA was prepared from a 1 cm piece of tail by digestion overnight at 37  degrees C in tail lysis buffer [300 mM sodium acetate, 1 % SDS, 10 mM Tris (pH 8), 1 mM EDTA, 200  microg PK ml to 1)] and subsequent extraction with an equal volume of phenol/chloroform.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	83	 DNA was precipitated with 2-propanol, washed with 70 % ethanol and resuspended in 100  microl TE buffer [10 mM Tris, 1 mM EDTA (pH 7 4)].
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	84	 A 605 bp PCR fragment for the Prnp ORF was generated from purified tail DNA with an ORF primer, PrP5' >  (5'-GTGGCTGGGGACAACCCCAT-3'), and an exon 3 3'-untranslated region primer, PrP3' <  (5'-GCCTAGACCACGAGAATGCG-3').
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Cycle conditions were: 35 cycles, 94  degrees C (30 s), 65  degrees C (30 s), 72  degrees C (1 min).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The PrnpLV allele was detected by the absence of a BstEII site within this product compared with the wild-type Prnpa allele.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The PrnpFT allele was detected by the absence of an MnlI site compared with the wild-type Prnpa allele.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	88	HM-1 ES cell clones bearing the targeted PrnpFT or PrnpLV alleles were injected into 3 5-day-old BALB/c blastocysts to create chimeric mice (Moore et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	89	, 1995), which were crossed with 129/Ola mice to establish the FT/FT and LV/LV transgenic lines co-isogenic with 129/Ola.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The identical genetic background of the lines ensured that any observed alterations in incubation time and disease pathology were a direct result of the targeted mutations and were not due to the effects of genes in mice of other genetic backgrounds.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	91	Expression of PrP in the gene-targeted lines Expression levels of Prnp mRNA and mature PrPC were investigated in FT/FT and LV/LV brain and compared with those in wild-type 129/Ola mice (LT/LT) and the existing gene-targeted transgenic line expressing Prnpa[108F_189V] (FV/FV) (Moore et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	92	 3) analysis of tissues from each line confirmed expression from the PrnpFT and PrnpLV alleles and indicated that the levels of expression in the three homozygous lines (FV/FV, LV/LV and FT/FT) were indistinguishable from those of wild-type 129/Ola mice.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Prnp gene expression was therefore not affected by the process of gene targeting, the introduction of a single polymorphism or the presence of the LoxP site 3' of the Prnp gene.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Thus, any alteration in incubation time and neuropathology observed on inoculation of these animals with TSE infectivity should be attributable to the specific alterations at codons 108 and 189, and not due to any differences in Prnp gene-expression levels.

0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	99	  View larger version (38K):    Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Western blot of uninfected mice expressing codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms.
