0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	103	  Interactions between codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms and ME7 scrapie The ME7 strain of mouse scrapie is passaged in mice that are homozygous for the Prnpa gene (LT/LT) and produces short incubation times in Prnpa (LT/LT) mice and prolonged incubation times in Prnpb (FV/FV) mice.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Following ME7 challenge, LT/FV mice had incubation times of 223 days, intermediate between those of the parental lines LT/LT (155 days) and the gene-targeted FV/FV (295 days).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	105	 This pattern of allelic interaction recapitulates that observed between wild-type Prnpa, Prnpb and F1 crosses and demonstrates that the gene-targeted FV allele can reproduce the dominance pattern observed in mice with wild-type PrP alleles.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Incubation times of 168 and 261 days were obtained in FT/FT and LV/LV lines of mice, respectively (Table 1), which were distinct from those in wild-type LT/LT and gene-targeted FV/FV mice, indicating that neither 108F nor 189T is solely responsible for the increased incubation time in FV/FV mice.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The most significant change in incubation time was due to the T to V alteration at codon 189, producing a difference of 100 days between LT/LT and LV/LV lines.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	108	 A much smaller difference of 13 days was produced by the L to F polymorphism at codon 108 (FT/FT), demonstrating that both codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms can alter murine scrapie incubation times independently.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Incubation times of ME7 and 301V in mice with different genetic combinations at codons 108 and 189.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	110	  In order to assess the full effect of the polymorphisms in both the homozygous and heterozygous situations, LV/LV and FT/FT mice were crossed with wild-type LT/LT mice, gene-targeted FV/FV mice and each other to produce the full repertoire of genetic combinations (Table 1).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	111	 This breeding strategy produced 10 lines of transgenic mice, each with a different PrP allelic combination.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Each line of mice was inoculated intracerebrally with ME7 and the resulting incubation times are shown in Table 1 and Supplementary Figure (available in JGV Online).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	113	Introducing heterozygosity at codons 108 and 189 revealed that the control of incubation time by these two polymorphisms is not as straightforward as suggested by data from the homozygous lines (Table 1).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	114	 There is no obvious pattern of allelic combination associated with increasing incubation time (see Supplementary Figure in JGV Online), with the exception that the two shortest incubation times are in mice that are homozygous for 189T (155 and 168 days) and the two longest are in mice that are homozygous for 189V (295 and 325 days), in keeping with identity at codon 189 with the source of the agent (LT/LT).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	115	 However, homozygosity at codon 189 does not always produce extreme incubation times, as LT/FT and LV/LV mice have intermediate incubation times of 196 and 261 days, respectively (Table 1).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	116	An association between genotype and incubation time can be identified when the 10 lines are examined by the allelic combinations at either codon 108 or codon 189 (Table 1).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	117	 When lines are sorted into groups by codon 189 genotype (189TT, 189VV or 189FV), the effect of codon 108 on incubation time is the same in each of the three groups: the shortest incubation times occur when the codon at 108 is homozygous for either L or F, although the shorter of the two is always 108LL, matching that of the source of the inoculum (LT/LT).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Therefore, at codon 108, heterozygosity always leads to increased incubation times with respect to the combination at codon 189, despite the inoculum matching one allele at codon 108.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Indeed, incubation times in excess of those in Prnpb (FV/FV) mice were observed in FV/LV mice [Table 1 and Supplementary Figure (available in JGV Online)].
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	120	 However, when sorted by codon 108 genotype (108LL, 108FF or 108LF), a different pattern of incubation time is observed.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	121	 For each of the three groups, homozygosity for threonine at codon 189 (which matches the source of the inoculum) gives the shortest incubation times and homozygosity for valine (which does not match the inoculum) gives the longest incubation times, whilst the heterozygotes (TV) produce intermediate incubation times.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Hence, at codon 108, ME7 incubation times follow the pattern LL < FF < LF, whilst at codon 189, the pattern of incubation time is TT < TV < VV.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	123	 These results show that the effect on incubation period depends upon the combination of PrP alleles, particularly the presence of homozygosity or heterozygosity at codons 108 and 189 and on identity with the source of the inoculum at these positions in PrP.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	124	Interactions between codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms and the 301V strain In contrast to ME7 challenge, LT/LT mice inoculated with the Prnpb (FV/FV)-passaged strain 301V have long incubation periods of 240 days.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Similarly, FV/FV mice that have long ME7 incubation periods produce short incubation periods of 125 days with 301V.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The role of codons 108 and 189 in the control of 301V incubation time was explored by challenge of FT/FT and LV/LV mice.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Incubation times of 141 and 202 days were obtained in the LV/LV and FT/FT lines of mice, respectively, compared to 125 days in FV/FV mice and 240 days in LT/LT mice (Table 1).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Hence, in agreement with the data obtained from inoculations with ME7, both codons 108 and 189 are responsible for the control of incubation time for the 301V agent strain.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Similarly to ME7, the greatest effect was produced by the T to V alteration at codon 189 (100 days reduction).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	130	 However the L to F change produced a greater effect on incubation time with 301V (60 days reduction) than with ME7, again showing that challenge with an agent that shows identity at codon 108 or 189 results in the shortest incubation times (Table 1).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The full range of allelic combinations has not been examined with this strain of TSE agent.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	132	 In addition, no incubation time is available for the LT/FT line.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Six LT/FT mice were culled due to welfare reasons between 327 and 377 days and all showed positive TSE pathology on examination of the brain tissue, suggesting an incubation time in excess of that of the LT/LT line (240 days).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	134	 However, the combinations that were examined have produced patterns of incubation-time alteration identical to those identified with ME7 [Table 1 and Supplementary Figure (available in JGV Online)], with the exception that the F1 cross LT/FV has an incubation time in excess of those of both parental lines.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	135	 This overdominance is characteristic of 301V and can be observed with other TSE strains.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Thus, the pattern of incubation time for 301V appears to be FF < LL < LF at codon 108 and VV < TV < TT at codon 189.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	137	 This pattern is the same as that observed for ME7, where heterozygosity results in extended incubation times for 108LF, but intermediate incubation times with 189TV.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The shortest incubation times for both strains of agent reveal a preference for identity with the genotype of the donor of infectivity (LT/LT for ME7 and FV/FV for 301V).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	139	Effect of polymorphisms on PrPSc production Detergent homogenates were prepared from three terminal ME7 brains of each genotype.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The homogenates were treated with PK and analysed by immunoblotting to assess the levels of PK-resistant PrP present in each model.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Equal levels of PK-resistant PrP were detected between the three mice of each genotype (data not shown).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Levels were also similar between the 10 different lines of mice (Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	143	 4), suggesting that the codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms have no effect on PrPSc levels in the brains of mice culled with clinical ME7 infection.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This was also true for the lines challenged with 301V (data not shown).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	145	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Western blot analysis of PrPSc levels in different allelic combinations inoculated with ME7.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Lanes 1 to 4, ME7-infected homozygous lines: 1, LT/LT; 2, FV/FV; 3, LV/LV; 4, FT/FT.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Lanes 5 to 10, ME7-infected heterozygous lines: 5, LT/FV; 6, LV/LT; 7, LV/FV; 8, FT/LT; 9, FT/FV; 10, FT/LV.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	149	 All samples were treated with PK at 20  microg ml to 1 for 1 h at 37  degrees C.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Blot was probed with anti-PrP monoclonal antibody 7A12.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Equivalent levels of PrPSc are present in all lines of mice.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	152	  Effect of polymorphisms on vacuolar pathology The targeting of vacuolar pathology in the brain was similar for all allelic combinations infected with ME7 (Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Thus, the codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms in host PrP do not influence the distribution of vacuolar pathology with the ME7 strain of scrapie.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	154	 However, the polymorphisms appeared to affect the degree of vacuolation.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	155	 In general, lines containing 189TT (LT/LT, FT/FT and LT/FT) or 189TV with homozygosity at 108 (LT/LV and FT/FV) had short incubation times ( < 215 days) and gave very similar vacuolation profiles.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Lines displaying higher vacuolation scores had longer incubation times and contained 189VV (FV/FV, LV/LV or FV/LV) or were heterozygous at both 108 and 189 (LV/FT).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	157	 However, the LT/FV heterozygote gave a vacuolation profile more similar to that in LT/LT mice (Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Alternatively, these observations may simply reflect incubation time of disease, with high degrees of vacuolation being associated with extended incubation times.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	159	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Lesion profiles of LV/LV and FT/FT transgenic mice infected with ME7 and 301V.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The extent of vacuolar change in the brain was assessed semi-quantitatively in nine areas of grey matter and three areas of white matter by lesion profiling, as described previously (Fraser  and  Dickinson, 1967).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Animals were scored on a scale of 0 to 5 in each specific area; mean scores (calculated from a minimum of six animals) are shown graphically (error bars plus or minus SEM).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Grey-matter scoring areas: 1, dorsal medulla: 2, cerebellar cortex; 3, superior colliculus; 4, hypothalamus; 5, medial thalamus; 6, hippocampus; 7, septum; 8, cerebral cortex; 9, forebrain cerebral cortex.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	164	 White-matter scoring areas: 1*, cerebellar white matter; 2*, midbrain white matter; 3*, cerebral peduncle.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	165	 (a) ME7 in lines with profiles similar to LT/LT mice; (b) ME7 in lines with profiles similar to FV/FV mice; (d) 301V in lines with profiles similar to LT/LT mice; (e) 301V in lines with profiles similar to FV/FV mice; (c, f) LT/LT, FV/FV and LT/FV lines with ME7 and 301V, respectively.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	166	  The effect of the codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms on targeting was more prominent in 301V-infected lines, where the targeting of vacuolation varied between LT/LT and FV/FV mice (Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	167	 189VV mice (LV/LV) and 189TV mice homozygous at codon 108 (LV/LT) gave profiles similar to those of FV/FV mice, whilst 189TT mice (FT/FT and LT/FT) gave profiles similar to those of LT/LT mice (Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The LT/FV heterozygote produced an intermediate vacuolation profile (Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The degree of vacuolation with 301V therefore does appear to be controlled by the codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms and not by incubation time, as extended incubation times in FT/FT and LT/FT mice resulted in lower vacuolation scores in areas 7 to 9 compared to FV/FV mice (Fig.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	170	The control of incubation time is thought to be due to PrP sequence identity between the host and the donor of infectivity.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	171	 However, our results show that short incubation times are obtained in FT/FT mice inoculated with LT/LT-derived ME7 and in LV/LV mice inoculated with FV/FV-derived 301V, despite the sequence incompatibility between donor and host at codon 108.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Hence, although codon 108 polymorphisms can affect scrapie incubation time independently, the major control is due to identity with the source of inoculum at codon 189.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The inoculation of mice expressing different combinations of PrnpLT, PrnpFV, PrnpLV and PrnpFT produced a complex series of incubation times (see Supplementary Figure in JGV Online).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	174	 It was clear that, in addition to identity with the inoculum at codon 189, homozygosity at codon 108 consistently gave rise to shorter incubation times in both 108L/L- and 108F/F-expressing lines.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Heterozygosity at codon 108 always resulted in extended incubation times with respect to the genotype at codon 189.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Although the series of allelic crosses produced for these experiments are described as homozygous and heterozygous at codons 108 and 189, expression from both Prnp alleles in a heterozygote will result in the presence of two different PrP populations in the cell.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	177	 It is interactions between these proteins, and not between Prnp alleles, that will determine the incubation time of disease.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Hence, the nature or combination of PrP variants in the recipient may be more important than PrP identity with the inoculum, indicating that interactions between amino acids 108 and 189, either on the same or different proteins, is a critical part of disease propagation.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	179	It has been proposed that the production of PrPSc is a two-step process that involves binding of PrP-res (PK-resistant PrP) to PrP-sen (PK-sensitive PrP), followed by the conversion of PrP-sen to PrP-res (Caughey, 2001).
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	180	 However, it is unknown which process requires PrP amino acid identity.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Cell-free conversion experiments have shown that mouse PrP-res (108L_111V) will convert mouse PrP-sen expressing the 3F4 epitope (108M_111M), but not hamster PrP-sen (also possessing the 3F4 epitope), even though both proteins were found to bind to mouse PrP-res (Horiuchi et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Deletion mutants lacking residues 34 to 113 (MoPrP34 to 113) also bound to mouse PrP-res and converted, albeit with reduced efficiency (Lawson et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	183	 These results imply that amino acid 108 is not required for either initiation of conversion or binding to PrPSc, but may be involved in the control of the rate of conversion and final conformation of PrP-res (Lawson et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Moreover, MoPrP34 to 113 was found to bind heterologous PrPSc, but, unlike the full-length molecule, did not prevent the conversion of homologous PrPC, again suggesting that this region is involved in the control of conversion, but not binding (Lawson et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The 34 to 113 truncation of PrPC was also found to affect the solubility of the molecule, as loss of these residues reduced the percentage of PrP-sen that was seen to self-aggregate when incubated under cell-free assay conditions in the absence of PrP-res.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	186	 This region may therefore be responsible for some degree of multimerization/aggregation of PrP-sen, which may be beneficial for conversion (Lawson et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	187	The individual effects of codon 108 and 189 polymorphisms in PrP have also been modelled in vitro by expressing recombinant 108F_189T and 108L_189V PrP in Escherichia coli (Brown et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	188	 These intermediate forms of PrP were found to be less stable than both PrP-A (108L_189T) and PrP-B (108F_189V) and were observed to lose their normal conformation and gain some PK resistance over time.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	189	 It was proposed that inheritance of either 108F or 189V alone may be a disadvantage in terms of mouse survival, and that mice expressing either of these polymorphisms separately could potentially develop spontaneous disease (Brown et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	190	 However, the recently reported existence of a Prnpc (108F_189T)-expressing line (Lloyd et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	191	, 2004) and the data presented here for transgenic FT/FT and LV/LV lines show that such mice are viable and do not develop any neurological phenotype during their lifespan.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	192	 PrP expressed in the brains of transgenic LT/LT and FV/FV mice is PK-sensitive and expressed at levels identical to those in wild-type mice of both genotypes.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	193	 These results demonstrate clearly that in vitro and in vivo studies can produce very different outcomes; these may be due to the difference in PrP post-translational modification and/or the physiological environment of the native protein.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	194	From the data presented here, we predict that: (i) polymorphisms at PrP codon 189 control the initial interaction and binding with the agent, as incubation times reflect a preference for sequence identity between the host and inoculum at codon 189; and (ii) polymorphisms at codon 108 control the rate of conversion of PrPC to PrPSc, where the ability to induce multimerization of PrPC and increase the efficiency of conversion is favoured when all PrP expressed in a cell is homogeneous in the N-terminal region.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Alternatively, the preference for codon 108 homozygosity may reflect a more complex interaction between host PrPC and PrPSc that is less efficient in the presence of heterogeneous protein populations.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	196	 However, the importance of codon 108 homozygosity in murine scrapie transmission may explain the role of PrP codon 129 in human TSE disease, where the majority of CJD cases occur in individuals who are homozygous for methionine or valine at codon 129 (Palmer et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	197	 There is an under-representation of M/V heterozygotes with CJD when compared to the distribution of genotypes in the normal population (Palmer et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	198	, 1991), suggesting that a similar mechanism requiring N-terminal homogeneity controls the efficiency of disease transmission in humans.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	199	The results of transmissions to the 108L/F_189T/V lines of transgenic mice have therefore shown that codon 189 polymorphisms exert the major control over scrapie incubation time, but that the efficiency of disease transmission is increased when codon 108 is homozygous, suggesting that a multimer of PrPC may be involved in conversion of PrP during TSE disease.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Several other studies have suggested the involvement of PrP dimers in disease (Priola et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	201	, 1995; Warwicker, 1997, 2000; Meyer et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	202	, 2003), yet most existing dimer models do not consider dimerization of the N-terminal region of PrP, due to the lack of structural information available for this region.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Combined with the in vivo data produced in this study, the observations that amino acids 90 to 121 are retained after PK cleavage of PrPSc and that deletion of this region affects susceptibility to disease (Fischer et al.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	204	, 2001) prove that this is a structurally important part of the molecule that is involved in the control of disease incubation time.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	205	Analysis of LV/LV and FT/FT transgenic mice has therefore shown that amino acid polymorphisms at both codons 108 and 189 in murine PrP are involved in the control of scrapie incubation time, and that distinct regions of PrP may play different roles in the disease process.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Interactions within a single PrP molecule and between molecules must therefore underlie the mechanism by which incubation times are controlled.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Such structural interactions may provide the key to replication of TSE infectivity.
0.16557215.15722549.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In Prions and Prion Diseases: Current Perspectives, pp.

0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	0	Specific inhibition of pathological prion protein accumulation by small interfering RNAs Nathalie Daude*, Mathieu Marella* and Joelle Chabry.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	1	Institut de Pharmacologie Moleculaire et Cellulaire, Unite Mixte de Recherche 6097, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	2	 660, route des lucioles, 06560 Valbonne, France.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	3	Author for correspondence (e-mail: chabry{at}ipmc.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	4	Key words: Transmissible spongiform encephalopathy, Prion, siRNA, Scrapie, PrP-res, PrPsc, PrP-sen, Prnp.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	5	Chronically scrapie-infected cell lines have been extensively used as models for selecting `anti-prion' drugs such as porphyrines (Caughey et al.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	6	, 1998), amphotericin B (Mange et al.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	7	, 2000) and quinacrine (Doh-Ura et al.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Since PrP-sen expression is essential for both TSE pathogenesis and conversion leading to PrP-res accumulation, we studied the effect of specific Prnp gene silencing molecules in scrapie-infected neuroblastoma cells (N2aS12sc+).
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) provide new powerful tools to potentially silence any targeted gene (Elbashir et al.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Because siRNA duplexes trigger specific gene silencing in mammalian somatic cells without the activation of any unspecific response, the analysis of gene function in cultured cells has now become possible.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Here, we show that transient transfection of siRNA duplexes designed from the mouse Prnp gene (moPrnp) causes a rapid loss of PrP-sen expression and abrogates PrP-res formation in N2aS12sc+ cells.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	12	 By contrast, the scrambled siRNA failed to inhibit both the PrP-sen expression and PrP-res accumulation in these cells suggesting a highly specific siRNA effect.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Finally, we demonstrate that the siRNA gene silencing is independent of both the host cell types and mouse-adapted scrapie strain.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	14	Cell cultures Neuroblastoma N2a cells over-expressing mouse PrP (subclone #58) were cultured in Opti-MEM containing 10% inactivated FBS (FBSi), penicillin-streptomycin and 1 mg/l G418.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This cell line named N2aS12sc+ has been chronically infected with brain homogenates of Chandler strain-infected mice (Nishida et al.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Since the treatment of N2aS12sc+ cells with Congo Red (1  microg/ml) totally cured the cells of PrP-res, Congo Red-treated N2aS12 cells were used as uninfected cells (N2aS12).
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The GT1 cells, infected with brain homogenates of 22L murine scrapie strain, were grown in Dulbecco modified Eagle's medium containing 5% fetal calf serum, 5% horse serum, and penicillin-streptomycin.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	18	 All cultured cells were maintained at 37 degrees C in 5% CO2 and split 1:4 every 4 days.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	19	siRNA preparation and transfection siRNAs corresponding to the moPrnp gene from codon 392 to 410 were synthesized by Eurogentec (Seraing, Belgium).
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Typically, siRNAs were made of 19 ribonucleotides followed by two extra thymidine bases at the 3' end overhang on both strands.

0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	93	To determine whether the PrP-res depletion induced by siRNA was transient or permanent, chronically infected N2aS12sc+ cells were transfected once with 400 nM siRNA and then cultured for either one and two weeks through two and four passages, respectively.

0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	95	 PrP-sen was barely detectable in transfected cells before passaging but levels increased with the number of passages, reaching the level observed with untreated-cells after four passages.

0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	108	The factors responsible for the rate and the strength of siRNA-induced gene suppression are currently unknown.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Here, we demonstrate that siRNA designed from the moPrnp gene was highly specific to cells expressing the PrP mouse sequence.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The siRNA effect was independent of both the scrapie strains and the host cell type.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Furthermore, no difference in siRNA efficiency was observed between moPrP overexpressing cells (N2aS12 subclone) and N2a cells expressing only endogenous PrP (data not shown).
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The finding that exposure of chronically infected neuroblastoma cells to siRNA results in undetectable amounts of PrP-res after 3-4 days, suggests that these cells express proteases that degrade PrP-res aggregates.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	113	 have proposed that the cellular level of PrP-res is determined by the rate of its formation from the substrate, PrP-sen, and its catabolism (Enari et al.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The removal of PrP-sen could displace the equilibrium to the degradation processes.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	115	 An obvious limitation is that although PrP-res levels were dramatically decreased by acute siRNA exposure, the cells were not definitively `cured' of scrapie infection; thus, chronic treatments or longer exposures of siRNA may be considered in the future.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	116	 We are currently performing experiments to improve the long-term effects of siRNA duplexes.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	117	Interestingly, a recent report has shown the selective suppression of gene expression induced by siRNA in primary mammalian neurons (Krichevsky and Kosik, 2002).
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The role of PrP and its interaction with putative partners in neurons have not yet been clarified.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Thus, siRNA technology should provide insights into the understanding of the physiological functions of PrP in somatic cultured cells.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	120	Although there is likely to be technical difficulties with siRNA delivery in vivo, its use to inhibit gene expression in mice has recently been reported (Lewis et al.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Although efficient and powerful brain delivery systems remain to be found, it appears likely that siRNA technology could constitute a new promising strategy for therapy against TSEs.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Current drug treatments delay, but do not prevent, the appearance of clinical symptoms and death in experimental scrapie-infected animals (Demaimay et al.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The in vivo use of siRNA alone, or in combination with these drugs, should be considered to improve the life span and cure sick animals.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The recent development of siRNA technology offers a powerful tool to ablate specific gene expression in a wide range of mammalian cells including neurons.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	125	Our results show that the siRNA technique should be useful for dissecting basic mechanisms of prion pathogenesis, in addition to its obvious potential as a therapeutic agent.
0.16906957.12759373.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Ultimately it may give effective results in therapy of numerous neurodegenerative diseases linked to expression of misfolded endogenous proteins such as Alzheimer's, Huntington's and Parkinson's diseases.

0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	0	MINIREVIEW PROLOGUE Prions of Mammals and Fungi Minireview Series* Herbert Tabor.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Laboratory of Biochemistry and Genetics, NIDDK, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	2	The mammalian spongiform encephalopathies gave rise to the concept of infectious proteins, proteins that can transmit an infection without an essential nucleic acid.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	3	 This concept is now identified with the term "prion.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	4	" These diseases, including scrapie of sheep, bovine spongiform encephalopathy, and human Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (and its variants), are believed to be the result of a self-propagating change of PrP, a cell surface protein.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The minireview in this issue by Charles Weissmann (1) examines the spongiform encephalopathies and summarizes work from a number of laboratories.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	6	In 1994, it was suggested that two non-chromosomal genetic elements of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, [URE3] and [PSI], were infectious protein (prion) forms of Ure2p and Sup35p.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	7	 These findings have been particularly exciting because these systems will permit the application of the powerful genetic methods available in yeast to the study of the prion problem.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Recently, [Het-s], a non-Mendelian genetic element of the filamentous fungus Podospora anserina has been identified as another likely prion.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In each case, the evidence points to an altered form of a chromosomally encoded protein that has acquired the ability to convert the normal form of the protein into the same altered (prion) abnormal form.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	10	 These new developments will be summarized in a second minireview by Reed Wickner et al.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	11	 (2), focused on the evidence that prions of yeast and fungi can serve as genetic material, and a third by Susan Liebman and Irina Derkatch (3) discussing the yeast [PSI+] prion in detail, including its interactions with chaperones and other proteins.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Although the epidemic of "mad cow disease" has brought this field to the headlines, its scientific excitement rests more on the notion that altered protein conformations can impart disease and the somewhat revolutionary concepts of infection and heredity that have come out of this work.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	13	* This minireview will be reprinted in the 1999 Minireview Compendium, which will be available in December, 1999.
0.17309903.9867801.html.plaintext.txt	14	Copyright   1999 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.

0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	3	Correspondence Rona Barron rona.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	4	Present address: Scottish Crop Research Institute, Invergowrie, Dundee, UK.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	5	The influence of other amino acid substitutions in the murine Prnp gene on the incubation time of disease has been demonstrated previously.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The substitution of leucine for proline at amino acid 101 (101L) in the murine Prnpa allele by gene targeting (Prnpa101L) has been shown to shorten TSE incubation times with P102L GSS from humans, 263K from hamsters and SSBP/1 from sheep when compared with wild-type (101P) mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Conversely, a second human TSE agent, variant CJD (vCJD), displayed prolonged incubation times in Prnpa101L (101LL) mice when compared with wild-type mice (Barron et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Furthermore, when challenged with the mouse-passaged scrapie strains ME7 (derived from mice carrying the Prnpa gene) and 22A (derived from mice carrying the Prnpb gene), the 101LL mice also displayed increased incubation times when compared with mice homozygous for either Prnpa or Prnpb alleles (Barron et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Transgenic mice overexpressing murine PrP containing a methionine substitution at position 108 have also been shown to produce a lengthening in scrapie incubation time compared with mice overexpressing the wild-type gene; however, the effect of mutation and transgene copy number cannot readily be separated in these experiments (Supattapone et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	10	The mechanism by which these polymorphisms and mutations in murine PrP control incubation time has not yet been established.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Amino acids 101 and 108 are located in the N-terminal region of PrP (amino acids 21 to 121), which has been described in NMR structural studies as having no discernible secondary structure (Donne et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	12	 However, despite the apparent lack of structure, this region of PrP contains the octapeptide repeat sequences which have been shown to bind copper, and therefore may influence both the structure and the function of the normal protein (Brown et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1997; Brown  and  Harris, 2002).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Deletion studies have shown also that removing sections of the N-terminal region can cause increased incubation times and reduced efficiency of disease propagation in mice (Flechsig et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	15	, 2001), and can reduce efficiency of PrPC conversion in cell-free conversion assays (Lawson et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Due to the close proximity of amino acids 101 and 108, it is possible that similar mechanisms are operating by which changes at these positions in murine PrP control scrapie incubation time in mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In order to further investigate the role of this region of PrP in influencing TSE disease transmission, we have inoculated 101LL mice with four mouse-passaged TSE strains derived from both Prnpa and Prnpb mice, and compared the disease profile of 101LL mice with that of Prnpa and Prnpb mice of the same genetic background.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	18	Scoring of clinical TSE disease.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The presence of clinical TSE disease was assessed as described (Dickinson et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Incubation times were calculated as the interval between inoculation and cull due to terminal TSE disease.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Mice were killed by cervical dislocation at the terminal stage of disease, at termination of the experiment (between 600 to 700 days), or due to intercurrent illness.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Half brains were fixed in 10 % formol saline for 48 h, followed by decontamination in 98 % formic acid for 1 h.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The remaining half brain was frozen at -70  degrees C for Western blot analysis.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Fixed brain tissue was dehydrated in alcohol and impregnated in wax during a 7 h automated processing cycle.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Sections were cut coronally at four levels and mounted on Superfrost slides.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Sections were haematoxylin  and  eosin stained and scored for vacuolar degeneration on a scale of 0 to 5 in nine standard grey matter areas and three standard white matter areas as described previously (Fraser  and  Dickinson, 1967).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Mean scores were produced from a minimum of six mice and plotted with standard error of mean (SEM) against scoring areas to give a lesion profile for each strain with each agent.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	28	 For detection of PrPSc in transgenic and wild-type mice, 10 % (w/v) homogenates of frozen brain tissue were prepared in NP40 buffer [0 5 % (v/v) NP40, 0 5 % (w/v) sodium deoxycholate, 150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 5].
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Homogenates were centrifuged at 10 000 g for 15 min at 4  degrees C to remove cellular debris.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Clarified supernates (100 mg wet weight ml-1) were incubated with or without Proteinase K at 20  microg ml-1 for 1 h at 37  degrees C, and the reaction terminated by addition of PMSF.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Samples were mixed with 2x sample buffer (Novex, Invitrogen) at 10 mg ml-1 final concentration and incubated at 90  degrees C for 20 min.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Total protein estimates were not performed, as the effect of the mutation on PrPSc levels was unknown.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Samples were therefore loaded as wet weight tissue equivalents.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Twenty  microl of each sample (approximately 200  microg wet weight tissue) was separated on 12 % Novex Tris/glycine acrylamide gels (Invitrogen).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Proteins were transferred onto PVDF membrane by electroblotting, and incubated for 2 h at room temperature with mAbs 8H4 or 7A12 (Zanusso et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	36	, 1998) at 50 ng  microl-1 concentration.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Proteins were visualized with horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-conjugated rabbit anti-mouse secondary antibody (Jackson ImmunoResearch), and a chemiluminescence detection kit (Roche Diagnostics).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Membranes were exposed to X-ray film for periods ranging from 10 s to 10 min.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	39	 All P101L transgenic mice were genotyped after termination of experiments to confirm genotype.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	40	 A 765 bp fragment containing the Prnp ORF was generated using a 5' primer (5'-ATGGCGAACCTTGGCTACTGGCTG-3'; position 107 to 130, GenBank acc.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	41	 M18070) and a 3' primer (5'-TCATCCCACGATCAGGAAGATGAG-3'; position 871 to 848, GenBank acc.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Cycle conditions were: 94  degrees C for 3 min, followed by 30 cycles of 30 s at 94  degrees C, 30 s at 62  degrees C and 1 min at 72  degrees C.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	43	 This was followed by a final 10 min at 72  degrees C (Biometra Triblock).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The presence or absence of a DdeI site within the PCR product provided a marker for the codon 101P to L alteration.

0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	51	 ME7 and 22A 101LL incubation times taken from Manson et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	52	  When inoculated with 139A and 79A, 101LL mice produced extended incubation times which were approximately double those obtained in Prnpa mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	53	 This observation was similar to that obtained previously with ME7 (Manson et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	54	 In order to assess whether this mechanism of control on incubation time could be similar to that of the 108F/189V polymorphisms, we compared the incubation times of these agents in Prnpa(108F/189V) mice, which are the same genetic background as 101LL mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The results showed that 79A and 139A incubation times were increased in both 101LL and Prnpa(108F/189V) mice when compared with Prnpa mice (Table 1, Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	56	 However, the degree to which incubation times were extended varied with the strain of agent.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	57	 With the 79A strain of agent the 108F/189V alterations lead to a more prolonged incubation time than the 101L mutation, whereas the opposite was true for the 139A strain.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	58	 This suggested that the interaction with each strain of agent and control of incubation time differs with 108F/189V and 101L.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	59	For the strains derived from mice homozygous for the Prnpb allele the situation was more complex.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Incubation times of 79V are reduced in Prnpa mice (234 days) compared with the expected homologous transmission in VM (Prnpb) mice of 270 days (Bruce, 1993) (data not available from transmission of 79V to Prnpa(108F/189V) mice).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	61	 However, the incubation time in 101LL mice was found to be extended by over 100 days with respect to both Prnpa and Prnpb genotypes (377 days).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	62	 With 301V, incubation times in both Prnpa and 101LL mice were extended with respect to Prnpa(108F/189V) mice, but the degree to which the incubation times were increased was greater in Prnpa than in 101LL mice (70 day difference).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	63	 These results also differed from those obtained previously with 22A (also Prnpb derived) in which incubation times of Prnpa and 101LL mice were increased by approximately the same degree compared with Prnpa(108F/189V) mice (Table 1, Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	64	 However, in transmissions of Prnpb strains of agent to 101LL mice, the observed effects are due to three amino acid changes in host PrP (108, 189 and 101).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	65	 To truly examine the effect of the 101L mutation on Prnpb-derived strains of agent would require the mutation to be expressed on this allele, as the possibility of combinatory or compensatory mechanisms of the 101L and 108L alterations cannot be ignored during infection with Prnpb strains (Vorberg et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	66	 However, the effect of Prnpb strains in Prnpa and 101LL mice (which differ by only one amino acid) was unpredictable.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	67	 While the 79V strain showed a further lengthening of the Prnpa incubation time in the presence of the 101L mutation, a reduction in the Prnpa incubation time was observed in 101LL mice inoculated with the 301V strain.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	68	 These results, particularly those produced with the 301V strain, again indicate that the control of incubation time by the 101L mutation is different from that of the 108/189 polymorphisms.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	69	 While the present results are unable to separate the effect of 108F from that of 189V we are currently addressing this issue in two further lines of gene-targeted mice homozygous for either Prnpa108F/189T or Prnpa108L/189V alleles.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	70	101L mutation can affect PrPSc production It had been observed previously that brain tissue from 101LL mice infected with ME7 contained lower levels of protease-resistant PrP at the terminal stage of disease than wild-type mice (Manson et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	71	 To determine whether the 101L mutation in the host PrP gene influenced the level of protease-resistant PrP produced by other strains of mouse scrapie, brain homogenates were prepared from 101LL and wild-type Prnpa mice infected with the Prnpa strains 139A and 79A, and the Prnpb strains 22A, 79V and 301V, and analysed by Western blotting with mAbs 7A12 and 8H4.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Preliminary analysis focused on three mice of each genotype with each strain of agent, to assess whether levels of PrPSc in the brain were consistent, or varied between animals.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	73	 For all transmissions, similar levels of PrPSc were observed between three mice in each group, except for the transmission of 22A to 101LL mice (data not shown).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Comparison of 101LL and Prnpa mice inoculated with Prnpa strains showed that heterologous transmissions to 101LL mice produced levels of PrPSc identical to those seen in the homologous transmission to Prnpa mice, despite the difference in incubation times (Table 1 and Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Similarly, transmission of 79V and 301V produced the same PrPSc levels in 101LL and Prnpa mice despite heterologous transmission in the presence of three and two PrP amino acid differences respectively.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The difference seen between 101LL and Prnpa mice with 79V on this blot appears, on examination of the lanes without proteinase K treatment, to be due to protein loadings (Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	77	 2a, lanes 5 to 8), as protein concentrations were calculated from wet weight of tissue.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Previous analysis has shown PrPSc levels in these mice to be similar (data not shown).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	79	 However, the heterologous challenge of 101LL mice with Prnpb strain 22A did show some degree of variation in the level of PrPSc present.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Of three animals examined, one showed similar levels to those found on inoculation of Prnpa mice, but the others contained much lower levels (Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The presence of the 101L mutation therefore does not affect the level of PrPSc produced by some strains of agent, but can alter PrPSc levels with other strains independent of the Prnp genotype of the source of infectivity, as found here with 22A and previously with ME7 (Manson et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	82	View larger version (63K):    Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Western blot analysis of brain homogenates for the presence of PrPSc, using mAb 7A12.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	84	 (a) Lanes 1 to 4, 79A; lanes 5 to 8, 79V; lanes 9 to 12, 139A.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	85	 (b) Lanes 1 to 4, 301V; lanes 5 to 10, 22A.

0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	89	  Targeting of vacuolation The effect of the 101L mutation in host PrP on targeting of pathology was assessed by comparing the degree of vacuolation in mice carrying the 101L mutation with that in mice carrying wild-type 101P PrP (Prnpa).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The degree of vacuolation in specific brain areas is characteristic of individual mouse-passaged scrapie strains.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Vacuolation is scored on a scale of 0 to 5 in nine grey matter and three white matter areas, and average scores ( plus or minus SEM) plotted to give a lesion profile, which is essentially a fingerprint for each strain (Fraser  and  Dickinson, 1967).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Lesion profiles were produced for each strain of mouse scrapie, comparing mean vacuolation scores from 101LL and Prnpa mice displaying both clinical and pathological signs of TSE disease (Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The heterologous transmission to 101LL mice of Prnpa-derived strains 139A and 79A produced significant variation in the targeting of vacuolation when compared with the corresponding homologous transmission in Prnpa mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The 139A and 79A Prnpa-derived mouse scrapie strains share a common lineage, and produce identical lesion profiles in wild-type mice of both Prnp genotypes.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	95	 These strains can, however, be distinguished by their incubation times in Prnpb (or Prnpa(108F/189V)) mice (Table 1, Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Both of these strains displayed increased levels of vacuolation in areas 1 (dorsal medulla), 3 (superior colliculus), 4 (hypothalamus) and 7 (septum), but decreased levels of vacuolation in the white matter regions (1* cerebellar white matter, 2* midbrain white matter, 3* cerebral peduncle) of 101LL mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The change in vacuolar profile and incubation time of these two related strains in 101LL mice appears identical (Figs 1, 3; Table 1), indicating a similar interaction between each strain and the 101L mutation in PrP.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Heterologous challenges with Prnpb-derived strains (79V, 22A and 301V) produced less variability between Prnpa and 101LL mice, despite differing from the source of infectivity by two and three PrP amino acids respectively.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Identical lesion profiles were obtained in 101LL and Prnpa mice challenged with 301V, and although 79V showed reduced levels of vacuolation in areas 6 to 9 (hippocampus, septum, cerebral cortex and forebrain cerebral cortex) of the 101LL brain, the overall pattern was the same as in Prnpa mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The 22A strain showed slightly more variability due to altered levels of vacuolation in areas 4 (hypothalamus), 7 (septum) and 8 (cerebral cortex), but all other areas of grey and white matter showed identical targeting of vacuolation in both lines of mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The 101L mutation therefore exerts a strain-specific effect on vacuolar targeting ranging from little or no alteration with heterologous challenges differing at three amino acids (108L, 189T and 101L), to major alterations with heterologous challenges differing at only one amino acid (101L), which was also observed previously with ME7 (Manson et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	102	View larger version (19K):    Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The extent of vacuolar change in the brain was scored on a scale of 0 to 5 in nine areas of grey matter and three areas of white matter, and mean scores (calculated from a minimum of six animals) are shown graphically (error bars represent  plus or minus SEM).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Grey matter scoring areas: 1, dorsal medulla: 2, cerebellar cortex; 3, superior colliculus; 4, hypothalamus; 5, medial thalamus; 6, hippocampus; 7, septum; 8, cerebral cortex; 9, forebrain cerebral cortex.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	105	 White matter scoring areas: 1*, cerebellar white matter; 2*, midbrain white matter; 3*, cerebral peduncle.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Separate profiles are shown for each mouse TSE strain: (a) 79A, (b) 139A, (c) 79V, (d) 301V, (e) 22A.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	107	  Conclusions Transmission of TSE disease is thought to be most efficient when identical PrP sequences are present in both the donor and recipient of infectivity.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The differences in PrP sequence between species are thought to reduce the efficiency of conversion of PrPC to PrPSc, and result in low transmission frequencies and long incubation periods.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	109	 However, TSE infectivity from human, hamster and sheep brain tissue has previously been transmitted to 101LL mice with reduced incubation times compared with wild-type mice, despite the lack of PrP sequence identity between species (Barron et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The PrP sequence of C57BL mice (Prnpa) in which ME7, 139A and 79A are propagated differs from that of 101LL mice by only one amino acid (101P), yet incubation times in 101LL mice are 2-fold greater than in wild-type mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The PrP sequence of VM mice (Prnpb) in which 79V, 301V and 22A are propagated differs from 101LL mice at three residues (101P, 108F and 189V); however, the effect is in this case far less predictable.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	112	 With Prnpb-derived strains, incubation times observed in 101LL mice were also extended when compared with Prnpb mice, but were found to be both shorter (301V) and longer (79V and 22A) when compared with the Prnpa mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Thus within the mouse species the presence of the 101L alteration prolongs the scrapie incubation time normally observed in the donor genotype.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	114	 However for agents from other species, the effect of the 101L mutation appears in most cases to be to facilitate the transmission of disease, perhaps indicating that the 101L mutation allows more efficient adaptation of an agent in mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	115	The effect of the 101L mutation on murine scrapie incubation times largely parallels the effect of the 108/189 polymorphisms in murine PrP, as incubation times are extended in 101LL mice compared with the homologous transmission in either Prnpa or Prnpb mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	116	 However, the degree to which incubation times are affected by 101L is distinct from 108/189, and is also very unpredictable with Prnpb-derived strains.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Specific differences between 101L and 108/189 are also evident with some Prnpa-derived strains.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The related strains 139A and 79A produce almost identical incubation times and lesion profiles in Prnpa mice, but can be distinguished by their incubation times in Prnpb and Prnpa(108F/189V) mice, where the 79A incubation time is approximately 140 days longer than 139A (Table 1, Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	119	 On inoculation of 101LL mice, the 139A and 79A strains of agent produced almost identical incubation times and alterations in lesion profile (Table 1; Figs 1 and 3), proving that the 101L mutation alters the disease profile of these agents in a manner that is indeed distinct from that of 108/189.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Future experiments involving mice expressing Prnpa(108F/189T) will allow us to examine the influence of L108F alone on TSE disease progression, and to directly compare the effect of the L108F and P101L alterations.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	121	 These experiments may reveal how mutations in this unstructured N-terminal region of PrP can have dramatic effects on disease phenotype.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	122	Other mutations in the N-terminal region of murine PrP have also been shown to affect incubation times of murine scrapie strains.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The introduction of methionine at positions 108 and 111 in murine PrP (to create the epitope for mAb 3F4) increased the incubation times of four mouse-passaged scrapie strains in transgenic mice overexpressing Prnpa(108M/111M) compared with mice overexpressing Prnpa (Supattapone et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The mutations caused prolonged incubation times (ranging from 1 6- to 2 8-fold) for each of the scrapie strains investigated, independent of the Prnp genotype from which the strain was derived.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Although the precise effects of the 108M/111M mutations are difficult to quantify in these experiments due to the differences in Prnp gene copy number and genetic background between control and mutant mice, the results suggested that mutations in this region of PrP may extend TSE incubation times with all mouse-passaged TSE isolates.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	126	 However, in this experiment incubation times with 301V were extended in Prnpa(108M/111M) mice compared with the transgenic mice overexpressing Prnpa.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	127	 This was not observed in 101LL mice, where a shortening of 301V incubation time occurred with respect to the wild-type Prnpa mice.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	128	 These observations indicate that the effect on incubation time of introducing the 3F4 epitope is distinct from that caused by the presence of 101L in murine PrP.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	129	The shorter incubation time of 301V (Prnpb mouse-passaged BSE) in 101LL mice, when compared with the wild-type Prnpa mice, is in complete contrast with previous experiments which have shown longer incubation times in 101LL mice inoculated with vCJD than in 101PP mice (Barron et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Strain characteristics of this particular TSE agent have been show to remain remarkably consistent after transmission through several different species (Bruce et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	131	 However, vCJD (which is thought to be human-passaged BSE) produced increased incubation times and altered lesion profiles in 101LL mice compared with wild-type mice (Barron et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	132	, 2001), while BSE transmitted through a Prnpb mouse (301V) produced shortened incubation times (Table 1, Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	133	 1) and unaltered lesion profiles in 101LL mice compared with wild-type mice (Fig.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Adaptation to mouse with this strain of agent therefore increases the efficiency of transmission to 101LL mice, even in the presence of three polymorphisms in murine PrP, and this may in some way be related to why this human TSE agent alone transmits efficiently to wild-type mice (Bruce et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	135	 These issues are currently being addressed by transmitting and subpassinging human TSE isolates in P101L mice (unpublished data).
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	136	The interaction between different strains of TSE agent and host PrP is a complex process, and alterations in the host PrP protein can have a dramatic effect on TSE disease progression.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	137	 If the infectious process is dependent on interaction between PrP molecules, it is unclear why in 101LL mice the Prnpb-derived strains behave in a more unpredictable manner than the Prnpa-derived strains.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	138	 It may be due to the presence of three amino acid changes between the 101LL host and the Prnpb line in which the agent was propagated.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	139	 It is also possible that Prnpb strains have more diverse PrPSc conformations than the Prnpa strains we have examined.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Alternatively, a direct interaction between PrPC and PrPSc may not define the infectious process.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Other molecules may be involved in this process, and their interaction with PrPC may define the importance of PrP sequence in transmission of disease (Kaneko et al.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	142	 We now aim to further define the nature of the interaction between the N terminus of host PrP and the infectious agent through the study of the other mutations in this region of PrP.
0.18022668.14573822.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The prion protein and copper: what is the connection? pp.

0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	4	, 1990; Horiuchi  and  Caughey, 1999; Safar et al.

0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	6	, 1993) and that the primary amino acid sequence of PrPc is associated with relative susceptibility to natural TSE infection in some species.

0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Genetic analysis of susceptible or predisposing prion protein precursor gene (PRNP) alleles in mule deer is complicated by the nearly universal presence of an unexpressed processed pseudogene (PRNP) in which exon 3 encodes a polymorphic open reading frame (ORF) (Brayton et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In this study, we examined the PRNP functional gene and pseudogene alleles in a herd of white-tailed deer with a high prevalence of naturally occurring CWD to investigate the possibility of predisposing genotypes in this species.

0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	62	  CWD in adult deer and fawns A hundred and thirty-three white-tailed deer in the study were killed after CWD was diagnosed in the deer within the fenced area.

0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	78	 the first five rows of Table 2) (2=12 2, 4 df, P=0 016).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The other genotypes were too rare for meaningful analysis.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The strongest association detected was between CWD occurrence and carriage of the QGAS allele (2=11 3, 1 df, P < 0 001).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Deer either haploid (2=6 52, 1 df, P=0 01) or diploid (2=9 36, 1 df, P < 0 01) for the QGAS allele were more frequently affected by CWD compared with deer lacking this allele.
