0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Odds ratios and 95 % confidence intervals (CI) for the occurrence of CWD in the most frequently occurring diploid genotypes, using the presumed wild-type allele QGAS homozygous deer as the reference group, are shown in Table 2.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In spite of the small sample size, the 95 % CI showed a decrease in the odds ratio for deer with the QSAS allele and lacking the QGAS allele when compared with deer with the presumed wild-type QGAS homozygous genotype.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Homozygous QSAS deer had a lower odds ratio (0 089, 95 % CI 0 016 to 0 502) than did heterozygous QSAS QGGS deer (0 167, CI 0 035 to 0 789).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The presence of the QGAS allele resulted in similar odds ratios for heterozygous QSAS (0 564, 95 % CI 0 212 to 1 501) or QGGS (0 444, 95 % CI 0 133 to 1 489) deer.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	89	The ORF of the PRNP gene was more variable in this group of deer than was reported previously for free-ranging elk (O'Rourke et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	90	, 1999) or mule deer (Brayton et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	91	, 2004) and was duplicated in the cervid prion pseudogene PRNP as described previously in mule deer (Brayton et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The presumed wild-type allele (QGAS) and three alleles with coding changes at codons 95 (H), 96 (S) or 116 (G) were identified in the functional gene.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	93	 In addition, a coding change at codon 138 distinguished PRNP (138S) from PRNP (138N) in this sample set.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Both the location and potential charge shift of the three amino acid replacements in the functional gene are of interest.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The H/Q polymorphism at position 95 results in substitution of a neutral for a polar residue but is commonly reported in the deduced amino acid sequences from the PRNP gene among and within a large number of species (Schatzl et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Residue 96, encoding G or S, is adjacent to the final octapeptide repeat in a region poorly conserved among the mammalian species examined, with insertions and single base changes reported (Van Rheede et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Although there was no evidence for resistance to disease in deer with any of the major genotypes in this study, deer lacking the QGAS allele and carrying one or two copies of the allele encoding 96S (QSAS) were less likely to be found in the CWD population than deer with the QGAS allele on one or both chromosomes.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	98	 This finding is consistent with data from deer in Wisconsin (Johnson et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	99	, 2003), although in that study universal prion primers were used and the functional genotype could not be determined for some animals from the data shown.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The sample sizes in both studies are relatively small (26 in Wisconsin, 67 in this study).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	101	 If larger sample sizes support these observations, however, the pattern of genetic susceptibility in white-tailed deer would be similar to that observed in Rocky Mountain elk, in which a predisposing genotype is reported (O'Rourke et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	102	, 1999), although all major genotypes are susceptible to CWD (Spraker et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	103	 In contrast, PRNP polymorphisms in sheep result in the lack of disease in virtually all sheep with resistant genotypes (Belt et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	104	, 1992, 1994, 1997; O'Rourke et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	105	The polymorphism at codon 116 of the functional gene is of interest.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The alanine (A) residue at this position is conserved across a large number of eutherian orders (Van Rheede et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	107	, 2003) and previously reported to be variant only in the tenrec, an insectivorous mammal found only on the island of Madagascar.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Residue 116 (human 113) is in a potential membrane-spanning domain (Hegde et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	109	, 1998) of PrPc, immediately adjacent to a proposed cleavage site for cytosolically derived protease but protected from proteolysis by its insertion through the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum (Hegde et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The AG mutation at residue 116 in white-tailed deer results in replacement of a hydrophobic, aliphatic residue with a polar residue and may affect the intracellular processing and transport of the PrP precursor.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	111	 However, in this study, the 116G allele was found in 13 CWD-positive heterozygous deer, demonstrating that the allele does not provide protection under these conditions.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Two 116G homozygous animals were identified (one adult and one fawn), arguing against an early lethal effect of the mutation.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Neither homozygous deer had detectable PrPd or neurodegenerative changes.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	114	The cervid prion pseudogene in white-tailed deer in this study appeared at low frequency in comparison with the pseudogene in O.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	115	 hemionus, the mule deer (Brayton et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	116	, 2004) and black-tailed deer (subspecies of O.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	117	 PRNP was characterized by a polymorphism not detected in the functional gene and heterogeneity was limited to a variable octapeptide repeat number.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The low frequency and lack of heterogeneity of the white-tailed deer pseudogene could be due to inbreeding within this confined herd, to polymorphisms in the primer binding sites resulting in detection of a limited subset of alleles or to a relatively recent introduction of the pseudogene into the genome of white-tailed deer.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Although the founder group in the study herd was estimated at fewer than 20 animals, loss of heterogeneity in the pseudogene due to inbreeding is an unlikely explanation because all functional alleles identified in the Wisconsin (Johnson et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	120	, 2003), Mississippi (unpublished data) and Wyoming (Heaton et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	121	, 2003) groups are represented in this herd.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Furthermore, using the 138N polymorphism as a marker for PNRP in the Wisconsin and Wyoming studies, pseudogene frequencies are similar among the groups.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Polymorphisms in the PCR primer-binding sites cannot be ruled out.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	124	 However, the pseudogene was detected with two primer pairs in all deer in which the 138N mutation was detected with the universal prion primer pair, suggesting that failure to amplify a novel PRNP allele is not likely.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The third explanation is the appearance of the pseudogene in O.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	126	 hemionus (mule deer and other black-tailed deer) after divergence from white-tailed deer, with limited and relatively recent introgression into the white-tailed deer genome through hybridization of ancestral sympatric populations.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Although the evolution and taxonomy of the dozens of subspecies of white-tailed and black-tailed deer in the Americas are complex, examination of mitochondrial DNA and Y-linked genes supports the model that white-tailed deer and black-tailed deer diverged on the North American continent during the Pleistocene, with subsequent hybridization of sympatric populations resulting in appearance of mule deer (reviewed by Geist  and  Francis, 1999).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Subsequent hybridization between mule deer and white-tailed deer probably occurred (and continues to occur) infrequently, with a low level of introgressive hybridization of maternal DNA from mule deer and black-tailed deer into white-tailed deer populations within limited geographic areas (Cronin, 1991).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	129	The PRNP alleles in this study and the previous study of mule deer (Brayton et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	130	, 2004) invariably encoded 138N and an expansion of the octapeptide repeat number was observed in some deer.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	131	 These changes were not seen in the functional gene, leaving unresolved the question of whether the changes occurred in the ancestral functional gene before the duplication event or in the processed pseudogene after duplication.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The substitution of N for S in the prion protein is common within and among species and functional alleles encoding 138N are common in fallow deer (Dama dama) and reindeer (Rangifer tarandus) (unpublished data).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Likewise, a variable octapeptide repeat number is common in some breeds of cattle.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	134	 There are several dozen subspecies of Odocoileus in the Americas and genetic examination of additional populations should demonstrate whether the changes noted in the pseudogene in this study are characteristic of the processed pseudogene or are found in functional alleles as well.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	135	 No evidence of the pseudogene was found in small populations of New World moose (Alces alces), holoarctic reindeer, Old World Rocky Mountain elk (C.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	136	 elaphus) or captive Asian fallow deer (unpublished data).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	137	 If PRNP arose after evolutionary radiation of Odocoileus species in the New World, this pseudogene is not likely to be found in more distantly related members of the order Artiodactyla such as sheep, cattle or goats.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Novel pseudogenes may yet be found in some populations of domestic livestock through judicious selection of primer pairs optimized for pseudogene discovery.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	139	 However, processed pseudogenes are not typically transcribed or translated (Mighell et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	140	, 2000) and are therefore not expected to affect susceptibility to a protein-based disorder.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	141	All major PRNP diploid genotypes were represented in the CWD group in this study.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	142	 We addressed the possibility of genetically controlled differences in incubation time (the period from infection until accumulation of detectable PrPd in the brain) by examining fawns (animals under 1 year of age) for late disease (PrPd in the brain).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Using this crude measure, we identified three fawns (QGAS QSAS and QGAS QGGS genotypes) with late disease, demonstrating an extremely rapid course in those animals.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	144	 PrPd is thought to accumulate first in the lymphoid tissues of the alimentary tract (Sigurdson et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	145	, 1999), with subsequent neuroinvasion and transport through the splenic or vagus nerves to the brain.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In experimental rodent models, the incubation time and neuroinvasion rate are associated with a number of variables, including PRNP polymorphisms (Dickinson  and  Outram, 1973), innervation and PrPc production in lymphoid tissues (Mabbott et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	147	, 2001), and route of infection (Bartz et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Transgenic mice with cervid PRNP genes may be an appropriate laboratory model for examining the extremely rapid neuroinvasion seen in some genotypes.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	149	CWD in mule deer is typically associated with weight loss, ataxia, hypersalivation, polyuria and polydipsia (Williams  and  Miller, 2002) and similar signs have been reported in captive white-tailed deer held in research settings (M.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Miller, personal communication).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In spite of an infection rate of nearly 50 % in this herd, no clinical evidence of CWD was noted in live deer by the property owner or hunters or at necropsy.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Losses to intercurrent viral diseases were extensive during some years and the terrain provided adequate cover for sick animals to evade detection prior to death, possibly masking the presence of a TSE in this herd.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Alternately, the clinical course in these white-tailed deer may have been more acute than described in mule deer due to differences in the biology of the cervid host, the strain of TSE agent in this herd or the dose of the disease-causing agent in this confined facility.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Additional observations on clinical CWD in white-tailed deer held in captive settings will be necessary to address the spectrum of phenotypes of TSE infection in cervids.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	155	PRNP alleles and diploid genotypes of white-tailed deer with CWD identify those associated with CWD susceptibility.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	156	 In contrast, disease resistance is considerably more challenging to define in free-ranging populations for several reasons.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	157	 First, equivalent exposure to the disease-causing agent cannot be demonstrated across the population.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Although the deer in this study were removed from a single fenced area, it is likely that the herd spent part of the year in small maternally related groups, congregating at feed plots and at natural watering areas.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	159	 CWD transmission routes are not known and the relative efficiency of transmission through deer-to-deer contact or through shared feed and water sources cannot be determined.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Microsatellite analysis of DNA from the affected animals needs to be performed to determine whether maternal contact increases the probability of infection.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Secondly, some of the alleles are relatively rare and additional study populations from the endemic areas or from selectively bred captive white-tailed deer will be needed to increase the sample size in these genotypes.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Thirdly, the interval from infection to the accumulation of detectable PrPd levels is not known.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	163	 CWD was diagnosed in deer at 8 to 10 months of age in this herd, establishing a minimum incubation period.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The maximum incubation period cannot be identified if infection times occur outside the perinatal period (Miller  and  Williams, 2003).
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Some older adult deer had detectable PrPd restricted to the lymphoid tissue.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	166	 If the temporal pattern of PrPd accumulation in white-tailed deer is similar to that in sheep (Hadlow et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	167	, 1982) or experimentally infected mule deer (Sigurdson et al.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	168	, 1999), this observation indicates that white-tailed deer can be infected as adults, as reported in mule deer (Miller  and  Williams, 2003) or that the incubation period can be as long as 5 years.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Failure to detect PrPd in some deer is less likely to be due to genetic differences than to the termination of the entire herd for regulatory reasons while some or all deer were in the very early stage of the disease, before PrPd is detectable.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Long-term observations of heavily exposed herds or direct oral challenge of captive deer will be needed to establish relative disease resistance in deer with the rare genotypes.
0.18326303.15105552.html.plaintext.txt	171	 However, the presence of a relatively resistant but rare genotype may not confer a selective advantage sufficient to reduce the prevalence of CWD in free-ranging herds.

0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Genotype analyses in sheep has shown that the polymorphism present at codon 171 of the ovine Prnp gene is correlated with the disease incidence and the modulation of its incubation time.

0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The transfer vector was also obtained from FIV-14-Petaluma by replacing the U3 region of the 5' LTR with a CMV promoter in order to enable the expression of the vector in cells.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Moreover, the gag gene was truncated at position 1243 and a frameshift introduced at position 926.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The pol, vif, orfA, env and rev genes were replaced by a cassette containing the mutated PrP sequences driven by the phosphoglycerate kinase promoter.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The PrP sequence is followed by an IRES sequence and the enhanced GFP marker gene.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	46	G, used for pseudotyping, contains the VSV-G envelope gene, which encodes the envelope G protein of the vesicular stomatitis virus.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	47	 PGK, phosphoglycerate kinase promoter; CTE, constitutive transport element; cPPT CTS, central DNA flap sequence; SD, splice donor site.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	48	Virion production VSV-G pseudotyped FIV lentiviral vectors were produced by transient transfections of HEK293T cells with the following three plasmids: the gene transfer vector, the packaging vector and the pMD.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The packaging vector was also derived from the FIV-14-Petaluma genome whose 5' LTR had been replaced by a CMV promoter and the 3' LTR had been replaced by a poly-A signal.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	50	G, used for pseudotyping contains the VSV-G envelope gene, which encodes the envelope G protein of the vesicular stomatitis virus (Fig.

0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	52	106 in 100 mm plates, were transfected by using the calcium phosphate method (Sambrook et al.

0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Every four days, the cellular lysates were collected and proteinase-K-treated to analyse the inhibition-kinetic of the endogenous MoPrPSc levels by immunoblotting.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	143	 After 8 and 12 days, the N2a58/22L cells expressing the dominant negative MoPrPQ167R and MoPrPQ218K mutants showed a strong reduction in endogenous wt MoPrPSc levels (Fig.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	144	 After 15 days of culture, the majority of PrPSc was cleared (Fig.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	145	 To confirm the elimination of PrPSc, we performed a SAF61 immunocytofluorescence of the PrPSc after 20 days.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	146	 We used a standard guanidinium thiocyanate protocol that allows PrPSc staining by promoting antigen retrieval of the PrPSc and elimination of PrPC staining (Mange et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	147	 This method also showed a large decrease of PrPSc in cells containing the dominant negative construct (Fig.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	148	 3D); the inhibitory effect was reproduced in three independent experiments (data not shown).
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Generally, these results show that the virions harboring the PrP dominant negative mutants are functional and that they are efficient to inhibit the endogenous wt PrPSc-conversion.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	150	 These results are in accordance with those obtained in previous studies (Kaneko et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	151	, 2002) who showed that inhibition of wt MoPrPSc-formation can occur with MoPrPQ167R and MoPrPQ218K mutants.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In addition, the lentiviral gene-transfer method allowed us to amplify the inhibitory effect of these dominant negative mutants in scrapie-infected cells.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The transient transfections of prion-infected cells performed by Kaneko et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	154	, 1997), resulted in only a minority of cells expressing the PrP mutants, which had an inhibitory effect only on the conversion of 3F4-tagged MoPrPC but not on the conversion of endogenous wild-type PrPC into PrPSc.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	155	 In our case, and because the majority of the cells expressed the PrP mutants, we were able to obtain a strong inhibition of the conversion of the endogenous wt PrPC into PrPSc.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Our results show that the delivery of dominant negative PrP mutants through lentiviral vectors, can not only provide a strong expression of the transgene, but also transdominantly inhibit the accumulation of the endogenous wt MoPrPSc in chronically scrapie-infected N2a58/22L cells.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	157	Lentiviral vectors possess the ability to transduce post-mitotic cells such as differentiated neurons as well as the cells of the lymphoreticular system in a prolonged and stable manner (Aguzzi et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	158	, 2004; Mabbott and Bruce, 2003; Mangeot et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	159	 To analyse whether our lentiviral vectors had the potential to deliver the gene to the brain or the peripheric organs, we performed ic and iv injections of lentivirus expressing the ss-galactosidase gene in mice.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	160	 For ic delivery, we used a stereotaxic frame to inject the lentiviral preparation in the right lateral ventricle or in the thalamus of adult C57BL/6 mice.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	161	 ss-galactosidase expression was assessed by direct X-Gal staining of the entire brain.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Following the intrathalamic injection, we observed a ss-galactosidase activity mainly in the injection site (Fig.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	163	 4A,B,E), which demonstrated the capacity of our lentivirus to transduce neural cells.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Following intraventricular injection, X-Gal-blue coloration was limited all along the syringe trajectory and around the lateral ventricle (Fig.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	165	 This was probably owing to the diffusion of the lentiviral particle in the whole ventricle.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	166	 However, close examination of the brain by immunohistochemical analysis allowed us to detect ss-galactosidase staining in the area of striatum, the cortex and in some more distant sites as well as the area of the cerebellum (Fig.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	167	 After systemic lentiviral injections, ss-galactosidase was observed around the blood vessels in the spleen of the mice and in some dispersed liver cells, probably due to the iv injection (Fig.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The spleen localisation in the vicinity of the vessels is somehow very pertinent because these structures are innervated by the noradrenergic peripheric autonomous nervous system implicated in the neuroinvasion process (Aguzzi et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	169	 These data showed that our lentiviral vectors can be used to transduce cells in the brain and in the spleen.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Because neurons are the main cells targeted in prion disease, the use of lentiviral vectors carrying dominant negative PrP mutants could slow or even prevent prion replication, at least in the brain area transduced with the virion particles.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	171	 In addition, the first stages of prion diseases are characterized by an increase of the PrPSc levels in the lymphoreticular system and in the spleen (Lasmezas et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Thus, lentiviral vectors could be useful effectors for the development of a gene therapy through repeated peripheral injections, with the aim of slowing down or preventing prion replication during the very early stages of disease, at least before neuroinvasion.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Moreover, a gene therapy strategy was recently evaluated by Marr et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	174	, as an alternative therapeutic approach for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease (Marr et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Lentiviral vectors expressing neprilysin, a major Ass-degrading enzyme identified in the human brain and implicated in the clearance of Ass amyloids, was tested in transgenic mouse models of amyloidosis.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	176	 A single lentiviral injection decreased the number and size of amyloid plaques by about 45%.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Altogether, these data have encouraged us to further evaluate therapeutic strategies based on injections of the lentivirus carrying dominant negative PrP mutants, by both ic and peripheral routes.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Moreover, the recent and promising results of the neuroprotective cell-therapy treatment have prompted us to consider an approach combining both cell therapy and gene therapy using these dominant negative PrP mutants (Bachoud-Levi et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	179	, 2001; Brustle and McKay, 1996; Lindvall, 2003; Lindvall and McKay, 2003).
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Indeed, neural precursors obtained after in vitro differentiation from embryonic stem cells could thus be transduced with the dominant negative PrP virion preparations before injection in the prion-infected brain.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The recent description of soluble dimeric PrP (Meier et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	182	, 2003) or RNAi interferences (Daude et al.
0.19237107.15494372.html.plaintext.txt	183	, 2003) that, antagonize prion replication may also be engineered in lentiviral vectors to extend the inhibitory effect.

0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	0	Low frequency of PrP genotype 225SF among free-ranging mule deer (Odocoileus hemionus) with chronic wasting disease Jean E.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Department of Veterinary Sciences, University of Wyoming, Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory, 1174 Snowy Range Road, Laramie, WY 82070, USA 2 Department of Forest, Range, and Wildlife Sciences, Utah State University, Logan, UT 84322-5230, USA 3 Colorado Division of Wildlife, Wildlife Research Center, Fort Collins, CO 80526-2097, USA.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	2	Published online ahead of print on 27 May 2005 as DOI 10.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	3	Although CWD is not perceived as an immediate major threat to deer or elk populations, it is of concern and interest for several reasons: (i) the possibility that wild herds could be gradually destroyed by CWD (Gross  and  Miller, 2001) due to the persistence of the infectious agent in the environment (Miller et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	4	, 2002) and the lethality of the disease; (ii) the unknown nature of circumstances, if any, under which this disease could affect a human; (iii) the greater understanding of human TSEs that could accrue by knowing more about related mammalian prion diseases that have not been well understood before; (iv) the economic impact of CWD on game farming; and (v) the possible spread of CWD to other members of the cervid family worldwide through unregulated commerce and transport of captive animals (Williams  and  Miller, 2003).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	5	In other acquired prion diseases, notably scrapie of sheep and variant Creutzfeldt to Jakob disease (vCJD) in humans, amino acids encoded at certain key positions in the endogenous host prion protein (PrP) are strongly associated with susceptibility to TSE infection (Goldmann et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	6	 A study of CWD in Rocky Mountain elk (O'Rourke et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	7	, 1999) suggested that the PrP sequence at position 132 influences likelihood of infection in that species.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	8	 To what extent similar influences affect deer (Odocoileus spp.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	9	) has been unclear (Johnson et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	10	 If heritable characters influence susceptibility to CWD in free-ranging mule deer, which are the most abundant of the three natural hosts within the Rocky Mountain endemic area (Miller et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	11	, 2000), it could have important implications for understanding the epidemiology of this disease.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	12	We investigated the possibility that PrP sequences may vary between CWD-infected and uninfected deer in the wild.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	13	 To that end we determined PrP polymorphisms in select populations of free-ranging mule deer in Wyoming and Colorado, and estimated the relative abundance of one particular polymorphism among CWD-infected and uninfected animals.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Specifically, we tested whether CWD status (positive or negative) was independent of genotype at codon 225, and constructed a regression model to test whether there was a population-level relationship between CWD prevalence and 225 genotype among the herds sampled.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	15	 We also retrospectively analysed experimentally infected deer for PrP genotype to look for possible effects of genotype during the course of the disease in these animals.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	16	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Boundaries, locations and designations of mule deer HUs in Wyoming and DAU in Colorado for samples used in genotype analysis.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	18	  DNA extractions, PCR amplifications and sequencing.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	19	 We extracted total genomic DNA from approximately 30 to 50 mg frozen brain tissue using a FastPrep F120 homogenizer and FastDNA kit (Q-Biogene), from 0 05 ml of 15 % (w/v) homogenates of retropharyngeal lymph nodes using a DNeasy kit (Qiagen), or from 0 3 ml EDTA-treated whole blood using an Aqua-Pure Genomic DNA kit (Bio-Rad Laboratories), all according to manufacturers' instructions.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The complete open reading frame (ORF) plus 25 bp of 5' flanking sequences and 53 bp of 3' flanking sequences in the PrP-coding region were amplified using PCR in 50  microl reaction volumes containing 200  microM each dNTP, 2 5 units Taq polymerase (Qiagen), 200 nM each of a forward (MD582F, 5'-ACATGGGCATATGATGCTGACACC-3') and a reverse (MD1479RC, 5'-ACTACAGGGCTGCAGGTAGATACT-3') primer, 2 5 mM MgCl2, 1x Qiagen PCR buffer and approximately 70 to 150 ng total genomic DNA.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Reactions were thermal-cycled in a PTC 200 (MJ Research) at 94  degrees C for 5 min and then 32 cycles of 94  degrees C for 7 s, 62  degrees C for 15 s, 72  degrees C for 30 s and a final cycle of 72  degrees C for 5 min, and kept at 4  degrees C until inspected for successful amplification by agarose gel electrophoresis before being submitted for DNA sequencing with reverse sense primers 12 (5'-TGGTGGTGACTGTGTGTTGCTTGA-3') and 3FL1 (5'-GATTAAGAAGATAATGAAAACAGGAAGG-3') (Amplicon Express).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In order to find recurring (5 % allele frequency) polymorphisms in deer over a widespread area, we examined sequences of the complete PrP ORF (Fig.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	23	 2a) from 363 samples that included 244 mule deer (95 CWD-negative, 149 CWD-positive) from throughout the south-eastern quarter of Wyoming, and 119 mule deer (105 CWD-negative, 14 CWD-positive) from the Estes Valley, Colorado.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	24	 We viewed sequence chromatograms and checked base calls using Chromas v.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	25	23 software (Technelysium Pty), and made alignments of DNA sequences for comparisons by using the SeqMan module of LaserGene software (DNAStar).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	26	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Polymorphic codons in mule deer PrP coding region of Prnp gene.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	28	 (a) Diagram of structural features in the deduced amino acid sequence of mule deer prion protein.

0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The mature peptide is deduced to include aa 25 through 234.

0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	39	  Codon 225 genotyping by EcoRI digestion.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	40	 To increase sample size for statistical analysis, PrP genotypes of 1119 additional samples selected from HUs in the study areas were analysed by EcoRI restriction digestion of the PCR-amplified PrP region, produced as described for samples to be sequenced.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	41	 This assay detects only the codon 225 polymorphism, which is the only one we found in mule deer PrP that encoded different amino acids in the mature polypeptide.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Aliquots (10  microl) of completed PCR reactions were incubated with 10 U EcoRI (New England Biolabs) in a total volume of 12  microl containing 50 mM NaCl, 100 mM Tris/HCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 0 025 % Triton X-100 (pH 7 5) at 37  degrees C for 2 to 16 h followed by the addition of 2 5  microl 6x concentrate gel loading solution (Sigma-Aldrich) per sample, and the inspection of products by agarose gel electrophoresis.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Occurrence of the phenylalanine (F) codon TTC at position 225 creates the EcoRI recognition sequence and cleavage site GAATTC from codons 224 to 225, whereas the serine (S) codon TCC creates the DNA sequence GAATCC, which is not cut by EcoRI.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	44	 When PCR products were incubated with EcoRI, the presence of a TTC codon at position 225 resulted in cleavage fragments of predictable sizes, and a search of the PrP ORF DNA sequence verified that no other sites were potentially transformable to GAATTC with one base change, supporting the use of this as a valid genotyping method.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Samples that showed evidence of cleavage were sequenced to verify the change.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The 1482 deer that were genotyped and tested for CWD were a subset of deer tested from the 2001 to 2003 CWD hunter harvest surveys in Wyoming or from 2002 to 2004 field studies in north-central Colorado (Wolfe et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	47	 For Wyoming data, tissues from sampled deer were screened for CWD infection by immunohistochemistry (IHC) (Miller  and  Williams, 2002) at the Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory, Laramie, WY (2001 and 2002 samples) or by CWD-ELISA (Bio-Rad Laboratories) at the Wildlife Disease Laboratory of the Wyoming Game and Fish Department with IHC confirmation of ELISA-positive samples (2003 samples).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	48	 For Colorado data, IHC was performed on tonsil biopsies from live deer sampled from Estes Park during 2002 to 2004 (Wolfe et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	49	 CWD prevalence for Wyoming mule deer HUs was estimated using data obtained from the Wyoming Game and Fish Department (H.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Edwards, personal communication); CWD prevalence for Colorado DAU 10, which includes Estes Park, were from harvest samples taken during 2001 to 2003 by the Colorado Division of Wildlife (http://wildlife.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Because this was essentially a case to control study, we used odds ratios rather than relative risk to analyse statistically the association between CWD status and genotype.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	52	 In these analyses, we used diploid genotypes rather than allele frequencies to avoid artificially inflating sample sizes and potentially biasing estimates of 2 and odds ratio statistics (Agresti, 1996; Sasieni, 1997).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	53	 We combined genotype 225SF with 225FF due to the low proportion of the latter genotype in our samples (0 2 %).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	54	 We used 2x2 contingency tables to test whether CWD status (positive or negative) was independent of 225 genotype (PROG FREQ; SAS OnlineDoc 8, SAS Institute).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	55	 If we failed to reject the null hypothesis, it would conclude that genotype was unrelated to CWD status.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	56	 We conducted the analysis for all data combined and then for Wyoming and Colorado separately.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	57	 We did not analyse the data by individual HU or DAU because we lacked sample size at that level and could not meet the assumptions of the 2 analysis.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	58	To test for a relationship between CWD prevalence and frequencies of 225 genotypes among sampled populations, we constructed a regression model of logit-transformed CWD prevalence versus proportion of 225SF genotype (PROG GENMOD; SAS Institute).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Our null hypothesis was no relationship between CWD prevalence and proportion of 225SF genotype.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Type III sum of squares was used to test our hypothesis (SAS Institute).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	61	Observations of experimentally infected mule deer.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Two pre-existing projects provided us with the opportunity to assess whether the course of CWD in captive, experimentally infected deer was different between 225SF and 225SS genotypic groups.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Williams and others, unpublished data), survival time and genotype data were obtained for eight hand-reared mule deer fawns, which had been exposed to CWD at 3 or 4 months of age by a single oral dose of 1 g pooled brain homogenate as previously described (Sigurdson et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The animals were later euthanized upon presenting with severe clinical signs of CWD (Williams  and  Young, 1992), and late-stage CWD infection at death was confirmed by necropsy and IHC of fixed tissues.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	65	 We isolated genomic DNA from blood samples collected during the course of the project, and obtained PrP sequences as described above.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Miller, unpublished data), we isolated genomic DNA from archived frozen tissues that were collected at necropsy from experimentally infected mule deer and obtained PrP sequences as described above.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	67	View larger version (50K):    Fig.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Genotype analysis by agarose gel electrophoresis of EcoRI digestion products.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The 225F polymorphism was detected by EcoRI cleavage of PrP-encoding DNA at the sequence that results from replacement of the serine codon TCC by a phenylalanine codon TTC (see Methods).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Lanes 1 to 7, EcoRI-digested PCR-amplified DNA containing mule deer PrP protein coding region; lane 8, undigested control (calculated size 897 bp); lane 9, X174/HaeIII fragment size markers with sizes in base pairs indicated at right.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Samples in lanes 3, 5 and 7 lack an EcoRI site and remained uncut (225SS genotype); DNA in lanes 1, 2, 4 and 6 contain an EcoRI site in the copies of PrP from one chromosome but retain the serine codon in the other (225SF genotype).

0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	73	 A fragment corresponding to the predicted 178 bp cleavage product was also detectable (arrow).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	74	  Statistical analysis The results, which are presented in Table 1, continued to show lower than expected numbers of 225SF genotypes among CWD-infected animals.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	75	 2 analysis performed with all data combined returned the result that CWD status was not independent of codon 225 genotype (P < 0 0001).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	76	 In a total sample of 290 free-ranging, CWD-positive mule deer, we observed only one 225SF individual (0 3 %); 22 were expected based on the overall genotype frequency (7 6 %) in the sample.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The odds that a deer of the 225SS genotype was CWD-infected were 30 times greater (95 % confidence intervals=4 to 213) than for deer of the 225SF genotype.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	78	 This pattern also held when Wyoming (P < 0 0001) and Colorado (P=0 012) samples were analysed separately.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For the Wyoming samples, the odds that a deer of the 225SS genotype was CWD-infected were 16 times greater (95 % confidence intervals=2 to 119) than for deer of the 225SF genotype; for the Colorado samples the odds ratio was 13 (95 % confidence intervals=1 to 209).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	80	 CWD prevalence and genotype data by deer management unit.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	81	Estimated CWD prevalence by HU and DAU in harvest samples taken during 2001 to 2003 from Wyoming (Wyoming Game and Fish Department) and Colorado (http://wildlife.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Proportion of 225SF in the genotyped samples by HU and DAU, and observed (Obs.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	83	) numbers of 225SF per unit among CWD-positive samples are also shown.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	84	  With odds ratios this high, we considered it possible that a relationship might be detected between CWD prevalence and genotype frequencies.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	85	 If the 225SF genotype provided a degree of resistance to CWD infection, then areas with high 225SF frequency might be expected to show low CWD prevalence.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Alternatively, if CWD provided selective pressure for the resistant genotype, then the SF genotype might be more common in areas of high prevalence.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	87	 However, neither relationship was observed.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Although both the proportion of 225SF individuals and CWD prevalence varied among the mule deer populations sampled (Table 1), the slope of the regression model shown in Fig.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	89	 4 was not significantly different from 0 (P=0 228).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	90	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Regression of logit-transformed CWD prevalence versus proportion of 225SF genotypes by HU or DAU for mule deer in Wyoming and Colorado.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	92	 CWD prevalence based on harvest samples taken during 2001 to 2003 from Wyoming (Wyoming Game and Fish Department) and Colorado (http://wildlife.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Proportion of analysed samples with 225SF genotype from each HU or DAU as given in Table 1.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	94	  Observations of experimentally infected mule deer and PrP genotypes Retrospective sequence analysis of DNA from two groups of experimentally infected captive mule deer revealed 10 225SF deer, as well as some differences in disease development that appeared to group according to codon 225 genotypes.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In the first experimental group, six of the eight deer were of the 225SS genotype and two were 225SF.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The time until development of severe clinical CWD in the 225SS deer ranged from 19 to 23 months post-inoculation (p.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	97	), and the two 225SF deer developed severe symptoms at 36 months p.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In the second group of deer, we identified eight 225SF animals, all of whom had been CWD-infected.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Preliminary results for a small number of deer infected for 16 months or longer indicated that PrPCWD was detectable by CWD-ELISA in brain tissue by 16 months p.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	100	 in 225SS deer but not until  > 25 months p.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Miller and others, unpublished data).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	102	Nevertheless, the precedent of genetic factors affecting susceptibility to infectious prion diseases is well-established (Prusiner et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The high odds ratios reported here for a possible genetically linked differential susceptibility to CWD in mule deer are consistent with the high degree of influence of genotype reported for scrapie in sheep (Hunter, 1997; Detwiler  and  Baylis, 2003).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Some differences between genetics of scrapie in sheep and CWD in cervids are notable: CWD is unique as a TSE that occurs in wild populations subject to genetic drift and natural selection, rather than in selectively bred domestic animals.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Also, the number of polymorphic codons in deer and elk PrP [two in mule deer, one in elk and three in white-tailed deer, all dimorphisms (Raymond et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	106	, 2004)] is low compared with the number of different amino acid positions that vary and the number of alleles that occur at these positions in domestic sheep breeds worldwide (Bossers et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	107	, 2000; Baylis  and  Goldmann, 2004).
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	108	 It should be noted that the odds ratios relating 225 genotype and CWD in mule deer stand in contrast to the low odds ratios previously reported by O'Rourke et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	109	 (2004) for genetic susceptibility to CWD in white-tailed deer based on the three different polymorphisms found in that species.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	110	Implications for CWD transmission If the effects observed that suggest the 225SF genotype is associated with longer incubation times in experimentally infected deer also apply to deer with naturally acquired CWD, this could affect transmission of CWD in areas where there is a high proportion of the 225SF genotype among mule deer, if they become infected.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Increased survival time for infected, asymptomatic animals might increase the period during which infectious agent is shed into the environment, although it should be pointed out that all but one of the 225SF deer in this study were not infected, rather than undergoing an asymptomatic, protracted subclinical phase.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The possibility of  dormant infections' or carrier state in TSEs has been raised in connection with scrapie (O'Rourke et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	113	, 1997) and more recently with inapparent vCJD infections in PrP codon 129VM heterozygous humans and 129VV transgenic mice (Carrell, 2004; Wadsworth et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Alternatively, slower development of CWD could mean 225SF deer require longer times of infection to reach the shedding stage.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	115	 This situation could be neutral for transmission in the wild, or it could lead to a decrease in CWD prevalence due to infected deer dying of other causes before becoming infectious.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	116	 This issue will remain unresolved until we learn when the infectious agent is shed during CWD infections and are able to measure its specific infectivity.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	117	Genotypes 225SF and 225FF do not confer complete resistance Even though the 225SF genotype may reduce susceptibility or affect the course of the disease, it clearly does not confer complete resistance.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Experimental infection of 225SF deer appears to take place readily at the oral doses typically administered.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	119	 In addition, we detected one free-ranging infected 225SF deer from Wyoming in our analysis, and subsequent genotyping of 234 additional CWD-positive samples from north-central Colorado revealed five 225SF individuals (M.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	120	 It is also important to note that 225FF homozygous deer are not resistant, as evidenced by two 225FF deer also found among the additional positive samples genotyped.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The 225F allele is present in such low frequencies in the deer herds sampled that free-ranging 225FF deer are not often found in surveys (e.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	122	 only three of the 1482 samples used in this analysis were 225FF), and accurate assessment of their relative susceptibility to CWD will depend on work with animals currently being bred in captivity.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	123	CWD prevalence and codon 225 genotype frequencies If free-ranging 225SF mule deer are less likely to be infected with CWD than 225SS deer because of genetic causes, an increase of this genotype among deer populations over time could contribute to a decrease of CWD.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Alternatively, selection against the 225SS genotype by high CWD prevalence could produce areas of both high disease prevalence and high frequency of the SF genotype.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	125	 On an overall basis we saw no relationship between the proportions of SF animals estimated in HUs and the prevalence of CWD, but it may be necessary to compare proportions of SF and CWD prevalence in the same unit over time to detect such trends.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Whether the time scales required for such observations would be feasible is not known.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	127	 CWD is estimated to have been present in wild cervids for 50 years or more (Miller et al.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	128	, 2000), so the time over which such effects could have been at work in CWD endemic areas may be too short to show reduced disease prevalence in areas of high SF frequencies.
0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Also, the effect could be small compared with drift or mutation if CWD exerts only a low level of genetic selection because of its normally long incubation period, which allows for continued reproduction or genetic replacement, despite disease status.

0.20848115.16033959.html.plaintext.txt	131	 HUs), which are large relative to the population units most affected by variations in factors involved in the disease, including genetics (Conner  and  Miller, 2004).

0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	0	Gene expression profiling in chronic copper overload reveals upregulation of Prnp and App Angela D.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Armendariz1, Mauricio Gonzalez2, Alexander V.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Department of Nutritional Science and Toxicology, University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California 2 Instituto de Nutricion y Tecnologia de los Alimentos, Universidad de Chile, Santiago, Santiago, Chile.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	3	microarray; amyloid-ss precursor protein; prion protein; outlier detection; bioinformatics; Menkes disease.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	4	Although copper is clearly an essential nutrient, this metal can be toxic if allowed to accumulate in excess of cellular needs.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The incidence of copper toxicosis in the general population is low (6, 46).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Acute copper poisoning is not frequent but is usually the consequence of consumption of contaminated foodstuffs or beverages, or from accidental or deliberate ingestion of high quantities of copper salts.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Acute copper poisoning is characterized with nausea, vomiting, and gastric pain.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In severe cases, intravascular hemolytic anemia, acute hepatic failure, acute tubular renal failure, shock, coma, and death can occur (46).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	9	Chronic copper toxicosis may be of greater concern (6).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Nutritional studies of chronic copper overload in both mice and rats have shown copper-induced liver damage in these animals (1, 19, 38).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In addition, WD, a human genetic disorder of copper overload, is characterized by a gradual hepatic accumulation of copper that eventually results in liver cirrhosis (7).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Other copper overload disorders in humans include Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC), endemic Tyrolean infantile cirrhosis (ETIC), and idiopathic copper toxicosis (ICT).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These diseases result in abnormal hepatic copper accumulation and can result in chronic hepatitis and hepatic failure (36).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Although the liver injury in each of these cases is copper induced, the mechanisms by which excess copper results in cellular toxicity have not been fully elucidated.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The increase in copper levels, especially in WD, occurs over a period of many years, and phenotypic consequences are not reported until copper levels are extremely elevated.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The lack of appreciable pathological changes from ever increasing copper levels until late in the disease process suggests that compensatory homeostatic mechanisms must exist.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	17	Toxicity resulting from copper overload has long been hypothesized to result from the redox cycling Haber-Weiss reaction in which cuprous ions react with H2O2 to form highly reactive oxygen species (ROS), which in turn catalyze the oxidation of biomolecules such as lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids (reviewed in Refs.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The suspected role of ROS in copper overload is supported by observations of increased generation of lipid peroxidation products, as well as evidence of DNA damage in hepatocytes reacted with ionic copper (6, 59).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In vivo studies have shown that markers of lipid peroxidation are increased in mitochondria from livers of WD patients (55).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	20	 There is also evidence of lipid peroxidation in livers of rats chronically fed very high copper diets (38, 54).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	21	The levels at which copper becomes toxic is not clear.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Most studies that indicate that copper causes oxidative stress have tested very high levels of copper (38, 54).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Indeed, a study in which a diet with moderately high levels of copper was fed to rats showed no lipid peroxidation (1).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	24	 DNA damage, often a consequence of oxidative stress, has been observed in copper overload in vivo, however, only in the cirrhotic livers of WD patients (21).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Nevertheless, the incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with WD is not higher than that in the general population (50).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	26	 This raises the question of whether copper, at moderately elevated levels, results in oxidative damage, and if not, what effects, if any, these levels have on cells.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Clearly, the cellular mechanisms that protect the cell are vigorous, and only at very high levels do they become overwhelmed.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We currently have only a limited understanding of the protective systems that operate in cells chronically exposed to copper.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Additionally, the limits of homeostatic regulation are not known, making it difficult to define the milder effects of copper excess (3).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Currently no early, biologically relevant markers of copper excess exist.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	31	 A robust assay to facilitate the diagnosis of copper excess and to distinguish mild, moderate, and severe copper overload is needed.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	32	To address these issues, we have investigated the effects on steady-state gene expression of chronic copper overload in a cell culture model system using cDNA microarray technology.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	33	 For this study we have chosen to utilize cells from a genetic model of copper overload.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	34	 We have used fibroblast cells from two mouse mutants, C57BL/6-Atp7aMobr and C57BL/6-Atp7aModap (henceforth to be referred to as Mobr and Modap, respectively, for simplicity) as genetic models of chronic copper overload.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Cultured cells from mice with mutations in the Atp7a represent genetic models of moderate cellular copper overload (12, 32).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Excess copper is normally exported by the ATP7A copper transporting P-type ATPase, which translocates from the trans-Golgi network (TGN) to the plasma membrane in the presence of elevated copper (45).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Mutations in ATP7A in both humans (Menkes disease) and mice (mottled mouse) lead to reduced intestinal basolateral export of copper and subsequent systemic copper deficiency (33).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	38	 All cultured cells tested, with the exception of hepatic cells, from mottled mice accumulate copper to abnormally high levels in normal culture media (12, 32).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Our results show no evidence of oxidative stress in the copper-loaded cells and suggest remarkable cellular compensation.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	40	 In addition, candidate components perhaps responsible for a copper-specific homeostatic response are identified.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	41	Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry.

0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Distortions in the data are readily apparent when using these exploratory tools but can be overlooked if not utilized.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	110	 For example, a multimodal distribution suggests that the data are drawn from several populations that are behaving differently such as data arising from nonhomogenous hybridizations.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The results of four exploratory data analysis tools for one of the hybridizations (Modap vs.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The results for the eight individual microarrays can be found in the Supplemental Figs.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	113	 S1 to S4 (the Supplementary Materials are available online at the Physiological Genomics web site).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	114	1 Inspection of the box plots (Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	115	 1A) show that scale, location, number of outlying observations, and asymmetry are similar for both channels (Cy5 and Cy3) for this data set.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Similarly, the average shifted histograms (Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	117	 1B) provide information on the empiric distribution of a random variable and reveal that the data resembles samples from univariate normal distributions for both channels.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	118	 1C) compares the quantiles of the empirical data distribution with the quantiles of the standard normal distribution.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The majority of points in QQNP for both channels of our data conform closely to a standard normal distribution except for longer tails.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	120	 These deviations may be due to random fluctuations and/or systematic variation.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Finally, each point on a scatter plot (Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	122	 1D) corresponds to one bivariate observation after appropriate normalization and log transformation.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	123	 These results show that the red and green channel intensities in the data sets are highly correlated having approximately symmetric distributions and are appropriate for further analysis for the determination of candidates for differentially expressed genes.

0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	130	  Detection of differentially expressed genes.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	131	 We identified differentially expressed genes from each hybridization by our outlier identification method (see MATERIALS AND METHODS and Ref.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	132	 We were interested in those genes that were significantly changed (either up- or downregulated) in the copper-overloaded cells compared with a control.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	133	 2, the majority of the data points lie in the vicinity of a robust linear regression line of the scatter plot of log2(Cy5) vs.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	134	 These data points signify genes with similar transcript behaviors in the two samples, whereas other data points lie outside the scatter plots and correspond to genes having noticeably different hybridization intensity values.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	135	 We determine statistics log2(Cy5/Cy3)/s(I) to estimate statistical significance (P values) for every gene to be a candidate for differential expression [s(I) is a robust scale estimator dependent on intensity] and use it to build simultaneous prediction intervals for graphical representation that genes outside the intervals are most likely outliers.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Robust scatter plot smoothers are used to account for heteroscedasticity (e.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	137	, variation in residual variance with intensity) in each data set.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Red outliers on the top of the graph in Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	139	 2 represent candidate upregulated genes, whereas the outlying spots of blue color, on the bottom, represent candidate downregulated genes.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Individual outlier plots for each data set can be found in the supplementary data (Supplemental Figs.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	141	 We considered data outliers with P  <  0.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	142	05 as candidate differentially expressed genes.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	143	 We then compared the candidate genes identified for each experiment and selected genes identified (i.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	144	05) in three or more repeat hybridizations as likely differentially expressed genes.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	145	 control experiments, there were 101 genes that were upregulated and 80 genes that were downregulated in, at least, three of the four experiments.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	146	 control experiments, there were 115 up- and 25 downregulated genes that were similar in at least three of the four experiments.

0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	179	  No evidence of oxidative stress-related gene expression.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Despite having copper levels five times greater than the control cell lines, these two chronically copper-overloaded cells show no evidence of changes at the transcription level of oxidative stress genes.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	181	 We expected that many of the differentially expressed genes would be those that encoded proteins involved in the response to oxidative stress.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	182	 A number of oxidative stress-responsive transcription factors and genes have been identified (reviewed in Ref.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	183	 However, none of these genes (e.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	184	, superoxide dismutase, catalase, cytochrome P-450s, DNA damage inducible genes) was induced, or repressed, in the either the Modap or Mobr cells (individual lists of differentially expressed genes are in Supplemental Tables S1 to S4).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The antioxidant response element (ARE) is responsible for the induction of several genes in response to oxidants (see Ref.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	186	 39 for review); however, of the known ARE-responsive genes present on the arrays [namely, heme oxygenase, glutamate-cysteine ligase, and glutathione-S-transferases (,  micro, , and )] only glutathione S-transferase- micro was differentially expressed, and only in the Modap cell line.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Metallothionein 1 (MT1), a known metal-responsive gene, was upregulated in the Mobr cells (it was not assayed in the Modap cells), as expected.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	188	To further confirm these observations, the expression of two genes [-glutamylcysteine synthetase (Gcs) and glutathione peroxidase (Gpx)] that are known to be induced by oxidative stress (28) were measured by sq-RT-PCR.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Sq-RT-PCR showed no significant induction of either of the two genes in either the Mobr or the Modap cell lines (Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	190	View larger version (51K):    Fig.

0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	195	  Differential expression of cytoskeletal and cell adhesion related genes.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	196	 A surprisingly high number of genes related to cytoskeletal organization and cell adhesion were found to be differentially expressed in both the Mobr and the Modap experiments.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The majority of these genes were upregulated, but several of them were downregulated.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Cell adhesion genes comprise 15% and 16% of the upregulated genes with known functions, in the Modap and Mobr cells, respectively (Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Fifteen percent and 8% of the upregulated genes with known functions, in the Modap and Mobr cells, respectively, are involved in cytoskeleton organization and biogenesis (Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Cytoskeleton organization and biogenesis genes make up 14% of the down genes with known functions in the Mobr cells (Supplemental Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The list of these genes and their respective experiments can be found in Table 2.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Cytoskeleton organization/cell adhesion-related genes up- and downregulated in Mobr and Modap fibroblast cell lines.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	203	  Confirmation of differential expression of App and Prnp.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Two of the genes upregulated in both the Mobr and Modap cells (Table 1) were amyloid-ss precursor protein (App) and prion protein (Prnp).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Previous research suggests that the protein products of both of these genes may play a role in copper homeostasis (61); thus we chose to confirm their differential expression.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Significant changes in App and Prnp as detected by microarray analysis were validated by Northern blot analysis and sq-RT-PCR, respectively.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Northern blot analysis showed induction of App in both Mobr and Modap fibroblast cell lines (Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Equal loading of samples for the Northern blot analysis is shown in Fig.

0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	211	 For Prnp, quantitative analysis was performed; a plot of the optical density for Prnp/G3pdh ratios revealed that Prnp was induced 3.
