0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	222	  To determine whether nutritional, chronic copper overload induced expression of these two genes, we analyzed, by sq-RT-PCR, the gene expression of App and Prnp in copper-treated control cell lines.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Chronic copper treatment of the wild-type, control cell lines (25  microM Cu-His for 5 days) induced App gene expression 2.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	224	 For comparison, App expression was also measured in the Mobr and Modap cell lines and showed a 3- and 4.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	225	5-fold induction, respectively (Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	226	 No change in Prnp gene expression was observed in the copper-treated cells (data not shown).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	227	View larger version (46K):    Fig.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	228	 sq-RT-PCR analysis of App in 25  microM Cu-treated wild-type cells.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	229	 App gene expression in control, and copper-treated control cell lines was analyzed by sq-RT-PCR as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	230	 App expression was also analyzed in the Mobr and Modap cell lines for comparison.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The density of the amplified products (A) was calculated and normalized against the G3pdh housekeeping gene control values.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	232	 B: a plot of the optical density for App/G3pdh ratios.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	233	We utilized cDNA microarray technology to investigate the effects of chronic copper overload.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The microarray experiments, which compared transcripts from each mutant (Mobr and Modap) to a control cell line, were carried out four times per mutant.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	235	 For the analysis of the individual microarray data sets, we employed a novel, data-driven approach, recently developed in our laboratory, for identifying differentially expressed genes.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The resulting lists of significantly up- and downregulated genes from each individual microarray were then compared with each other and showed high reproducibility.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	237	An investigation into the functions of the differentially expressed genes led us to some surprising results.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Copper is thought to be toxic if allowed to accumulate in excess of cellular needs because of its ability to generate free radicals (6).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Indeed, there are reports of copper-induced oxidative damage at high doses of exposure (55).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Hence, we expected that many of the differentially expressed genes would be those that encoded proteins involved in the response to oxidative stress.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Surprisingly, both mottled cell lines, despite being chronically copper overloaded, show no differential expression of oxidative stress genes besides the upregulation of MT1.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	242	 MT1, long known to be induced by copper (and other heavy metals) and to be elevated in the cultured fibroblasts (and other nonhepatic cell lines) from both Menkes patients (25, 49) and mottled mice (41), was upregulated in the Mobr cells, (it was not on the array and, therefore, not assayed in the Modap cells).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	243	 In contrast, glutathione peroxidase (GPX), one of the main intracellular antioxidants, and -glutamylcysteine synthetase (GCL), a regulator of glutathione synthesis, which previously has been shown to be upregulated under oxidative stress (13, 35), were not induced in either of the two cell lines.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In support of our findings is a recent study that showed that fibroblasts from Menkes patients, despite having intracellular copper levels five times that of control cells, had decreased basal oxidative stress and a more efficient protection toward free radicals than fibroblasts from controls (18).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Their results, which included measurements of redox metal content, antioxidant equipment, and oxidative stress markers, showed that the activity of catalase and GPX, TBARS (a marker of lipid peroxidation), and the production of hydrogen peroxide were all decreased in the Menkes (MNK) cells.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Metallothionein production was also increased in the MNK cells.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Together, these data suggest that chronic exposure to moderately elevated intracellular levels of copper does not induce oxidative damage to cells; instead, we observe evidence of an adaptive response to copper.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	248	A large number of differentially expressed genes in both the Mobr and Modap cell lines are involved in cytoskeleton organization and cell adhesion (Table 2).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The relationship between cytoskeletal organization and copper metabolism is not known.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	250	 It is possible that copper may be affecting the cytoskeleton directly.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Polymerization/depolymerization of actin and tubulin is regulated in part by divalent metal-ion-binding sites, generally for Ca2+ and Mg2+; thus other divalent metals may act as potential toxic interferers (58).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Whether copper or other metal ions actually compete with or displace Ca2+ or Mg2+ in the cytoskeleton is not known, but there is evidence that zinc, arsenic, mercury, and cadmium can disrupt actin and microtubules in intact cells (58).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Another possible explanation of the expression changes could be an indirect effect secondary to lysyl oxidase (LO) deficiency.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	254	 LO is a copper-containing protein that is responsible for the formation of lysine-derived cross-links in connective tissue, particularly in collagen and elastin (52).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	255	 LO activity has been shown to be decreased in fibroblasts from patients with Menkes disease (17, 51).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Hence, alterations in the extracellular matrix could have a downstream effect on the cytoskeleton and lead to the observed changes in gene expression.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Additionally, amyloid precursor protein, induced in our models of copper overload and whose function is still undetermined, has been shown to interact with collagen, sharing common binding sites with heparin, and has been proposed to be a mediator of cell-matrix and cell-cell interactions (56).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The changes we observed could also be due to changes in function of this protein.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Furthermore, defects in the trafficking of the ATP7A protein may be leading to changes in cytoskeletal organization.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Normally, the ATP7A protein traffics between the TGN and the plasma membrane and is vesicle mediated (45, 42).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The molecular mechanisms responsible for membrane trafficking of ATP7A have recently been under extensive investigation and may involve cytoskeletal factors that have yet to be identified.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	262	In search of the genes that may be involved in the putative adaptive response, we investigated the specific genes that were differentially expressed in both the Mobr and Modap cell lines.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	263	 It is important to note that two different microarrays were used for each set of experiments, and it is possible that significant genes from the Mobr experiments were not assayed in the Modap experiments, and vice versa.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Nevertheless, we compared the 193 and 130 reproducible genes from each mutant, and 12 genes were found to be similarly differentially expressed in the mutants (Table 1).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Because of the different microarrays, the true number of similar genes may, in fact, be higher.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Interestingly, 2 of the 12 genes found to be upregulated in both the Mobr and Modap mutant were App and Prnp.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	267	The protein products of these genes are involved in the pathology of two neurodegenerative diseases, AD and prion disease, respectively.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The identification of copper binding sites on both of these proteins suggests a possible role in copper homeostasis (61).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	269	 APP is a cell surface transmembrane glycoprotein ubiquitously expressed in mammalian tissues and, although the function is unknown, is likely to play an important role in normal cell physiology.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	270	 APP contains two copper-binding sites and is able to reduce Cu(II) to Cu(I) in vitro (37).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	271	 APP is the precursor of the ss-amyloid (Ass) peptide, which constitutes the characteristic amyloid plaques of AD.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The homeostasis of copper is significantly altered in the AD brain (57).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Copper inhibits ss-amyloid production by stimulating the non-amyloidogenic pathway of APP (5); however, in vitro, copper induces aggregation of the soluble amyloid peptide, suggesting a role in both the processing of APP and amyloid plaque assembly and may contribute to AD development (24).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	274	 App to / to  mice have increased copper in their livers and in the cerebral cortex, with no change in their serum (63).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	275	 App to / to  neurons are less sensitive to copper toxicity compared with wild-type cells (62).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	276	 These observations led Strausak et al.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	277	 (57) to suggest that the amyloid precursor protein could be involved in the release of copper from the cell.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	278	Our results, demonstrating upregulation of App in both genetic models and a nutritional model of chronic copper overload, support a role for this protein in copper homeostasis.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Recently the Menkes protein was overexpressed in human fibroblasts (a state of decreased intracellular copper), and the researchers showed that copper depletion significantly reduced APP protein levels and downregulated App gene expression (4).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	280	 We suggest that the adaptive response to moderately elevated levels of copper may involve the amyloid precursor protein.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	281	Prion diseases, also known as transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs), which include scrapie, bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), result in fatal neurodegenerative conditions (47).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	282	 In prion disease, it is thought that the pathogenic process is related to transformation of the normal cellular prion protein (PrPc) into a protease-resistant and readily aggregated isoform, called PrPsc (scrapie prion protein) (31).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Evidence is mounting that copper may play a role in PrPc biology (9).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The Prnp to / to  mouse has decreased copper levels in the brain and liver, whereas copper levels in their serum were increased (10).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	285	 In addition, cell lines from Prnp to / to  mice are more sensitive to copper exposure (11).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The prion protein may therefore represent a potential copper-transporting or -sequestering protein that may prevent copper toxicity (9).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	287	Our results demonstrate upregulation of Prnp in the genetic models but not the nutritional model of chronic copper overload.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The copper-treated cells, although copper loaded, still have the capability to export copper, whereas the mutant cells do not.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	289	 It could be that prion protein is functioning secondarily to copper export, thus protecting the cell from copper toxicity only when copper s normal export is disrupted.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Additionally, cellular distribution of copper may be different between the genetic and the nutritional models, and this may have an effect on the prion protein.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Clearly, further studies on the role of this protein in copper overload are needed.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	292	Copper exposure has been proposed to play a role in cardiovascular disease and cancer, in addition to neurodegenerative diseases (8, 16, 23, 61).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Although overt copper toxicity is relatively rare, signs of moderate copper overload may be more common (6).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The relationship between these conditions and the effects of chronic copper exposure has not been adequately assessed, possibly due to the inadequacy of current methodology for assessment of copper status (3, 34).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Currently there is no effective measure of copper overload besides invasive liver biopsy (36).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Serum ceruloplasmin (Cp) levels (53) can be decreased in copper deficiency, but since Cp is an acute phase protein, levels can be elevated in a variety of inflammatory conditions independent of copper levels (34).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Clearly, there is need for a more robust assay to facilitate the diagnosis of copper excess and to distinguish mild, moderate, and severe copper overload.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	298	Gene expression patterns could serve as biomarkers of exposure or effect (2, 40, 44).
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	299	 We have compared our results to all published studies (as of January 2004) on the gene expression effects of nutrient and xenobiotic exposure on mammalian cells and found no significant overlap of differentially expressed genes assayed.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	300	 These include studies of several metals such as arsenic and cadmium.
0.21379416.15467011.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Thus we suggest that the genes which we have identified to be differentially expressed in both Mobr and Modap cells lines may be specific for chronic copper exposure.

0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	0	Molecular Determinants of the Interaction of Mad with the PAH2 Domain of mSin3* Xavier Le Guezennec, Gert Vriend, and Hendrik G.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Molecular Biology, Centre for Molecular and Biomolecular Informatics, University of Nijmegen, 6500 HB Nijmegen, The Netherlands.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, December 18, 2003 , and in revised form, March 16, 2004.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	3	A large number of transcription factors have been described to recruit Sin3 to target genes.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	4	 These include: Pf1, TIEG2, Opi1, Mnt, Mad family members, and S.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The interaction between Mad and Sin3 is of great interest as it targets deacetylation and repression of transcription to genes required for proliferation of cells.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Mad belongs to the basic helix-loop-helix leucine zipper protein family and is part of the Myc/Mad/Max network.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The tumor suppressor Mad and the proto-oncogene Myc independently heterodimerizes with Max to form complexes capable of targeting the hexanucleotide core sequences 5'-CACGTG-3' enhancer box present on specific promoters such as cyclin D2, htert, and Id2 (24-29).
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The Myc/Max heterodimer can recruit the TRRAP/GCN5 complex containing HAT activity in proliferating cells, as opposed to the Mad/Max heterodimer, which recruits the Sin3 complex triggering deacetylation of histones in differentiation (30-32).
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	9	Interactions between Sin3 and transcription factors are mediated by four PAH domains within the Sin3 protein.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Opi1, pf1, N-CoR, and the SMRT co-repressor have been described to interact with PAH1 (33, 34).
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	11	 PAH2 has been reported to interact with Mad family members, Mnt, Ume6, as well as with TIEG2 and Pf1.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	12	 So far, PAH3 has been shown to interact with SAP30.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Recently glycosylation was linked to transcriptional repression by showing interaction between PAH4 and O-Glc-NAc transferase (35).
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	14	 A minimal conserved binding motif consisting of the N terminus residue 8-20 of Mad1 was established to interact strongly to PAH2 (36).
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The interaction between the PAH2 domain of Sin3 with the SID of Mad has been characterized in detail by NMR.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	16	 PAH2 folds as a wedged four-helix bundle structure that is stabilized upon complex formation with the Mad-SID, which adopts an amphipathic -helix (37, 38).
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Although the four domains have a high degree of homology, they seem to interact with distinct subsets of factors.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Structural prerequisites of PAH interactors for a stable interaction with a PAH domain seem to be -helicity and amphipathicity, but the structural studies do not shed light on the role of individual residues in binding and specificity.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	19	Here, to uncover residues that convey the specificity of interaction between PAH2 and Mad, PAH2 residues contacted by the Mad-SID were introduced into the PAH1 domain of mSin3b and tested for gain of interaction.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	20	 We report that the insertion of PAH2-specific residue Phe-7 in PAH1 conveyed an interaction with the Mad-SID.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Stabilization of Mad-SID interaction with PAH1-Phe-7 occurred upon extra insertion of Val-14 and Gln-39.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Strikingly, in PAH2, Phe-7 was further identified as a critical residue.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Overall, we established Phe-7 as the most important molecular determinant of the interaction between PAH2 and Mad.

0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	126	Phe-7 Is Critical in PAH2/Mad Interaction To corroborate and extend the importance of PAH2 contact residues 7, 14, and 39 in the interaction with Mad-SID, these residues in PAH2 were mutated into the amino acid present at the respective positions in PAH1 and screened for their ability to interact with the Mad-SID.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Strikingly, PAH2-F7V completely abolished the interaction with Mad-SID, further substantiating its critical role (Fig.

0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Remarkably, the double-mutant PAH2-V14L/Q39K still supported a low level but substantial interaction.

0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	132	 We conclude that Phe-7 plays a key role in establishing the specific interaction between PAH2 and Mad-SID.

0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In the context of PAH2, Phe-7 is critical for the interaction with Mad-SID.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	135	 PAH2-F7V abolished interaction with Mad-SID in vivo.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	136	 PAH2 was mutated at critical positions 7, 14, and 39 toward PAH1 specificity, respectively, F7V, V14L, and K39Q.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	137	 PAH2 indicated mutants were fused to G4DBD and transformed in yeast strain Y190 with G4AD-TRX-Mad or control G4AD-TRX.

0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	140	  Structural Determinants of the Mad-SID: Constraints versus Helical Propensity In our assays, the Mad-SID was conformationally constrained by insertion into the surface loop of the TRX that is between two cysteines.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In its native context, Mad-SID is located at the N terminus of Mad and can freely adopt any structure.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Therefore, we evaluated the interaction properties of the PAH domains with the Mad-SID when displayed in a more flexible environment.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	143	 To achieve this, a stop codon was inserted downstream of the Mad sequence before the second cysteine, thus creating a C terminus.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	144	 In this C-terminal, "flexible" context, Mad-SID strongly interacted with PAH2 but not detectably with PAH1, and hence the specificity of interaction was not altered in this context (Fig.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The single-mutants PAH1-L14V and PAH1-K39Q remained at background levels (Fig.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	146	 5B), whereas a modest but reproducible interaction was obtained with PAH1-V7F.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	147	 This modest gain of interaction is probably due to unleashing free helical properties.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Similarly, the double-mutants PAH1-V7F/L14V and V7F/K39Q displayed a 3-fold higher activity, as compared with the constrained context.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	149	 The PAH1-L14V/K39Q, lacking the critical V7F, remained at background level.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The flexible triple mutant displayed roughly equal -galactosidase activity (to 30%) as compared with the constrained version.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	151	 These results show that free helicity plays an important role in establishing an interaction with Mad, but without a phenylalanine at position 7, unleashing of free helical properties is insufficient to support an interaction.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	152	View larger version (31K):    FIG.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Free Helicity of Mad is a molecular determinant for residues 7, 14, and 39 of the PAH1 and PAH2 domains of mSin3b.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The indicated PAH mutants fused to G4DBD were transformed in yeast with G4AD-TRX-Mad or a C-terminal-truncated variant G4ADTRX-Madstop and subjected to quantitative -galactosidase assay.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	155	 -Galactosidase units activity and standard error are indicated.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Results are the average of at least five assays.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	157	 A, free helicity stabilizes interaction of PAH2 with Mad.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	158	 B, free helicity provides a 3-fold increase in the levels of PAH1-V7F/L14V and PAH1-V7F/K39Q and detection of PAH1-V7F.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	159	 C, free helicity compensates for V14L and Q39K effects at the PAH2 domain of mSin3b.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	160	 D, IgG pull-down confirms critical role of Phe-7 in vitro.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Equal amounts of GST-PAH1- or GST-PAH2-mutated proteins were incubated with fixed amounts of ProtG-Mad-SID(5-24) bound to IgG-Sepharose and washed extensively.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Bound material was eluted, separated on SDS-PAGE, and Coomassie Blue-stained.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	163	  The interaction of the flexible Mad-SID with single PAH2 mutants V14L and K39Q or their combination yielded a 5-fold higher level of -galactosidase, as compared with the constrained setting (Fig.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Mutation of F7V again abolished the interaction, as observed in constrained conditions.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Noticeably, the gain of free movement by Mad-SID tolerated and partially compensated for the loss of interaction because of V14L and Q39K, but not when the mutation F7V was present.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	166	To extend and validate in a cell-free system the observed role of PAH residues 7, 14, and 39 in the interaction with Mad, we used the IgG pull-down assay.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	167	 PAH1 and PAH2 mutants were fused to GST, purified, and incubated with fixed amounts of immobilized ProtG-Mad bound to IgG-Sepharose beads (Fig.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	168	 In the context of PAH1, Phe-7 partially facilitated binding to Mad-SID, which was further enhanced with the inclusion of Val-14 and/or Gln-39.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Val-14 in the context of PAH1 displayed some binding to the Mad-SID, whereas Gln-39 was unable to support an interaction.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Overall, the in vitro data show that Phe-7 is the residue that contributes most for binding, followed by Val-14 and Gln-39.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	171	 In the reverse situation, mutation in PAH2 of Phe-7 abolished the interaction in vitro, as observed in the yeast two-hybrid setting.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Mutating Gln-39 in PAH2 slightly affected the interaction, whereas no effect could be observed when Val-14 was mutated.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Combining Phe-7 and Gln-39 mutations yielded background levels as observed in vivo.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Mutations combining Phe-7 and Val-14 in PAH2 resulted in a substantial interaction, whereas no effect could be observed from combining Val-14 and Gln-39.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	175	 We conclude that the phenylalanine at position 7 is the specific, critical molecular determinant of complex formation between PAH2 and Mad-SID in vivo in a yeast two-hybrid assay, as well as in vitro in a direct interaction assay.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	176	An analysis of interatomic contacts of structural units (CSU) on the NMR structure of the PAH2 domain of msin3b with the Mad-SID revealed possible molecular contacts of Phe-7, Val-14, and Gln-39.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Gln-39 side-chain displays some atomic contacts with Leu-13 of the Mad-SID.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Mutating Gln-39 to a Lys does not change the length of the side-chain, but changes the charge.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Thereby, Lys-39 would maintain atomic contacts with Leu-13 of the Mad-SID and, thus, does not provide an explanation for Gln-39 stabilizing role.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Remarkably, Gln-39 displays many hydrophilic-hydrophilic contacts with other PAH2 residues, such as His-36, Thr-37, Tyr-38, and Gln-42.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Therefore, Gln-39 could have an important role in charge maintenance.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	182	 A lysine mutation would lead to a unilateral positive charge and, as a consequence, these hydrophilic-hydrophilic interactions could be affected and disturb the folding of PAH2.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	183	Careful inspection of the NMR structure with respect to Val-14 residue as well as CSU analysis show intermolecular contacts with conserved residues Leu-12, Ala-15, Ala-16, and Leu-19 of the Mad-SID.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	184	 It has already been remarked that the short side-chain of Ala-15 and Ala-16 of the Mad-SID might play a crucial role in allowing the maintenance of the PAH2/Mad-SID interface.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Val-14 fits in a hole formed by Ala-15, Ala-16, and Leu-19 of the Mad-SID (38).
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Replacement of Val-14 with a leucine would increase the side-chain length.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	187	 This increase could generate a distance as close as 2.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	188	4 A between Leu-14 in PAH2 and Ala-15 in the Mad-SID.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	189	 It suggests that Leu-14 bumps into the Mad-SID, and thus explains our results with the PAH2-V14L mutation.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The PAH1 molecular model depicts a distance as close as 2.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	191	2 A between Leu-14 and Ala-15 and 2.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Proper contact distances can be restored when introducing the PAH1-L14V mutation.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Distance can be measured as close as 3.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	194	4 A between Val-14 and Ala-15 and 4.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	195	4 A between Val-14 and Ala-15 (Fig.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	196	 6), overall strengthening the stabilizing role of Val-14.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	197	View larger version (45K):    FIG.

0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	203	  Strikingly CSU analysis of PAH2 residue Phe-7 depicts a contact with Mad-SID residue Tyr-18.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Careful inspection of the surrounding of PAH1-Phe-7 in our molecular model suggests contact with the Mad-SID aromatic residue Tyr-18.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	205	7 A can be measured between those residues (Fig.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Based upon the results from our experiments, structural information, and modeling, a stacking interaction between the aromatic rings of Phe-7 and Tyr-18 is most likely the key to the complex formation between PAH2 and Mad.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	207	In conclusion, interaction between the Sin3 co-repressor, the tumor suppressor Mad, and other PAH interactors seems to be characterized by conserved properties such as amphipathicity and -helicity and reach their specificity at a molecular level through residues such as Phe-7 that is present only at the PAH2 domain of Sin3.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Open questions remain on understanding the specificity of PAH1, PAH3, and PAH4 and their interacting partners.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Consensus sequences for PAH-interacting protein are still unsolved and subject to many questions.
0.21711254.15047710.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Ultimately, a definition of the specificity of every PAH domain can provide a new way to identify the residues required and needed in amphipathic -helix motifs of Sin3-interacting members, enlarging our molecular view of the role of the Sin3 co-repressor complex in transcriptional repression and cell growth.

0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	151	  Apoptotic cell death induced by CVB3 From the results of these experiments, the presence of PrPC apparently correlates with susceptibility to virus replication and consequent apoptotic cell death.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The higher levels of IFN in HpL3-4-TRPrP cells may inhibit CVB3 replication and CPE production.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Although IFN would interfere with virus replication, CPE was influenced by the mechanism of apoptotic cell death.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	154	 To study this, apoptosis was examined by staining DNA extracted from cells following electrophoresis, while the fragmented (apoptotic) nuclei were evaluated in virus-infected HpL3-4-phyg cells (Fig.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Fragmented nuclei were frequently observed in HpL3-4-phyg cells, whereas none was observed in HpL3-4-TRPrP cells after virus infection (Fig.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The DNA laddering assay also showed DNA fragmentation only in HpL3-4-phyg cells infected with CVB3 (Fig.

0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	163	This study suggests two possible roles for PrPC during CVB3 infection.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	164	 One possibility is that PrPC increases the antiviral activity in neurons, mediated by higher levels of IFN activity.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Another is that loss of PrPC stimulates the apoptotic signalling pathway.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The results of DNA fragmentation indicated the induction of apoptotic cell death in the CVB3-infected Prnp-/- cell line.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	167	 After the Prnp transfection, apoptotic cell death was suppressed.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	168	From previous publications it has been shown that, while PrPC prevents Bcl-2-mediated apoptosis (Kuwahara et al.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	169	, 1999), PrPC prevents Bax-mediated apoptosis (Bounhar et al.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	170	 CVB3-infection promotes apoptotic cell death in the heart, pancreas and in cell lines (Carthy et al.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Although the mechanisms of CVB-induced apoptotic cell death remain unknown, the present study apparently showed pronounced apoptotic cell death in Prnp-/- cells.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	172	 An ongoing study has shown that CVB3 replication promotes apoptotic cell death via a mitochondria-dependent pathway (Blom et al.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	173	, 2003) in Prnp-/- cells (data not shown).
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Further studies are required to understand this signal transduction via mitochondria.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	175	IFN- is produced in neuronal cells (Ward  and  Massa, 1995).
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	176	 PrPC may promote the production of IFNs in neuronal cells and those cytokines could influence CVB3 replication.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The absence of PrPC permits virus replication and so induces necrotic and apoptotic cell death.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	178	 (2001) have reported that IFN-/ promotes cell survival by activating NF-B.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Further investigation of the antiviral activity of PrPC and the inhibition mechanisms of apoptotic cell death are necessary to elucidate fully the function of PrPC in the context of virus infection.
0.25954077.14645931.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Regional loss of the mitochondrial membrane potential in the hepatocytes is rapidly followed by externalization of phosphatidyl serines at that specific site during apoptosis.

0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	0	The prion gene is associated with human long-term memory Andreas Papassotiropoulos1,*, M.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Axel Wollmer1, Adriano Aguzzi2, Christoph Hock1, Roger M.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	2	1Division of Psychiatry Research, University of Zurich, 8032 Zurich, Switzerland and 2Institute of Neuropathology, University Hospital of Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	3	* To whom correspondence should be addressed at: Division of Psychiatry Research, University of Zurich, Lenggstr.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	4	 31, PO Box 1931, 8032 Zurich, Switzerland.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Tel:+ 41 13842644; Fax: +41 13842686; Email: papas{at}bli.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	6	Received May 2, 2005; Accepted June 23, 2005.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	7	In contrast to short-term memory, long-term memory (i.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	8	 the ability to retain information for several hours, days and even years) depends on de novo protein synthesis and on long-term changes in the molecular components of the neuronal synapse (5).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, little is known about the cell biology and molecular mechanisms that initiate and maintain these structural changes.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Recent experiments in yeast and Aplysia suggest that a prion-like protein switch might help to maintain long-term synaptic changes required for the formation of long-term memory.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Specifically, it has been shown that a neuronal isoform of the cytoplasmic polyadenylation element binding protein (CPEB) regulates local protein synthesis and stabilizes synapse-specific long-term facilitation in Aplysia (6).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In addition, Aplysia CPEB has prion-like properties when expressed in yeast and it is the self-perpetuating prion-like form of CPEB that has the capacity to activate translationally dormant mRNA (7).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These studies led to the radically new notion that prion-like conformational changes may be a key event for the maintenance of structural synaptic changes underlying long-term memory.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	14	 If the conversion of proteins into a self-perpetuating state represents a mechanism for long-term memory storage, genes encoding proteins with prion-like properties are excellent candidates for association with human long-term memory capacity.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	15	In humans, the only protein with well-characterized prion properties is the prion protein PrP, encoded by the PRNP gene on the short arm of chromosome 20.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	16	 PRNP is polymorphic with intronic, 5'- and 3'-UTR SNPs as well as a common methionine/valine polymorphism at codon 129 (M129V), which modulates the folding behavior of the protein (8,9) and controls susceptibility to prion diseases (10).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Human genetic variation is often organized into population-specific haplotype blocks, i.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	18	 areas of the genome with substantial correlations among neighboring alleles (11).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In populations of Caucasian origin, genetic variability of PRNP is represented by a haplotype block spanning 25 kb including the M129V SNP (www.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	20	 On the basis of the recent experimental observations related to the mechanisms of long-term memory formation (6,7), we hypothesized that human genetic variability of PRNP might be related to long-term memory and, therefore, investigated the influence of polymorphic sites within PRNP on memory capacity in 354 healthy young subjects (Table 1).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	21	View larger version (14K):    Figure 1 Genomic structure and association findings of the chromosomal region harboring the prion protein gene.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	22	 PRNP and PRND (encoding prion protein and Doppel, respectively) are located on the short arm of chromosome 20 between 4660 and 4700 kb (NCBI Map Viewer, http://www.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	23	 SNPs hCV2969384 and hCV2969397 (Celera database: http://myscience.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	24	jsp) are G to C and A to G transitions, respectively, and are located within PRNP.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	25	 SNP rs1029273 (dbSNP: http://www.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	26	html) is a T to C transition 25 kb 5' to PRNP.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The methionine to valine substitution at codon 129 of PRNP (M129V) is caused by a common A to G transition (rs1799990); the threonine to methionine substitution at codon 174 of PRND (T174M) is caused by a common C to T transition (rs2245220).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	28	 All PRNP SNPs were significantly (P0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	29	01) associated with long-term memory performance, with M129V (underlined) yielding the most significant result.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	30	 T174M and rs1029273 failed to reach significant levels of association.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Significances were obtained by forward and backward logistic regression analyses controlled for age, gender, education and 5 min free-recall performance.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Long-term memory performance (median split) served as the dependent binary variable.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	33	  View this table:    Figure 2 Better long-term memory performance in 129MM and 129MV carriers.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The figure shows the cumulative percentage of study subjects with increasing long-term memory performance (number of freely recalled words 24 h after presentation of a word list).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The curves of 129MM carriers (n=159) and of 129MV carriers (n=151) are essentially identical.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	36	 129VV carriers (n=44) have significantly (P=0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	37	001) lower long-term memory performance than 129MM and 129MV carriers, as indicated by the left shift of the corresponding curve.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Influence of PRNP and adjacent polymorphisms on long-term memory (24 h free recall of words) in the entire sample and the two subsamples   Exclusion of nearby genomic loci Next, we investigated whether the observed association of the M129V SNP with long-term memory was due to linkage disequilibrium with a nearby genetic variation.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In the 3' flanking region of PRNP, we analyzed the T174M substitution of the PRND gene, which is located 25 kb 3' to the M129V SNP and encodes the PrP homologue doppel (Fig.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Twenty five kilobases 5' to the M129V SNP we analyzed SNP rs1029273 which has been previously shown to confer susceptibility for sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) independently of the M129V polymorphism (12).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Consistent with existing data in the populations of Caucasian origin (www.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	42	com), the three PRNP SNPs and the 5'-flanking SNP rs1029273 were part of a haplotype block in our study population (multi-allelic D'=0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	43	000001) with the PRNP SNPs exerting the highest LD values.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The T174M SNP of PRND was not part of the haplotype (D'=0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Of note, none of the examined SNPs deviated from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (P0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Neither T174M nor rs102973 showed significant association with long-term memory performance (Fig.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Therefore, we conclude that the codon 129 polymorphism fully accounts for the association between the PRNP locus and long-term memory.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	48	Exclusion of non-random genetic heterogeneity Association studies in outbred populations such as the present one may be prone to false-positivity because non-random genetic heterogeneity within the study sample (i.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	49	 population structure) can lead to spurious associations between a candidate marker and a phenotype (13).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Therefore, we calculated the structure of genetic heterogeneity in our study population by genotyping each subject for 318 SNPs located in both genic and non-genic regions and distributed over all autosomes.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Structured association analysis (14) revealed a low allele-frequency divergence in our population (Kullback-Leibler distance=0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The individual genetic background values were normally distributed (P=0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Ten subjects were identified as outliers (i.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	54	 beyond the 25 or 75% limits of the normal distribution curve).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Importantly, our findings remained unchanged after exclusion of these subjects from the statistical analyses.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	56	 In addition, we included each subject's genetic background value as a covariate in each analysis.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Again, the results remained unchanged.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Therefore, we conclude that the significant association of the M129V SNP with long-term memory is independent of the observed genetic heterogeneity levels of our population.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	59	View larger version (20K):    Figure 3 Genetic structure of the study population: estimates of the ancestry of study subjects under the a priori assumption of K=2 discrete subpopulations.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The histograms show the number of individuals with distinct proportions of ancestry in subpopulation 1.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Using 318 unlinked SNPs, structured association analysis revealed low allele-frequency divergence among populations (Kullback-Leibler distance=0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The superimposed curve indicates normal distribution of the data (P=0.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Ten subjects were identified as outliers (i.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	64	 outside the 25 or 75% limits of the normal distribution curve).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Identical results were obtained under the a priori assumption of 3K6 discrete subpopulations.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	66	In vitro experiments suggest that the 129M allele results in a higher propensity of the prion protein to form beta-sheet-rich oligomers (9).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Recently, transgenic mice expressing human PrP with methionine 129, but not valine 129, presented with a variant CJD-related phenotype (15).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	68	 These findings indicate that the 129M allele may facilitate self-perpetuating conformational changes of the human prion protein.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Interestingly, our results demonstrate a beneficial effect of the 129M allele on long-term memory in healthy young subjects and therefore support the hypothesis that a prion-based mechanism is involved in the formation of long-term memory.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	70	Is the association of the PRNP locus with human long-term memory related to the susceptibility for prion diseases? In humans, but not in any other mammalian species (16), PRNP displays the common methionine/valine polymorphism at codon 129.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Approximately 40% of our population was heterozygous for this polymorphism, which is in line with reports in middle European populations (17).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	72	 However, 129MM and 129VV homozygotes are heavily over-represented in sporadic CJD and iatrogenic CJD (10).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	73	 In addition, all victims of variant CJD, which is thought to result from infection with bovine prions, were found to be 129MM homozygotes (18).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Therefore, 129MV heterozygosity appears to be protective against prion infection (10,19).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	75	 We observed that the methionine allele correlated dominantly with better long-term memory, because we were unable to discern any difference between the 129MM and the 129MV subgroups.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Therefore, the association of the PRNP locus with human long-term memory seems to be unrelated to the susceptibility for prion diseases.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	77	Although prions were originally described as transmissible pathogens (20), the induction of a self-perpetuating conformational change within populations of cellular proteins does not always need to be deleterious (21).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	78	 For example, the Podospora anserina prion, Het-S, may confer a selection advantage to its host (22).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Also, the Sup35 translational termination factor may act as a useful evolutionary buffer for infected yeast (23).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Finally, the CPEB protein which is involved in the maintenance of long-term synaptic changes (6) has been shown to possess prion-like properties when expressed in yeast (7).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	81	 One might therefore speculate that the impact of PrP variants on long-term memory in healthy humans is related to physiologically occurring conformational changes (24).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	82	Taken together, the human prion protein is genetically associated with long-term memory.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Further evaluation of the biological consequences of the M129V polymorphism in neurons will help elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying this association.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	84	Memory capacity was tested during two consecutive days.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	85	 On the first day, subjects viewed six series of five semantically unrelated nouns presented at a rate of one word per second with the instruction to learn the words for immediate free recall after each series.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In addition, subjects underwent an unexpected delayed free-recall test of the learned words after 5 min and again after 24 h.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Both delayed recall tests reflect episodic memory (25).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	88	 In contrast to the 5 min recall, the 24 h recall additionally requires long-term synaptic changes (5).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	89	 To control for type I statistical error and for effects of educational level on memory, we recruited two independent populations of either university students (academic group) or non-academic employees/trainees (non-academic group).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	90	Blood collection and genotyping We collected 18 ml blood (2x9 Monovette  tubes with EDTA; Sarstedt, Germany) from each donor by venous puncture.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Genomic DNA was extracted using the QIAamp DNA blood maxi kit (Qiagen).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Genotyping of PRNP SNPs was done by the AmplifluorTM method with following primers.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	93	 For the M129V SNP primers, 5'-GAA GGT GAC CAA GTT CAT GCT CAT GGC ACT TCC CAG CAT-3' (A allele), 5'-GAA GGT CGG AGT CAA CGG ATT GCT CAT GGC ACT TCC CAG CAC-3' (G allele) and 5'-TGG GGG GCC TTG GCG GCT A-3' (common) were used.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Primers for SNP hCV2969397 were 5'-GAA GGT GAC CAA GTT CAT GCT TAG TAA TAA ACA GGT ATT GAC CAT TAC CA-3' (T allele), 5'-GAA GGT CGG AGT CAA CGG ATT GTA ATA AAC AGG TAT TGA CCA TTA CCG-3' (C allele) and 5'-GTC CTC TGG CAT ATT TCA AGA TAT CCT AT-3' (common).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Primers for SNP hCV2969384 were 5'-GAA GGT GAC CAA GTT CAT GCT CCC ACC CTC TGT TCT CCA GG-3' (C allele), 5'-GAA GGT CGG AGT CAA CGG ATT CCC ACC CTC TGT TCT CCA GC-3' (G allele) and 5'-GCA GAC CTG CAG CTC CTC TCT-3' (common).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The T174M SNP of PRND and rs1029273 were genotyped by PyrosequencingTM on a PSQTM 96 machine.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Primers for T174M were 5'-ATT GCG AGT TTT GGT TGG AG-3' (forward), 5'-GTC ACT TGC CAG GAT TTG CT-3' (reverse, 5' biotinylated) and 5'-GGC TTT GAT CTG GCT C-3' (sequencing primer).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Primers for rs1029273 were 5'-AAC CAG AAA CAT GGG GTG TT-3' (forward), 5'-CCT GGC TTT TAC AAA GAA CCT C-3' (reverse, 5' biotinylated) and 5'-GGT GTT AAA TCA ATT ACA GG-3'(sequencing primer).
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	99	 To analyze the genetic structure of our population, we used 318 SNPs located in both genic and non-genic regions and distributed over all autosomes.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Please contact the authors for the detailed list of examined SNPs.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	101	Statistics Analysis of linkage disequilibrium and haplotype reconstruction was done with PowerMarker version 3.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Forward and backward logistic regression analyses and multifactorial analyses of covariance were done for the simultaneous assessment of the influence of age, gender, education, and PRNP and PRND genotype effect on immediate, 5 min and 24 h delayed free-recall performance.
0.26525193.15987701.html.plaintext.txt	103	 To improve estimation of the type I statistical error, we performed permutation analysis (50 000 permutations) and used Monte Carlo simulations (100 000 random samplings) in addition to the logistic regression analysis.

0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	0	Evolution of Vertebrate Genes Related to Prion and Shadoo Proteins Clues from Comparative Genomic Analysis Marko Premzl*, Jill E.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Jermiin, Tatjana Simonic and Jennifer A.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	2	* Computational Proteomics Group, John Curtin School of Medical Research, Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; School of Biological Sciences and Biological Informatics  and  Technology Centre, University of Sydney, NSW, Australia; Dipartimento di Patologia Animale, Igiene e Sanita Pubblica Veterinaria, Sezione di Biochimica e Fisiologia Veterinaria, Universita di Milano, Milan, Italy; and Comparative Genomics Group, Research School of Biological Sciences, Australian National University, Canberra, Australia.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	3	Key Words: comparative genomics   conserved contiguity   phylogenetic analysis   repeats   regulatory sequences   phylogenetic footprinting.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	4	The first gene distal to PRNP in eutherian mammals is PRND, which encodes the doppel (Dpl) protein (Moore et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	5	 1999) and is thought to have arisen by a duplication of PRNP (Mastrangelo and Westaway 2001).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The next neighbor gene to PRND, detected so far only in humans and not present in mouse, is the related PRNT gene (Makrinou, Collinge, and Antoniou 2002), which seems to be a pseudogene that has arisen from duplication of PRND.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	7	The complexity of the mammalian PRNP locus and the conundrum of PrP function provided the impetus for searching publicly available genomic sequence databases of human (Lander et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	8	 2001) and model vertebrates (Aparicio et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	9	 2002) to discover PrP paralogs in silico.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	10	 As these paralog genes may have functions related to those of PrP, their characterization may illuminate its functions and reveal the basis for PrP's disease associations.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The paralogs themselves may be indicated to be potential drug targets (Lander et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	12	Using this comparative genomics approach, we recently manually annotated a new gene, SPRN, that is a paralog of PRNP (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	13	 SPRN was detected in mammals (human, mouse, rat) and fish (Fugu, Tetraodon, zebrafish).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	14	 It encodes the Shadoo (Sho) protein, and is better conserved between mammals and fish than is PRNP (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	15	View larger version (20K):    FIG.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	16	  Overall structures of prion proteins (PrPs), PrP-related proteins from fish (stPrP-2, stPrP-1, stPrP-3, PrP-like protein) and Shadoo (Sho) proteins.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Numbers indicate the first residue of each section and last one of each protein.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	18	 S, signal sequence; B, basic region; R, repeats or low complexity region; PGH, Pro-Gly-His rich; RG, Arg-Gly rich; H, hydrophobic region; N, N-glycosylation site; S-S, disulphide bond; GPI, glycophosphatidylinositol anchor.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	19	 (A, F) Numbers refer to human; (E) numbers refer to Fugu; (G, H), numbers refer to zebrafish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	20	  Several other genes encoding proteins with homology to PrP have also been described recently in fish only (table 1): PrP-like protein from Fugu, Tetraodon, and zebrafish (Suzuki et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	21	 2002), a protein from Fugu and Tetraodon named PrP461 (Rivera-Milla, Stuermer, and Malaga-Trillo 2003) or stPrP-1 (Oidtmann et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	22	 2003), and stPrP-2 from Fugu and stPrP from salmon (Oidtmann et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In contrast to Shos, these new fish proteins are not well conserved among the major fish lineages nor among mammalian or other vertebrate PrPs (frog, reptile, and bird).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	24	View this table:    Table 1 Summary of Vertebrate Proteins and Genes Related to PrP, Dpl, and Sho.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	25	  However, despite divergence of their amino acid sequences, many overall protein features peculiar to these proteins are conserved; these features are summarized in figure 1.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	26	 First, all these proteins are extracellular and predicted to be GPI-anchored and, with the exception of the most divergent PrP-like proteins, are also actually or potentially N-glycosylated.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In addition, PrPs and stPrPs do, or can be predicted to, contain a disulfide bond.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Next, all mature proteins have basic regions and, except for frog PrP, repeats.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The most characteristic feature of all PrPs and fish proteins related to PrP is a middle stretch of hydrophobic amino acids, which in mammals is essential for the pathogenic PrP isotype conversion (Prusiner 1998).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Sho protein shares with these PrPs this unique property of a middle non to membrane-spanning hydrophobic region (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In contrast, the Dpl sequence lacks both repeat and hydrophobic regions and shows homology only to the C-terminal folded domain of PrP.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	32	In addition to the serious problem of transmission of prion disease among mammals and to humans in the recent bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) crisis arising from feeding of contaminated mammal-derived proteins to cows, these new findings of PrP homologs in fish raise new issues: the possibility of spread of prion disease to farmed fish from mammals (and vice versa?) from meat and bone meal feedstuff derived from farm animals.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Hence, understanding the evolution of the fish proteins and definition of their functions appear both critical and timely for defining the function, and dysfunction, of the mammalian PrPs, as a means for understanding the transmissibility of infectious prion disease.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	34	Genes in different species defined as orthologous by their derivation from a common ancestor generally lie in the same genomic context and perform the same function; this property is the basis for prediction of gene function in newly sequenced genomes (O'Brien et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Although this comparative genomics approach is a powerful tool for understanding biological function, the appropriate evolutionary distance of species in a comparison depends on the biological question addressed (Frazer et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	36	 For example, a comparative study of custom-sequenced genomic data for four yeast species that diverged 5 to 20 MYA allowed a complete analysis for gene identification, determination of gene structures, estimate of rapid/slow evolutionary changes, detection of regulatory elements, detection of combinatorial control of expression, and identification of the key regulatory elements determining gene activity (Kellis et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	37	 However, there are limitations in the depth and extent of possible mammalian comparative genomic analysis, which parallel availability of eutherian, marsupial, and monotreme lineage representatives (O'Brien, Eizirik, and Murphy 2001; Graves and Westerman 2002).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The most comprehensive targeted comparative genomic analysis reported to date included 13 vertebrate species (one human, eight other mammals, one bird, and three fish) and allowed identification of conserved coding and noncoding sequences as well as insight into the genome dynamics (Thomas et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	39	The aim of this work is to analyze the evolutionary relationships among mammalian PRNP and fish genes encoding proteins related to PrP, and also their relationships with SPRN from mammals and fish, by means of comparative genomic analysis.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	40	 This analysis comprises both homology and nonhomology criteria for assessing gene orthology (Eisen and Wu 2002).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Apart from identification of gene similarity (homology criteria), we tested whether homologous rearrangement events have occurred in the intergenic regions (nonhomology criteria).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Conserved order and transcription orientation with respect to adjacent gene or genes, also dubbed "conserved contiguity," implies that there has been no rearrangement in the intergenic regions and that the genes share common evolutionary history.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	43	 This is suggested to be a strong indication of orthology (Comparative Genome Organization Workshop 1996; Gilligan, Brenner, and Venkatesh 2002).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	44	Our analysis is based on sequence data available in public databases.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Apart from human, only two vertebrate genome sequences are available in draft form: those for mouse (Waterston et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	46	 2002) and tiger pufferfish Fugu rubripes (Aparicio et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Substantial data for the rat genome is also available (http://www.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Rodents are separated from human by 75 Myr of independent evolution, and mouse and rat (separated by 30 Myr) are the major mammalian models for genetic and immunological research and physiological research, respectively.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Data from the recently reported dog genome, which is at only 1.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	50	5x sequence coverage (Kirkness et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	51	 2003), is not yet available in searchable form.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Fish are at the root of vertebrate diversification, and extant fish are separated from mammals by 450 Myr of independent evolution.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The compact vertebrate genome of Fugu rubripes was proposed as a tool for discovery of vertebrate genes and their regulatory elements (Brenner et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	54	 1993), and, indeed, its draft genome sequence showed significant conservation of protein-coding genes, intron-exon structures, and gene arrangement with human (Aparicio et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Partial genomic sequence information is also available for green pufferfish Tetraodon nigroviridis (http://www.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	56	fr/), which diverged from Fugu 20 to 30 MYA, and also for zebrafish Danio rerio (http://www.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	57	org/), which diverged 100 to 150 MYA from pufferfish and is a popular experimental model in developmental studies.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The availability of genome information has led to increased recent interest in zebrafish as a model system for human disease (Ward and Lieschke 2002).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	59	Here, we compare genomic sequences, including adjacent genes, protein alignments, and phylogenetic analysis of mammalian PRNP, related fish genes, and SPRN genes from mammals and fish, together with their adjacent genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	60	 We provide detailed descriptions of the mammalian PRNP, PRND, PRNT, and SPRN genes, and performed "phylogenetic footprinting" on the aligned human, mouse, and Fugu SPRN genes to define possible regulatory regions and transcription factor to binding sites.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	61	 We present evidence for novel fish genes related to PrP that we identified in public databases: stPrP-2 from Tetraodon and stPrP-3 from zebrafish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	62	 We derived the SPRN sequence coding for Sho experimentally from Tetraodon, and for Fugu, Tetraodon, carp, and zebrafish, we found in silico a duplicated SPRN gene (SPRNB) encoding the related Shadoo2 protein (Sho2).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	63	 We have assessed orthology of the mammalian PRNP and fish genes related to PrP and the mammalian SPRN and homologous fish genes, respectively, and have inferred evolutionary patterns for the mammalian PRNP and SPRN genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	64	 We have developed an evolutionary model consistent with our various findings, as well as information available in the literature, and propose it as a framework for investigating gaps in knowledge in these genes, particularly in fish and tetrapod lineages.

0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Initially, every possible tree was assessed to produce a set of 2,000 near-optimal trees (using the -jfen 2000 option).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	140	 This set of trees was then analyzed more rigorously without, and with, nearest-neighbor interchanges (using the -jfu and -jfRu options).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Local bootstrap probabilities (LBP) were estimated using the resampling estimated log-likelihood method for internal edges in the tree examined.

0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	143	 2000) was considered using model averaging (Jermiin et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	144	 1997); when considered, we used the class V weighting scheme with = 0.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	145	05 to produce (1) a majority-rule consensus tree and (2) relative-likelihood scores (RLS) for internal edges in the inferred phylogeny.
