0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	176	 There are several possible explanations; for example, the gene has been lost from the mammalian lineage, or it is so diverged that searches cannot recognize it.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The most obvious possibility, that the gene was duplicated after divergence of mammals and fish, is not consistent with phylogenetic results we present later.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	178	We found another stPrP-like gene, we here call stPrP-3, in zebrafish in the Ensembl genomic contig NA3274.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Its proximal flanking gene is unknown, but its distal flanking genes code for green cone photoreceptor (gcp) and annexin a6 (anxa6).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	180	We observe some major differences between the PrP-related genes in the mammalian and fish genomes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	181	 First, neither PRND nor PRNT genes were detected in fish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Although the similarity in position and orientation of PRNT in human and the PrP-like gene in pufferfish might suggest orthology, sequence comparison shows no similarity (i.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Obversely, no PrP-like protein to coding genes were found in mammals.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	184	 (2002) correctly noted that the genes encoding Rassf2 and Slc23a1 are in proximity to the PrP-like protein to coding gene in Fugu but reported them in a different gene order and relative gene orientation.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Rivera-Milla, Stuermer, and Malaga-Trillo (2003) stated that the genomic environments around the Fugu genes encoding PrP461 and PrP-like proteins seemed to have undergone multiple chromosomal rearrangements, but they did not present supporting data.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In the Fugu genomic data, Oidtmann et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	187	 (2003) found the stPrP-1 to coding gene on scaffold_96, and the stPrP-2 to coding gene on scaffold_155, adjacent to the PrP-like protein to coding gene; they concluded it was unlikely that ancestors of the stPrP-1 and stPrP-2 genes evolved directly into present mammalian forms of PRNP and PRND.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	188	 As supported by our later phylogenetic analysis, we suggest that stPrP-2 shares an ancestor with the fish gene encoding stPrP-1, but the gene duplication giving rise to stPrP-1 and stPrP-2 occurred after the evolutionary separation of fish and mammals.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Although stPrP-2 in pufferfish and PRNP in mammals share the same proximity to the Rassf2-coding and Slc23a1-coding genes and are likely orthologous, their sequences have diverged greatly, and they may have evolved significantly different functions.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The relaxation of conserved contiguity between the sites with different genes distal to PRNP and stPrP-2 (i.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	191	 PRND and PrP-like genes) suggests independent duplications producing PRNP-PRND and stPrP-2 and PrP-like genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	192	 As shown in figure 1, the C-terminal regions of PrP and stPrP-2 proteins have similar features, but these are not present in the PrP-like protein sequences; hence, the function of the PrP-like protein is likely different from that of stPrP-2.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	193	Identification of Genomic Sequences Containing SPRN in Mammals and Fish We recently characterized the genomic environment of the SPRN gene in the human, mouse, rat, Fugu, and zebrafish genomes (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	194	 2003); this is summarized in figure 3, together with that of Tetraodon.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Interestingly, we have recently detected an apparent duplication of the SPRN gene in human, about 140 kb downstream, from genomic data (L.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	196	 We obtained the Tetraodon SPRNA context by finding overlapping genomic sequence reads in the Genoscope database (http://www.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	197	fr/) and assembling them into a virtual genomic contig (Tetraodon virtual contig 2 [see below]).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	198	 (The fish gene is here labeled SPRNA to differentiate it from the related gene in fish, SPRNB, reported in this paper.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	199	) Genes adjacent to SPRN in mammals and SPRNA in pufferfish are those encoding the GTP-binding protein (GTP) and AO; both gene order and relative orientation are conserved in the two vertebrate clades, implying orthology.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	200	 However, in zebrafish, although we found the GTP-binding to protein gene adjacent to sprna in the same tail-to-tail orientation, the proximal adjacent gene is the long-chain fatty-acyl elongase (fae) to coding gene rather than the AO-homologous gene.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Because the next proximal genes are not known from the assembly, it is not clear whether the AO-encoding gene is present.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	202	View larger version (8K):    FIG.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	203	  Overview of the local genomic contexts of the SPRN gene coding Shadoo protein in mammals and fish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	204	 AO, Amine oxidase; GTP, GTP-binding protein; FAE, long-chain fatty-acyl elongase.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Figure is approximately to scale as shown by rulers.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	206	 For ruler under (D), gene sizes and intergenic distances refer to Fugu.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Genomic coordinates and DB information for the genomic sequences roughly correspond to those used for the cross-species Vista analysis; these are given in Materials and Methods.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	208	  Identification and Annotation of Tetraodon Genomic Context Containing stPrP-2 to coding Gene and SPRN We assembled and annotated Tetraodon genomic sequences in silico.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	209	 First, we extracted 22,249 bp of genomic sequence containing the stPrP-2 to coding gene and its neighbor genes (FS_CONTIG_4238_2, FS_CONTIG_4238_1, FS_CONTIG_24895_1, FS_CONTIG_31286_1; Genoscope) and assembled it into the Tetraodon virtual contig 1.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	210	 To verify this assembly and assess its validity for our comparative genomic analysis, we aligned it to its orthologous Fugu genomic sequence using the PiPMaker program (Schwartz et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	211	 2000), which is able to compare both complete and incomplete sequences.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The dot plot of the Fugu (chr_scaffold_155: 247,572 to 271,811 bp; Ensembl) and Tetraodon genomic sequences is given in figure S1A in Supplementary Material online.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	213	Among the four genes in this genomic fragment, the exon-intron structure is known from comparison of the genomic and cDNA sequences only for the PrP-like protein to coding gene.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The single-exon ORF of the stPrP-2 to coding gene and GenScan predictions for Rassf2-coding gene and Slc23a1-coding gene exons are also shown.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The dot plot indicates that the Tetraodon virtual contig 1 is assembled in an order consistent with the Fugu genomic sequence; we conclude the assembly is correct and valid for comparative analysis.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Additionally, we deduced the Tetraodon stPrP-2 amino acid sequence from the genomic sequence information (see later figure S3 of Supplementary Material online).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	217	Second, we identified 19,029 bp of Tetraodon genomic sequence (FS_CONTIG_4144_1, FS_CONTIG_31029_1, FS_CONTIG_37429_1; Genoscope) containing the SPRNA gene and adjacent genes, and merged it into the Tetraodon virtual contig 2.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The dot plot of 10 kb of this sequence aligned to orthologous Fugu genomic sequence (chr_scaffold_28: 384,496 to 394,338 bp; Ensembl) is shown in figure S1B of Supplementary Material online; this shows the GenScan exon predictions for the single-exon Sho ORF and for genes encoding AO and GTP-binding protein.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The dot plot again shows consistent patterns in the aligned sequences, suggesting correct assembly of the second virtual Tetraodon contig and its suitability for computational cross-species comparisons.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Conservation of sequence proximal (4.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	221	5 kb) and distal (6 kb) to the GTP-binding protein to coding gene may denote exons not recognized by the GenScan prediction (Guigo et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	222	 2003) (see also figure S2 of Supplementary Material online).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	223	Comparative Genomic Analysis of PRNP and SPRN Genomic Regions Genomic sequence annotation comprises gene order and relative transcriptional orientation, gene structure, distribution of repeat elements, and distribution of GC islands.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The information for the human (base [reference] sequences in our study) and mouse genomes is provided in the interactive Ensembl genome browsers (http://www.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	225	 An extensive collection of transcripts is available only for these two species, with the rat, Fugu, and zebrafish genome annotations (http://www.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	226	org/) being much less comprehensive.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	227	 There are some major differences between the genomes of homeothermic and poikilothermic species; for example, the GC compositional heterogeneity in poikilothermic animals is less pronounced (Aparicio et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	228	 In addition, the depth of fish transposable element analysis is less than that of primates and rodents (Aparicio et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	229	 In the following section, we compare annotations of the human and mouse PRNP, PRND, PRNT, and SPRN genes and of their local genomic contexts.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	230	Gene Structure, Gene Features, Gene Density, and CpG Islands Genomic location, gene structure, gene size, GC content, and features of exons and introns of human and mouse PRNP, PRND, PRNT, and SPRN genes are summarized in table S1 of Supplementary Material online.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	231	We found that gene density and GC content are much higher in the SPRN genomic environment than in the PRNP environment, in all mammals analyzed (figs.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	232	 2 and 3, and see also tables S2 and S3 of Supplementary Material online).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	233	 There are five genes in 380,074 bp of the human PRNP local genomic environment, which is 45.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	234	02 % GC rich, compared with three genes in 51,425 bp of the human SPRN gene context, which is 50.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	235	 In all four genes, (PRNP, PRND, PRNT, and SPRN), the ORF is contained in a single coding exon.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Their gene lengths correlate inversely with GC content, and GC content is also higher in the exons (comparing exon 1/intron 1 pairs and, where relevant, exon 2 /intron 2 pairs).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The GC content of the human and mouse SPRN genes (66% and 58%, respectively) is much higher than that of PRNP (42% and 45%), PRND (46% and 47%), and PRNT (43%, human).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	238	 For reference, mammalian GC content is known to vary genome-wide at different scales; for example, the average GC content of the human genome is 41%, ranging from 36% to 47% on the large scale ( < 10 Mb) and from 33% to 59% on the small scale ( < 300 kb) (Lander et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	239	 2001), with similar values reported for the mouse genome (Waterston et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	240	 An analysis of CpG islands in the human and mouse genomic contexts of PRNP, PRND, PRNT, and SPRN using the cpgplot program (Larsen et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	241	 1992) (results not shown) showed islands associated with the PRNP and SPRN promoter regions but not those of PRND (as shown by Comincini et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	242	Distribution of Transposable Elements in PRNP and SPRN Genes The role of repeats in the genome is controversial.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Although often considered as just "junk," it is now recognized that active elements have reshaped genomes (e.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	244	, creating new, modified, or reshuffled genes).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Passive elements are excellent markers for mutation and selection analyses (Lander et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Differences in the repeat content and distribution denote differences in the gene/genome dynamics (Thomas et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Discernable interspersed repeats are reported to comprise approximately 45% of the human genome (Lander et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	248	5% of the mouse genome (Waterston et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The lower content in mouse is thought to be caused by a higher nucleotide substitution rate in mouse (4.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	250	2 x 10 to 9), which makes older elements difficult to identify.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The depth of the repeat analysis using the RepeatMasker program (http://ftp.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	252	html) is 150 to 200 and 100 to 120 MYA for human and mouse elements, respectively (Waterston et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	253	Our analysis of the distribution of interspersed repeat elements in the local genomic environments of the human, mouse, and rat PRNP and SPRN genes shows more transposable repeats in human than in mouse and rat, for both regions (given in tables S2 and S3 of Supplementary Material online).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	254	 There are more interspersed elements in the SPRN genomic environment than in that of PRNP of human and rat but fewer in mouse.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	255	At the single-gene level, however, we observe some striking differences in the transposable-element content and distribution; this is summarized in table 2 for the human and mouse PRNP, PRND, PRNT, and SPRN genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	256	 For a detailed analysis of repeat distribution in eutherian PRNP and PRND genes, see Lee et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The repeat content of these four genes correlates with their length and inversely with their GC content; thus, PRNP, has the most repeats.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	258	 (1999) suggested that the gene had expanded independently in all lineages since the mammalian radiation by numerous insertions.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Strikingly, in contrast, SPRN, the shortest gene with the highest GC content, is devoid of transposable elements.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	260	View this table:    Table 2 Summary of Transposable-Element Content in Human and Mouse PRNP, PRND, PRNT, and SPRN Genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	261	  The frequency of fixation of transposable elements is known to vary genome-wide.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	262	 At two extremes, human Hox gene clusters contain less than 2% repeats in approximately 100 kb, whereas human Xp11 has accumulated 89% of transposable elements in a 525-kb region (Lander et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	263	 There is also a strong correlation between divergence in noncoding DNA and the amount of repetitive DNA (Chiaromonte et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	264	 2001): "flexible" genomic regions accumulate many changes, whereas "rigid" regions accumulate fewer.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Rigidity of sequence may reflect strong selection on a large number of gene regulatory elements (Lander et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	266	 2001), or, alternatively, may be determined by the local genomic mutation rate (Chiaromonte et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	267	 We suggest that the fact that SPRN lacks repeats in its local genomic environment is an indication of strong purifying functionally driven selection acting on the gene.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Conversely, PRNP's flexibility and "promiscuity" for accepting repeat insertions suggests a more relaxed evolutionary history of the gene.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	269	Alignment of Genomic Sequences Orthologous genes can usually be aligned and recognized by comparative genomic analysis in closely related species.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Between evolutionarily more distant species, such as mammals and fish, it is the coding regions that are primarily recognizable (Frazer et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	271	 However, where rapid divergence of nucleotide sequence, indels, and gene loss or acquisition has occurred, sequences cannot readily be aligned, so orthologs will not be recognized (Kellis et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Indeed, the analysis of Thomas et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	273	 (2003) showed that almost one third of human coding sequence did not align to fish in the corresponding genomic region.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	274	To detect highly diverged but orthologous sequences in two long contiguous sequences, global alignments are an advantage (Frazer et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	275	 We used the VISTA global alignment tool (Mayor et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	276	 2000) for this purpose to detect conserved, orthologous elements in mammalian and fish genomic sequences.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Cross-species VISTA analysis of genomic fragments containing the mammalian PRNP and fish stPrP-2 to coding and PrP-like protein to coding genes is shown in figure 4, with similar analysis for the mammalian and fish SPRN genes in figure S2 of Supplementary Material online.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Description of the genomic context and coordinates is given in Materials and Methods.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	279	View larger version (93K):    FIG.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	280	  VISTA plot showing peaks of similarity in pairwise sequence alignments between 1, human versus mouse; 2, human versus rat; 3, human versus Fugu; and 4, human versus Tetraodon.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	281	 PRNP, prion protein coding gene; PRND, doppel coding gene; PRNT, PRNT gene; RASSF2, ras association domain family 2 coding gene; SLC23A1, solute carrier 23, member 2 coding gene.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Peaks are shown relative to their position in the reference human sequence (horizontal axis) and their percent identities (30% to 100%) are indicated on the vertical axis.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	283	 For the reference sequence, the direction of gene transcription is indicated by a horizontal arrow, blue rectangles denote coding exons, and light blue rectangles indicate 5' and 3' untranslated regions.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Pink (noncoding), UTR (light blue), and coding (blue) sequence peaks fitting the criteria for conserved elements (50% over 50 bp) are indicated.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Genomic coordinates are given in Materials and Methods.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	286	  VISTA Plots for Genomic Regions of PRNP, PRND, and PRNT We observe substantial conservation in both coding and noncoding sequences of the PRNP, PRND, RASSF2, and SLC23A1 genes between human and rodents; conservation is high in the exons, and there are a few highly conserved regions in the introns as well.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	287	 For the PRNP gene, our results agree with those of Lee et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	288	 For the PRND gene, we note highest conservation in the coding exon 2: exons 1 and 3 seem less conserved.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	289	 An intergenic exon in mouse (85,944 to 86,046 bp in the mouse sequence) does not align with its corresponding human region.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	290	 The human and rodent RASSF2 and SLC23A1 genes align extensively.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	291	We observe that conservation with rodents in the human PRNT gene region differs from that of other genes shown in the plot.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	292	 There is almost no conservation between rat and human (none at all in exons), and conservation between human and mouse appears poor.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	293	In contrast to the human-rodent comparison, the VISTA plot in figure 4 detects no conservation between mammalian PRNP and fish stPrP-2 to coding and PrP-like protein to coding genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Neither homology criteria nor nonhomology criteria for gene orthology are fulfilled.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	295	 First, the coding exons of the genes do not align, indicating divergence of mammalian PRNP and fish stPrP-2 to coding genes beyond detectable conservation.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Second, there is clear evidence of deletion, translocation, or duplication events in the local genomic sequence since divergence of mammals and fish: the PRND gene (and PRNT gene in human) exists in mammals but not in fish, whereas the PrP-like protein to coding gene is present in fish only.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	297	 The adjacent RASSF2 and SLC23A1 genes align with their fish orthologs in the exons.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	298	PipMaker Analysis of PRNT To test the Vista observation for the PRNT gene further, we aligned human (chr20: 4,657,104 to 4,708,670 bp; Ensembl) and mouse (chr2: 132,957,930 to 132,998,136 bp; Ensembl) genomic sequence regions between the PRND and RASSF2 genes using the PipMaker program.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	299	 The dot plot results presented in figure 5, like those of the Vista results, show no conservation of PRNT gene exons between human and mouse.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	300	View larger version (6K):    FIG.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	301	  Analysis of human-mouse conservation in the genomic region of the human PRNT gene.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	302	 PipMaker dot plot of the human (chr20: 4,657,104 to 4,708,670 bp; Ensembl) and mouse (chr2: 132,957,930 to 132,998,136 bp; Ensembl) genomic sequence between the PRND and RASSF2 genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Human sequence is along horizontal axis.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	304	  When we translated exon 2 of the (human) PRNT gene, we detected two potential ORFs encoding 60 and 94 residues and also several smaller ORFs (not shown).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Makrinou, Collinge, and Antoniou (2002) reported the expression of the PRNT gene exclusively in testis, as for the PRND gene, and noted 50% similarity and 42% identity between a potential 94-residue protein and human Dpl.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	306	 The absence of a long ORF and its apparently recent origin suggest that human PRNT is a pseudogene arising originally from duplication of PRND.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Pseudogenes are often remnants of duplicate genes arising either from tandem duplication or retrotransposition of processed mRNA.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Although their sequences show similarities to coding regions of known proteins, they have acquired many stop codons or frame shifts so that they no longer code for full-length protein.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	309	 They are usually not transcribed but occasionally are resurrected in response to a new organismal need (Harrison and Gerstein 2002), or they acquire additional functions such as a specific regulatory role (Hirotsune et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Also, in the intron of the PRNT gene, we detected a processed pseudogene sequence with high homology to the mRNA for isopentenyl-diphosphate delta isomerase 1, which is disrupted by an Alu insertion.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	311	It is likely that the PRNT gene appeared in the human lineage after the evolutionary split with rodents.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	312	 This is consistent with the position of the PRNP genomic context on chromosome 20 in a highly recombinogenic region that may have fostered a recent duplication of PRND to create the human-specific PRNT gene.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	313	 However, it is also possible that the PRND duplication is more ancient and that PRNT survives as a pseudogene in other mammalian lineages as well as human but has been deleted in rodents.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	314	VISTA Plot for SPRN Genomic Region Alignment of the mammalian and fish genomic regions containing the SPRN and adjacent genes shows conservation in all three genes (figure S2 in Supplementary Material online).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Notably, the coding exon sequence of SPRN aligns in all five pairwise alignments.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	316	 We note several conservation peaks distal to the SPRN promoter in mammals and fish (human sequence positions approximately 48 to 48.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	317	5 to 50 kb); a detailed analysis of the regulatory region is given below.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	318	The coding exons of the GTP-binding to protein gene are mostly conserved between mammals and fish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	319	 The large gap in the alignment (approximately 24.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	320	5 to 39 kb in human sequence) is caused by the insertion of LINE elements in human sequence only (two complete elements in antisense orientation and two truncated human LINE/L1 elements).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	321	 L1s are the "young" transposable elements actively amplified during the past 40 Myr of primate evolution; that is, after the evolutionary divergence of human and rodents.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	322	 The distal end of the GTP-binding to protein gene overlaps with the distal end of the SPRN gene in the human, but not the mouse, sequence; the functional significance of this, if any, is unclear.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	323	 A few other examples of such antiparallel overlapping of untranslated exons of functional genes have been reported (Miyajima et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	324	 1989; Batshake and Sundelin 1996; Dan et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	325	There are four polyadenylation signals in the human GTP-binding protein to coding gene, resulting in alternative transcription of the noncoding part of its 3' terminal exon.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	326	 All four sites differ in one position from canonical consensus polyadenylation signals (AAUAAA and AUUAAA); the sequence of the first (41,227 to 41,232 bp; for AK095872, BC00409, and BC000920 transcripts), second (41,262 to 41,267 bp; for BC026725 transcript), and third (41,321 to 41,326 bp; for BC035721 transcript) signals is GTTAAA.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The most distal fourth signal sequence, which overlaps with the 3' end of the SPRN gene, is AATCAA (42,068 to 42,072 bp; for cDNAs AK074976, NM_138384).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Untranslated gene fragments may contain regulatory sequences that affect mRNA stability and translation efficiency, so the choice of alternate polyadenylation sites may strongly affect expression of the gene (Beaudoing and Gautheret 2001).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	329	 The sequence of the polyadenylation signal site for SPRN is canonical consensus AATAAA (41,454 to 41,449 bp; for BC040198 transcript).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	330	The exons of the third gene encoding AO are conserved between mammals and pufferfish but not zebrafish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	331	 In the zebrafish sequence, the third gene is for the long-chain fatty-acyl synthetase (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	332	 As the zebrafish contig does not contain the next proximal gene, it is not clear whether the synthetase gene is merely inserted or the AO-coding gene, which is found on another contig, is at another location.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	333	Conservation of the SPRN-coding exon between mammals and fish satisfies homology criteria for gene orthology.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Next, conserved gene order and relative transcription orientation of SPRN and its adjacent gene encoding GTP-binding protein (including also AO-coding gene in pufferfish) between mammals and fish indicates that no rearrangement occurred in this genomic fragment after the evolutionary divergence of fish and mammals 450 MYA.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Thus, we conclude that the SPRN gene is likely to be orthologous between mammals and fish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	336	Phylogenetic Footprinting of the SPRN Gene "Phylogenetic footprinting" is a method for identifying regulatory elements in a single gene by comparing orthologous sequences from several species (Blanchette and Tompa 2002).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	337	 The basic assumption is that functional regions, including regulatory elements, are under greater selective pressure and will be more conserved between species than nonfunctional regions.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	338	 However, as regulatory elements may be quite short (5 to 20 bp), it is difficult to recognize them in the nonfunctional background noise.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	339	 We used the program Footprinter (Blanchette and Tompa 2002; http://abstract.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	340	edu/blanchem/FootPrinterWeb/FootPrinterInput.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	341	pl) to identify such elements conserved in the human, mouse, and Fugu SPRN genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	342	 The program reports sets of conserved motifs, taking into account a phylogenetic tree relating the input species.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	343	As shown in table 3, we identified 16 conserved motifs upstream to the SPRN ORF, in the intron, exon 1, and upstream promoter.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	344	 In human and mouse, five motifs were detected in the upstream promoter, one in exon 1, and 10 in the intron, as shown in figure 6.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Although this set of motifs contains candidates for regulatory regions of the SPRN gene, it may also contain false positives.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Also, Footprinter may miss motifs present in a single species (i.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	347	, false negatives), motifs shorter than 6 bp in multiple species, motifs containing indels, motifs that fail to meet statistical significance, and dimers with variable internal sequences (Blanchette and Tompa 2002).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	348	 We next checked whether any known transcription factor to binding sites were among the detected motifs using the MatInspector program (Quandt et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	349	de) for human and mouse sequences.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	350	 This program predicts transcription factor to binding sites deposited in the TRANSFAC database (Wingender et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	351	 We detected 155 and 159 likely transcription factor to binding sites in the human and mouse sequences, respectively (69 or 82 in the intron, 11 or 14 in exon 1, and 75 or 62 in the upstream promoter): full lists for human and mouse are given in tables S4 and S5, respectively, of the Supplementary Material online.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	352	View this table:    Table 3 Conserved Motifs in Human, Mouse, and Fugu SPRN Gene Identified by Phylogenetic Footprinting.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	353	  View larger version (6K):    FIG.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	354	  Potential regulatory motifs in human SPRN and mouse Sprn genes identified by phylogenetic footprinting.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Motifs 4, 14, and 16, labeled by an asterisk (*), denote potential nurr1, ATF6 (activating transcription factor 6) and MAZR (MYC-associated zinc-finger protein to related) transcription factor to binding sites, respectively.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	356	  This combined analysis showed that three of the motifs detected by phylogenetic footprinting correspond to predicted transcription factor to binding sites, and, significantly, we note that these elements are present in the same relative order in the human and mouse sequences.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	357	 All three motifs were detected in the SPRN intron; we note, again, that this intron is free of transposable elements, so the presence of the motifs suggests the intron may play an important role in gene regulation.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	358	Motif 4 denotes the binding site for the nurr1 nuclear receptor, which is expressed only in brain and is known to play an important role in coordinate neuroendocrine regulation of activity of the hypothalamic/pituitary/adrenal axis (Murphy and Conneely 1997).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	359	 It is also critical for dopaminergic neuron development by activating tyrosine hydroxylase transcription in a cell context to dependent manner (Kim et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Aberrations in the dopaminergic system are associated with Parkinson disease and schizophrenia.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	361	Motif 14 corresponds to the activating transcription factor 6 (ATF6) binding site.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	362	 ATF6 is a member of the basic leucine-zipper family.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	363	 It is involved in induction of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response, during which transcription of genes encoding molecular chaperones and folding enzymes located in the ER is upregulated.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Some genes in this pathway are directly activated by ATF6 binding sites.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Upstream to ATF6 in the ER stress response is IRE1 (Wang et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Remarkably, the ER stress-response pathway is involved in familial Alzheimer disease (FAD) pathogenesis.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	367	 FAD-linked PS1 mutants attenuate autophosphorylation of IRE1 and lead to impaired induction of the ER stress response.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	368	 These mutants also attenuate the ATF6 signaling pathway (Kudo et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	369	 We have already shown predominant expression of mammalian SPRN in brain (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	370	 These new findings of conserved and clustered nurr1 and ATF6 transcription factor to binding site motifs in the human and mouse introns are further suggestive of Sho's brain-specific function and are targets for experimental analysis.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	371	Finally, part of the third conserved motif 16 binds the MYC-associated zinc-finger protein to related transcription factor (MAZR).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	372	 MAZR interacts with Bach2, a B-cell and neuron-specific transcription repressor (Kobayashi et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	373	Protein Alignment and Phylogenetic Analysis As already discussed for the genomic sequences and summarized in figures 1 to 3 and table 1, we have expanded the data set of fish proteins related to PrP.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	374	 First, we deduced a sequence of 395 amino acids for Tetraodon stPrP-2 protein from the assembled genomic sequence.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Second, we translated the zebrafish stPrP-3 to coding sequence in Ensembl genomic contig NA3274.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	376	1 into a protein of 561 amino acids.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Third, based on the incomplete genomic sequence we had assembled, we cloned and sequenced the Tetraodon Sho ORF and deduced a 155-residue protein, thus adding a third fish Sho sequence to those for zebrafish and Fugu we had previously reported (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Last, as already discussed, we identified a new Sho-related class, Shadoo2 (Sho2), of sequences in public databases.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	379	 We were able to deduce Sho2 protein sequences of 150, 150, and 135 amino acids, respectively, from genomic information for Fugu (scaffold_96 from Ensembl), Tetraodon (FS_CONTIG_41464_1 from Genoscope), and zebrafish (ctg10456 from Ensembl).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	380	 Carp Sho2 was conceptually translated from EST data (CA964511 from NCBI) to give a protein of 145 amino acids.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	381	As described in Materials and Methods, the amino acid sequences of 11 PrP-related proteins from human, chicken, turtle, Xenopus, Fugu, Tetraodon, and zebrafish and 10 Sho and Sho2 proteins from human, mouse, rat, Fugu, Tetraodon, zebrafish and carp, were aligned independently using ClustalW (Thompson, Higgins, and Gibson 1994).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	382	 After refinement of the alignments using GDE (Smith et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	383	 1994), we assessed the alignments and chose 118 and 149 sites from the PrP-related and Sho/Sho2 proteins, respectively, for phylogenetic analyses using the maximum-likelihood program MOLPHY (Adachi and Hasegawa 1996).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	384	 The alignments are shown in figures S3 and S4 of Supplementary Material online.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	385	The analysis of the PrP-related sequence set identified a single most-likely tree, shown in figure 7, and 281 near-optimal trees, none of which differed significantly from the most-likely tree.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	386	65, implying that every site in the alignment (figure S3 of Supplementary Material online) has changed on the average 5.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	387	65 times, which, in turn, implies that interpretation of the tree must be done with some caution; this is also reflected in several low LBP and RLS values (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	388	 However, the fact that we found only 282 "good" trees (i.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	389	, the most-likely tree and near-optimal trees) out of 34,459,425 possible trees places the result in a better light.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	390	View larger version (9K):    FIG.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	391	  The most likely tree based on phylogenetic analysis of the PrP-related proteins in the alignment of figure S3 of Supplementary Material online.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	392	 Local bootstrap probabilities (LBP) are listed above the edges, and relative-likelihood scores (RLS) are listed below the edges.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	393	 The error bar at bottom corresponds to 1.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	394	  The most-likely tree groups the human, chicken, turtle and frog sequences together to the exclusion of all fish sequences, as expected from known phylogeny.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Although the inferred evolutionary relationship among higher vertebrates has human PrP more distantly related to birds and reptiles than frog, the most likely tree is not significantly different from others consistent with the current view on tetrapod evolution (i.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	396	, with PrPHu and PrPFr changed over).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	397	 The divergence of the amino acid sequence between the fish proteins related to PrP and the PrPs of higher vertebrates suggests no orthology between these proteins.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	398	 The clustering pattern of the stPrPs also indicates that the genes coding for these proteins were duplicated in fish after the evolutionary split from tetrapods.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	399	The analysis of the Shadoo proteins identified a single most-likely tree, shown in figure 8, and 48 near-optimal trees, none of which differed significantly from the most likely tree.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	400	77, implying that every site in the alignment (figure S4 of Supplementary Material online) has changed on the average 4.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	401	 Again, this implies caution must be applied in interpretation of the tree, this need being reflected also in some low LBP and RLS values (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	402	 However, again we note we found only 49 "good" trees (i.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	403	, the most-likely tree and the near-optimal trees) out of 2,027,025 possible trees, setting the result in a better light.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	404	View larger version (9K):    FIG.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	405	  The most likely tree (and the consensus tree) based on phylogenetic analysis of the Sho/Sho2 proteins in the alignment of figure S4 of Supplementary Material online.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	406	 Local bootstrap probabilities (LBP) are listed above the edges and relative-likelihood scores (RLS) are listed below the edges.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	407	 The error bar at bottom corresponds to 1.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	408	  The Shadoo tree indicates that Shos and Shos2s lie on two separate branches, implying these two genes duplicated before the divergence of fish from tetrapods.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	409	 Most importantly, the fish Shos cluster with their mammalian homologs, rather than with their fish Sho2 paralogs.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	410	 This clustering pattern strongly suggests orthology between mammalian and fish Shadoos, an inference previously made on the basis of sequence conservation (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	411	 As noted previously, conserved genomic context and failure to detect SPRNB in mammalian genomes suggests either that the SPRNB gene has been lost between fish and mammals or that it is highly diverged and yet to be found.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	412	It is established that gene duplication occurred in several fish lineages and that many duplicated fish genes have only one homolog in mammals (Taylor et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	413	 Two fates of duplicated genes have been proposed.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	414	 The classical model of neofunctionalization predicts that one of the duplicate loci retains its original function, whereas the other duplicate is fixed only if rare beneficial mutations occur (Ohno 1970).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	415	 This model fits current knowledge of Shos and Sho2s, with the Sho2 duplicate either deleted in mammals (and other tetrapods?) or so highly diverged by neofunctionalization that its mammalian ortholog is not recognizable.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	416	 The alternative model proposes that both duplicates are preserved because of subfunctionalization, where proteins encoded by the duplicates complement each other functionally (Force et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	417	 This model fits the fish stPrPs, which have sequences similar to each other but dissimilar to those of tetrapod PrPs.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	418	Protein Sequence Features We introduced previously a model for the structures of mature Sho, PrP, and PrP-related proteins, which is a useful basis for discussing both conserved and highly variable regions in these sequences (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	419	 The model consists of four regions: a basic region 1, which shows a tendency for insertion of repeat or other sequence (region 2), a hydrophobic region 3, and a C-terminal region 4.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	420	 Figure 1 and figures S3 and S4 of Supplementary Material online show the model represents a quite dynamic structural scaffold, with substantial differences in the presence, lengths, and sequence compositions of the regions and insertions among the complete Sho/PrP set, particularly taking account of the numerous fish proteins.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	421	 As we have already compared the sequence features of all proteins in figure 1 except for the ones newly reported here (TestPrP-2, ZestPrP-3, TeSho, FuSho2, TeSho2, CaSho2, and ZeSho2 [see table 1]), we confine attention here largely to the new proteins.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	422	Fish proteins from the known stPrP set (FustPrP-2, 424 residues; TestPrP-2, 395 residues; FustPrP-1, 461 residues; and ZestPrP-3, 561 residues) are much longer than tetrapod PrPs (frog, 216 residues; turtle, 270 residues; chicken, 273 residues; and human, 253 residues) or fish PrP-like proteins (170 to 190 residues) and show significant sequence heterogeneity among themselves, especially in the seemingly "free format" low-complexity repeats and large insertion in region 2 and for large insertions within region 4.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	423	 Most of the difference in length between TestPrP-2 and FustPrP-2 is in the large insertion in region 2, whereas the very large ZestPrP-3 protein shows increases of approximately 90 and approximately 45 residues in the region 2 insertion and in region 4, respectively, compared with stPrP-2s.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	424	 More useful alignment and analysis requires better knowledge of the number of stPrP proteins in individual fish and their variation among the major fish lineages (see also Protein Alignment and Phylogenetic Analysis above).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	425	 As shown in figure 1, the new stPrPs are also predicted to have N-terminal and C-terminal signal sequences for extracellular export and GPI-anchor attachment, respectively (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	426	 2003 and Materials and Methods), and also one disulfide bridge and three N-glycosylation sites.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	427	The main significantly conserved feature among all PrP-related proteins is the hydrophobic region 3 (residues 112 to 131 in HuPrP) and also subsequent sequence in region 4 up to about residue 160 (HuPrP).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	428	 Interestingly, this includes the beginning of sequence shown to be folded in the NMR structures (L125-R228 for HuPrP [Zahn et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	429	 2000]) and includes the first unusual (highly hydrophilic) -helix (D144-M154, HuPrP) and the first part of the antiparallel ss-sheet (Y128-G131, HuPrP).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	430	 This segment also includes the region from residues 119 to 138 (HuPrP) implicated as a PrPC dimerization site and potential binding site for PrPC-PrPSc complex formation (Horiuchi and Caughey 1999; Zuegg and Gready 2000).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	431	 We note a repetitive insertion in this region in fish PrP-like proteins.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	432	Compared with PrP-related proteins, conservation of features, including length, is much higher in the Sho/Sho2 set.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	433	 We previously noted very high conservation (identity 81% to 96%) among mammalian Shos (human, mouse, and rat), and good conservation, particularly for zebrafish, between fish and mammalian sequences to slightly beyond the end of the hydrophobic sequence (identity 41% to 53%, zebrafish 1 to 78) (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	434	 The fish proteins are all of similar length (FuSho, 146 residues; TeSho, 149 residues; ZeSho, 131 residues; FuSho2, 150 residues; TeSho2, 150 residues; ZeSho2, 136 residues; CaSho2, 145 residues).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	435	 There is an insertion in the Fugu and Tetraodon Sho basic repeats that is not present in other Shos.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	436	 Of note, however, is that Sho2 sequence in this region is different from that in Shos, with the Sho basic region N-terminal to the hydrophobic region being missing in Sho2s.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	437	 Although there are some local regions of sequence conservation, including around the N-glycosylation site conserved in all Shos and Sho2s, the C-terminal regions of fish Shos and Sho2s are quite diverged; this is also the sequence region most diverged between fish and tetrapod Shos (see above).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	438	Model for the Evolution of PRNP-Related and SPRN-Related Genes In their paper reporting the finding of the fish PrP-like protein to coding genes, Suzuki et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	439	 (2002) made the initial suggestion of an evolutionary link between the fish PrP-like protein to coding genes and tetrapod PRNP genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	440	 This was based on both weak "homology" (both encode extracellular GPI-anchored proteins with repeats and an unusual internal hydrophobic region [see figure 1]) and context-based (conservation of genes encoding Rassf2 and Slc23a1 in both genomic contexts) criteria.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	441	 (2003) of the stPrP-2 to coding gene proximal to the PrP-like protein to coding gene in Fugu, somewhat strengthened the homology argument for an evolutionary relationship between tetrapod PRNPs and this fish gene because the C-terminal regions of the proteins are similar, whereas those of PrP-like proteins are quite different (see figure 1).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	442	 However, this finding weakened the context-based argument.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	443	 Although the orientation of the stPrP-2 gene is now the same as that of mammalian PRNP, the two genes are separated from the Rassf2 coding gene by different genes (PrP-like gene and PRND) with different orientations (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	444	 We have suggested previously that this could be accounted for by independent duplications.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	445	 (2003) also reported another fish gene, stPrP-1, in another genomic context.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	446	 In our earlier paper (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	447	 2003) reporting the finding of the SPRN gene in both fish and mammals, we provided clear evidence, both homology and context based, that suggested a direct evolutionary relationship.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	448	 However, at this stage, we had no evidence for an evolutionary link between Sho and PrP proteins, although the overall structural features were intriguingly similar.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	449	In this paper, we applied several methods of homology-based (VISTA genomic global alignment, promoter-region footprinting, and protein sequence alignment and phylogenetics) and context-based (genomic context and relative gene order and orientation) analysis to see whether more definitive statements can be made on the relationships between the fish and tetrapod genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	450	 We also included in the analyses sequences of several relevant new genes we found in fish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	451	 It is now clear that fish contain a plethora of genes with similarities to PRNP and SPRN, with quite diverged sequences even among the few fish lineages available to us.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	452	 Also, data on SPRN and PRND genes of tetrapods other than mammals are lacking.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	453	 Remarkably, in all these genes, the ORF is contained within a single exon.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	454	 Hence, although we can make some firm conclusions, others are more tentative and await the correction of the current draft data for Fugu, Tetraodon, and zebrafish genomes as well as the availability of more data for tetrapod lineages other than mammals (i.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	455	, amphibians, reptiles, birds, marsupials, and monotremes).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	456	Considering first the issues for PrP and related genes, our VISTA analysis for global alignment of genomic environment does not show conservation between mammalian PRNP and fish stPrP-2 and PrP-like protein to coding genes, although the adjacent Rassf2 and Slc23a1 coding genes align with their fish orthologs in the exons.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	457	 There is clear evidence of rearrangements in this genomic region, as the PRND gene (and PRNT gene in human) exists in mammals but not in fish, where the PrP-like protein to coding gene is so far reported only in fish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	458	 It, thus, seems clear that the PRNP and stPrP-2 to coding genes have diverged greatly since they last shared a common ancestor.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	459	 There is no basis for suggesting functional homology; that is, the genes are likely to have evolved significantly different functions.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	460	 Second, our phylogenetic analysis suggests that the gene duplication giving rise to stPrP-1/stPrP-3 and stPrP-2 is likely to have occurred after evolutionary separation of fish and mammals.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	461	 The clustering of the fish stPrPs separately from the tetrapod PrPs in figure 7 is indicative of the divergence of the amino acid sequence between the fish and higher-vertebrate proteins, and of likely different functions.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	462	Remarkably, we found a new SPRN-related gene, SPRNB, adjacent to the stPrP-1 coding gene in both Fugu and zebrafish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	463	 As current data indicate the genomic contexts of the genes (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	464	 2) are different, caution in interpreting these results is necessary.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	465	 However, it seems unlikely to be accidental that these two genes have been found together twice.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	466	 Hence, these findings provide the first hint of an evolutionary link between the SPRN and PRNP families.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	467	 The fact that these two genes code for the unique hydrophobic segment, as we reported initially (Premzl et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	468	 2003), is further evidence at the protein level of an evolutionary link.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	469	Considering now the SPRN/SPRNB genes, a quite different picture emerges.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	470	 All evidence suggests mammalian and fish SPRN/sprn genes are likely to be orthologous; that is directly descended from a common ancestor and with preserved function.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	471	 VISTA analysis shows the SPRN gene aligns in our cross-species analysis, together with its adjacent genes, whereas protein-sequence alignment and phylogenetic-tree analysis also indicate conservation between mammalian and fish Shos.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	472	 Phylogenetic analysis shows Shos and Sho2s lying on two separate branches (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	473	 8), implying the two genes were duplicated before the divergence of fish from tetrapods.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	474	We present an evolutionary model consistent with these various findings in figure 9, as a basis for discussion and future investigation.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	475	 The model proposes that the ancestral gene leading to all the PrP-related and Sho-related encoding genes was the SPRN-like gene.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	476	 First, an ancient prevertebrate duplication produced the SPRNA and SPRNB genes within an environment that may have contained the AO-binding protein and GTP-binding protein encoding genes proximally, and the Rassf2 and Slc23a1 encoding genes distally.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	477	 The model then proposes separation of the SPRN and SPRNB genes, by a translocation of half of the gene cluster.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	478	 The subsequent history of the two branches suggests the genomic environment containing the SPRNB gene was highly recombinogenic, whereas that containing the SPRNA gene was stable, leading to the currently known fish and mammal Sho orthologs.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	479	 The stability of this gene suggests that orthologous SPRN genes coding Sho protein will be found in the other tetrapod lineages.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	480	 A further duplication of the SPRNB gene is then proposed, still before the divergence of fish from tetrapods, with the duplicate genes acquiring additional C-terminal coding sequence to produce SPRNB1 and SPRNB2 protogenes with a completed C-terminal domain, as in tetrapod PrP and fish stPrP-1/-2/-3 proteins (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	481	View larger version (14K):    FIG.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	482	  An evolutionary model for origin of Sho-related and PrP-related coding genes consistent with current data for vertebrates.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	483	  As shown in figure 9, acquisition of the additional sequence to form the complete C-terminal domain at this stage is necessary to explain subsequent gene evolution steps.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	484	 It is intriguing that this model predicts the C-terminal domain sequence of genes evolved from SPRNB1 and SPRNB2 has been truncated or replaced at least three times, leading to the PrP-like protein and Sho2 (SPRNB) coding genes in fish and the PRNT gene in human.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	485	 Figure 9 shows that SPRNB2 translocated at this ancestor stage as separate contexts is consistent with the known fish stPrP-1 and stPrP-2 gene contexts (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	486	 However, as no genes descendent from SPRNB2 are reported in tetrapods, it is not certain if this translocation occurred before or after the separation of fish from tetrapods.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	487	After divergence of fish from tetrapods, the model proposes independent duplications of the SPRNB1 and SPRNB2 protogenes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	488	 In the tetrapod lineage, a gene duplication of SPRNB1 produced a gene cluster containing PRNP and PRND genes, together with Rassf2 and Slc23a1 coding genes.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	489	 The timing of this duplication is unclear because known genes are limited to PRNPs in frogs, reptiles, birds, and mammals and PRND in mammals.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	490	 As noted above and elsewhere in this paper, it is not known at what stage the SPRNB2 gene was deleted in tetrapod evolution or whether it has simply diverged beyond levels currently detectable in mammals.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	491	 The model allows for a more ancient origin of PRNT than necessary simply to explain the existing minimal data (i.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	492	, absent in rodents but present in human).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	493	In the fish branch, initial duplications of the SPRNB1 protogene to produce stPrP-2 and PrP-like protein to coding genes and duplications of the SPRNB2 protogene to produce SPRNB (Sho2 coding gene, as observed) and stPrP-1 to coding gene, are proposed.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	494	 As drawn in figure 9, these gene clusters are already separated.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	495	 If the separation occurred after these duplications, translocation of the SPRNB and stPrP-1 fragment might more conveniently explain the different contexts observed in Fugu and zebrafish.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	496	 The additional complexity and plethora of genes in fish is consistent with existing knowledge of the higher rate of gene duplication in fish and the fact that many duplicated fish genes have only one homolog in mammals (Taylor et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	497	Dynamics of Mammalian PRNP and SPRN Genes We observed some interesting differences in the mammalian SPRN and PRNP gene characteristics, which offer some insights into how these genes have been evolving.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	498	 First, although in the SPRN and PRNP local genomic environments (covering several genes as in VISTA analyses in figure 4 and in figure S2 of Supplementary Material online), we found the percentage of repetitive elements is comparable (tables S2 and S3 of Supplementary Material online), at the single-gene level the picture is strikingly different.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	499	 The SPRN gene has no transposable elements, whereas PRNP and PRND have up to 46% and 24%, respectively, in human, all in the introns (table 2).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	500	 Consistent with this picture of gene dynamics, the brain-specific SPRN gene has evolved conservatively between fish and mammals, and Sho is predicted to have a conserved basic function in vertebrate brain.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	501	By contrast, we have shown that the PRNP gene has undergone major and rapid changes at several levels of comparison: it does not align with sequences of fish stPrP-2 to coding genes (fig.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	502	 4); the sequence, and subsequence composition (Strumbo et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	503	 2001), of the tetrapod PrPs (frog, reptile, bird, and mammal) show significant differences; and the number of exons and size of introns varies significantly in mammals (Lee et al.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	504	 1998; Makrinou, Collinge, and Antoniou 2002 [table 2]).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	505	 These features are characteristic of genes evolving under relaxed evolutionary constraints, typical of proteins with rapidly evolving function (Harrison and Gerstein 2002; Kitami and Nadeau 2002).
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	506	 What these functions are has yet to be elucidated.
0.3283119.15342797.html.plaintext.txt	507	 Despite extensive study, the functions of mammalian PrP remain elusive (Aguzzi and Hardt 2003), and no functional studies, or tissue expression profiles, of the other tetrapod PrPs have been reported.

0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	0	Bovine Prion Protein Gene (PRNP) Promoter Polymorphisms Modulate PRNP Expression and May Be Responsible for Differences in Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy Susceptibility* Petra Sander, Henning Hamann, Cord Drogemuller, Kseniya Kashkevich, Katrin Schiebel, and Tosso Leeb1.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Institute for Animal Breeding and Genetics, University of Veterinary Medicine, Bunteweg 17p, 30559 Hannover, Germany and the Institute for Biochemistry, University of Erlangen-Nurnberg, Fahrstrasse 17, 91054 Erlangen, Germany.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, June 10, 2005 , and in revised form, July 20, 2005.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	3	At least for some transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, host genetic factors modulate susceptibility to prion infection.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	4	 This phenomenon was initially discovered in sheep, in which several mutations within the coding sequence of the prion protein gene (PRNP) are known to lead to increased or decreased scrapie susceptibility (10 to 14).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In humans, a polymorphism at codon 129 of the PRNP coding sequence is strongly correlated with susceptibility to variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, as all human variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease patients share the homozygous Met129/Met129 genotype, whereas Val129/Val129 and heterozygous individuals have not been diagnosed with variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease so far.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	6	 However, in cattle, none of the known polymorphisms within the bovine PRNP coding sequence seem to have an influence on BSE susceptibility.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Alternatively, it has been speculated that the promoter region of the PRNP gene might influence the expression level of the protein and thus the incubation period of transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (15).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	8	We previously reported the first tentative association of BSE susceptibility with polymorphisms in the PRNP gene promoter (1).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In our previous study, the allele frequencies at two linked insertion/deletion (indel) polymorphisms within the bovine PRNP promoter differed significantly between the 48 healthy and 43 BSE-affected German cattle analyzed.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The most common haplotypes at these two polymorphisms contained either both insertions (referred to as ins/ins) or both deletions (referred to as del/del).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The frequency of the del/del haplotype was higher in the BSE-affected group.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	12	 We therefore hypothesized that the observed differences in haplotype frequencies may reflect differences in PRNP promoter activity.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	13	 According to this hypothesis, the del/del allele, which was over-represented in the affected group, should show stronger promoter activity than the ins/ins allele.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	14	 To test our hypothesis, we investigated the functional properties of different allelic variants of the bovine PRNP promoter by performing reporter gene assays in vitro and by quantitative real-time (qRT) PCR in vivo.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	15	Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA) Nuclear extracts were prepared from bovine brain and PT cells transfected with the vector pRP58 (see below) following the protocol of Dignam et al.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Approximately 50-bp oligonucleotides surrounding polymorphisms  to 1980TC,  to 1594indel23bp,  to 85GT, +300indel12bp, +571AG, and +709AG were designed with both alleles (see Fig.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The oligonucleotides with the sequence surrounding the polymorphism +571A G were used for EMSA with the gel shift assay system (Promega, Mannheim, Germany) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The other oligonucleotides were double-stranded and 32P-labeled and used at 25 fmol for DNA-protein binding reactions with 1  microg of poly[d(I-C)], 10  microg of bovine serum albumin, 5x binding buffer (250 mM HEPES/NaOH (pH 7.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	19	5 M NaCl, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 5 mM EDTA, and 25% glycerol), 2.

0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	57	2  microl of Enhancer reagent (Qiagen GmbH, Hilden, Germany).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	58	 If constructs were transfected without a transcription factor-building plasmid, 135 ng/well each test construct and 15 ng/well (10%) pRL-TK (Renilla luciferase reference control plasmid, Promega) were used.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	59	 If cotransfection with pRSV/SP1 and/or pRP58 was performed, 75 ng/well each test construct, 15 ng/well pRL-TK, and 30 ng/well transcription factor plasmids were used.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The pRP58 plasmid was also used alone in transfections (450 ng/25-cm2 flask) for nuclear extract preparation.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Cells were harvested 48 h after transfection using 200  microl of passive lysis buffer (Promega).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Lysates were frozen until all experiments had been performed.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	63	 All samples were measured for firefly and Renilla luciferase activities with a Lucy 2 luminometer (Anthos Mikrosysteme GmbH, Krefeld, Germany) using the Dual-Luciferase assay system (Promega).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	64	 50  microl of luciferase assay reagent II were injected into 10  microl of each lysate; and after a 2-s delay time and a 10-s measurement of the firefly luminescence, 50  microl of Stop  and  Glo reagent were injected into each well, followed by a second luminescence measurement.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Relative luciferase activities are defined as the ratio of the firefly luciferase to Renilla luciferase mean value of each construct relative to the pGL3-Control vector, which contains the SV40 promoter.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The constructs pDelDel, pDelIns, pInsDel, and pInsIns were transfected alone in three separate experiments.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Cotransfection of these constructs in combination with the transcription factor expressing plasmid pRP58 or pRSV/SP1 was performed in two or three separate experiments, respectively.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	68	 All assays were carried out in triplicates and in both cell lines (KOP and PT).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	69	RNA Isolation and qRT-PCR Tissues from 6-month-old calves were isolated from the liver, spleen, brain stem, and intestinal lymph nodes directly after slaughtering in a commercial slaughterhouse.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	70	 They were stored in RNAlater reagent (Qiagen GmbH), and the RNA was isolated using the RNeasy 96 universal tissue kit (Qiagen GmbH) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Reverse transcription into cDNA was performed using 4 units of Omniscript (Qiagen GmbH), an oligo(dT) primer ((T)24V), and 2  microl of the isolated RNA in a 20- microl reaction.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The expression levels of bovine PRNP and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH; used as an endogenous control) were determined using the following primer pairs: PRNP, 5'-TCC CAG AGA CAC AAA TCC AAC TT-3' (forward) and 5'-TGT GGC TTT TCA CCA TGA TGA-3' (reverse); and GAPDH, 5'-GGC GTG AAC CAC GAG AAG TAT AA-3' (forward) and 5'-CCC TCC ACG ATG CCA AAG T-3' (reverse).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	73	 A specific TaqMan probe for each PCR (VIC  -labeled PRNP probe, 5'-TGA ATC ACA GCA GAT ATA A-3'; and FAMTM-labeled GAPDH probe, 5'-ATA CCC TCA AGA TTG TCA GCA ATG CCT CCT-3') was also used.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	74	 qRT-PCR was carried out with an ABI 7300 sequence detection system (Applied Biosystems, Darmstadt, Germany) in a 20- microl reaction containing TaqMan Universal MasterMix (Applied Biosystems), 50  microM forward primer, 50  microM reverse primer, and 10  microM TaqMan probe at an annealing and elongation temperature of 60  degrees C.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	75	 A standard curve from linearized plasmids carrying the cloned target sequence from the PRNP and GAPDH genes was arranged over 5 log levels on each plate.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The PRNP expression level was normalized by dividing it by the bovine GAPDH expression level.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	77	 All assays were performed in duplicates.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	78	DNA Isolation and Genotyping A second piece of each tissue sample used for RNA isolation was used for DNA isolation with the Nucleospin 96 tissue kit (Macherey-Nagel, Duren, Germany).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	79	 To determine the genotype with respect to the indel polymorphisms  to 1594indel23bp and +300indel12bp, PCRs flanking the polymorphisms were carried out as described above, and product sizes were evaluated on agarose gels (1).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	80	Statistical Analysis Differences between constructs were tested for significance using the procedure MIXED of the SAS software package (23).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	81	 A linear model was applied, including the effects of the constructs and the repeated measurements.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Contrasts between least-square means were calculated and tested for significance in both cell lines separately.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	83	 All p values are provided in supplemetal Tables 1 to 3.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The same model was used for the qRT-PCR data from the four different bovine tissues.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	85	All alleles for each polymorphic position were screened for transcription factor-binding sites.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	86	 This led to the identification of 18 differences in putative transcription factor-binding sites between the different alleles.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	87	 We excluded 12 of these differential sites based on the properties of the potentially binding transcription factors.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	88	 For example, we did not follow up a differential transcription factor-binding site of hepatic nuclear factor-4, as this transcription factor is involved mainly in liverspecific gene regulation.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Consequently, we selected six transcription factor-binding sites that seemed most likely to be functionally relevant for the regulation of PRNP transcription (TABLE ONE).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	90	View this table:    TABLE ONE Polymorphisms within the bovine PRNP promoter that affect transcription factor-binding sites.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	91	  Binding of Putative Transcription Factors to Selected Sections of the PRNP Promoter Oligonucleotides surrounding the six selected polymorphic transcription factor-binding sites were designed and used as probes in EMSAs.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Every probe was designed with one or the other allele of the polymorphisms described in TABLE ONE.

0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The +12 oligonucleotide probe produced a shift with purified SP1 protein and with nuclear extract from bovine brain.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The observed SP1 binding to the +12 oligonucleotide was specific, as it could be competed with the unlabeled +12 oligonucleotide, but not with the nonspecific unlabeled  to 12 oligonucleotide.

0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	106	  The most striking differences in transcription factor binding to different PRNP alleles were observed in the case of the 12-bp indel polymorphism at position +300 and the transcription factor SP1 (Fig.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The 12-bp insertion allele was able to bind SP1, whereas the 12-bp deletion allele did not bind SP1.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	108	EMSA was also performed with the potential RP58-binding site within the 23-bp indel polymorphisms at position  to 1594 in the 5'-flanking sequence.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Using the same brain nuclear extract as used in the SP1 EMSAs, no band shifts were initially visible (data not shown).
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	110	 However, reproducible band shifts with nuclear extracts from pRP58-overexpressing cells were obtained (Fig.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The experiment showed that the 23-bp insertion allele produced strong and specific band shifts with transcription factor RP58.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	112	 However, the deletion allele produced only a weak band shift that could be competed with the unlabeled insertion allele, indicating that RP58 has a higher affinity for the insertion allele than for the deletion allele.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	113	The polymorphic transcription factor-binding sites for POZ (position  to 1980), neurogenin-1 (position  to 85), AP2 (position +571), and EGR4 (position +709) were also evaluated in similar EMSAs (supplemental Fig.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In these four instances, no conclusive differences in the binding properties of the different respective alleles were observed.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Both allelic POZ probes produced identical band shift patterns with two shifted bands for each probe.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	116	 In the case of the  to 85G T polymorphism, both allelic probes led to a shifted band of the same size.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The shifted band with the G allele had a higher intensity; however, as this allele was predicted to be the non-binding allele for NEUROG1, the polymorphism was not further studied.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Both allelic AP2 probes did not produce any band shift, whereas a control oligonucleotide with a perfect AP2 consensus site led to a shifted band of the expected size.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	119	 In the case of EGR4, both allelic probes produced identical band shift patterns with two bands for each probe.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	120	 This led to the conclusion that only the 23- and 12-bp indel polymorphisms are involved in differential allelic PRNP promoter modulation and thus in PrPc expression.
0.34315994.16141216.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Therefore, our further experiments focused on these two polymorphisms.
